Consumer complaint narrative:
Under **the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) ** ( 20 U.S.C . 1232g ) and **the Privacy Act of 1974** ( 5 U.S.C. 552a ), my student loan information is protected from unauthorized access and disclosure. The Department of Education and loan servicers are legally required to safeguard my personal and financial data, ensuring that it is not accessed or shared without my explicit consent.

If Elon Musk has gained access to my student loan records without lawful authorization, this constitutes a clear violation of federal privacy laws. Such unauthorized access compromises my rights and may constitute grounds for legal action, including but not limited to, seeking the discharge of my student loans due to privacy breaches and noncompliance by the responsible entities.

I formally request an immediate investigation into this matter and the appropriate remedial actions, including the potential cancellation of my student loans due to this serious breach of privacy.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) XXXX XX/XX/XXXX Aidvantage Dispute Resolution Department Office of the Customer Advocate XXXX XXXX XXXX, TX XXXX Subject : FORMAL DISPUTE AND DEMAND FOR LOAN DISCHARGE DUE TO LEGAL VIOLATIONS Dear Aidvantage Dispute Resolution Department : I am writing to formally dispute the legitimacy of my student loan obligations transferred from XXXX to Aidvantage. Due to serious legal violations and breaches of the federal privacy laws, including the FAMILY EDUCATIONAL RIGHTS AND PRIVACY ACT ( FERPA ), the PRIVACY ACT OF 1974, and the HIGHER EDUCATION ACT, I demand the immediate cancellation of all financial obligations related to these debts.

It has come to my attention that my personal educational and financial information has been improperly accessed by unauthorized third parties, including Elon Musk or affiliated entities. This unauthorized access constitutes gross violation of my federal privacy rights and nullifies any enforceable loan agreements under federal law.

LEGAL GROUNDS FOR DISCHARGE : 1. FERPA VIOLATION : The exposure of my educational records without my express written consent is a direct breach of FERPA, which mandates the protection of personally identifiable information.

2. VIOLATION OF THE PRIVACY ACT OF 1974 : The mishandling and unauthorized disclosure of my personal information contravenes federal requirements that safeguard the privacy of individuals data managed by federal agencies and contractors.

3. BREACH OF THE HIGHER EDUCATION ACT : The Higher Education Act requires servicers to maintain strict confidentiality and compliance in loan transfers. The transfer of my loan to Aidvantage and subsequent data breaches demonstrate clear negligence.

4. BREACH OF CONTRACT AND DATA SECURITY OBLIGATIONS : By failing to protect my sensitive information, both MOHELA and Aidvantage have breached contractual terms and obligations, rendering these debts unenforceable.

DEMAND FOR RESOLUTION : Due to these violations, I formally demand : Immediate and unconditional cancellation of all financial obligations associated with my student loans.

Complete removal of all Aidvantage-related entries from my credit report.

Written confirmation of this cancellation and credit correction within 30 days.

If my demands are not met, I reserve the right to pursue all available legal remedies, including claims for damages arising from these privacy breaches and violations of federal law.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/year>, I, XXXX XXXX, received an email claiming the status of the account was changed to " an Income-Driven Repayment Plan '' and that an application for that plan was in process. I never applied for any repayment plan nor forbearance. I submitted a 1099-C Copy B form, that I received in the mail from Nelnet, proving cancellation of debt. A closure of the account should have followed. Instead, the account has undergone fraud on several occasions. 

During my several attempts at communication with NELNET ( by phone, email, fax, and USPS mailing ), I thoroughly explained and submitted proof how fraud was committed by NELET INCORPORATED to Nelnet. To date, they are operating the account without authorization or permission from the debtor BY THE LENDER. The lender has changed the status on the account multiple times without the debtors signature or request. 

These actions are fraudulent because the debt was discharged from NELNET via the IRS 1099-C Copy B form that was sent to the debtor. Instead of the account being properly closed, the account balance and status was improperly changed. The discharge of debt copy B form NELNET was sent via the mailing system and should be fully upheld. 

History of Fraud by Lender : XX/XX/year> administrative forbearance ( {$24000.00} ) XX/XX/year> income-driven repayment plan ( {$24000.00} ) XX/XX/year> administrative identity theft forbearance ( {$24000.00} ) The accurate discharged loan balance purchased from Great Lakes reflected in NELNETs balance prior to unauthorized changes to the account was {$24000.00}. 

Thank you

Consumer complaint narrative:
Good day, I am writing to request urgent assistance with an ongoing issue involving my federal student loan servicer, Mohela. Despite my repeated attempts to resolve this matter, Mohela has failed to take action, and it is now jeopardizing my ability to purchase a home and achieve financial stability for my family. 

Here are the key details of my situation : Forbearance Issue : My federal student loans have been in forbearance for several months. I have contacted Mohela multiple times via phone, email, and written correspondence to request that my loans be removed from forbearance so I can resume making payments. However, Mohela has not taken any action, and my loans remain in forbearance.

Public Service Loan Forgiveness ( PSLF ) : I am a public servant with now more than XXXX qualifying payments toward PSLF. I am on the verge of having my remaining loan balance forgiven, but Mohelas inaction is delaying this process.

Home Purchase : I am currently under contract to purchase my first home, a critical step toward providing stability for my two children, both of whom have special medical needs. Unfortunately, Mohelas refusal to remove my loans from forbearance is preventing me from finalizing this purchase.

Financial Impact : I am willing and able to make payments ( as low as {$1.00} per month under an income-driven plan ), but Mohelas failure to act is causing significant stress and instability for my family during an already challenging time.

As a public servant, I dedicate my time to educating others on food stability and community well-being. Yet, the very system that was supposed to help me achieve the XXXX  dream is now holding me back. With the rising cost of housing and the uncertainty in our economy, this delay is not just frustrating ; it is devastating.

I am humbly requesting the CFPBs assistance in resolving this matter with Mohela. Specifically, I ask for help in : Ensuring my loans are removed from forbearance immediately.

Expediting the certification of my PSLF payments so I can achieve loan forgiveness.

Holding Mohela accountable for their lack of responsiveness and action for not just myself but others in my same situation. 

Please do not hesitate to contact me at XXXX XXXX XXXX or XXXX if you need additional information or documentation. 

Thank you for your time and attention to this matter. I look forward to your assistance in resolving this issue so I can continue working toward a stable and secure future for my family and keep working hard to help others. 
Thank you!

When I called Aidvantage, they said this decision was up to the " XXXX Department '', and they were under no obligation to waive or stop interest from accruing. Consumer complaint narrative: Back in XXXX, I spoke with customer service representatives, who informed me that my XXXX payment should have been completed, but for some reason the XX/XX/year> payment was being marked as not qualifying ( Im sitting at XXXX ). They informed me that that indeed should have counted as a payment under the XXXX pause that counted those months towards PSLF, specifically being the last month to count for it. They informed me that the way to get that fixed was to submit a reconsideration form, which I did in XXXX. After not ever hearing any information back, I called and did another reconsideration. I was told that the reconsideration was declined because there was already XXXX opened even though they closed the XXXX XXXX, which was the first XXXX with still no resolution. The person that I spoke to again confirmed that payment should have counted, and that if the reconsideration didnt work, the next step was to file a complaint ( which I did a couple months ago ). I have been going back-and-forth with them. I have also been kicked off of my save plan which I was already on, so I should be on a forbearance with the legal actions that are taking place, but that loan that is sitting at XXXX keeps getting taken off the forbearance. XXXX said that its not on a qualifying plan, even though it was, or I wouldnt be at XXXX payments, and I never changed it myself. I am told that I have a balance due, while I am still waiting on a resolution with this final payment. As a last resort, I requested buyback information to hopefully buy back that final month from XX/XX/year>. I have also not received any correspondence from that. After multiple phone calls and being on hold this is my last resort to try and get somebody to help me.

Consumer complaint narrative: MOHELA has failed to put my loans in a 60-day processing forbearance while reviewing my IDR application. I was previously enrolled in SAVE, and in XX/XX/year> my loans were placed in a forbearance ineligible for PSLF. On XX/XX/year> I submitted an IDR application, requesting to be removed from the SAVE forbearance immediately ; MOHELA never acknowledged or took any action that application. On XX/XX/year>, I submitted another IDR application, for PAYE, and again requested my loans be taken out of the SAVE forbearance. Shortly thereafter, MOHELA acknowledged receipt of my PAYE application but did not change the status of my loans, which remained in the SAVE-related forbearance. On XX/XX/year>, I called MOHELA to ask about the status of my PAYE application; the representative I spoke with told me that MOHELA is backlogged and would need more time to process it. But my loans are still sitting in the SAVE-related forbearance. It has now been nearly two months since I first submitted a new IDR application and requested to be taken out of the SAVE forbearance, and Mohela has neither processed my application nor placed me in a PSLF-eligible forbearance while it take the additional time to process it and issue me a bill.

Consumer complaint narrative: I received a call from someone in a call center claiming to be from the XXXX with the goal of finalizing my student loan forgiveness eligibility but they said it would require me to have my loans, currently in deferment, to be repaid beginning next month. I told them my loans aren't set to come out of deferment until XXXX so it doesn't make sense for me to agree to pay up to {$170.00} per month while I'm unemployed when I'm currently required to pay {$0.00} per month. They had my account information already, although I did confirm a few details. They were able to reset my password to XXXX @ XXXX. I changed it after the call but wanted to follow up on the official site just in case. Essentially, if they were trying to hack me they would have been able to without calling me but still I was concerned that I was misled. When I said I couldn't repay right now they just said ok and hung up. If I'm eligible for student loan forgiveness on the condition of repayment I would think I wouldn't be asked to pay anything while I'm currently on deferment. If it's a scam, it's already compromised the system. If they are scammers and not an authorized XXXX party then the data breach is severe. My mom said student loan forgiveness doesn't call out but it seemed very official, even the email for authentication. I just didn't understand the sudden call for eligibility. I also want to make sure I'm not losing my chance at student loan forgiveness just because I can't pay right now. My phone usually blocks spam so that is something I considered as well. They claimed they already had my SSN by reciting the last XXXX digits, and already had my address too. The phone call location was from XXXX, IL with phone number XXXX. My phone shows they ended the call after XXXX minutes and XXXX seconds. The call came in at XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. I blocked the number and changed the password they reset after following up on the direct website. I am XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXo I am usually good at determining phishing. This may just be a massively sophisticated scam and data breach. I only answered the phone because the caller ID said " US Department of Education ''. None of my loan statuses have changed on the studentaid.gov website and I will confirm with my loan provider. If this truly is a scam and data breach then I expect to be part of a massive class action settlement. I don't remember the name of the person but it was a male, likely between the ages of XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX but could have been XXXX. The background noise was the sound of a standard call center and I was told that, after confirming my information, I was going to be transferred to get an estimate of the forgiveness amount I was eligible for.

Consumer complaint narrative:
To the Departments Overseeing School & Loan Server Compliance, We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXXaffiliated schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding Borrower Defense applications and provide full relief for those impacted. 
Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : * XXXX University XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX University XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX University XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX University XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX University XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXX University misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within six months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 
At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in XXXX states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts.

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : 1. Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions. 
2. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans.

3. Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts.

Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the American Dream, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it. 
We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays. 
Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter.

Consumer complaint narrative: I am writing to formally express my concerns regarding the processing of my Income-Driven Repayment ( IDR ) plan request and the handling of my federal student loans by FSA.gov. On XX/XX/XXXX, I submitted a request for an IDR plan through FSA.gov, which was directed to my then-loan servicer, XXXX. However, this request has remained in review with no action taken. Despite making monthly payments of {$190.00} for the past year, I had assumed these payments were in line with an IDR plan, when, in fact, I had been on a standard repayment plan. When I contacted MOHELA regarding my concerns, I was informed that because my loan servicer had changed, I was required to submit a new IDR request. I find it troubling that this responsibility was placed on me, the borrower, rather than being managed by the loan servicer or communicated through Federal Student Aid ( FSA ) notifications. On XX/XX/XXXX, I submitted a new request for an IDR plan due to a change in my financial circumstances. My husband, who is XXXX XXXX in the XXXX, was stationed in XXXX for the next three years, and I had to relocate with him. As a result, I lost my job on XX/XX/XXXX. After speaking with a customer service representative, I was advised that my loans could be placed in deferment while my IDR request is reviewed. However, I was informed that this process could take up to a year for review, which seems excessive, especially given my current financial hardship. Since XX/XX/XXXX, my income has been {$0.00}. Today, I received an email stating that I am required to begin making standard payments next month. This is both concerning and overwhelming, given my current circumstances and the extended delays in processing my request. I am respectfully requesting immediate attention to my situation, including the approval of my IDR request and a deferral of any required payments until my application is reviewed and finalized. Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to a timely resolution. Sincerely, XXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Consumer complaint narrative:
I have two big issues with Ed Financial. 
1 ) the larger issue is that I have been working for a government approved agency since XXXX. During the COVID pause on federal student loans, my counts have not been updated. I have requested that the forbearance that was given during this time should be updated and it has not. I have been reassured that the counts will be updated. I have seen other people have their counts reflect the pause and I have not. There are four years worth that should be updated. 
2 ) I had my payments restart in XX/XX/XXXX. I made 8 payments before the current court injunction lead to a forebearnace where counts will not be given. I have 8 receipts of payments deducted from my account, but Ed Financial only shows 3 payments in their system of the last 24 months. This is ridiculous that actual money was deducted and they havent counted these toward my count.

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to file a formal complaint with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) regarding a serious violation of my personal and financial privacy rights. I have recently discovered that XXXX XXXX, or individuals associated with him, have gained unauthorized access to my sensitive personal and financial information, including my Social Security number. This access occurred both through my educational records and the Social Security Administration ( SSA ), without my knowledge or consent. 

The unauthorized disclosure and potential misuse of my financial information, including my Social Security number, is deeply concerning. I have not authorized any individual or entity to access or use my financial data, and I have not provided consent for XXXX XXXX or any associated parties to gain access to my information. 

The access of my personal data, including financial records and my Social Security number, appears to be a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), which protects consumers from unauthorized access to their financial information. Additionally, any misuse of my Social Security number could expose me to identity theft and other financial harm, which the CFPB actively works to prevent and protect consumers from. 

I request the CFPB to : Investigate how XXXX XXXX and his associates were able to gain unauthorized access to my financial data and personal information through both educational institutions and the Social Security Administration.

Take the necessary steps to hold the responsible parties accountable for violating consumer privacy laws and ensure this type of data breach does not continue. 
Provide me with guidance on how I can take additional steps to protect myself from any potential misuse of my personal and financial information, particularly my Social Security number. 
This situation is distressing, and I trust the CFPB will investigate these serious violations of my rights under the applicable consumer protection laws. 

Please contact me at your earliest convenience to confirm receipt of my complaint and inform me of the next steps in the process. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

I recently received a communication indicating that the IDR application to SAVE I submitted in XXXX was denied because MOHELA determined that I improperly self-certified my income. Once I described my problem, the representative transferred me, at which point MOHELA 's automated system told me that the wait time would be nearly four hours.

I have no way to put myself back into the processing forbearance because MOHELA will not let me speak to a representative, instead leaving me on hold for hours on end or not returning my call after I use the callback option.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
My federal Direct student loans are currently on the SAVE payment plan. I electronically submitted an IDR Application to switch to IBR using the studentaid.gov application tool linked in Mohela 's FAQs webpage. On XX/XX/XXXX, Mohela uploaded a letter to my online account stating they could not grant my application because it was missing my signature. I reviewed the PDF of my application on my studentaid.gov account, and my name was typed in the signature field like all my previously submitted and approved electronic applications. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I called the Mohela customer service tool-free number to inquiry about the denial. During the conversation, the Mohela representative informed me that Mohela stopped accepting electronic signatures in XX/XX/XXXX, so all IDR applications require physical signatures. I explained I had submitted my application through the online portal and had not been informed the application required a physical signature. I also asked how they could not accept a form submitted through an online tool Mohela directs borrowers to use. The representative repeated that Mohela does not accept electronic signatures. Further attempts to reason with the representative were unproductive. 

Additionally, when I asked that my loans be placed on a PSLF-qualifying processing forbearance for the 60 days following my submission of my IDR application in XXXX, the representative informed me that the general forbearance on my loans could not be changed to a processing forbearance because I did not have a currently pending IDR application. I pointed out Mohela had been processing my IDR application from XX/XX/XXXX, until they denied it on XX/XX/XXXX, so I should have been placed on a processing forbearance during that time. After placing me on hold to speak with her supervisor ( named either XXXX or XXXX XXXX, the representative returned to our call and told me that she was submitting a request to the team that handles forbearances to ask that my loans be switched to a processing forbearance for the 60 days following my application 's submission in XXXX. She further informed me that this request would take 5-10 days to process. 

All of this is compounded by the fact that my remaining direct loans have 119 PSLF-qualifying months, meaning I only need one more qualifying month to trigger forgiveness. In addition to the issue described above, I told by Mohela on a phone call on XX/XX/XXXX, that the forbearance placed on my loans for that month would qualify for PSLF when I called to request the forbearance be removed from my loans in order for me to make my final payment. I was told not to worry and submit an ECF at the end of XXXX. I did so only to find that XXXX designated XXXX as well as XX/XX/XXXX as ineligible, even though I had made a payment in XXXX. I submitted a reconsideration request for both months, and eventually XX/XX/XXXX was marked eligible and qualifying, though XX/XX/XXXX remains ineligible. 

Mohela 's failure to accept IDR application forms submitted to through an online portal their own website instructs borrowers to go to is an unfair business practice at minimum and could be seen as deliberately delaying and/or preventing forgiveness for borrowers entitled to PSLF. Mohela 's actions, whether by incompetence, negligence, or malice, have repeated denied me the ability to fulfill my obligations under PSLF and prevented the discharge of my loans.

When I learned that this payment was not actually necessary, I requested a refund for this payment. I later learned however that the request was canceled ( unbeknownst to me ) when the MOHELA system transitioned to another platform in the summer of 2024. Since then, I again requested the refund which has still not been processed. I have contacted MOHELA via phone on multiple occasions with the bulk of the time being spent on hold ( at least 10 hours in total ) and was told that the money is stuck with the Department of Treasury without any signs of progress and certainly no steps toward resolution or end date in sight. On every occasion of speaking with a MOHELA representative, it requires multiple phone transfers committing me to waiting even longer and having to re-explain the entire situation with every representative unclear on how to resolve the issue or escalate it further. There is never any record on my file of the conversations that have been had and no progress occurs. Most recently, we escalated this at least twice to a manager who attempts to escalate our case even further, again without any indication of when progress will be made, nor any way to inquire about updates. When we request for a more direct way to call back to request updates to this case, no contact information is provided. Multiple complaints were made online to MOHELA as well to no avail. It has been over a year since this overpayment was made with no indication that our refund will ever be processed and returned.

Consumer complaint narrative:
My understanding is that loan servicers were forbidden from applying borrower defense refunds to loans ( Outstanding Principle Balance OPB ) for other schools or loans that were also in a separate borrower defense case.

So I have the following questions : 1. Shouldnt my refunds from ITT borrower defense case 1 have been sent to me directly and not applied to my outstanding principle balance for XXXX loans in borrower defense case 2?

2. What action do I need to take and who do I take it with?

3. If my borrower defense case for XXXX is eventually approved, but that balance has been discharged under the XXXX forgiveness, will I still receive a retro-active refund of money that I paid on those loans, including the refund payments that were applied to them? 

I was considered a class member of the XXXX case for my XXXX borrower defense application. 
I applied for borrower defense for my XXXX loans on XX/XX/XXXX. 
I received notification on XX/XX/XXXX, from the Department of Education, that my application was approved. 
My studentaid data history shows that XXXX applied XXXX XXXX related refunds to my OPB for my remaining XXXX balance, rather than issue a refund directly to me. This is what I see : o Refund 1 : Loan Disbursement Amount : {$23000.00} Aid Recipient 's Loan Discharge Type Code : XXXXXXXX XXXX Recipient 's Loan Discharge Type Code Description : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 's Loan Discharge XXXX Amount of Discharge : {$8400.00} Amount of Discharge Applied to OPB : {$8400.00} Amount of Discharge Applied to XXXX : {$0.00} o Refund XXXX : Loan Disbursement Amount : {$11000.00} Aid Recipient 's Loan Discharge Type Code : XXXX Aid Recipient 's Loan Discharge Type Code Description : Borrower Defense XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Discharge XXXX Amount of Discharge : {$4700.00} Amount of Discharge Applied to OPB : {$4700.00} Amount of Discharge Applied to XXXX : {$0.00} I applied for borrower defense for my XXXX loans on XX/XX/XXXX. 
I was considered a post-class member of the case for my second borrower defense application. 
I have been told that the Dept. of Edu. has until XXXX to respond to this second application. If they do not, the loans would be automatically XXXX. 

I received notification on XX/XX/XXXX, from the Department of Education, that I received a full discharge of my remaining balances for XXXX  because I was paying on an XXXX plan for XXXX  years. But the second borrower defense case is still pending. 

I sent multiple inquiries about this on the studentaid.gov website which received no response. 

I created a dispute case with the Department of Education. I received an email from XXXX  XXXX XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX stating that they were working on the case. I emailed requesting a status update on XX/XX/XXXX which went unanswered. I sent another email requesting an update again today.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I have a joint consolidated loan with my ex-husband with Mohela. Last I heard, the loan is in forbearance. I have not received a bill or a statement since the pandemic pause of student loan payments. I can not create an account or access an account with Mohela. I have received mixed messages saying my information doesn't match their records or that they are waiting for a transfer of an unrelated student loan ( which no longer exists because I paid it off before the transfer ). 

I can not contact their customer service online for help with my account because I have to be logged in to do so, yet I can't login. I can't call them because waiting times are too long ( hours and hours ). I have heard others say that Mohela isn't sending bills but claims their payments are overdue. 

I do not know how much I owe, if the payments are still in forbearance or overdue, or anything for that matter. I do not have any of the loan paperwork or the prommisory note. I have never had access because my ex-husband handled the account, and I can't ask him because he always says he doesn't know or doesn't want to discuss it. In the past, he has refused to pay the loan and damaged my credit. 

I have applied for joint loan separation with XXXX. I'm currently waiting on them to process everything. 

I am including screenshots of the login error messages I receive. These are the same error messages I have been seeing for the last 4 years.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the U.S. Department of Education and the Department of Governmental Entities. This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act violation and Title VA regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security. I recently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent.

1. My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ).

2. My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including financial aid history and loan information.

3. My IRS tax transcripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization.

These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information.

Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards.

Given the severity of this breach and1. Immediate discharge and cancellation of all my federal student loans due to the breach of my financial aid and tax records, which invalidates the integrity of my loan agreements.

2. A formal investigation into this data breach, including details on how my records were accessed, who accessed them, and for what purpose.

3. A full report on the extent of my data exposure and the corrective measures being implemented to prevent future violations. 
4. Immediate notification to all major credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX XXXX ) to place a fraud alert and investigate any unauthorized activity that may have resulted from this breach. the direct impact on my financial security and privacy, I demand the following corrective actions :

They need to apply the {$2600.00} check as of XX/XX/XXXX ; reconcile the loan account ; and refund me my money immediately. 

I previously submitted a complaint to the CFPB about the same issue ( complaint # XXXX ). MOHELA 's response was essentially " we're working on it. '' But they haven't done anything to resolve the problem. They have similarly stonewalled complaints that I've submitted through the XXXX XXXX XXXX, the Department of Education, and even my congressional representative. Consumer complaint narrative: XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. My student loans entered repayment with MOHELA in XXXX of XXXX. The government put all income driven repayment ( IDR ) on pause at that time. I was unable to apply for an IDR and Public Service Loan Forgiveness ( PSLF ) until my loans entered repayment in XXXX of XXXX. I submitted my application for both an XXXX plan and XXXX in XXXX of XXXX when my loans entered repayment. I XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  and would qualify for XXXX. Since the government was not and is still not processing these applications, I have not paid the monthly amount due. The IDR monthly payment would be around {$100.00} where the MOHELA monthly payment is {$810.00}. The full monthly payment will not count towards the XXXX IDR payment required for PSLF. When talking to customer service, they told me there was nothing they could do to help me and put me in a general forbearance. After speaking to a different representative, they told me that I should have been put on a processing forbearance because I am waiting for the applications to be processed by the government. I have been on 60-day forbearances since then. The monthly payment is {$0.00}, but my interest has been building since XXXX of XXXX. People who already were on IDR and have PSFL, have not been building interest or been charged since the government has been on pause. I think it would be fair if I was no longer charged interest on my loans since I am on a processing forbearance. I should not have been charged interest since XXXX of XXXX. The customer service at MOHELA is also horrible. You can only contact them via phone. Once you call, they put you on hold for 40-90 minutes. Once you pass that hold, they put you on a second hold ( I waited 2 hours ) to get you to the second group of people who can actually change things in your account. I was told that this is the only way to manage your account. I have to call every 60 days to ask for another processing forbearance taking up 3-4 hours of time. I am hoping for some resolutions to these issues. Thank you.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the U.S. Department of Education ( DOE ) and the Department of Governmental Entities ( DOGE ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security.

I recently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes but is not limited to : 1. My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ).

2. My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including financial aid history and loan information. 
3. My IRS tax transcripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization.

These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information.

Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards. 
Given the severity of this breach and the direct impact on my financial security and privacy, I demand the following corrective actions : 1. Immediate discharge and cancellation of all my federal student loans due to the breach of my financial aid and tax records, which invalidates the integrity of my loan agreements.

2. A formal investigation into this data breach, including details on how my records were accessed, who accessed them, and for what purpose.

3. A full report on the extent of my data exposure and the corrective measures being implemented to prevent future violations.

4. Immediate notification to all major credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX XXXX ) to place a fraud alert and investigate any unauthorized activity that may have resulted from this breach. This breach has caused significant distress and concern regarding the security of my personal and financial data. If my demands are not met within 30 days, I will be left with no choice but to escalate this matter through legal channels, including filing complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and pursuing legal action against the responsible parties. I request a written response addressing these concerns and outlining the immediate actions being taken to remedy this situation. Please direct all correspondence to the address listed above. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this urgent matter. I look forward to your immediate response and resolution. 

Also, the school ( XXXX XXXX ) was closed/shut down by the government for fraud

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem with forgiveness, cancellation, or discharge
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Sir or Madame, I am submitting this complaint regarding an issue that has significantly impacted my ability to access my student loan information. Recently, I became aware that access to the U.S. Department of Educations ( DOE ) system was restricted due to actions allegedly taken by Elon Musk or an entity under his control. As a result, I have been unable to retrieve essential information related to my student loans, which has directly caused delays in processing my income-driven repayment application. Due to this delay, I have accrued additional interest on my loans, increasing my overall debt burden through no fault of my own. I respectfully request the following actions : Immediate restoration of access to my student loan information.

Financial relief in the form of reimbursement or cancellation of the accrued interest caused by the delay in my IDR application processing.

Reversal of any late fees or penalties that may have resulted from the restricted access.

Investigation into the cause of the restricted access and whether this violates my rights under FERPA, federal loan servicing agreements, or other relevant regulations.

Assurance that future access to my loan records will not be unlawfully obstructed. 

Please confirm receipt of this complaint and provide guidance on the next steps. I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter and request a formal response outlining how you will address this issue. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Given the severity of this breach and the resulting compromise of my personal and financial information, I request that the US Department of Education immediately cancel and discharge my student loan debt in full.

Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, Mohela sent me correspondence - warning that interest continued to accrue and capitalize on my accounts despite being in administrative forbearance ( can be supplemented upon request ). All of my loans are currently covered under the SAVE repayment plan.

According to Mohela, I owed {$890.00} in interest that had accrued over the past several months. I immediately issued specified payments on each of my loans to resolve the outstanding interest.

Thereafter, I consulted with a financial advisor/attorney, who advised me that Mohela had improperly claimed interest existed, when it in fact, did not.

Mohela appears to have allocated the funds to each of my principal balances respectively, however, Mohela also continues to report the funds paid were specifically applied to " interest ''.

As Mohela has done nothing but lie and misrepresent issues surrounding my ( and millions of other ) student loans, I am contacting the CFPB to report this event, and to otherwise request clarity as to whether funds paid to Mohela on XX/XX/XXXX should or should not be present/accounted for on my annual taxes, specifically the 1098-e form.

Respectfully, - <redacted>

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to express my extreme frustration with the ongoing lack of resolution regarding my request for a written confirmation of my repayment plan. I have made several attempts over the past months to speak with Mohela to get clarity on this matter, but despite countless hours spent and numerous attempts I am still without the required documentation. 

After finally being able to speak with a XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX, we discussed my repayment plan, and I explicitly requested a memo confirming my repayment amount under the agreed plan. However, due to system issues, the XXXX had to manually calculate my repayment, which resulted in a completely different figure than the one provided by XXXX online simulator. I was informed that I would receive this document within XXXX to XXXX business days, and I have yet to receive any correspondence or documentation. I know now, with experience that they will never reach out to me as I have previously attempted to receive this document via email which they never replied to. 

This delay has directly impacted my ability to secure housing, as the document is a critical requirement for my housing approval process. Because of this, I have been denied housing for XXXX, XXXX and XXXX. I have been trying to resolve this issue since XXXX, even submitting my XXXX application multiple times. Each time, I was told it was under review for months, which has added even more frustration to an already difficult situation. Noting, my lease ends in XX/XX/XXXX and I have no idea what to do. 

This ongoing lack of communication and failure to deliver on promised timelines is unacceptable. I need this documentation as a matter of urgency to move forward with my housing application. 

I kindly request immediate intervention so I XXXX be contacted ASAP I can expect to receive the written documentation of my repayment plan. If this matter is not resolved promptly, I will have no choice but to escalate my concerns further. I have attempted to seek help from XXXX but that attempt failed and was redirected to Mohela ( my loan servicer ). 
Thank you for your attention to this matter. I expect a swift and satisfactory resolution.

Consumer complaint narrative: In XXXX and XX/XX/2024, MOHELA has said my payment for my student loans was late despite that payment being removed from my account. In XXXX, they " created an investigation '' that they said would take up to 37 business days to complete. The agent I spoke with on the phone told me that she could see that my payment was there, but it wasn't being applied. Basically, they had my money and weren't putting it onto my student loan account. A couple of months later, after the " investigation " ended, they claimed that my account was put in retroactive forbearance and they never applied that payment because it does not show on my payment history. Now, they are telling me my XXXX payment was late despite again the payment coming out of my bank account. I am waiting for an agent to call me back, but at this point, they have almost {$500.00} of my money and haven't applied those payments properly. I have seen many other borrowers have this same issue with the company, and I think it's time that someone reports them so that it can be handled properly.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Immediate Action Needed : Approve Outstanding Borrower Defense Applications To the Departments Overseeing School & Loan Server Compliance, We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXXaffiliated schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding Borrower Defense applications and provide full relief for those impacted.

Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX The Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXXXXXX XXXX misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within six months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 

At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly 70,000 students across campuses in 26 states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, Ohio, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Student Loan Forgiveness Dear Sir/Madam, I am writing to formally request complete forgiveness of my student loans due to significant violations of my privacy and federal law, particularly concerning the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) XXXX These violations have caused severe emotional distress and hardship, further exacerbated by the involvement of external parties who have accessed sensitive information related to my education without my consent. 

It has come to my attention that my private educational records were compromised due to an illegal disclosure or breach, specifically involving individuals or entities with no legitimate need to access this information. As you are aware, FERPA is a federal law designed to protect the privacy of student records, and any unauthorized access to these records is a clear violation of my rights under this law. 

Furthermore, I have reason to believe that XXXX XXXX or associated entities have gained unauthorized access to government records that include personal information about my educational background. The improper handling of such sensitive data has not only violated my privacy but has also undermined my ability to trust institutions that hold my personal and academic records. 

Given the severity of these violations, I believe it is both justified and necessary for my student loans to be forgiven as a means of addressing the harm and distress caused by these breaches of privacy. The violation of FERPA rights and the involvement of external actors, particularly those with substantial power and access to sensitive data, has placed an undue burden on me that I should not have to bear. 

I kindly ask that you review my case thoroughly and consider the extenuating circumstances surrounding this matter. I am happy to provide any additional documentation or information needed to support my request. I simply do not feel comfortable with the fact that my personal information has been compromised. This is the reason I believe all of my student loans should be forgiven. I also make below average in America. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX.

Consumer complaint narrative:
My loans are with Nelnet and have been for a few years. I have always been in good standing for 12 years to be exact due to the fact I qualify for the Income driven repayment plan ; that I recertify for every year. My next recertification was due in XX/XX/XXXX. XXXX XXXX I received a notification of delinquent status for XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX from my credit wise account and XXXX points was deducted from my XXXX XXXX from Sloan servicing. I immediately look them up and contact them to see what's going on, and dispute the XXXX deduction from my score. The representative advised that XXXX is the sister company of Nelnet and some of my loans were transferred with them including the Income driven repayment plan. The representative also stated that they will review the credit report dispute and have contacted me via email on several occasions and by mail. Also, an XXXX XXXX application is needed at this time to stop the ongoing delinquency. However, the only mail I got from XXXX is the recent credit report review that they denied. I did a search through my email for XXXX and nothing comes up. I only have email from Nelnet. If I did get anything I would have handled whatever was needed immediately because I like to be in good standing with my accounts and have always been. During my call with XXXX, I recertified online while on the phone with the representative and the representative said it was received. A representative at XXXX told me that my Income Driven Plan recertification app was approved. However, I have not received any communication/mail stating it was approved or not. I asked the representative, if my loans and Income driven repayment app was transferred over then why would I be put in delinquent status when it was not due for recertification until XX/XX/XXXX. The representative just kept repeating, we looked into it and the account has been delinquent since XX/XX/XXXX and there is nothing they can do. I work very hard to keep a positive credit record. I never received anything from them, not a call, an email or, mail but a credit dispute review denial letter. Additionally, If I was delinquent since XX/XX/XXXX I would have been in delinquent status way before XX/XX/XXXX as their website states Until an account reaches 90 days past due, it's reported as up to date. When an account reaches 90 days past due, it's reported as delinquent. 
I repeatedly advised them I am not receiving any communications from them and to please investigate the communications issue further, through my BBB dispute. As of today XX/XX/XXXX I still have not received any mail from them. They clearly are not trying to fix the communication issue that will cause me to go in delinquent status in the future. Sloan servicing put me in a payment status when I already had and IDR app filed for XXXX and have damaged my credit by putting me in delinquent. I found that they have put several borrowers back in repayment without properly notifying them causing them to be past due and/or delinquent. I still have not received any communication from them, even after completing another XXXX app XX/XX/XXXX. I do not know what else to do to resolve this communications issue because they clearly do not care.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I currently have {$170000.00} in student loan debt being serviced by Mohela. I work in a non-profit setting, and thus I am in the Public Service Loan Forgiveness ( PSLF ) program. I have applied for discharge / forgiveness because I am over the required 120 qualifying payments while working for a public service / non-profit employer. Mohela has my account currently in a " general forbearance '' which means no payments are due at this time each month, but the months do not qualify for PSLF forgiveness.

However, I believe I should be in a " processing forebearance '', which the Office of Federal Student Aid ( FSA ) states does qualify each month as a qualified month towards gaining forgiveness to 120 qualifying months.

I was in the Income Driven Repayment ( IDR ) plan under the SAVE program, but on XX/XX/XXXX I submitted an application to switch my repayment plan to the Income Contingent Repayment ( ICR ) plan. To this day, my application still says it is being reviewed by Mohela and I am thus still on the SAVE repayment plan.

I received an email from FSA on XX/XX/XXXX updating me on SAVE. This is where I learned that my account should really be in a processing forbearance ( see email attachment ).

Per FSA guidelines, if the loan servicer ( Mohela ) has not processed a repayment application within 60 days, you are supposed to be placed in a " Processing Forbearance ''.

Per FSA : If servicers need time to process a borrowers IDR application, servicers will move the borrower into a processing forbearance for up to 60 days. Interest accrues during this short-term processing forbearance, and time in the processing forbearance is eligible for PSLF and IDR forgiveness. If the borrowers application is not processed by their servicer within 60 days, the borrower will be moved into a general forbearance that does not count toward PSLF or IDR until their application is processed. Interest will not accrue in this general forbearance. 

Thus, since I applied on XX/XX/XXXX, and my application is still not processed, my account should have been placed in a Processing Forbearance on XX/XX/XXXX. From this time forward, my months should be counted towards my PSLF forgiveness, which at this point puts me over 120 qualifying months, and my entire balance should be discharged per PSLF guidelines. 

I spoke to Mohela and requested this change to be made to my forbearance, but they said they could not do this. I explained the FSA guidelines and they still refused to process my request.

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX Email : XXXX Phone # XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Subject XXXX Dispute of Inaccurate Student Loan Information Dear XXXX, I am writing to formally dispute the accuracy of certain information regarding my student loans as reported on my credit report. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically Sections 605 ( b ), 615 ( 1 ), and 623 ( a ) ( 6 ), I have the right to dispute any inaccurate or incomplete information.

Upon reviewing my credit report, I noticed that the following student loans contain negative history that I believe is incorrect : Dept of ED/ Nelnet- Account Number : XXXX According to Section 605 ( b ) of the FCRA, negative information must be accurate and verifiable. Additionally, under Section 615 ( 1 ), I am entitled to a notice if adverse action is taken based on this information. Furthermore, Section 623 ( a ) ( 6 ) requires furnishers of information to investigate disputes and provide accurate reporting. 
I request that you investigate these accounts and remove any inaccuracies from my credit report. Enclosed are copies of relevant documents supporting my claim, including payment records and correspondence with the loan servicer. 
Please confirm receipt of this letter and inform me of your findings within the legally required timeframe. 
Thank you for your attention to this matter. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
iv been requesting all orignail forms and documnetation to my student loan i have a right to these documents I have asked several times in 5 years for these documents and I have yet to recieve them please send me all the documents numbered below numberedXX/XX/XXXXMaintenance of records. 
( a ) Each student loan servicer shall maintain complete records of each student education loan transaction, including recordings of communications with borrowers, for not less than two ( 2 ) years following the final payment on such student education loan or the assignment of such student education loan, whichever occurs first, or any longer period as may be required by any other provision of the general or public laws. 
( b ) If requested by the division of banking, each student loan servicer shall make all records available, not later than five ( 5 ) business days after requested. Upon request, the department may grant a student loan servicer additional time to make these records available.

History of Section. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ch. 265, 1. 

When you take out a student loan, several documents are typically associated with the loan process. Here is a list of the common documents that come with a student loan : 1. **Promissory Note** : A legal contract between the borrower and the lender outlining the terms of the loan, including repayment conditions, interest rates, and default consequences.

2. **Loan Application** : The form you fill out to apply for the loan, which may include personal and financial information.

3. **Admission Acceptance Letter** : A document from your educational institution confirming your acceptance to the program, often required for loan processing.

4. **Financial Aid Offer Letter** : This outlines the types and amounts of financial aid you are eligible for, including grants, scholarships, and loans.

5. **Loan Disclosure Statement** : A document detailing the terms of the loan, including the interest rate, principal amount, fees, and repayment schedule.

6. **Student Aid Report ( SAR ) ** : A summary of your Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) submission that includes your Expected Family Contribution ( EFC ) and eligibility for federal student aid.

7. **Exit Counseling Materials** : Information provided when you graduate, withdraw, or drop below half-time enrollment, detailing your repayment options and obligations.

8. **Repayment Plans** : Documents outlining various options for repaying your loans, including standard, graduated, and income-driven repayment plans.

9. **Loan Servicer Contact Information** : Information on who will manage your loan, including their contact details for future correspondence.

10. **Interest Rate and Fee Information** : Documentation stating the interest rates applicable to your loan and any potential fees ( e.g., origination fees ).

11. **Forbearance or Deferment Requests** : Forms that allow you to temporarily postpone payments under certain conditions if needed.

12. **Tax Documents** : Yearly tax statements regarding interest paid on federal student loans ( e.g., Form 1098-E ) helpful for tax deductions. 

ALL DOCUMENTS IN THEIR ORIGINAL FORM. I ALSO WANT THE SIGNATURE THEY HAVE ON FILE FOR THE NELENT PROMISSORY NOTE THEY SENT. I WAS IN LABOR AT THE TIME OF THE SIGNATURE, AND THERE IS NO WAY I SIGNED THAT PROMISSORY NOTE IN XXXX. I WANT THE ORIGINAL PROMISSORY NOTE

Consumer complaint narrative:
I called Aidvantage on Monday, XX/XX/year>, on or around XXXX XXXX PST. I spoke to a female customer service representative named XXXX XXXX. She was nice and professional. However, I asked to speak with a supervisor regarding previous agents engaging in call-avoidance and violating hold procedure. I respectfully declined to provide my personally identifiable information ( " PIl '' ) to XXXX XXXX. 
While attempting to get a supervisor pursuant to my request, XXXX XXXX brought it to my attention that supervisor XXXX XXXX refused to take my call unless I provided my PIl to authenticate my account. Supervisor XXXX XXXX engaged in call-avoidance and violated policies and procedures. Student loan borrowers are not required to authenticate or verify their account in order to speak with a supervisor. Customer service agents are required to ask and attempt to authenticate the account, however, again, the borrower is not required to provide account details in order to be transferred to a supervisor. I had a valid complaint to bring to the attention of a supervisor regarding agents engaging in, among other things, call avoidance. Because XXXX XXXX refused to do his/her job, I was forced to disconnect and call back in order to get to a supervisor ; causing an undue delay and wasting company time. I called back and spoke to a supervisor who took my call without account verification without issue. I seek to hold XXXX XXXX accountable. Please reprimand or terminate XXXX XXXX.

XX/XX/XXXX @ XXXXXXXX XXXX EST Called FSA to check on reconsideration for PSLF counts.

XX/XX/XXXX Called FSA and spoke to XXXX to check on reconsideration request. She stated that my case has been escalated and is being worked now. She gave me the case number for this call as XXXX.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I was in the cohort of DoEd borrowers on PSLF who transitioned their PSLF servicing from MOHELA to FSA/studentaid.gov in the summer of XXXX, despite MOHELA servicing every other aspect of my loans. This transition placed me on an administrative forbearance.

To add to this confusion, during this transition the SAVE plan was also published and then subsequently challenged/frozen in court. All this resulted in me being placed on multiple forbearances, during which time conflicting information was shared by both FSA/DoEd as well as MOHELA as to whether or not these forbearance months would count as qualifying months towards my PSLF.

I've certified my employment as working for an eligible employer several times this year, the last being on XX/XX/XXXX, with FSA confirming my count is still at 115. Then on XX/XX/XXXX, at the instruction of FSA, I submitted a buyback request for the missing months, which is still in processing with no transparency.

I also submitted a request with MOHELA on XX/XX/XXXX to change payment plans to get me off SAVE and into an IDR plan to continue making eligible payments in case my buyback request with FSA didn't pan out. That is also stuck in processing.

After multiple attempts at outreach to both MOHELA and FSA/DoEd, I've been stuck in administrative limbo making no
progress towards my count of 120 in PSLF. I have been sitting at 115/120 since XXXX of 2024 and am well past what should have been my required 120 months of qualifying employment and payment. I have kept my end of the proverbial bargain when it comes to time spent in public service, and in return I've been forgotten.

Consumer complaint narrative: I attended XXXX XXXX  under the belief that their advertised graduation rates, job placement success, and post-graduation salary expectations were accurate. XXXX falsely claimed that a high percentage of graduates secured jobs in their field with competitive salaries and that the university provided meaningful career placement assistance. These claims were a significant factor in my decision to enroll and take on substantial student loan debt. However, these promises were misleading. XXXX was later proven in court to have falsified this information, and my experience reflects this deception. The school did not provide the career assistance they advertised, and I did not receive the job opportunities or salary expectations they promised. Furthermore, the tuition was significantly higher than comparable institutions, making the financial burden even greater. I am filing this complaint with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to seek accountability for these deceptive practices and request any available relief for the financial harm caused by XXXX fraudulent misrepresentations.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX. During my transition from REPAYE to SAVE on around XX/XX/XXXX, MOHELA rightfully placed my loan account in Administrative Forbearance for 60 days processing but also erroneously billed and collected payment from my direct debit account during the same period. I was later contacted by MOHELA in XX/XX/XXXX about this issue and I was offered the choice of a refund for the premature billing/payment I made during that processing administrative forbearance period or I can be reinstated to an equivalent administrative forbearance period which is eligible towards my PSLF counts for the same period to rectify MOHELA 's mistake. I opted for the administrative forbearance reinstatement which the attached documents verifies my administrative forbearance from XXXX to XXXX by MOHELA. I called FSA and was told to submit a document from MOHELA which I obtained and submitted as evidenced and referenced by FSA as Feedback Case # XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX. FSA has not acted and still erroneously classifying my payments of XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX as regular forbearance which does not count towards my PSLF eligibility. 
Expected resolution is that FSA update my loan payment history to make my payments months of XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX qualify and count as Administrative Forbearance as the evidence provided my MOHELA shows which counts towards my PSLF eligibility. 

XXXX. I made full payment for my student loan due for XX/XX/XXXX to MOHELA but on FSA website, XXXX out of my XXXX loans does not reflect my XX/XX/XXXX payment and does showing I missed a payment although for the past 15 years, I made only I payment and its distributed among the XXXX loans which are consolidated into XXXX payment. I have submitted evidence from MOHELA to FSA evidenced by FSA PSLF Reconsideration request case # XXXX but had no response or resolution from FSA despite multiple follow up calls to MOHELA and FSA. 
Expected resolution is that FSA update my loan payment history to reflect all XXXX parts loans of my consolidated student loan payment was made for XX/XX/XXXX.

Consumer complaint narrative: I submitted XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX  paperwork for the second time with corrections asked during the first denial with aidvantage. Upon second submission I was not notified of receiving my application and the uploads page on the account will never show what I have upload the status or anything related to it. I reached out XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX they told me 60 days to process from submission. In XXXX I was told it was actually 90 days. In XXXX they stated the processing was on hold until XXXX but my application was reviewed and I should hear on next steps soon. Never heard from them until I called on XX/XX/XXXXXXXX I spoke with three different aidvantage reps and each told me to contact FAFSA as aidvantage doesnt process or know the status. Never once was I told it was denied through any three phone calls. I then called FAFSA after each time I was told they process this by three different aidvantage people. I spoke to 12 people and departments at student aid. Each of them told me that they dont process teacher loan forgiveness paperwork and it was through the lender service. The final aidvantage person I spoke to told me to resubmit the application from XX/XX/XXXXXXXX  Which now I know is incorrect. I sent a heated email that afternoon on XX/XX/XXXXXXXX demanding action and response or I would seek legal action. I got an immediate response on XX/XX/XXXX stating it was denied as my school wasnt on the directory. I emailed back stating my school wasnt and that I have the five documents from directory downloaded to show. They then responded my application didnt list my specific school and that it stated I still worked for my district but that the last 3 years my specific schools was listed as low income. I responded back with questions on what specifically they need the services to look like since I still worked for the district and that is what my XXXX XXXX indicated and that I would make sure that the XXXX listed my school specifically as listed in directory. I now will be submitting the application for the fourth time. The lack of communication and effort on their part along with the lack of knowledge relating to this program and who processes it is concerning. Yet they can easily take my direct deposits monthly with no qualms. I demanded processing and action of the new application within 7 calendar days when I submitted the application on XX/XX/XXXX. I now know this is Incorrect and will have to work with hr to get a new application signed and verified asap and rep loaded to aidvantage. I plan to let them know from the date I upload I still expect 7 calendar processing. At this point I have no clue who actually processes it however they can figure this out amongst themselves before legal action is taken on aidvantage.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I received notification from MOHELA that my student loans were put into a forbearance on XXXX XXXX, XXXX as a result of the XXXX injunction. In the letter from MOHELA it stated, We will notify you before the forbearance comes to an end. We do not currently have a time estimate. We will then send you your next monthly billing statement at least XXXX  days before your next monthly payment is due. XXXX days later, on XXXX XXXX, XXXX, I received billing due date for XXXX XXXX, XXXX without any notification about the forbearance ending. It is XX/XX/XXXX and I still have not received notification that the forbearance has ended. 

I currently have my loans pending for the XXXX program and should not be receiving any bills during the injunction. 

When I have attempted to connect with a MOHELA representative over the phone, the auto-recording states, " for borrowers with pending XXXX applications and borrowers enrolled in the XXXX plan, MOHELA is working to place your account into a forbearance. Placing you into a forbearance will take time and we will notify you once this has been completed. In the meantime, you may receive notices from us regarding making your monthly payment. Please disregard those. '' My account says that I am currently past due on payments and have over {$1700.00} due in XXXX. This is not a doable amount for me to pay. I am a non-profit employee and this is nearly 50 % of my monthly income. 

I have been enrolled in XXXX and have XXXX payments remaining until I have completed my XXXX payments. 

Via email, I have asked MOHELA to respond to the following questions : XXXX. Has my forbearance ended? 
XXXX. Do I currently have a balance on my account that needs to be paid? 
XXXX. Will my XXXX eligibility be impacted by this past due payment? 

I have tried calling and discussing with a MOHELA representative multiple times now and can not get in touch with a representative. XXXX time I waited XXXX hours to talk to a representative, connected with a person who confirmed my contact information and then asked to transfer me to another person. When transferred, I was told this wait time would be another XXXX hour wait. This is unreasonable. I am doing everything in my power to manage my student loan payments appropriately, but this system is ineffective for allowing me to manage my loans.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing a complaint against EdFinancial Services for failing to move my federal student loans from the SAVE ( Saving on a Valuable Education ) repayment plan to the Income-Based Repayment ( IBR ) plan, despite clear guidance from the U.S. Department of Education stating that borrowers are permitted to make this change upon request. I formally requested this change from EdFinancial on XX/XX/year> and have not received confirmation that my request has been processed. Instead, my loans remain in the SAVE plan, and I have not been provided with a valid reason for the delay or denial. Per the Department of Educations published guidance, servicers have resumed processing applications for IBR, ICR, and PAYE plans. If additional processing time is needed, borrowers should be placed in a processing forbearance that provides IDR and PSLF credit. However, EdFinancial has failed to comply with this guidance and has not moved my loans accordingly. This delay is negatively impacting my repayment plan selection, and I am concerned about the improper handling of my account. I request that EdFinancial immediately process my change from SAVE to IBR as required and ensure that my forbearance status, if necessary, aligns with Department of Education policy. I ask the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to investigate this issue and ensure that EdFinancial follows the proper procedures for handling borrower requests. 

Thank you for your consideration.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Immediate Action Needed : Approve XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX To the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXX schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX and provide full relief for those impacted. 
Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXX XXXX misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within XXXX months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 
At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in XXXX states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Summary and Statements of Facts. 
We are asking you to take immediate steps to : XXXX. Approve all outstanding XXXX XXXX applications for students who attended these institutions. 
XXXX. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans. 
XXXX. Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts. 
Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the XXXX XXXX, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it. 
We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays. 
Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 
Sincerely, Students & Graduates of XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative: Mohela changed platforms this summer ( 2024 ) and put many of us in mandatory administrative forbearance without any notice. This also meant that our autopay was disrupted without our awareness. I called multiple times to both Mohela and XXXX and both confirmed repeatedly that though I was put in " mandatory administrative forbearance for processing purposes '' as they moved moved to a new platform and collected documentation to support our loans on the new platform, XXXX and XXXX would still count as qualifying payments for XXXX. In addition, Mohela informed me that this was a mandatory forbearance and there was nothing I can do ( but again they assured me that if my concern is PSLF, that I should not worry because both months will count toward my qualified payment count ). However, the system continues to say to date that my XXXX and XXXX payments are marked " ineligible '' under payment status and the prompt shows Loans in non-qualifying forbearance. Even the prompt though says that administrative forbearance is eligible, and though this was the type of forbearance on my account at the time, it is still marked ineligible. In addition to all this, both entities told me at the time that because it is a mandatory admin forbearance, my interest should be {$0.00} -- then I pointed out to Mohela that my account showed that I was continued to accrue interest. In response, Mohela told me that while it will show as accruing interest now, once the forbearance is lifted and my account moved to the new platform, I would be credit back the interest as if it was at 0 % rate. None of that turned out to be true. I continue to have difficulty getting any further clarity from either Mohela ( who will no longer comment as they are no longer administering XXXX ) or FSA/StudentAid.gov. I submitted yet another case/complaint on XXXX ( Complaint case # XXXX ) more than a month ago but have not gotten any response or resolution. Meanwhile multiple areas in the StudentAid.gov site and the PSLF Certification form say on pg. XXXX ( and pg. XXXX of the old form ) eligible payment equivalents include admin forbearance and mandatory admin forbearance.
