Consumer complaint narrative:
I am seeking your assistance regarding an ongoing issue with my student loan servicer, MOHELA. 

It has been several months since I was placed on deferment, yet I still have not been granted access to my account, preventing me from setting up any type of payment plan. Whenever I attempt to log in, my account remains locked. When I contact MOHELA, they claim I do not have an account, but when I speak with StudentAid.gov, I am informed that my account does indeed exist.

I am deeply concerned that I will be marked as delinquent and unable to make payments on my loans by XX/XX/XXXX, which would have serious financial consequences. It seems as though MOHELA is setting me up for failure, possibly with the intent to issue a garnishment order, which is unfair given that I am actively trying to address my loan situation. 

I am seeking your guidance and support on how to resolve this issue. I have exhausted all available options with MOHELA, and I am unsure how else to proceed. 

Calls Placed to Moehla : Timeline of MOHELA Contact Attempts XX/XX/XXXX Date : Friday, XX/XX/XXXX Issue : Account locked ; no resolution after call. 

XX/XX/XXXX Date : Friday, XX/XX/XXXX Issue : Account still locked ; MOHELA claims no account exists. 

XX/XX/XXXX Date : Friday, XX/XX/XXXX Issue : No resolution ; account still locked, error message received stating no account found. 

XX/XX/XXXX Date : Friday, XX/XX/XXXX Issue : MOHELA still unable to assist ; locked account persists. 

XX/XX/XXXX Date : Friday, XX/XX/XXXX Issue : Continued account lock ; error message upon entering full name, XXXX, and date of birth. 

XX/XX/XXXX Date : Friday, XX/XX/XXXX Issue : Same error ; no account found despite information matching. 

XX/XX/XXXX Date : Friday, XX/XX/XXXX Issue : Account still locked ; no progress made despite multiple calls. 

XX/XX/XXXX Date : Monday, XX/XX/XXXX Issue : Account remains locked, still receiving error when trying to unlock. 

Emails sent to California XXXX XXXX XXXX and California XXXX XXXX XXXX on Monday, XX/XX/XXXX. 

Your assistance in advocating for a solution would be greatly appreciated.

Consumer complaint narrative: I XXXX XXXX XXXX in XX/XX/XXXX. I did not start working XXXX XXXX until XX/XX/XXXX because I had to take time off to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. I XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX so I am planning on PSLF. I was told to consolidate my loans and apply for IDR by a student loan counselor. My payments for the first year should be XXXX because I made very little last year and this year, as reflected on the tax forms attached. I applied to consolidate my loans on XX/XX/XXXX and submitted an IDR application with the consolidation application. My loans were consolidated on XX/XX/XXXX. Soon after that, MOHELA sent me a notice that I was on a standard repayment plan and owed around {$780.00} starting on XX/XX/XXXX. I submitted additional IDR applications on XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX, and nothing happened. I called MOHELA on XX/XX/XXXX and waited on hold for over an hour just to have the call drop as soon as I was connected to a person. Everyone online said the only way to get through is to call right when they open at XXXX CT, so on XX/XX/XXXX I woke up at XXXX MT so that I could do that. I talked to an agent who requested a processing forbearance be placed on my account, so now my account is in a processing forbearance ending on XX/XX/XXXX. The MOHELA agent said that if my IDR application is not processed by that date I need to call again to get an extension on the processing forbearance. From what I've seen online my time in this forbearance will count towards my 120 PSLF payments, but I'm not totally confident in that so I want to get the IDR application processed to reflect the {$0.00} payments I'll have based on my XXXX tax returns so that they definitely count. I also don't want to have to wake up at XXXX again to call if I can avoid it. I am not sure why my original application from XXXX wasn't processed since they seemed to process the consolidation application so quickly. I submitted different applications for SAVE and other IDR plans because I'm aware some of this is tied up in the courts. I've attached screenshots reflecting the dates described as well as my proof of income in the form of an IRS document from my most recent tax filing ( filed in XXXX  XXXX ).

Consumer complaint narrative: I have been the PSLF program for my federal student loans for over 10 years. I am an attorney working in eviction defense for Legal Services NYC. I have certified my employment each year. I have 115 out of 120 qualifying payments. I have followed all the rules, made on time payments, certified my employment, submitted my income-based repayment applications yearly, and been a dedicated public servant for over a decade. I entered into the SAVE IBR plan in XXXX. Due to the litigation around SAVE brought by attorneys general in states I have never lived or worked in, I was placed into involuntary forbearance in XX/XX/XXXX, and that forbearance does not count towards PSLF. I do not have the option to make payments during this time, and I am not able to switch to a different IBR plan, so I am trapped. I've never missed a payment before and would never have entered into forbearance voluntarily. The only viable option I have is the buyback program. I submitted a buyback request on XX/XX/XXXX and requested to pay the months of XXXX - XX/XX/XXXX in order to reach 120 qualifying payments for PSLF. I have not received any update on my buyback request, and representatives from FSA can only tell me that the request is processing. I am extremely distressed that my request won't go through while the president is threatening to abolish the DOE. All I want to do is pay what I owe under this program and apply for the forgiveness I've been working towards for over 10 years.
Company: Servicer under contract with Federal Student Aid

I consolidate federal student loans to AIDVANTAGE, completed in XXXX. I applied for the XXXX loan plan and was placed in a 60-day ADMINISTRATIVE forbearance. At the end of 60 days I was supposed to be placed in a GENERAL forbearance. This is what I was told by supervisors at AIDVANTAGE and is on the Dept. of Education website ( below ). AIDVANTAGE did not place me in General forbearance they erroneously placed me into repayment and added interest to my account. They must remove this interest. 

I called once in XXXX, 3 times in XXXX and spoke to 3 separate supervisors. 

FROM XXXX XXXX________ If servicers need time to process a borrowers IDR application, servicers will move the borrower into a processing forbearance for up to 60 days. Interest accrues during this short-term processing forbearance, and time in the processing forbearance does provide IDR credit and PSLF credit XXXX with certified employment ). If the borrowers application is not processed by their servicer within 60 days, the borrower will be moved into a general forbearance that does not count toward XXXX or XXXX until their application is processed. Interest will not accrue in the XXXX forbearance.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I have been trying to communicate with the " Advanced Department '' at Mohela since XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
I have been accepted into the Public Safety Loan Forgiveness ( PSLF ) and just paid my XXXX qualified payment in XX/XX/year>. I verified my employment thru the proper methods multiple times and all of my payments indeed qualified. This XXXX milestone was the target to complete the PSLF terms. I contacted XXXX XXXX XXXX to request the next step. 
They informed me that they are ready to process the PSFL forgiveness but Mohela has not updated their website since XX/XX/year>, which shows that I had only made XXXX payments. As soon as they get the payments updated from Mohela, they will forgive the loans. I have been trying to communicate with the correct people at Mohela since XXXX. 
I have tried several times waiting XXXX minutes each time just to get thru the phone trees and then eventually several hours either on hold or awaiting a call back. XXXX times, after waiting for hours I did end up speaking with a representative. They informed me that I was indeed compliant with the terms of PSFL program. They have been receiving all of my payments and that I was now paying extra payments. They assured me that any additional payments would be refunded, however they informed me that they were not the correct department to update the XXXX XXXX website. They forwarded me to the Advanced Department who would be able to update the XXXX XXXX website. I sat on hold for hours and there was not an opportunity to have them call me back. 
The XXXX time I waited XXXX hours on hold until I could not longer wait any longer. The XXXX time I waited XXXX hours with no answer. I have since tried the phone tree to call and leave a message to try and attempt to reach this department again. I did receive a call from another rep who reviewed the notes on the case and tried to forward again to the Advanced Department. She would not provide me with a direct number to call the appropriate department to prevent me for waiting hours, She reported that I needed to go thru the process each and every time. She did apologize and I sat on hold a final time only to be disconnected after XXXX hours. 
In the meantime, my automatic payments continue to be deposited into Mohelas accounts and I am not able to cancel these payments. I tried signing into my Mohelas account. I signed in and there was a message that they have a new platform wit a link. I was redirected to this website and none of my credentials will work. When I try to hit forgot my username, this new platform does not recognize my SS #, Mohela account # or name. 
I can not get anyone from Mohela to discuss this case and have them place me into a forbearance to stop taking additional payments and give them the opportunity to update to XXXX XXXX website so they can process the PSFL process. 
Please, please, please, help.

MOHELAs lack of responsiveness and inefficient handling of repayment applications is deeply concerning, and I urge the CFPB to investigate their practices. I would appreciate any assistance in ensuring that my application is properly processed without further delays.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
My student loans are handled by MOHELA. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I applied to be a part of the XXXX plan. MOHELA informed me that they had paused processing applications. 

On XX/XX/XXXX I was placed on processing forbearance by MOHELA, with interests in all loans continuing to accrue. 

Throughout this time, I had called MOHELA approximately XXXX times, often waiting on hold for over XXXX hours to address various issues. 

On XX/XX/XXXX I called MOHELA to inquire about the Department of Educations XX/XX/XXXX instructions regarding treatment of such loans. Under these guidelines, " Processing forbearance will last no longer than 60 days, at which point a borrower may be placed into general forbearance under the terms described for that status. '' https : //www.ed.gov/higher-education/manage-your-loans/save-plan. " If the borrowers application is not processed by their servicer within 60 days, the borrower will be moved into a general forbearance that does not count toward PSLF or IDR until their application is processed. Interest will not accrue in this general forbearance. " After speaking with a representative about this issue, she agreed that I was in processing forbearance, but refused to comply with the Department of Education guidelines instructions to move me into " general forbearance. '' I requested to speak with a supervisor. The supervisor also agreed that I was in processing forbearance, and refused to provide an explanation about why I was not moved into general forbearance. Again, I pointed the supervisor to the clear mandate from the Department of Education. The supervisor informed me that they were not currently following those guidelines. 

To be clear, MOHELA has refused to comply with the guidelines of the Department of Education, instead choosing to continue to charge severe interest rates to a recent graduate. After speaking with the supervisor, it is clear MOHELA believes they are " above the law '' and are immune from any action regarding the movement of accounts into general forbearance.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Consumer complaint narrative: Like many, I applied to consolidate my student loans and change to the SAVE plan when it was announced by the XXXX administration. I initially did this in XX/XX/XXXX. By the time the SAVE plan had been put on hold in the courts however, MOHELA had still not processed the change. Because of that, I had to repeatedly contact them about being placed in forbearance, as it would only last a month or so until my payments would be slated to resume. In Fall XXXX, however, I was finally placed on the administrative forbearance intended for borrowers in a similar situation as myself. In XXXX, however, I received a notice through email that my payments would be resuming. I again contacted MOHELA through their secure messaging system, at which time I was assured that " another forbearance will be applied to your account and would begin on XX/XX/XXXX. '' On XX/XX/XXXX, I received an email from MOHELA stating that my loans were placed in a forbearance, and on XX/XX/XXXX I received an email stating that I'd missed a payment for my loans. That same day I submitted another message through their system asking to confirm that my loans would be appropriately placed into forbearance and that the missed payment would be stricken from my record, after which I received a response that a request was submitted to have a forbearance applied to all loans on my account. I received no further correspondence from them until I made a similar request on XX/XX/XXXX, and at some point following that they only responded that my account was delinquent and that " calls and/or letters will continue until the account is current. '' I appears that they are willfully ignoring my requests and also intending to continue to mark payments as missed on an account that should, according to them, be in forbearance.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX  XX/XX/XXXX Formal Dispute and demand for loan discharge due to Legal Violation and Data Breach Complaint - Unauthorized Access to my Education Records I am writing to formally dispute the legitimacy of my student loan obligation. Due to serious legal violations and breaches of federal privacy laws including the Family Educations Rights and Privacy Act ( FEPRA ), the Privacy Act of 1974 and the Higher Education Act.

I am filing a formal Complaint under the Family Educations Rights and Privacy Act ( FEPRA ), the Privacy Act of 1974 and the Higher Education Act regarding an unauthorized access and disclosure of my financial aid records, sharing my personal and banking information. I have not given permission to disclose my information. 
It has come to my attention that my personal educational and financial information has been improperly accessed by unauthorized third parties XXXX XXXX, unofficial government entity XXXX, and other possible affiliated entities. 

This unauthorized access constitutes a gross violation of my federal privacy rights and nullifies any enforceable loan agreements under federal law. 

Legal grounds for discharge. 
FERPA violations : The exposure of my educational records without my expressed written consent is a direct breach FERPA, which mandates the protection of personally identifiable information.

Violation of the Privacy Act of 1974 : The mishandling and unauthorized disclosure of my personal information contravenes federal requirements that safeguard the privacy of individuals data managed by federal agencies. 

Breach of Higher Education Act : The higher Education Act requires servicers to maintain strict confidentiality and compliance in loan transfers. The transfer of my loan information to XXXX and subsequent data breaches demonstrates clear negligence. 

Demands for Resolution : Due to these violations, I formally demand : Immediate and unconditional cancellation of all financial obligations associated with my student loans. 
Complete removal of all student loan related entries to my credit report. 
Written confirmation of this cancellation and credit correction within 30 days. 

If my demands are not met I reserve the right to pursue all available legal remedies, including claims for damages arising from these privacy breaches and violations of federal law. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX
Company: Servicer under contract with Federal Student Aid

Consumer complaint narrative: I have been trying for a month to get my PSLF status recertified and have my payments recalculated. First they kept prompting me to use the digital signature option, but their system wasn't sending the email to my HR. Every time I updated the website, it would update the next day showing their email was updated to " " ( blank ). Reached out to customer service and they sent me a template email back referring me to their website and referencing common things people are emailing about ( did not address my question at all ). I tried to submit another ticket, and got the same useless response. Tried calling and was stuck in the phone tree for 40 minutes before I gave up. Eventually cancelled the submission altogether and resubmitted using the old method where you upload a PDF. Did that, and 2 weeks later, got an email that my application was closed due to missing information. The letter stated that my employers signature was missing, and I would have to start over and provide the completed application. I downloaded the form from the student aid portal, and it is filled out completely, including the employer signature. I'm so tired of this. Every year I have to submit this paperwork just to know how many payments I owe them, since they apparently can't keep track of it, or are not expected to manage it themselves. I'm tired of getting the runaround. If I owe them money, they should be responsible for keeping an accurate track of what is owed without me having to beg for it.
Company: Servicer under contract with Federal Student Aid

Consumer complaint narrative:
Complaint Against Mohela for Failing to Honor General Forbearance Agreement, Interest Accrual Correction, and Repeated Mishandling of My Case 1. Issue Summary I am submitting this complaint because Mohela has failed to honor the general forbearance agreement that was supposed to prevent interest from accruing on my student loans while the injunction for the XXXX repayment plan is in effect. Despite clear guidance from the Department of Education, my loan servicer has allowed interest to accrue, failed to correct the accrued interest, and is now demanding a payment. 

Additionally, I have made repeated attempts over several months to resolve this issue through Mohelas customer service, spending hours on phone calls, only to be met with delays, unhelpful responses, and multiple instances of being hung up on mid-conversation. This has caused significant financial and professional distress. 

I am a XXXX XXXX working an average of XXXX hours per week, earning a modest salary that makes it impossible to afford payments under the XXXX XXXX XXXX. This is precisely why I applied for the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ensure my payments would be adjusted based on my income. Mohelas failure to follow federal guidance and place me in the required 0 % interest general forbearance has placed undue financial stress on me. 

XXXX. Relevant Loan Applications & Timeline : - Direct Consolidation Loan Application Submitted : XX/XX/XXXX ( See attached screenshot. ) - Income-Driven Repayment Selection ( SAVE Plan ) Was Part of the Consolidation Loan Application As part of the Direct Consolidation Loan process, I was required to select a repayment plan, and I chose the XXXX Repayment Plan at the time of submission. Because my application has been delayed beyond 60 days, I should have been placed in a general forbearance where no interest accrues, as per the Department of Educations directive. 

3. Mohelas Agreement to Place My Loan in Forbearance Without Interest Accrual The Department of Education clearly states : If the borrowers application is not processed by their servicer within 60 days, the borrower will be moved into a general forbearance that does not count toward PSLF or IDR until their application is processed. Interest will not accrue in this general forbearance. ( See attached screenshot from the Department of Education website. ) Additionally, Mohela acknowledged this requirement in their own communication, stating : Mohela is in the process of making the necessary system adjustments to your account to apply the 0.00 % interest rate forbearance to your loan. ( See attached Mohela statement. ) Despite this, Mohela has not applied this forbearance correctly, nor have they corrected the improperly accrued interest. 

XXXX. Evidence of Mohelas Non-Compliance & Poor Customer Service - Interest has continued to accrue on my loans, as reflected in my account balance. 
XXXX Mohela has not corrected the interest that already accrued, even though they acknowledged my forbearance should have been interest-free. 
- My Mohela account statement still shows accrued interest, contradicting the agreed-upon forbearance terms. 
XXXX Mohela is now demanding a payment despite my loan being in forbearance. ( See attached account summary screenshot. ) Repeated customer service failures : - I have made multiple phone calls from the summer of XXXX through XX/XX/XXXX, spending hours trying to resolve this issue. 

- As a XXXX XXXX working XXXX hours per week, I have had to use my limited days off to make these calls, often spending my entire day off dealing with this issue instead of resting. 

- On multiple occasions, I have been hung up on mid-conversation, and I have proof of these instances. 

- I have received no resolution, only delays and unhelpful responses from Mohela representatives. 

This lack of customer service, failure to follow federal guidelines, and outright negligence by Mohela has made it nearly impossible for me to resolve this situation despite my continued efforts.

I sent this to them : My Formal Dispute of Loan Repayment Due to Unauthorized Third-Party Data Breach I am writing to formally dispute the repayment of my student loans due to a severe and unauthorized breach of my personal and financial information, which appears to violate the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and the Privacy Act of 1974. Recent investigative reporting from USA TODAY and The Washington Post has confirmed that XXXX XXXX Department of Government Efficiency (XX/XX/XXXX) has been granted unauthorized access to federal student financial aid databases, including the National Student Loan Database System ( NSLDS ) and the Common Origination and Disbursement ( COD ) System. 

The University XXXX California XXXX XXXX has already filed a lawsuit in federal court, accusing XXXX of illegally infiltrating systems that house personal financial aid records. A U.S. Department of Education employee has further confirmed that XXXX team has viewed sensitive financial data of students receiving federal aid. These actions represent a clear violation of FERPA, which mandates that student records can not be accessed without explicit consent, as well as a potential breach of federal regulations governing student loan agreements. 

As a borrower whose financial data has been unlawfully accessed, I believe this compromises the integrity of my loan agreement. If my contract states that unauthorized third-party access voids repayment obligations, then this breach has rendered my agreement unenforceable. I demand the following immediate actions : 1. Formal confirmation from XXXX regarding whether my financial records were accessed or compromised due to this unauthorized breach. 
2. Immediate cancellation and discharge of my student loan debt on the grounds that the agreement has been violated by external interference. 
XXXX. A written response within 30 days outlining the steps being taken to protect my financial information and ensure compliance with federal privacy laws.

If this request is not addressed, I am prepared to escalate this matter through legal action, including joining any class-action lawsuits that may emerge in response to this breach. I will also be filing formal complaints with the U.S. Department of Education, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) to investigate this violation of my rights under federal law.

Please respond to this letter as soon as possible to confirm receipt and outline the next steps. If you require additional documentation, I am happy to provide supporting evidence. 

Sincerely, XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : FORMAL DEMAND FOR FULL STUDENT LOAN DISCHARGE FEDERAL PRIVACY VIOLATIONS & ILLEGAL DATA ACCESS To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to demand the full and immediate discharge of my federal student loans due to multiple violations of federal privacy laws, unauthorized access to my loan data, financial risk exposure, and the complete loss of consumer protections due to the illegal dismantling of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ).

Recent federal investigations, including reporting from Inside Higher Ed ( link ), confirm that the U.S. Department of Education ( ED ) has unlawfully disclosed sensitive borrower data to unauthorized entities, including the Office of Governance and Ethics ( DOGE ). As my loan servicer, XXXX has an obligation under federal law to ensure my personal and financial information is protected, yet my records have been accessed, compromised, and potentially modified without my knowledge or consent. 
Because my student loan records have been unlawfully accessed and my privacy rights have been violated, my federal loans are now subject to immediate discharge under existing legal frameworks. 

I. LEGAL BASIS FOR LOAN DISCHARGE Under federal law, student loans obtained or serviced under unlawful conditions, including violations of privacy rights and unauthorized data disclosures, may be discharged in full. My case qualifies under multiple violations of federal privacy, consumer protection, and financial security laws as follows : 1. Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 o My student loan records have been accessed without my consent and disclosed to unauthorized entities, violating FERPA protections.

o The Master Promissory Note ( MPN ) strictly limits third-party data access, yet my financial records have been exposed without notification or consent.

2. Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( GLBA ) 15 U.S.C. 6801 et seq.

o XXXX and the Department of Education failed to implement safeguards to prevent unauthorized access to my financial data.

o My personal financial data has been improperly accessed, putting me at significant financial and credit risk.

3. Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq.

o If any modifications have been made to my loan balance, terms, or repayment status without my direct authorization, this constitutes an FCRA violation.

4. Privacy Act of 1974 5 U.S.C. 552a o Federal agencies are prohibited from disclosing personal records without explicit consent, yet my student loan data has been accessed by unauthorized entities.

5. Federal Trade Commission Act 15 U.S.C. 45 o The unauthorized access and potential misuse of my financial data constitutes an unfair and deceptive practice under FTC law.

6. Internal Revenue Code 26 U.S.C. 6103 o If my Federal Tax Information ( FTI ) was accessed in connection with my student loan records, this constitutes a federal violation of tax confidentiality laws.

7. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) Violations & Loss of Consumer Rights o The illegal shutdown of the CFPB has deprived me of federal oversight, making my student loan obligations inherently unlawful.

o Without the CFPBs enforcement authority, there is no legal regulatory body protecting borrowers from misconduct, placing the full liability for compliance on XXXX

II. DIRECT IMPACT LOSS OF LOAN ENFORCEABILITY My student loan records have been unlawfully accessed, violating multiple federal laws. 
I did not authorize XXXX, the U.S. Department of Education, or any third party to access, share, or alter my student loan data beyond legal servicing requirements. 
Because my financial data has been exposed, my loans have been tainted by unlawful handling and are no longer enforceable under federal lending laws. 
Since the conditions under which my loans were serviced and maintained are unlawful, XXXX can not legally continue to enforce repayment. The only appropriate remedy is immediate loan discharge. 

XXXX. FORMAL DEMAND FOR ACTION I am formally demanding the following actions : Full and immediate discharge of my federal student loans due to unlawful data exposure and privacy violations. 
A written confirmation of which unauthorized entities accessed my records and how XXXX allowed this to occur. 
A full forensic audit of my loan account history to determine if unauthorized modifications were made. 
A formal response within 30 days outlining XXXX corrective actions and compliance measures. 
Failure to comply with this demand will result in immediate legal escalation to : The U.S. Department of Justice ( DOJ ) for a federal investigation into data privacy violations. 
The Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) for enforcement of consumer protection laws. 
The U.S. Senate Banking Committee and House Financial Services Committee for Congressional oversight and intervention. 
If XXXX refuses to act, I will pursue all available legal avenues to ensure that my student loans are discharged and that XXXX is held accountable for its failure to comply with federal consumer protection laws. 

IV. FINAL NOTICE & ESCALATION WARNING I expect a written response and confirmation of loan discharge within 30 days from the date of this letter. Failure to comply will result in immediate legal action. 
XXXX must acknowledge that the conditions under which my loans were managed have been compromised by federal violations, making them unenforceable. 
If no action is taken, I will escalate this case to federal authorities, legal counsel, and media organizations for further exposure.

As a federal student loan borrower, my private financial and personal data has been accessed without my authorization, constituting a violation of my consumer protection rights. 

Summary of Complaint : Recent reports indicate that DOGE personnel have been granted unauthorized access to the Department of Education 's internal databases, which store sensitive financial and personal data of millions of federal student loan borrowers. This includes, but is not limited to : - Social Security numbers- Dates of birth - Loan balances - Repayment history This access was granted without borrower consent, constituting a severe violation of my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and XXXX, as well as potential violations of the Privacy Act of XXXX. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) has an obligation to investigate this unauthorized access, given its impact on financial data security and consumer protections.

( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) XXXX. Ongoing Lawsuits : XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX has filed legal action alleging a massive breach of borrower privacy due to XXXX  involvement. ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ) Requested Resolutions : Given the severity of this breach and its impact on my financial privacy and security, I am requesting the following actions to be taken place bye XX/XX/XXXX : 1. Immediate Investigation : The CFPB must investigate the DOEs role in granting unauthorized access to borrower data and XXXX use of this information. 
2. Account Remediation : Ensure that my student loan data is secured, reviewed, and corrected for any unauthorized modifications.

This violation directly impacts my financial security and consumer rights. I urge the CFPB to take swift action in investigating and addressing this breach. Please provide me with updates regarding the status of my complaint and any actions taken to resolve it.

To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the U.S. Department of Education ( DOE ) and the Department of Government Efficiency ( DOGE ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations, as well as a significant infringement on my personal privacy and financial security.

Details of the Breach : On XX/XX/XXXX, I discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes, but is not limited to : Academic Records and Personally Identifiable Information ( PII ) : Unauthorized access to my educational records without my consent.

FAFSA Data : Improper access to my Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) information, encompassing financial aid history and loan details.

IRS Tax Transcripts : Unauthorized retrieval and utilization of my tax records, violating federal data security standards.

These actions contravene my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me control over access to my educational records, and Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. The unauthorized access to my IRS tax data also raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft and fraud.

Personal Impact : I hold a federal student loan of {$150000.00}, serviced by XXXX, which I incurred for my XXXX XXXX XXXX, graduating in XXXX from the XXXX XXXX. The breach of my financial aid and tax records has invalidated the integrity of my loan agreements and has caused significant distress and concern regarding the security of my personal and financial data. 

Demands for Corrective Action : Given the severity of this breach and its direct impact on my financial security and privacy, I demand the following actions : Immediate Discharge and Cancellation of All Federal Student Loans : Due to the compromise of my financial aid and tax records, the integrity of my loan agreements has been invalidated. 

Formal Investigation : A thorough inquiry into this data breach, detailing how my records were accessed, who accessed them, and for what purposes. 

Comprehensive Report : A full account of the extent of my data exposure and the measures being implemented to prevent future violations.

Credit Bureau Notifications : Immediate alerts to all major credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX XXXX ) to place fraud alerts and investigate any unauthorized activity resulting from this breach. 

If my demands are not met within 30 days, I will have no choice but to escalate this matter through legal channels, including filing complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and pursuing legal action against the responsible parties. 

I request a written response addressing these concerns and outlining the immediate actions being taken to remedy this situation. Please direct all correspondence to the address listed above. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this urgent matter. I look forward to your immediate response and resolution. 

Sincerely,

On XX/XX/XXXX, I became aware of a major breach involving My personal educational and financial information through XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX XXXX. Despite the public exposure of this security breach accessed by unauthorized third parties, including XXXX XXXX, Co-Head of DOGE ( department of government efficiency ) and/or DOGE Associates . This unauthorized access constitutes a gross violation of my federal privacy rights and nullifies any enforceable loan agreements under federal law., I received no direct communication from Edfinancial or my previous servicers ( XXXX XXXX and XXXX ) regarding the compromise of my sensitive data.

Under FERPA, my student loan data is protected, and Edfinancial has a legal responsibility to ensure its confidentiality. 
The breach has exposed me to the risks of identity theft, financial fraud, and other potential damages. 
2. Failure to Notify Borrowers & Address the Breach : Despite the severity of this data breach, Edfinancial has failed to notify me or take corrective action to protect my rights as a borrower.

1. FERPA Violation : The exposure of my educational records without my express written consent is a direct breach of FERPA, which mandates the protection of personally ident
ifiable information.

2. Violation of the Privacy Act of 1974 : The mishandling and unauthorized disclosure of my personal information contravenes federal requirements that safeguard the privacy of individuals ' data managed by federal agencies and contractors.

3. Breach of the Higher Education Act : The Higher Education Act requires servicers to maintain strict confidentiality and compliance in loan transfers. The transfer of my loan to Edfinancial and subsequent data breaches demonstrate clear negligence.

4. Breach of Contract and Data Security Obligations : By failing to protect my sensitive information, both XXXX and Edfinancial breached contractual terms and obligations, rendering these debts unenforceable. 
I filed a formal dispute with Edfinancial under Case Number XXXX, requesting loan discharge due to the violation of my privacy rights.

To the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXX schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding Borrower Defense applications and provide full relief for those impacted. 
Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : * XXXX University XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX The Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXX University misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within XXXX months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 
At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in XXXX states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts.

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : 1. Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions.

We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays.

Sincerely, Students & Graduates of XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally dispute my student loan due to the recent major data breach that has compromised the personal and financial information of millions of borrowers, including my own. This breach directly violates the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ) and other federal protections designed to safeguard student information.

Recent reports confirm that sensitive Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, personal identifiers, and financial records have been mishandled, allowing unauthorized access to my information. This mishandling represents gross negligence by the government and corporate entities responsible for protecting our data. Due to this breach, I am now at increased risk of identity theft, financial fraud, and third-party exploitation.

Under FERPA, educational institutions and agencies must maintain the confidentiality of students ' personal and financial data. The unauthorized exposure of my information violates the following federal statutes and regulations : Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ) : FERPA protects student records and restricts unauthorized disclosures.

Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( GLBA ) ( 15 U.S.C. 6801 et seq. ) : Financial institutions, including those handling student loans, are required to implement safeguards for protecting personal financial information.

Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) Act ( 15 U.S.C. 45 ) : Prohibits unfair or deceptive practices, including failure to secure sensitive consumer data.

Higher Education Act ( HEA ) of 1965 ( 20 U.S.C. 1081 et seq. ) : Governs federal student aid programs and mandates data security measures.

Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq. ) : Ensures protection of consumer credit information, which may have been compromised in this breach.

Privacy Act of 1974 ( 5 U.S.C. 552a ) : Restricts federal agencies from disclosing personal information without consent.

Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act ( 18 U.S.C. 1028 ) : Criminalizes the misuse of personal data leading to identity theft. 

Please provide written confirmation of receipt of this dispute and keep me informed on all steps taken to address my concerns. If necessary, I am prepared to take further legal action to uphold my rights and financial security.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Data Breach, FERPA and Title IV Violations To Whom it May Concern : I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the U.S. Department of Education ( DOE ) and the Department of Governmental Entities ( DOGE ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security.

I recently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes but is not limited to : 1. My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ).

2. My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including financial aid history and loan information. 

3. My IRS tax transcripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization.

These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information.

Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards.

Aidvantage operates under horrible business practices and should not be allowed to be a federal loan servicer. 

In XX/XX/year> I set up auto pay. On XXXX XX/XX/year>, I received an email from Aidvantage saying that they had approved my request for auto pay. I logged onto today, and found that they did not charge me for XXXX, XXXX, XXXX or XX/XX/year> as I had directed them to do via the autopay agreement. There were XXXX Terms and conditions that I agreed to which would allow them to not charge me for these months. I am an XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX months would have gone toward my federal student loan forgiveness. I can not get that time back, and I did not agree to not be charged during those months. I understand that there is a federal forbearance. Going on right now, however, I am still able to pay on those student loans if I choose to, and I chose to do so when I set up auto pay. I am now out XXXX months of interest, free payments that I thought were being made on my behalf, as I legally agreed to that with Aidvantage via the autopay agreement. I have previously run into shady business practices with them, including overpaying on my student loans XXXX month by several XXXX dollars, and theyre choosing to not put enough toward XXXX of my student loans that missed the minimum that month. I still have XXXX clue how they managed to make that error. I do not think that they are operating legally, and if they are, they are clearly operating unethically. I do not want to work with them anymore as a servicer, and I do not think that the federal government should be working with them if they are choosing to, not follow contracts entered into for auto pay.

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem with your payment plan
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, the Bureau issued an order against XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, to address its unlawful collection activities involving student-loan borrowers who were attempting to bring their student loans out of default. Student loan borrowers who have defaulted on Federal Family Education Loan Program loans have a one-time right to rehabilitate their loans and bring their loans back into good standing by entering into a rehabilitation agreement and making a series of reasonable and affordable payments. If a borrower enters into a loan-rehabilitation agreement within 65 days of defaulting on the loan, the borrower is also not required to pay collection costs associated with the default. From XXXX to XXXX, XXXX used its control over the rehabilitation process to delay borrowers loan rehabilitations so that collection costs would be added to their loans. If borrowers in default called XXXX to rehabilitate their loans within 65 days from default, XXXX agents were instructed to do whatever they could to delay the borrowers rehabilitation until after 65 days had passed, allowing for the imposition of collection costs on the borrowers. Through these practices, XXXX generated fees for itself while causing individual borrowers to incur XXXX  of dollars in additional costs added to their loan obligations. This conduct constituted unfair and abusive acts or practices in violation of the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 and unfair and unconscionable means to collect or attempt to collect debts in violation of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. The order requires XXXX to stop servicing and collecting on any student loan debt and to pay a {$700000.00} civil money penalty. 

According to this summary above, the actions of the student loan agencies have violated my rights from my income driven repayment plan and have reported to the credit agencies that I have missed payments when in fact there were measures taken to cause me to go in default of my student loans. this is an unfair practice.

On XX/XX/XXXX, my application for Defense of Repayment on this loan from XXXX XXXX XXXX based on fraudulent misrepresentation was confirmed approved.

An agent responded with " I'll get back to you with an investigation '' and three months passed and I had not received a follow-up email. The only document that contains information about my payments is the discharge letter, stating that my refund amount is {$5500.00} meanwhile the second page of the letter says I made {$10000.00}. None of the totals add up correctly, and I know I made $ XXXX in payments since XXXX. 

I had made serious life decisions based off that money that is rightfully owed to me and they have done everything they can to withhold what is rightfully mine, short of having to file a lawsuit. This fraudulent activity by NELNET Federal Student Loan Servicer has caused me significant financial injury and I want my payments returned to me. I need this complaint on record for use in court if they continue to assert they don't owe me my student loans.

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem with your payment plan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I submitted an application to MOHELA to change my repayment plan ( attached ) from SAVE to PAYE on XX/XX/XXXX. I sent in a letter as a supplement ( attached ) to expedite processing. I also called MOHELA on XX/XX/XXXX to confirm that my application was received - XXXX ( Worker ID XXXX ) answered and confirmed they received my IDR PAYE Application. 7 months later on XX/XX/XXXX I received a reply from MOHELA denying my application ( attached ) with the reason : " The version of the form you submitted has expired '' as well as " Your signature was missing. '' Both mine and my spouse 's signatures are on the application, and the expiration of the form occurred because MOHELA did not process my application for 7 months. If my application had been processed in XX/XX/XXXX, I should have been on the PAYE plan prior to the SAVE court injunction, which began in XX/XX/XXXX. The months since XX/XX/XXXX should count towards my PSLF payment count, but I am missing 6 months as XXXX have been put in forced forbearance, since I could not get off of the SAVE plan given that my application was not processed on time. Because of the forced forbearance, these months have not been counted and it has pushed back my forgiveness by 6 months. My PSLF count should be at XXXX/XXXX, which would include XXXX  as I should have been moved to the PAYE plan before the injunction if MOHELA had processed my application on time. 

It is crucial that my application from XXXX is processed, as my tax information submitted at that time allows me to qualify for the PAYE plan. Consumer complaint narrative: My student loans have been mishandled by Mohela. Mohela has failed to inform, process, and render decisions for me, particularly pertaining to my enrollment in the Public Service Loan Forgiveness program. Despite Mohela being the designated PSLF servicer for over a year before student loan payments were scheduled to resume ( following the COVID-19 pandemic relief efforts ), Mohela has not provided me accurate payment amounts in a timely fashion, has not responded to my phone or email inquiries in their published timeframe, has provided me CONTRADICTORY information regarding forbearances and payment counts, and is now failing to take accountability citing a lack of support from the Department of Education . Mohelas delays, inaccurate and untimely payment information, and inability to provide me with accurate information surrounding my loans and the PSLF program breach its responsibilities and duties. Inaccurate payment counts towards the required 120 payments for PSLF have been questioned by me ( either via phone or email/online chat ), and requests to be removed from forbearances that I did not consent to have been ignored or delayed such that a loss in ability to make qualifying payments has occurred. After being forced into a SAVE-related forbearance, Mohela was unable to process IDR-plan applications except for the Income-Based Repayment ( standard IBR ) option, leaving borrowers only one option for a payment plan that counted towards PSLF. A borrowers Defense Application was submitted by me to the Federal Student Aid in XXXX XXXX XXXX and as part of that application I requested ( documented in a saved copy of the signed application ) NOT to be placed in a forbearance so that my payments ( even the {$0.00} CARES Act ones ) would continue to count towards PSLF. Despite this, Mohela learned of my Borrowers Defense application ( attached in this complaint as a PDF ) and placed my loans in a forbearance that would NOT count towards PSLF. After calling Mohela to dispute the issues, with signed and dated proof of their error, they did not remove the forbearance in a timely manner and payment ( s ) that should have counted towards my PSLF were deemed not-qualifying. They also did not provide a reason for THEIR error. Currently, my Income-Driven-Repayment Plan renewal has been submitted to Mohela in order to participate in a IDR plan that qualifies for PSLF, and I requested not to be placed in a forbearance, yet I continue to be in one that does not count towards PSLF.

Subject : Data Breach Notification and Request for Resolution Dear US DEPT OF ED I am writing to inform you of a serious concern regarding a recent data breach involving my personal information. It has come to my attention that my sensitive data has been compromised as a result of inadequate security measures on your part.

I am extremely disappointed and concerned about this breach of trust, which has left my personal information vulnerable to misuse. As a consumer, I entrusted your company with my confidential data, and this breach has significantly affected my peace of mind and confidence in your services. 

To address this issue, I request the following actions : 1. An immediate investigation into the breach, including details of how and when it occurred.

2. Written confirmation of the personal information that was compromised.

3. Steps your company is taking to mitigate the impact of this breach and prevent future occurrences.

4. Complimentary credit monitoring services for at least 12 months.

5. A direct point of contact at your company to address any further concerns or questions. 

Please consider this letter a formal complaint and request for resolution. I expect a prompt response within 30 days. 

Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. I look forward to your swift and thorough response. 

Sincerely, XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Immediate Action Needed : Approve Outstanding Borrower Defense Applications To the Departments Overseeing School & Loan Server Compliance, We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXXaffiliated schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding Borrower Defense applications and provide full relief for those impacted. 

Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXX University misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within six months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 

At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly 70,000 students across campuses in 26 states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts. 

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : 1. Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions.

2. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans.

3. Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts.

Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the American Dream, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it. 

We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays. 

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 

Sincerely, Students & Graduates of XXXX XXXX

On XX/XX/2024, MOHELA performed an account rectification and I received a letter with my corrected balances. A copy of this letter will be provided upon request. 

On XX/XX/2024, interest capitalized on my loans. I contacted MOHELA and was informed this was an error. This error was corrected. 

On XX/XX/2024, I received a letter from the XXXX XXXX stating my loans were being placed into a forbearance with 0 % interest and that no interest would accrue during this forbearance. A copy of this letter will be provided upon request. I also received my XXXX billing statement which reflected the correct totals for interest and principal for all loans. Interest continued to accrue so I contacted MOHELA by phone and a representative informed me the problem would be corrected and the incorrectly accrued interest would be backdated. 

On XX/XX/2024, I contacted MOHELA via email because interest was still accruing on my account. I received a response that the problem has been rectified even though interest was still accruing. 

On XX/XX/2024, interest again capitalized on my accounts. I contacted MOHELA and was informed the capitalized interest would be removed and the interest that incorrectly accrued would be backdated and payments would be reapplied. 

On XX/XX/2024, interest capitalized on my accounts again. I contacted MOHELA and the representative was able to correct the capitalized interest to reflect {$0.00}. But I was told the incorrectly accrued interest was still being reviewed and it would take some time to receive a resolution. 

In XXXX, I was placed into the XXXX forbearance with 0 % interest. The XXXX interest issue was still not addressed and interest continued to accrue. On XX/XX/2024, I contacted MOHELA to let them know interest was still accruing and nothing had been done to address the incorrectly accrued interest. I received a response saying my account was in a XXXX forbearance and explaining what the FORBEARANCE was for and why my billing statements would be delayed. 

On XX/XX/2024, interest capitalized on my account and interest was still accruing. I contacted MOHELA by phone and spoke to a representative that informed me they could correct the interest capitalization but my account would need to be corrected by a supervisor to remove the interest that accrued while I was in the 0 % forbearance and to ensure the payments I made during that time were correctly applied to my account. I was told it would take some time for this to be completed as there had been many issues like what I was experiencing. I contacted MOHELA in XXXX and was told by a representative the request had been elevated and to allow more time before calling back. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I contact MOHELA via email because the incorrectly accrued interest was still not addressed. I received a generic response providing information about the XXXX forbearance, but my problem was not rectified. 

On XX/XX/2024, interest capitalized on my account again and interest was still accruing. I called and was transferred to a supervisor named XXXX. XXXX was able to review the billing statements in my account and determine not all of my loans had been placed into the 0 % forbearance which was why interest was still accruing. He was able to set the interest rate to 0 % on all of my loans, but was unable to correct the amounts. He could not explain why interest had capitalized several times in a few months. XXXX put in a request to correct my interest and principal balances to reflect the correct amounts. 

On XX/XX/2024, I contacted MOHELA because the interest and principal balances were still not corrected. 

On XX/XX/2024, I contacted MOHELA because the interest and principal balances were still not corrected. 

On XX/XX/2024, I contacted MOHELA because the interest and principal balances were still not corrected. 

On XX/XX/2024, I contacted MOHELA because the interest and principal balances were still not corrected. 

On XX/XX/2024, I contacted MOHELA because the interest and principal balances were still not corrected. 

On XX/XX/2024, I contacted MOHELA because the interest and principal balances were still not corrected. 

On XX/XX/2024, I contacted MOHELA because the interest and principal balances were still not corrected. I was transferred to the supervisor XXXX again. He was able to locate the problem immediately and determine the correct interest and principal balances. 

On XX/XX/2024, I contacted MOHELA because the interest and principal balances were still not corrected. 

On XX/XX/2024, I contacted MOHELA because the interest and principal balances were still not corrected. 

At this point, I have spoken to several supervisors at MOHELA, including XXXX, and all have informed me that my total interest is {$3000.00}, and the total principal is {$150000.00}. The individual loans are as follows : Loan XXXX : Total interest- {$1400.00}. XXXX Principal- {$22000.00}. Loan XXXX : Total interest- {$1200.00}. XXXX Principal- {$20000.00}. Loan XXXX : Total interest- {$110.00}. XXXX Principal- {$6600.00}. Loan XXXX : Total interest- {$0.00}. XXXX Principal- {$3400.00}. Loan XXXX : Total interest- {$220.00}. XXXX Principal- {$24000.00}. Loan XXXX : Total interest- {$64.00}. XXXX Principal- {$20000.00}. Loan XXXX : Total interest- {$0.00}. XXXX Principal- {$8000.00}. Loan XXXX : Total interest- {$0.00}. XXXX Principal- {$4500.00}. Loan XXXX : Total interest- {$0.00}. XXXX Principal- {$5400.00}. Loan XXXX : Total interest- {$0.00}. XXXX Principal- {$11000.00}. Loan XXXX : Total interest- {$0.00}. XXXX Principal- {$10000.00}. Loan XXXX : Total interest- {$0.00}. XXXX Principal- {$5300.00}. Loan XXXX : Total interest- {$0.00}. XXXX Principal- {$10000.00}. 

This is a substantial difference from what MOHELA is reporting. Additionally, multiple MOHELA supervisors have done an accounting and determined because there are multiple loans, some loans were placed in the XXXX  forbearance while others were not. The supervisors all informed me this has been a reoccurring issue for people with multiple loans. I have been told since I was first placed on the XXXX administrative forbearance with 0 % interest in XXXX and interest continued to accrue, that this issue would be corrected. Then when I was placed into the XXXX forbearance in XXXX and interest continued to accrue, I was told the payments I made would be reapplied to the account and the accrued interest would be removed. Yet somehow I continue to get a generic response from MOHELA that no interest accrued during the XXXX forbearance and my interest is {$4000.00}. Despite speaking to multiple supervisors at MOHELA that have found that interest did accrue, MOHELA continues to respond to complaints stating no interest can accrue during the XXXX forbearance. It seems just because MOHELA states that no interest accrued, no one will do an investigation to see that MOHELA is wrong and not doing it's job properly. It's concerning that when I call and speak to a supervisor, my issue is immediately found, but MOHELA continues to deny the problem. It is even more concerning that the company is mishandling loans and no one will do anything about it. To further complicate the matter, many people just believe MOHELA because they trust MOHELA will properly service their loans. The ramification of this massive accounting error has resulted in incorrect interest, incorrect principal balances which increases the amount of interest i will pay, and incorrect credit reporting. It's pathetic that I reep all of the consequences of MOHELA 's fraudulent behavior and no one can or will help me.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Illegal debt buyer Reliant capital solutions XXXX XXXX # : XXXX Date open : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX status : collection Type of acct : debt buyer Original balance : {$4300.00} NOTICE TO AGENT IS NOTICE TO PRINCIPAL AND NOTICE TO PRINCIPAL IS NOTICE TO AGENT To Whom It May Concern : in response to CFPB # XXXX. Your debt validation has been officially denied. I recently received a copy of my credit report and I noticed some accounts on my consumer report that should not be on there. I demand this account be deleted from my consumer report immediately. The transfer of my nonpublic personal information in your office as stated by Reliant Capital Solution LLC is an act of aggravated identity theft and using the mailing system to collect debt that is not owed to your company is mail fraud and extortion. 

XXXX XXXX. XXXX Simply stated, aggravated identity theft occurs when someone knowingly transfers, possesses, or uses without permission, identification of another person, and then uses that identification during and/or in relation to the act of a particular felony violation. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX- XXXX of extensions of credit by extortionate means ( A ) whoever knowingly participates in any way, or conspires to do so, in the use of any extortionate means. ( 1 ) to collect or attempt to collect any extension of credit, or ( 2 ) to punish any person for the nonpayment thereof, shall be fined under this title or imprisoned not more than 20 years, or both. 

XXXX XXXX. XXXX is a federal law that defines mail fraud. It states that mail fraud occurs when someone uses the XXXX mail to further a criminal act, such as by : Devising a scheme to defraud, Intending to perform fraudulent acts, Mailing something to execute the scheme, and Making false representations. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) - False or misleading representations ( XXXX ) The false representation or implication that accounts have been turned over to innocent purchasers for value. 

I have recently come across information from the XXXX XXXX Rights and Privacy Act of XXXX. This law protects the privacy of student education records from kindergarten through graduate school. XXXX applies to all schools that receive funds through an applicable program of the XXXX Department of Education, and thus most postsecondary schools are covered by XXXX. 

The XXXX XXXX Rights and Privacy Act of XXXX ( XXXX ) protects the privacy of students by limiting third party access to student education records. When a student reaches the age of XXXX or begins attending a postsecondary institution, regardless of age, XXXX rights transfer from the parent to the student. Students have a right to know about the purpose, content, and location of information kept as a part of their educational records. They also have a right to expect that information in their educational records will be kept confidential. 

Accordingly, XXXX gives students the following rights regarding their education records. The right to access education records kept by the school, The right to amend education records, The right to request that education records be disclosed only with student consent ( this means that the student " owns '' the XXXX record in that no one at the University may access or discuss the content of the file with parents, guardians, or third-party providers WITHOUT THE XXXX WRITTEN CONSENT of the student ) and The right to file complaints for unauthorized disclosure of education records. The right to request education records be disclosed only with student consent. The right to consent to disclosures of personally identifiable information contained in the student 's education records, except to the extent that XXXX authorizes disclosure without consent. One exception, which permits disclosure without consent, is disclosure to school officials with legitimate educational interests.

Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
Hello, I am writing to express my urgent concern about the detrimental effects of the SAVE Plan on borrowers like me, specifically the inability to opt out and resume repayment under another Income-Driven Repayment ( IDR ) plan. As someone actively working toward Public Service Loan Forgiveness ( PSLF ), this policy is creating unnecessary financial strain and disrupting my repayment strategy. 

The current situation under the SAVE Plan has placed my loans in administrative forbearance, preventing me from resuming payments under a different IDR plan. According to MOHELA, my only option for exiting the SAVE Plan is to choose a full-term non-IDR repayment plan, which is entirely incompatible with my financial circumstances and PSLF eligibility . This lack of an exit strategy from SAVE, other than committing to an unaffordable plan, is not only unfair but also deeply harmful to millions of borrowers. 

The administrative forbearance and restrictive policies of SAVE are undermining the very purpose of IDR plansto provide flexible and affordable repayment options based on a borrower 's income. By denying borrowers the ability to switch plans, the administration is forcing us into financial uncertainty and jeopardizing access to critical programs like PSLF. 

I respectfully urge you to advocate for immediate policy changes, including : - Allowing borrowers to exit the SAVE Plan and transition to other IDR plans without barriers. 
- Ensuring clear communication and transparency about repayment options for borrowers affected by SAVE. 
- Protecting PSLF-eligible borrowers from policies that disrupt their repayment strategies and harm their financial stability. 

Borrowers should have the autonomy to choose repayment plans that align with their needs and goals. The inability to leave the SAVE Plan for a suitable IDR option is causing unnecessary harm and demands immediate attention. 

Thank you for your leadership and your commitment to addressing these pressing concerns. I look forward to seeing action on behalf of borrowers like me who are seeking fair and equitable treatment in managing our student loans. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

I have contacted Federal Student Aid ( " FSA '' ) on several occasions, including reconsideration requests and complaints, informing them that my federal students loans were placed by my servicer in a mandatory administrative processing forbearance for XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXX for the purpose of recalculating my payments on an XXXX plan. Every instance I contacted FSA, I was met with long wait times and/or individuals who could provide no substantive guidance on the process of my reconsideration requests. Some of my requests have been open since XXXX, and would have been made even earlier but for FSA 's delay in updating my qualifying payment counts leading my to have to wait for them to post completed counts before I could take any action. 

Attached, I have included documentation demonstrating that my loan servicer, XXXX, placed me in a recalculation processing forbearance ahead of the months of XXXX and XX/XX/2024. As per FSA 's own guidance, if a student loan servicer needs additional time to recalculate payments on an XXXX plan and your account is placed in a processing forbearance, up to 60 days of processing forbearance time is eligible for XXXX credit. ( See https : //studentaid.gov/announcements-events/save-court-actions ; see https : XXXX ). Furthermore, federal regulation dictates that time spent in a mandatory administrative forbearance pursuant to 34 CFR Section 685.205 ( b ) ( ( 9 ) ( when time is needed to collect and process documentation supporting a forbearance request - in this instance the recalculation processing forbearance ) qualifies for XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( " XXXX '' ). 34 CFR Section 685.219 ( c ) ( 2 ) ( v ) ( H ). 

FSA has to date failed to credit me with qualifying months for XXXX XXXX and/or XXXX XXXX, despite the fact that I have provided an Employment Certification Form evidencing qualifying employment and separate documentation showing that I was placed in a processing forbearance that qualifies for XXXX pursuant to FSA 's own guidance. I am at XXXX qualifying months, so if either XXXX XXXX or XXXX XXXX become eligible - as they should already be- I would be eligible for loan discharge pursuant to XXXX. FSA 's lack of responsiveness and failure to respond to or take action on my reconsideration requests have prevented me from receiving the XXXX loan discharge that I should have been entitled to in XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute the legitimacy of my student loan obligations transferred from Nelnet to XXXX. Due to serious legal violations and breaches of federal privacy laws, including the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ), the Privacy Act of 1974, and the Higher Education Act, I demand the immediate cancellation of all financial obligations related to these debts.

It has come to my attention that my personal educational and financial information has been improperly accessed by unauthorized third parties, including XXXX XXXX or affiliated entities. This unauthorized access constitutes a gross violation of my federal privacy rights and nullifies any enforceable loan agreements under federal law.

Legal Grounds for Discharge : 1. FERPA Violation : The exposure of my educational records without my express written consent is a direct breach of FERPA, which mandates the protection of personally identifiable information.

2. Violation of the Privacy Act of 1974 : The mishandling and unauthorized disclosure of my personal information contravenes federal requirements that safeguard the privacy of individuals data managed by federal agencies and contractors.

3. Breach of the Higher Education Act : The Higher Education Act requires servicers to maintain strict confidentiality and compliance in loan transfers. The transfer of my loan to Aidvantage and subsequent data breaches demonstrate clear negligence.

4. Breach of Contract and Data Security Obligations : By failing to protect my sensitive information, both Nelnet and XXXX have breached contractual terms and obligations, rendering these debts unenforceable.

Consumer complaint narrative: I am filing this complaint against Nelnet for potential violations of the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) due to their failure to provide accurate and transparent disclosures about the terms of my student loans. Under TILA, borrowers are entitled to clear information about loan terms, including interest rates, fees, and repayment schedules. However, I have experienced the following issues : Misrepresentation of Loan Terms : Nelnet has provided unclear and inconsistent information about my interest rate and how my loan balance grows during periods of nonpayment. Failure to Disclose Accrued Interest : Nelnet did not adequately explain how forbearance and interest capitalization significantly increase my loan balance, making it impossible to understand the financial impact fully. Lack of Transparency : Nelnet has not provided a clear breakdown of how my balance has grown since origination, leaving me unable to reconcile their statements with the original loan terms. These issues violate TILAs transparency requirements, causing financial harm and unnecessary stress by inflating my balance without clear justification. Requested

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Immediate Action Needed : Approve Outstanding Borrower Defense Applications To the Departments Overseeing School & Loan Server Compliance, We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXX schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding Borrower Defense applications and provide full relief for those impacted.

Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : * XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX The Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXX XXXX  misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within XXXX months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 

At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in XXXX states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts.

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : 1. Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions.

2. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans. 
XXXX. Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts. 

Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the XXXX XXXX, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it. 

We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays. 

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 

Sincerely, Students & Graduates of XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative: XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( Owned by XXXX ) was advertised as having graduates with {$250000.00} of student debt, which was about double the " in state '' school tuition. They used high pressure recruiting and admissions tactics, making you put an immediate non-refundable deposit to hold your seat if accepted. There was little to no actual information provided on how to navigate student loans other than how to apply to take them out. There was also little information given on how to plan to pay off the loans. Our budgeting exercises in class focused only on income based repayment amounts, which never touch the loan principal. They used XXXX XXXXXXXX as our " educators '' for student loan repayment. XXXX XXXX  offices were raided by the FBI, and its CEO and principal owner was arrested and charged with multiple counts of criminal fraud, identity theft, and obstruction of justice. All they taught us was to take out our loans, do income based repayments, and told us after 20 years of payments our loans would be forgiven. There was no mention of tax XXXX, or the forgiven amount being counted as taxable income the year it was forgiven. Most of us will never be free of these loans. We will have paid 20 years of payments, then owe the IRS MORE THAN WE BORROWED for taxes once loans are forgiven
