Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom it May Concern, I am formally disputing the legitimacy of my student loan obligations with Advantage due to serious legal violations and breaches of federal privacy laws, including the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ), the Privacy Act of 1974, and the Higher Education Act ( HEA ). Based on these violations, I demand the immediate cancellation of all financial obligations related to these debts.

Legal Violations Supporting My Demand for Cancellation 1. FERPA Violations : My personal and financial information may have been disclosed without my consent to unauthorized third parties, violating my privacy rights.

Inaccurate or misleading loan records may have been maintained, and I was not given proper access to review and correct them.

2. Privacy Act of 1974 Violations : If my loan records were mishandled by the Department of Education or Advantage, it constitutes a violation of federal data protection laws.

If my Social Security Number or other personal information was shared without my authorization, my rights under the Privacy Act were infringed.

3. Higher Education Act Violations : If I was misled about loan terms, repayment obligations, or forgiveness options, it constitutes a violation under HEA.

If my school improperly certified my eligibility for loans or engaged in fraudulent practices, I should not be held responsible for this debt.

Additionally, it has come to my attention that my personal educational and financial information has been improperly accessed by unauthorized third parties, including Elon Musk or affiliated entities. This unauthorized access constitutes a gross violation of my federal privacy rights and nullifies any enforceable loan agreement under federal law.

Demands for Resolution Immediate and unconditional cancellation of all financial obligations associated with my student loans.

Complete removal of all Advantage-related entries from my credit report.

Written confirmation of this cancellation and credit correction within 30 days of receipt of this letter.

Failure to comply with this request will result in formal complaints being filed with the U.S. Department of Education, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ). I expect a written response within the stipulated time frame and immediate corrective action regarding these violations.

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Can't temporarily delay making payments
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have been enrolled in the Income-Based Repayment plan for many years. I need to re-apply annually to continue being enrolled in this program. After I re-enrolled in XX/XX/XXXX for the XXXX calendar year, it takes nearly a month to learn what your new payment amount will be. And after you receive the notice with information about your new payment, you are provided with less than 30 days notice of the new payment amount, which isnt a lot of time to be able to process and figure out how to absorb the higher payment, if indeed your payment amount will increase, as mine did by nearly XXXX the previous payment amount. 
Immediately after receiving notice of my pending new payment amount for XXXX, I immediately reached out to an ombudsman since I believed this amount to be incorrect. I also stated my position that I could not afford this new payment, since I was barely able to afford the 2024 monthly payment amount. 
I asked if mortgage or rents were taken into consideration, since currently, most consumers ( me included ) are paying 2 to 4 times more in rent or mortgage than we were paying prior to XXXX and XXXX. I was very rudely informed that this information wasnt considered and basically, didnt matter to the federal government. 
I currently rent, since I am priced out of the market as a single person trying to buy a home with the equally unaffordable current mortgage interest rates. And as such, I am at the mercy of whatever market rates are for apartments. Rents are outrageous since there are a lot of people in similar financial dire straights of being kept out of homeownership by housing prices and mortgage rates, therefore due to increased demand for rental properties, monthly rents have increased 2 and 3-fold. This information absolutely should be taking into consideration. Should someone be homeless just to be able to pay their student loan payment? Because currently that is the choice I am facing.either pay my rent OR pay my student loan payments, income-based as they may be. I can not afford both. I actually can not even currently afford food, I only eat because of my local food pantry. 
After I reached out to Mohela for assistance with my payment and to immediately inform them that I could not pay the increased amount for XXXX, and also to complain that 30 days is just not enough time to increase someones payment by nearly 3x the amount, it took well over a week to investigate and receive a response. This used up a lot of valuable time in my 30-day window notification of my pending payment increase. I find this response time completely unacceptable. 
The bottom line is I was told to use the online portal to seek an alternate payment plan or request for temporary postponement of payments. 
After utilizing the portal and applying for a temporary forbearance, I was denied a forbearance and given a reason of having used up my allotment of forbearance time ( due to being seriously ill for many years, nearly unable to work ), so I attempted to apply for economic hardship deferment. It seems the economic hardship deferment criteria has now changed and you need to be receiving public assistance or not working to qualify for economic hardship deferment. 
Which leaves me with trying to find another payment plan. 
I had also repeatedly DIRECTLY asked the Mohela service rep for other repayment options to lower my payment amount, and I shared with this person that I was aware that if I opted out of the current payment plan I was in, it would automatically revert my payments back to full payments, which I would be required to make at least one month of payments before I could apply for a different payment plan. However, this would only exacerbate the problem, since if I could not afford the reduced payment under the income-based payment plan, how was I supposed to afford a full payment for even one month? This is the horrible loop they put you in, with no way out, no empathy or XXXXXXXX XXXX  to the problem of not being able to afford the payment. 
In addition, now my car has serious mechanical issues, and I will need to find some money somewhere to fix it or I will also be out of a job. I drive a nearly XXXX old car, and I only have food because I visit the food pantry. 
There needs to be BETTER SOLUTIONS to real financial issues people are facing. This is not a joke to me and I am not trying to get out of paying. I have been repeatedly asking for help, and proactively BEFORE my next ( increased ) monthly payment, because I desperately do not want to default on my loans. 
I am being treated harshly and being railroaded at every turn. There have to be WORKABLE solutions for people who are struggling to pay and who are asking for help and needing options that fit their circumstances. 
There needs to be more forbearance and deferment time, especially for people like me who had extended health challenges that I didnt ask for. 
This entire system is broken and rigged against the borrowers.there needs to be at least XXXX to 90 days notice of payment increases on your loan, so people struggling to keep a roof over their head and food on their table can figure out where the money will come from. 
You should also be able to refinance student loan interest, just like you can refinance your mortgage interest. Without losing all your time in repayment. Why isnt this an option to help borrowers pay off their loans???

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative:
All of the below issues occurred with the same loan service provider, Mohela. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, due to a personal miscommunication, both my spouse and I made a pay in full payment to the provider to pay off my student loans, in the amount of {$9300.00} ( due to the duplicative payment, the initial total submitted was {$18000.00} ). When we realized the error ( our bank flagged what would have been an overdraft ), I contact the provider to ask them to stop the payment on XX/XX/XXXX. I was informed that the payments were already processing on their end, so the only solution was to contact my bank and stop the payment, which I then did. Because it was a duplicative payment to the same vendor, the stopping of one would trigger ( according to the bank ) the stopping of both. I said ok and asked them to stop the payment. 

Here begins the source of the issue and the complaint. 

I waited for a few business days to allow the provider 's system to process the payment, the cancellation, and update my account so I could make payments. I then called on XX/XX/XXXX to ask for an update on when the status would clear. I was told to wait until the account was reconciled, as that could take XXXX business days. I then called back on XX/XX/XXXX for an update, at which point I was given the same general advice. 

At this point, rather than showing that the account had not been paid, it was appearing on my account that I had not only not paid the amount, but I had overpaid by double the amount. I proceeded to tell them that, despite their records, they had not received their money at all ( I could verify that it had never left my bank account ). I was told they put a note in my account and would flag it for review. I waited for another billing cycle to move through in case it needed time to get to accounting when they reconciled their books. Over this time, nothing in my account changed. Each time I had communicated with a representative, they assured that I was not being charged, nor would I be charged, interest. 

I called back on XX/XX/XXXX and finally was able to speak to a supervisor that pushed the review through to accounting. She told me to give it XXXX business days and I would be contacted by accounting once the issue was resolved. I was never contacted by accounting. 

I then logged into my account on XX/XX/XXXX to see that my account had been reversed and I now owed {$18000.00} and they were processing a refund for the amount they had originally thought I overpaid. The refund for {$9300.00} posted to my account on XX/XX/XXXX, and I have not yet received this refund check ( as of today, XX/XX/XXXX ). I called and asked them to stop the payment on the refund check, and clear my account back to the original amount owed to I could pay it off. 

Additionally, when they reconciled the account to reverse the payment they had posted but not received, they back-dated the posting to XX/XX/XXXX, and then added the interest that would have accrued on an $ XXXX loan over the months of XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX ( which I had been assured would not happen each time I called ). 

The account is still accruing interest. 

I have since called on the following dates : XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX Each call involved XXXX hours of wait time to reach a supervisor ( often a XXXX hour wait to reach an initial rep who then connects me with someone from the resolutions team, requiring an additional wait. Previous calls have had a callback option, preventing extended holds, but they have since removed the callback option and required a live hold. I have been on hold today ( XX/XX/XXXX ) for XXXX hours with still not contact from a representative. 

The latest activity on my account, communicated with a resolutions representative on XX/XX/XXXX was that I would pay my initial balance ( {$9300.00} ) and they were to put an inquiry through to the accounting department to remove the accrued interest since the start of this event, and stop payment of the refund check. This would result in my account being cleared to zero balance and the end of the issue. I was also told I would receive communication from the accounting department when this was resolved. 

I have since paid my portion, and the payment posted on XX/XX/XXXX. I was informed on my check in call on XX/XX/XXXX to give the department XXXX business days to resolve the inquiry. It has been XXXX business days, I have not received any updates, and my account still includes a balance for the refund they sent ( which I still have not received and have asked them to stop payment on multiple times ) and accrued interest. I am currently on hold ( XX/XX/XXXX at XXXX, current hold time XXXX XXXX minutes ) to inquire about a final resolution. For obvious reasons, I am not confident of the services ability to reconcile this issue. 

I have spent XXXX hours on hold or in communication with Mohela XXXX am continuing to be charged, and have not resolved this issue, which occurred from an error on their end of posting payment they never received. ( It actually took several phone calls an disbelieving representatives for me to even make them believe I had not sent the money ). 

See attached screen shots for dates and times of calls to Mohela at XXXX ( incoming calls represent a callback from their automatic hold system ). 

Please help.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Formal Dispute of Inaccurate Credit Reporting under FCRA and Consumer Law To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate information on my credit report. This dispute is submitted under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681i, which requires credit reporting agencies to conduct a reasonable reinvestigation of disputed items. 
Recent findings by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) have brought to light significant concerns regarding XXXXXXXX XXXX  failure to conduct proper investigations. 
Specifically, in a lawsuit filed against XXXX, the CFPB alleges that the company engaged in sham investigations, violating consumer protection laws by failing to meet its obligations under the FCRA. 
As per 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ), XXXX is required to conduct a thorough and reasonable reinvestigation of disputed items within 30 days. Furthermore, under 15 U.S.C.

1681 ( a ) ( 5 ), any information found to be inaccurate, incomplete, or unverifiable must be promptly deleted or corrected. Failure to adhere to these requirements constitutes a violation of federal law. My personal and financial information was compromised without my authorization. FERPA protects the confidentiality of student records. The breach violates the contract and renders it null and void. 

I hereby request that XXXX : Conduct a thorough reinvestigation of the following disputed accounts or items from [ EDFINANCIAL SERVICES ]. 
Provide me with all documentation used to verify the accuracy of the disputed information. 
Correct or delete any information that can not be verified or is inaccurate, as mandated by law. 
Given the recent CFPB findings, I expect XXXX to handle this dispute with the utmost seriousness and compliance with legal standards. A copy of my identification and any relevant supporting documents can be provided to facilitate your investigation. 
If XXXX fails to comply with its obligations under the FCRA, I will not hesitate to escalate this matter to the CFPB and pursue any necessary legal action to protect my rights. 
Please respond to this dispute in writing within the legally mandated timeframe. I expect written confirmation of any changes made to my credit file.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, OR, XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX Consumer Financial Protection Bureau XXXX XXXX XXXX, IA XXXX Subject : Complaint Against MOHELA for Failure to Process Forbearance Directive From DoE To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally lodge a complaint against MOHELA regarding their failure to process the student loan forbearance on my account as directed by the Department of Education ( DoE ) in a timely manner, resulting in my account being placed in delinquency. Despite my proactive efforts, including multiple hours-long phone calls with MOHELA customer service representatives, to ensure my loans were placed in a 0 % interest forbearance as directed by the DoEand as confirmed in two letters from MOHELA dated XX/XX/XXXX, and XX/XX/XXXX, XXXXMOHELAs negligence has caused undue stress and potential financial harm. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I applied for federal direct loan consolidation through Studentaid.gov to enroll in the new XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) Plan and benefit from the One-Time Payment Count Adjustment, as encouraged by the XXXX Administration. As a XXXX XXXX I indicated my eligibility for the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX  ) Program and applied for the XXXX XXXX plan. My loans were consolidated and assigned to MOHELA for servicing on XX/XX/XXXX. However, due to a federal court injunction preventing the implementation of XXXX  while my application was processing, MOHELA was unable to process my XXXX XXXX request and instead placed me on a standard repayment plan, which I did not request and which does not qualify for XXXX. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I contacted MOHELA for an update on my XXXX application and to explore repayment options, as the standard repayment plan was unaffordable and did not qualify for XXXX. MOHELA placed me on a XXXX processing forbearance while awaiting updates on the XXXX litigation. I called again on XX/XX/XXXX, to extend the processing forbearance for another 60 days, as there had been no progress on my XXXX XXXX request. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I received a letter from MOHELA assuring me that my student loans were placed in forbearance at 0 % interest due to either ( 1 ) the federal court injunction affecting the XXXX plan and other XXXX plans, or ( XXXX ) their failure to process my IDR application within the required 60-day timeframe. However, despite this confirmation, MOHELA failed to implement the forbearance properly, causing my account to become delinquent in XXXX. 

I contacted MOHELA at least XXXX separate times, spending hours on hold to speak with a representative, only to be transferred to an " advanced team, '' in an effort to have my account updated in accordance with the letters I had received. Despite repeated assurances from multiple customer service representatives, MOHELA failed to process my request, and my account remains marked as delinquent. 

I have made every reasonable effort to resolve this issue directly with MOHELA, yet they have been unresponsive and unwilling to take appropriate action to correct their mistake, adhere to DoE guidance, and process my forbearance request. Their failure to act is unacceptable and has caused unnecessary financial and emotional distress while also putting me at risk of defaulting on my loans. 

I request that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau investigate this matter and hold MOHELA accountable for its negligence. Furthermore, I urge MOHELA to retroactively apply the 0 % interest forbearance, backdated to no later than XX/XX/XXXX, as originally intended, and correct any negative impact this delinquency has had on my loan balance, credit report, or loan status, including the removal of any accrued interest. 

Thank you for your time and attention to this serious matter. Please let me know if any further documentation is required. I appreciate your prompt assistance in resolving this issue. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX MOHELA Account # XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
Immediate Action Needed : Approve Outstanding Borrower Defense Applications To the Departments Overseeing School & Loan Server Compliance, We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXX schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding Borrower Defense applications and provide full relief for those impacted. 

Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : * XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX The Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXXXXXX XXXX misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within six months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 

At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in XXXX states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts.

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : 1. Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions.

2. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans.

3. Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts. 

Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the XXXX XXXX, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it. 

We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays. 

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 

Sincerely, Students & Graduates of XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I attended XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX from XXXX to XXXX for their masters, then doctoral graduate programs. When I initially enrolled, it was XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX, it was focused on small class size, applicable clinical skills and focusing on the student. It was a hard program to get into then. The program was very high regarded in our community as an institution to train clinical psychologists as stellar treatment providers. 

The year after I began, XXXX took over. The class sizes grew massively each year. The teachers were exhausted and overwhelmed. The program was disorganized as they became a mill for graduate students. I recall my professors being concerned about the class sizes and that students were not capable of graduate work. They had to institute a writing program for over 50 % of students as many were writing at a high school level. It was terrible. I decided to stay because I was already so far into my program and I did not want to have to start over. I tutored the writing program and continued to be one of the top students of my class. 

In my XXXX year, we had to take comprehensive exams. I took my exams and it took about XXXX weeks for the results. When my results came, it said that I had failed my exam. I was devastated. It was also time to apply for internships so I had to wait until my peers applications went out before my advisor had time to review my exam with me. I will never forget when she handed me my exam and I was so confused. In order to not show bias, we were expected to give our exams with only our social security number- not our names. The exam that was handed to me was not my social security number nor my exam. They had mixed them up. 

I learned that I had actually passed my exams and did not need to retake them. However, it was too late for internship and I had to wait another year. I was devastated. My parents wanted to sue the school. I refused because I was desperate for my degree. The school agreed that I could do an advanced practicum at no cost for the year, while I waited to apply to internship. 

I decided to move to FL to do my internship because my classes were all complete and all I had was this practicum, internship, and my dissertation left. I found my own practicum in XXXX XXXX. Then I started getting bills for tuition. I reminded them of what they said and they claimed that they could not fix it because the system would not allow them override tuition so I had to pay it to stay in the program. Another year of tuition. 

The following year came and I applied for internships. I was focused on XXXX XXXX  because my grades were good and I had another year of training. I applied to several child neuropsychology programs that were competitive. I practiced interviews and worked hard to be able to prove myself worthy of their programs. Then the rejection letters arrived. Turned out the internship advisor, XXXX XXXX XXXX, had accidentally checked that I was on academic probation and I was not. She wrote letters to correct her errors, but it was too late. I was left with waiting yet another year or finding an XXXX XXXX. I went with the XXXX  because I just wanted to graduate. 

Post graduation, I had been told my dissertation was approved. I decided not to return to campus for the graduation ceremony because I was too disenchanted with the program. I went right into my post-doc program. I was about 2 months in and my diploma still had not arrived. I called my school and was told that I had to finish edits for the librarian on my dissertation and they would not send me my degree until she approved it. I was also told that if I didnt get it done, I needed to pay another semester of tuition. I literally made the edits the day she sent them to me. I had to stop my post-doc program until I got my degree. It took another 2 months. 

I share this with you because I worked while in grad school to keep my loans at a minimum. However, due to XXXX mistakes, I had XXXX extra years of tuition. Additionally, with having attended an XXXX  XXXX, there are many jobs for which I am not qualified because they require an XXXX XXXX- particularly federal jobs. 

Currently, I have been paying 15 years on my student loans, with little reduction. I can not work for a place that would offer loan forgiveness because I did not have an XXXX internship. 100 % of my student loans are from XXXX XXXX. The current balance is {$130000.00} in the form of XXXX federal loans. The original amounts were {$50000.00} & {$98000.00}, totaling {$140000.00}. My current loan payment is about 13 % of my income. 

It would be such a gift and relief to have my loans forgiven. It would help with the healing from the trauma of a subpar program for which I am still indebted even though they were able to file bankruptcy and start again. 

I work hard, often over XXXX hours a week. I am fortunate to have obtained my degree and licensure. However, I am still left with considerable debt for a program that failed me along with so many others. If you are able to push through and allow XXXX students loan forgiveness as the government has done for other defunct programs, it would definitely help XXXX of students who were taken advantage of. 
On XX/XX/XXXX the XXXX University borrowers sent the Department of Education XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXX Defrauded a Generation of Students and the Federal Government that detailed copious evidence collected by XXXX borrowers themselves. The evidence comes from lawsuits, settlements, congressional testimony, and federal investigations. Furthermore, our letter to the Secretary of Education cosigned by nine organizations including the XXXX XXXX XXXX, Project on Predatory Lending, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, Debt Collective, and XXXX XXXX students, faculty and staff collectively recommends the broad cancellation of all XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX 
I am filing a complaint for the Department of Education to take notice that the borrowers deserve to be made whole from a governmental system of oversight that has failed them.

Consumer complaint narrative: My loans were transitioned to Mohela last Spring. I made a XXXX payment. This is documented in my payment history. Within 1-2 weeks, the Mohela site said my payment was late. I called and spent an hour on the phone. The Mohela rep confirmed that my XXXX payment was processed. She said from her end she did not see any missed or late payments and assured me it was a website glitch. Further, she told me the SAVE injunction was about to go into effect, and I would be placed in a forbearance so the next months payment would not even be due. Which is exactly what happened. So THERE ARE NO MISSED PAYMENTS. Still, it has continued to show a late/missing payment. I spent 2.5hrs on the phone with Mohela just this week. Neither of the two reps I spoke to could see a late payment. I called Federal Student Aid today because I have done what I need to do to achieve forgiveness. Surprise! FSA says the problem is Mohela showing a late payment. I now have FOUR days before the administration changes and further litigation and red tape is likely. Because of these things, which are beyond my control, I am now missing out on forgiveness. I dont deserve this. Mohela is completely incompetent and impossible to deal with. Currently awaiting a 2 hr hold time for what? To be again given constant conflicting or inaccurate information?? SOMEONE PLEASE HELP. WHAT IS THE POINT OF CFPB WHEN THERE IS ZERO OVERSIGHT AND NO ONE CARES???!!!! MOHELA- How do you guys sleep at night??? The way you have disregarded your consumers is so awful. Is this how youd want your kids or family to be treated? Does it make you happy that you are royally XXXX  people like me out of everything they have worked hard to achieve? This is a big deal. This is my life and my future. Its my kids future. We dont deserve this!

Consumer complaint narrative:
Statement of Events : I began my student loan journey in XXXX when I XXXX  enrolled in school. Over the years, I encountered periods of deferment during which I was not required to make payments. While these deferment periods do not count toward qualifying payments for the federal student loan forgiveness program, I have identified that payments made between XXXX and XXXX are missing from my payment history. Given the persistent misinformation from Nelnet, I have concerns that other qualifying payments may also be absent from the records. 

Throughout the life of my loans, they were serviced by several loan servicers, including Great Lakes. As of XX/XX/XXXX, my loans were transferred to Nelnet. Between XX/XX/XXXX and XXXX, XXXX, I contacted Nelnet multiple times to inquire about the process of consolidating my loans. I was advised by a Nelnet representative that consolidation was the only method to qualify for the federal student loan forgiveness program. Subsequently, on XX/XX/XXXX, I requested my payment count to date, but I was informed that this information could not be provided until after the consolidation was completed. 

Following the guidance provided by Nelnet, I submitted my consolidation application, which was approved, and I was placed on the XXXX plan on XX/XX/XXXX. 

After completing the consolidation, I was alerted to a significant drop in my credit scoreover XXXX points. I was never informed by Nelnet that consolidating my loans would negatively affect my credit, particularly because this loan was my longest-standing account. This dramatic decline in my credit score has adversely impacted my ability to secure housing, obtain an auto loan, rent a home, and may potentially affect my ability to secure employment, as many employers conduct credit checks. This decision was based on erroneous advice from Nelnet, which has had a profound negative impact on my financial standing and future opportunities. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I received an email from Nelnet containing my payment history. However, the document was filled with unreadable and nonsensical information. I contacted Nelnet again, and on XX/XX/XXXX, the consolidation was completed. Once again, I received a document containing incomprehensible data. I was subsequently informed by a Nelnet representative that previous representatives had provided inaccurate information and that the consolidation needed to be completed before XX/XX/XXXX. Despite my repeated requests, I was still unable to obtain an accurate payment count. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, another Nelnet representative informed me that my payment count would be sent to me via mail, which would take XXXX months. In the summer of XXXX, I received a letter from Nelnet ; however, it only contained loan amounts and did not include the requested payment history. Upon contacting Nelnet again, I was told that the prior information provided was incorrect and that I would have to wait until the end of the year for the one-time payment adjustment to be processed. 

By XX/XX/XXXX, I had still received no satisfactory resolution, prompting me to file a formal complaint with the Department of Education. In response, Nelnet stated that " the consolidation resulted in paying off your original loan balance '' and that consolidation was recommended to expedite eligibility for the one-time account adjustment. However, this adjustment failed to reflect payments made from XXXX to XXXX, as well as potentially other periods of qualifying payments. As a result, my payment count was not properly adjusted. 

In XX/XX/XXXX, Nelnet responded again, inaccurately stating that I was concerned because my previous loans were listed as " paid in full. '' This statement is incorrect, as I never made such a claim. It was Nelnet that informed me that my loans were paid in full. Furthermore, I never stated that my payment count was incorrect ; I simply requested an accurate payment count, which I had yet to receive. 

After over a year of waiting, Nelnet has provided a payment count, but it still contains inaccuracies. It shows that I owe XXXX additional payments, extending my repayment period until XX/XX/XXXX. While the months I was enrolled in school in XXXX are not eligible, they should still be listed, as my current in-school deferment is clearly labeled as ineligible. The count also fails to account for months from XXXX to XXXX when I was neither in school nor in an in-school deferment due to a family medical emergency. These months should have been counted as qualifying payments, yet Nelnet does not show them at all, even though the Department of Education records show that I had a loan during this period. Unlike my current in-school deferment, which is clearly marked as ineligible, these missing months should have been listed with the same level of detail, indicating whether they are eligible or ineligible. I understand that my loan servicer has changed several times over the past XXXX  years, but I have already made enough qualifying payments for loan forgiveness, and this issue needs to be rectified as soon as possible to accurately reflect my eligibility. 

To summarize, I have spent countless hours trying to get resolution however, Nelnet 's failure to provide accurate information regarding loan consolidation, combined with incomplete and incorrect payment records, has caused significant financial hardship and emotional distress. My credit score has dropped dramatically, and I was misinformed about the necessity of consolidation. Consequently, my loans have not been processed properly for forgiveness. I believe that the missing payments from XXXX to XXXX, as well as other potentially qualifying months, should be properly accounted for in the one-time payment adjustment. I should also have been fully informed of the impact of consolidation on my credit. 

As a result of Nelnets actions, my credit score has been severely impacted, placing me in a poor credit category, which affects my ability to purchase a vehicle, secure housing, or rent a home. Additionally, should I be applying for employment that involves a credit check, my chances of securing the job could be adversely affected. I respectfully request that Nelnet take immediate action to rectify these issues, provide an accurate payment count, and process my loan forgiveness in accordance with the guidelines of the federal student loan forgiveness program.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX : My concern with my loan provider ( XXXX ) at the time was that they continued to break apart and sell my loans causing me to have multiple student loan bills which forced me to either have missed payments ( marked on my credit ) due to multiple payments required and or have to continue to periodically call to consolidate the loans which changed the terms of the loan. 

XXXX : I found out that I qualified as a teacher working 5 years in my district for teacher loan forgiveness. I contacted my loan provider at the time, XXXX to inquire and the representative told me no such program existed and didn't know what I was referring to. This was baffling because I was able to locate, via online search, loan forgiveness paperwork but I did not know where or how to best submit it given the representative 's response. 

XX/XX/XXXX : I attempted calling again and was told that I could be enrolled in a " program '' that would allow me to take advantage of teacher loan forgiveness. I asked if that would go into effect as of XXXX ( or after completing the XXXX school year ) since at that time I would have taught for 10 years. I was told " no '' and that it would be 10 years from the date I signed up for the program, seeing no other options in taking advantage of the teacher loan forgiveness initiative, I signed up for the program, and my loans moved from XXXX to Mohela. The Mohela customer service is difficult to reach in that I have on numerous occasions called and either sat on hold waiting for a representative anywhere from XXXX hours, I have tried using the option to " save my spot '' and have someone call back and never received a return call ( on XXXX different occasions ). They have changed their website so I am no longer able to access and manage my information and have moved their platform to the studentaid.gov website. 

XXXX : I completed and had my most recent degree conferred in XX/XX/XXXX, according to my understanding - loans are not to go back into repayment until XXXX after completion of the degree program or 6 months after I discontinue if I choose to pause my program. This would mean that I would not go into repayment until XX/XX/XXXX. I received postal mail in XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX of XXXX telling me that I have a bill due or past due. I called twice during that time to let them know that this was inaccurate. On the first call, the representative told me that I would have to be in repayment despite what I said to them about the 6 months rule and told me the best they could do was put me on deferment until XX/XX/XXXX and I could call back again if I needed to. I called back again closer to that time and spoke with a different representative and they understood and agreed with my statements about the 6 months. At that time, they stated that repayment would not begin until XX/XX/XXXX. I asked about the past due notices and I was told that they would go away and would not be reflected on my credit ( and or removed if already there ). 

XX/XX/XXXX : I received XXXX envelopes each from Mohela regarding my loan, the first I opened just stated that I was past due on my payments, the second stated I was past due in an amount of over {$700.00}, and the third I opened stated I was past due in an amount of over {$400.00}. The fourth envelope had notice that my new monthly payment is {$250.00} beginning on XX/XX/XXXX. The prior XXXX envelopes opened also had a due date of XX/XX/XXXX. I inspected each set of documents and all listed the same account number ending in XXXX. Again, all XXXX of the envelopes regarding payment were sent at the same time. I called today, XX/XX/XXXX to speak with someone, and the automated service stated I had both an upcoming balance for XX/XX/XXXX of {$250.00} and a past due balance giving a total due on XX/XX/XXXX of XXXX. Currently, as I type, I have been on hold to talk to someone about this for XXXX out of the XXXX minutes that were stated as my " wait time ''.

Consumer complaint narrative:
In XX/XX/year> ( CFPB ID : XXXX ) I asked why my SAVE application was not processed AND/OR PLACED IN FORBEARANCE WITH NO INTEREST ACCRUAL. On XX/XX/year>XXXX  - the company replied with the following : Thank you for reaching out to the CFPB with your concerns regarding your federal student loan account. We understand you are concerned that your newly consolidated loan has not been enrolled in the SAVE plan. You also stated that when you contacted Aidvantage we were unable to advise why the loan hasnt been enrolled in the plan. However, our records show that when you called Aidvantage on XX/XX/year> you were correctly advised that due to a Federal court issued injunction the U.S. Department of Education is prevented from implementing parts of the SAVE Plan and other IDR Plans. As advised on XX/XX/year>, we are unable to process the plan due to the court injunction. Youre welcome to call us at XXXX, with any questions you may have concerning this issue. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  Given the updates made by the government, my application should have been placed on forbearance until new recertification amounts could have been made, which is what I stated in my previous complaint ( https : //www.ed.gov/higher-education/manage-your-loans/save-plan ) ; I believe Aidvantage intentionally did not place me in forbearance ( with no interest accrual after 60 days ), and am requesting for them to now follow up on the application that I submitted back in XX/XX/year>, to place me in general forbearance with no interest accrual. It has been over 60 days with interest accruing, and the SAVE application should now be in forbearance since I applied and it was never processed. The government states : As of XX/XX/scrub>XXXX XXXX borrowers may apply for the following IDR plans : Pay As You Earn ( PAYE ), SAVE ( previously known as REPAYE ), Income-Based Repayment ( IBR ), and Income-Contingent Repayment ( ICR ), if borrowers meet any plan specific eligibility requirements.. 

For borrowers who would prefer to make payments during this time -- such as borrowers pursuing PSLF or low-income borrowers who would owe no monthly payments -- enrolling in PAYE or ICR may be an option to consider. 

Borrowers are still permitted to apply for the SAVE plan ( previously known as REPAYE ), even though the court has enjoined some of the SAVE and other IDR plan provisions, including forgiveness. The Department is working with servicers and contractors to update their systems to align with the terms of the SAVE plan, based on the terms of the injunction. This process will take several months. Ultimately, the terms of the SAVE Plan and other IDR plans are subject to the outcome of ongoing litigation.

If servicers need time to process a borrowers IDR application, servicers will move the borrower into a processing forbearance for up to 60 days. Interest accrues during this short-term processing forbearance, and time in the processing forbearance that does provide IDR and PSLF credit. If the borrowers application is not processed by their servicer within 60 days, the borrower will be moved into a general forbearance that does not count toward PSLF or IDR until their application is processed. Interest will not accrue in this general forbearance.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I graduated in XX/XX/year> and have a receipt indicating that I filled out all the proper loan exiting paperwork at that time. I have double-checked with the college, and it has been confirmed by a MOHELA representative that, the college notified MOHELA at the end of XXXX of my XXXX graduation date. Yet, MOHELA did not move my loans into repayment at the end of the six-month grace period. After OVER A MONTH of trying to get this corrected, and after two different representatives claimed that they'd put in the request and that I wouldnot be penalized for the unpaid months, my loans still have not been moved into repayment. 

WHAT I'VE DONE TO RESOLVE THE ISSUE : XXXX - I tried calling, but got put on hold for over two hours just to speak to someone who could not help me and put me on hold for another XXXX  hours. I finally spoke to a representative about this issue after three hours. She admitted that this was strange and that everything had been done correctly on the college 's end, but MOHELA had not transferred me into repayment at the proper time - something that normally happens automatically. She said she put in the request for changes to be made ( my loans would be moved into repayment, and any unpaid loan payments for months after the grace period where I was not notified would be put into forbearance so I would not be penalized ), and that it should happen within XXXX days and that I would receive an email with my first payment amount and due date. 
XXXX Amidst all the holds, I sent a message via their online portal detailing my situation. 
- They responded after my call noting that I had already spoken to a representative, and therefore my issue had been resolved. 
XXXX There were still no changes to my account, so I sent another message through the MOHELA portal detailing, again, my situation, and asking for someone to help me. 
- I eventually received a response - sometime between XXXX letting me know how they move students out of deferment after a school sends information, etc. They said I should respond to the email if I wanted to make a special request to move my student loans out of deferment while I am still in school - so clearly they did not read my message. Also- they don't have a reply button for customers, so I can not respond to their emails, and I have to keep sending new messages every time. 
XXXX I emailed through the MOHELA portal again, this time under the category of " Complaints ''. 
- I still have not received a response. 
XXXX I tried calling. After XXXX hours, I finally talked to XXXX - She immediately transferred me to an advanced agent. The estimated wait time for the advanced agent was another XXXX hours and XXXX minutes. 
XXXX After XXXX more hours, I talked to someone at XXXX named XXXX who said that she couldn't see any requests put in to change my deferment, but that she put in a new request for my loans to be moved out of deferment - Request ID # XXXX. She said it should take XXXX  days for the request to go through. 
XXXX - There have still been no changes to my account, and I still have not received any actual help at all.

XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 
At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in 26 states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts.

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : 1. Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions. 
2. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans.

3. Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts.

Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the American Dream, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it. 
We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays. 
Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 
Sincerely, Students & Graduates of XXXX XXXX

So I have the following questions : 1. Shouldnt my refunds from XXXX XXXX XXXX  case 1 have been sent to me directly and not applied to my outstanding principle balance for XXXX XXXX in borrower defense case 2? 
2. What action do I need to take and who do I take it with? 
3. If my borrower defense case for XXXX is eventually approved, but that balance has been discharged under the IDR forgiveness, will I still receive a retro-active refund of money that I paid on those loans, including the refund payments that were applied to them? 

I was considered a class member of the XXXX case for my XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
I applied for borrower defense for my XXXX loans on XX/XX/XXXX. 
I received notification on XX/XX/XXXX, from the Department of Education, that my application was approved. 
My studentaid data history shows that Aidvantage applied XXXX XXXX related refunds to my OPB for my remaining XXXX balance, rather than issue a refund directly to me. This is what I see : o Refund 1 : Loan Disbursement Amount : {$23000.00} Aid Recipient 's Loan Discharge Type Code : XXXX Aid Recipient 's Loan Discharge Type Code Description : Borrower Defense Aid Recipient 's Loan Discharge XXXX Amount of Discharge : {$8400.00} Amount of Discharge Applied to OPB : {$8400.00} Amount of Discharge Applied to OIB : {$0.00} o Refund 2 : Loan Disbursement Amount : {$11000.00} Aid Recipient 's Loan Discharge Type Code : XXXX Aid Recipient 's Loan Discharge Type Code Description : Borrower Defense Aid Recipient 's Loan Discharge XXXX Amount of Discharge : {$4700.00} Amount of Discharge Applied to OPB : {$4700.00} Amount of Discharge Applied to OIB : {$0.00} I applied for borrower defense for my XXXX XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX. 
I was considered a post-class member of the case for my second borrower defense application. 
I have been told that the Dept. of Edu. has until XXXX to respond to this second application. If they do not, the loans would be automatically discharged. 

I received notification on XX/XX/XXXX, from the Department of Education, that I received a full discharge of my remaining balances for XXXX because I was paying on an IDR plan for XXXX years. But the second borrower defense case is still pending. 

I sent multiple inquiries about this on the studentaid.gov website which received no response. 

I created a dispute case with the Department of Education. I received an email from Ombudsman XXXX XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX stating that they were working on the case. I emailed requesting a status update on XX/XX/XXXX which went unanswered. I sent another email requesting an update again today. 

I sent inquiries on the Aidvantage website and I also called customer service to inquire about this. The staff seemed to be uneducated about the XXXX ruling forbidding them from applying my first case refund to the loans contained in the second case. They were not helpful and always told me they could not do anything and that I had to talk to the Department of Education. The Dept. of Ed told me to talk to Aidvantage about it. All I got was the runaround.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding MOHELA 's Handling of Student Loan Forgiveness and Loan Discrepancies I am writing to file a formal complaint regarding issues I have encountered with MOHELA, the student loan servicer responsible for managing my student loan forgiveness process. I wish to address the following concerns : Ongoing Issues with Loan Forgiveness Process : Despite my repeated efforts to contact MOHELA regarding my student loan forgiveness application, I have faced significant delays and have received little to no response. This lack of communication is not only frustrating, but it also violates the Consumer Financial Protection Act ( CFPA ) and the Student Loan Servicing Regulations, which require loan servicers to provide clear, accurate, and timely information regarding federal student loan repayment and forgiveness programs.

Discrepancies in Loan Amounts : Additionally, I recently discovered discrepancies in the total amounts outstanding on my loan after my loans were transferred from XXXX, which is currently involved in a lawsuit. These discrepancies may constitute a violation of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), as it is crucial that the amounts listed by servicers accurately reflect the loan balance and history. As such, the failure to provide a clear and accurate account of my loan balance is causing undue confusion and distress. 

These issues have created significant delays in the processing of my loan forgiveness application and have caused unnecessary stress in an already difficult financial situation. It is unacceptable for a student loan servicer such as MOHELA to exhibit such disregard for its borrowers, particularly when the servicer is entrusted with the management of important and time-sensitive matters like loan forgiveness. 

As MOHELA is required to adhere to federal laws governing student loan servicing, I respectfully request that the CFPB investigate these matters and take appropriate action to ensure that MOHELA complies with all applicable regulations. It is imperative that borrowers like myself are provided with transparent, accurate, and timely information, and that the loan forgiveness process is handled with the efficiency and professionalism expected of an organization managing federal student loan programs. 

Thank you for your attention to this serious matter. I look forward to your prompt response and any assistance you can provide in resolving these issues.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint regarding the handling of my student loan records by Nelnet following the transfer of my loans from XXXX during the pandemic. Over the years, my loans have been serviced by multiple entities, including XXXX XXXX, XXXX, and Nelnet, and I believe that somewhere along the way, my information has been mismanaged. This has resulted in incomplete and inaccurate records that impact my ability to verify my loan history and payments. I am including supporting files to provide evidence for the statements made in this complaint. 

XXXX. Failure to Provide Complete Loan History After my loans were transferred to Nelnet, I reached out multiple times by phone to request my complete loan history to ensure that all records were transferred accurately. Despite repeated assurances that the information would be emailed to me, I never received it. 
I escalated the matter to the XXXX XXXX XXXX site, filing XXXX XXXX # XXXX in XX/XX/XXXX. This was due to discrepancies between the loan information displayed on the Nelnet site and the Federal Student Loan site. Attempts to call Nelnet were often unsuccessful, with wait times of XXXX minutes and frequent disconnections. 
XXXX. Inaccurate and Incomplete Information Provided Nelnets responses to my feedback cases have been incomplete : In XX/XX/XXXX, I filed Feedback Case # XXXX, again requesting a complete history of my loans. The information provided by Nelnet was still incomplete and included inaccuracies, such as a XXXX Promissory Note with an address I had not lived at since XXXX. While my mothers address from XXXX was listed correctly, this error highlights inaccuracies in their records. 
XXXX. Missing Data in Payment History The Federal Student Aid site now displays payment counts ; however, significant gaps exist in the details section for my payment history, including : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
XXXX. Mismanagement Across Multiple Servicers My loans have been serviced by multiple entities over the years, including XXXX XXXX, XXXX, and Nelnet. Somewhere in this process, my loan information has been mismanaged, resulting in discrepancies and gaps in my records. 
XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX and federal regulations require loan servicers to maintain accurate records and ensure the proper transfer of information when loans are transferred between servicers. This duty has clearly not been fulfilled, as evidenced by the gaps and inaccuracies in my records. 
Specifically, 34 CFR 682.208 ( b ) and related regulations outline the responsibilities of loan servicers, including accurate record-keeping, prompt communication with borrowers, and ensuring seamless transitions during loan transfers. Nelnet, as the current servicer, has failed to meet these obligations. 
Supporting Files I am including documents that provide evidence of the issues described above, including correspondence with Nelnet and the Federal Student Aid site, feedback case details, and discrepancies in loan records.

Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the U.S. Department of Education ( DOE ) and the Department of Governmental Entities ( DOGE ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security. 
I recently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes but is not limited to : My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ). 
My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including financial aid history and loan information.

My IRS tax transcripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization.

These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards.

Given the severity of this breach and the direct impact on my financial security and privacy, I demand the following corrective actions : Immediate discharge and cancellation of all my federal student loans due to the breach of my financial aid and tax records, which invalidates the integrity of my loan agreements.

A formal investigation into this data breach, including details on how my records were accessed, who accessed them, and for what purpose.

A full report on the extent of my data exposure and the corrective measures being implemented to prevent future violations.

Immediate notification to all major credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) to place a fraud alert and investigate any unauthorized activity that may have resulted from this breach. 
This breach has caused significant distress and concern regarding the security of my personal and financial data. If my demands are not met within 30 days, I will be left with no choice but to escalate this matter through legal channels, including filing complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and pursuing legal action against the responsible parties. 
I request a written response addressing these concerns and outlining the immediate actions being taken to remedy this situation. Please direct all correspondence to the address listed above. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this urgent matter. I look forward to your immediate response and resolution. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
In XXXX of XXXX I reivewed my credit report and noticed I had two accounts open with XXXX, which is a Federal Student Aid Creditor. I contacted XXXX regarding these, as I have never requested an form of student loans and was advised to fill out a " False Certification Discharge Application '' from the XXXX  website. Upon submitting, I received a confirmation email from their customer service team listing out the documents I had sent, and was advised there is a 60-90 business day review period for these cases. This 'fraud packet ' required me to provide proof that these loans were fraudulent, including a photocopy of my Drivers License. Throughout the 60-90 business day waiting period, I contacted XXXX multiple times to check on my fraud packet, and was advise it was still being reviewed. On XXXX XXXX I contacted EdFinancial and was advised by a customer services representative that I was just short of the 90 business days, and that he would escalate this and I would hear back in 2-5 buisness days. I never received a call back. On XX/XX/XXXX I contacted XXXX once again and was told by a customer service representative that I did not submit the documents and that there was no record of them reviewing the fraud packet. I was offered a 6 month forbearance regarding these fraudulent loans, which I was never told about prior to XX/XX/XXXX, so I have had a negative credit impact due to this. I requested to speak with a supervisor, and this lady was extremely rude and advised I would need to resubmit the packet. I asked if there was an escalation path for this since I had been told misinformation for multiple months. She advised that because the fault was not of XXXX that they would not escalate this issue. Today on XX/XX/XXXX, I am starting this process over again, with little to no faith that this company can handle the documents they lost initially. I have had negative impacts to my credit score due to this issue, and will be subject to another XXXX business day review period for this fraud packet when I did not open these loans. 

I have contacted the college which the loans were funded to and provided them with the same documents and they said they filed an identity theft report with the state of Oregon. 

Please take note that I have never once received any sort of communication regarding delinquent student loans PRIOR to providing my information to XXXX. The information they had on file was either the fraudsters or fake information. After providing them with my phone number, I received a text message from a 3rd party creditor offering a loan to pay off my delinquent student loans. This leads me to believe that my information was given out via XXXX and mishandled. 

Please help me. Please help others who are victims of fraudulent student loans dealing with XXXX. Thank you.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to submit a formal complaint regarding my student loans, which are currently impacting my credit report. Despite having applied for student loan forgiveness and meeting the necessary criteria, my loans were recently transferred to a new servicer, and I am now facing difficulties that I can not afford to resolve. Initially, my loans were marked for forgiveness by my previous loan servicer, and I was under the understanding that they would be discharged and removed from my credit record. However, after the loan was transferred, the new servicer has not honored the forgiveness agreement, and the loans have reappeared on my credit report. 

Given my financial situation, I am unable to afford the repayments on these loans. The student loan forgiveness program was my last viable option for resolving this debt, and it was my understanding that my loans would be forgiven and removed from my credit record. I am now facing undue stress and financial hardship as I continue to be held responsible for a debt that should have been discharged. It is causing significant harm to my financial well-being and preventing me from moving forward in rebuilding my credit.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Immediate Action Needed : Approve Outstanding Borrower Defense Applications To the Departments Overseeing School & Loan Server Compliance, I am writing as part of a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXX-affiliated schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding Borrower Defense applications and provide full relief for those impacted. 

Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : * XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX The Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXX University misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within six months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 

At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in 26 states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts.

I am asking you to take immediate steps to : 1. Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions.

2. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans.

3. Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts.

Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving me unable to move forward with my life. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the American Dream, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it.

I implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays. 

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 

Sincerely, A XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX of a XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative: I was previously serviced by XXXX. I was on auto-pay at all times up until the COVID-19 repayment pause. During the COVID-19 repayment pause, the loans were transferred to MOHELA to be serviced. My auto-pay history shows payments in Between XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX, every month like clockwork. But for some reason MOHELA removed me from Autopay thereafter. As soon as the repayment pause stopped, I signed back up for Auto-pay, which continued until I was notified on XX/XX/XXXX, that the repayment scheduled had changed, and again I made sure that auto-pay was scheduled for the next payment date, to begin on XX/XX/XXXX. For whatever reason, Mohela did not auto-debit my account and I received a delinquency notice on XX/XX/XXXX, at which time I paid not only the arrearage but also the next payment and against signed up for Auto-Pay. Again on XX/XX/XXXX, I got a delinquency notice, at which time I again paid the overdue amount and again. This one was especially difficult to take care of since the website wouldn't even allow me to make a payment because it says all payments current. I asked for them to contact me and no one did. I paid XXXX 's on XX/XX/XXXX after getting a past-due notice because Mohela again failed to auto-debit in on the XXXX, and made another complaint on XX/XX/XXXX. On XX/XX/XXXX I got a message saying that they had tried to reach me which is inaccurate. I am still waiting on contact from anyone at MOHELA. I call, but the wait time when I call is always over 2.5 hours. Every time the auto-pay doesn't take, I go online and resubmit the auto-pay information, it says that I am all set and the account will be auto-debited, and then it is not. This has been going on every month since inception and I can not get anyone on the phone. I keep getting messages that says I have missed a payment, and now I am advised that my credit score will be impacted - and it is apparent that I am not receiving credit for the interest reduction associated with being on auto-pay. The most recent instance has occurred on XX/XX/XXXX. Again, no auto-debit, causing my loans to be labeled as past due. So i just made a payment manually, again. And because they are past due, I can not just pay XXXX 's amount ( approx. XXXX ), it makes me pay all amounts due for XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX ( because I can not auto-allocate payments ) and this is very difficult because I am unemployed at the moment. Now the amounts of the auto-debit authorization DIFFER from my repayment plan ( as they now want {$1000.00} per month. My loan repayment should be {$81000.00} until at least XXXX according to the XX/XX/XXXX notice of change to my repayment plan ( which I did not request and MOHELA did unilaterally. ). PLEASE HELP.

In XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX  my student loans were forced into forbearance because I was on the SAVE repayment plan, which was blocked by a judge during this time. I did this on XX/XX/XXXX, as I was then at my 120 months of payments. I have not received a response since. I have tried multiple times to contact someone at the Department of Ed who knows what's going on with my request. I was told I needed to wait 45 business days from when I submitted the request. It has now been 81 days, with generous holiday allowances considered. Whenever I speak with someone through the online chat at the department of Ed, they tell me they don't have access to this information. I have received XXXX correspondence when I try to submit a complaint. The last person I chatted with told me I should try to contact my other loan servicer because the Dept of Ed might be waiting on information from them, which leads me to : XXXX : I called them twice and waited on hold for XXXX hours the first time, and 5 hours the second time, and no one ever answered the phone. Consumer complaint narrative:
I submitted my loan forgiveness application to Mohela in XXXX of XXXX. I finally got confirmation of Mohela receiving it via a message on the website, on XX/XX/XXXX saying that they received it on XX/XX/XXXX. I messaged twice over the next month on the Mohela website asking for a status update. Mohela responded on XX/XX/XXXX saying that " due to the complex nature of my request '' they needed me to call their customer support line. So I called them, waited on hold for hours multiple times, and finally got in touch with someone a few weeks later ( couldn't wait on hold for XXXX hours at a time during the work day ). When I finally talked to someone, they said that my application had an error because my first principal wrote his name on the supervisor line but did not specify his job title, so they needed me to submit it again after he wrote the word " principal '' on the line. Interest continued to accrue during this time. So I did as they requested. I asked for an update, and about a month later ( on XX/XX/XXXX ) Mohela said they had forwarded my application to " FSA ( DL ) '' so they could review it and, if I was approved, the amount I would be forgiven would be from them. The message ended " Further notification will be sent to you if any updated information is received regarding your Forgiveness. '' After waiting over a month, in XX/XX/XXXX I began to ask Mohela via messaging and trying to wait on hold for XXXX hours at a time to ask about my status. I received a message on XX/XX/XXXX saying the same thing as the previous message. All this time, more interest has accrued, about {$500.00} over the amount that is supposed to be forgiven. 
Finally, after XXXX weeks of calling XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) and Mohela, waiting on hold, being transferred up to XXXX different times, and being told different things by different agents at XXXX, I finally talked to Mohela on the phone on XX/XX/XXXX. In order for this to happen, I waited on hold for XXXX hours and XXXX minutes, then I talked to someone for XXXX minutes, and that person said they were going to have me talk to a XXXX agent and put me on hold. I waited on hold for another XXXX hours and then finally talked to the XXXX agent, who was confused and did not understand why Mohela XXXX showing I was approved for {$5000.00} of forgiveness instead of {$17000.00} worth of forgiveness like it is supposed to be. I asked several questions, she put me on hold for about XXXX minutes. She then told me she was unable to complete the " escalation process '' but was not sure why. We talked and she suggested I have my principal write a letter with the letterhead on it and the date on it. I asked some more questions and she said the problem could be that the principal I currently work for wrote the word " present '' for the dates worked for section on the application, which is because I still work for that principal. I asked if the interest could be prorated to a date when I initially turned in my first application, and she said its not possible. So, I have been paying interest while Mohela is failing to process the application and failing to notify me of any problems with the application. The last XXXX messages I submitted on the XX/XX/XXXX have not been answered by Mohela yet, so they would not have notified me of the problem unless I had the phone call that lasted XXXX hours and XXXX minutes. Someone please help, this is just wrong. XXXX does not offer a call back option, so you are stuck on hold for XXXX of the day just to talk to someone and be put back on hold.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I had a complaint filed already regarding a loan refund that MOHELA has inadequately addressed. 

CFPB closed the complaint despite me feeling that the response from the company was not adequate. 

This does not do anything to address the underlying reason for the complaint in the first time. This is a generic response simply stating they are still working on it. This is the same type of response that led to all of the issues and does not address the incompetence of the company that led to the report in the first place. I want specific answers. 

XXXX. When will my request be processed? 

XXXX. When will I receive my refund? 

XXXX. Why was I given false timelines for processing? 

XXXX. Why after so many inquiries did I finally get told that a whole new process would need to be started? 

Here are the details of the original complaint. Please do not accept a response or close the case until all XXXX of those questions are answered. 

Complaint number : XXXX " YOUR COMPLAINT I have a student loan through Mohela, which is currently eligible for Public Service XXXX XXXX XXXX From XXXX to XXXX of XXXX, I made XXXX payments during a forbearance period that were not required of me. In XXXX of XXXX, I made a refund request to have the money returned to me, which Mohela let their customers know was available. From XX/XX/XXXX through XXXX of XXXX, I called Mohela customer service multiple times to check on the status of the refund. I received multiple different answers from various employees of Mohela regarding to process for the refund. XXXX of the more recent calls I spoke with a representative that stated the refund would be processed within XXXX business days and that I should receive the refund in that time frame. I then waited the full 90 days and called them back on XX/XX/XXXX. This time, I spoke with a new customer service rep who told me that they needed to escalate the request because it had not yet been approved by Mohela, so therefore was not sent to the XXXX. of XXXX. I inquired about why after several phone calls and reassurances that the request would go through, why this new escalation needed to be done. I explained that over XXXX dollars is not a small sum of money and that I was unhappy with the handling and runaround that I had been getting. I then spoke with a supervisor, XXXX, who then informed me that she needed to start a whole new process to have my account " rebilled '' so that they requests could even go through. She refused to give me a time frame, and then confirmed that it may take several months, which is well over the initial 90 day time frame. I asked why these requests were so mishandled and she did not give me an answer. She said this needs to be approved by " upper management ''. However, when asking to speak to someone from this upper management, she told me the best she could do was send an email request which would take several weeks. I then inquired if I was entitled to interest for the untimely handling of money that was rightfully mine given how much predatory interest I already pay on these loans, and she told me no. I explained to her that I was very unhappy with the mishandling of my request, the multiple different answers that I received, and now having to go through multiple new processes to receive a large sum of money that is rightfully mine. I let her know that I think both her and the people that work under her that I had previously spoken too were bad at their jobs given how many wrong answers and quite frankly complete incompetence in performing the right processes to properly refund me. If this is not handled in a timely manner, I will also be planning to take legal action.

Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally file a complaint against Nelnet regarding their refusal to return {$10000.00} that I am owed. PLEASE SEE ALL EXHIBITS ATTACHED. Description of each exhibit at end. 

The total loan amount for the XXXX academic year was {$20000.00}. On XX/XX/XXXX, Nelnet disbursed {$10000.00} of this loan to the XXXX XXXX XXXX on my behalf for the Fall XXXX semester. On XX/XX/XXXX, I paid off that full Fall XXXX loan to Nelnet. Specifically, including interest, I paid {$10000.00} to Nelnet toward the Fall XXXX loan. However, on XX/XX/XXXX, I unenrolled from the XXXX XXXX XXXX  and as a result, the university canceled the Fall XXXX loan from Nelnet on XX/XX/XXXX. The funds returned to Nelnet on or about XX/XX/XXXX. 

The {$10000.00} loan disbursed on XX/XX/XXXX, was for the Fall XXXX semester. The remaining {$10000.00} of the full {$20000.00} loan was scheduled for disbursement in XX/XX/XXXX for the XXXX XXXX semester. Since I WAS NO LONGER ENROLLED after XX/XX/XXXX, Nelnet DID NOT disburse the Spring XXXX loan. Despite this, in an answer to my complaint, Nelnet claimed that the full {$20000.00} loan was disbursed on my behalf, including the XXXX XXXX portion. Nelnet claims the {$10000.00} I paid goes toward the XXXX XXXX loan. However, that can not be true if I am unenrolled and no XXXX XXXX loan was disbursed to the XXXX XXXX XXXX. Nelnets claim is incorrect, as I was no longer enrolled, and the XXXX XXXX XXXX  has confirmed in writing that the XXXX XXXX loan was never disbursed. The other half of that total {$20000.00} loan, the XXXX XXXX portion, would never be disbursed because I UNENROLLED from the university.

I have also made numerous attempts to resolve this issue through phone calls, but each time I was given no clear answers or a resolution.
