Consumer complaint narrative: Hello, Thank you for reviewing my complaint and providing support in hopefully reaching resolution. I have submitted at least 2 requests to Mohela ( upploading the appropriate forms ) for a 12 month deferrment as I work to resolve a financial hardship. Each request has been met with no confirmation of approval, only a response stating " please allow up to 90 days for processing your request '' however, I never receive confirmation it in fact has been processed ( approved ). The first request was in XX/XX/year> and the second request may have been in XXXX ( I am not certain ). A forebearance of 2 months was issued however, it was unrelated to my request of 12 months and was an Administrative Forebearance. I understand through my research that in XX/XX/year>, Moehla was sued for a wide range of unlawful practices including illegally denying service to borrowers that need help. The only communication I receive from Mohela, is notification of a past due payment. I understand repayment is my responsibility and I have only requested a 12 month forebearnce. Additionally, documents I have sent to them appear listed in their Inbox only to dissappear several weeks later. I am in desperate need for assistance. Attempts to contact them by phone have been futile as the wait time to speak to a customer service representative often exceeds one hour. Messages sent to them using their Message Center still do not provide me with the forebearance approval I am seeking and do little to answer the questions posed to them. If you notice, the " Documents Sent to Me '' list is quite extensive however, documents I sent to them have been deleted. Again, I sincerly appreciate your time and consideration. Thank you.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Re : PSLF.gov. I began application for PSLF in XXXX. I submitted the required information and signatures of the six churches I served. My application was consolidated somehow and some confusion about one of the churches was evidently resolved and it all went to XXXX. which has sent me a statement every month since. Beginning in XX/XX/XXXX they show XXXX payments. So for months I assumed I was good to go. 
Recently PSLF showed a new format where I can go to a page that shows my activities. On that page it shows one church, XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, once as complete and once under review. It omits another XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX 's. I had XXXX online " chats '', the first two of which were ridiculous. One suggested I begin the whole application from the beginning. Another thought I might need to try another computer. The third said the name of the church doesn't matter as long as the EIN is correct and concluded the chat. But I was worried about the EIN and went back online to check EINs. I couldn't do that, but discovered a subsequent page which showed all XXXX churches I have served as complete. However they show XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, as rejected as of last XXXX for no apparent reason. I was never notified about this, and the two churches are no different from the other four, except that PSLF shows a little trash can emoji next to them. So I am objecting to the way this was handled, and of course above all I am determined to receive the thousands of dollars I believe are due to me.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Misapplication of Loan Payments and Non-Responsive Customer Service To Whom It May Concern : I am writing to file a formal complaint against Sloan Servicing for the mishandling and misapplication of my student loan payments, which I believe constitutes unethical and potentially illegal practices in violation of federal consumer protection laws. 

Summary of Complaint : Misapplication of Payments : Up until XX/XX/XXXX, Sloan Servicing properly applied my monthly payments to both principal and interest. 

Beginning in XX/XX/XXXX, Sloan Servicing stopped applying any portion of my {$560.00} monthly payments to the principal. Instead, 100 % of each payment was applied solely to interest. This continued through XX/XX/XXXX. 

This misapplication persisted despite my consistent, on-time payments. For example : XX/XX/XXXX : {$560.00} {$490.00} applied to principal, {$61.00} to interest. 

XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX : {$560.00} payments {$0.00} to principal, {$560.00} entirely to interest. 

Lack of Resolution and Follow-Up : I have contacted Sloan Servicing multiple times regarding this issue. Each time, customer service assured me that the matter would be escalated to a XXXX. Despite these assurances, I never received any follow-up communication or resolution. 

History of Timely Payments : I have never missed or been late on any payment. My payment history reflects consistent, timely payments through auto-debit, emphasizing the seriousness of this misapplication issue. 

Prior Large Principal Payment : On XX/XX/XXXX, I made a {$10000.00} payment, with {$10000.00} explicitly applied to principal. This significant payment was made with the clear intent to reduce my loan balance. The current misapplication undermines this effort and suggests a pattern of negligence or intentional misconduct. 

Potential Violations : XXXX XXXX actions XXXX violate federal laws governing fair loan servicing, including the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) and Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). 

Their failure to apply payments correctly and refusal to address my concerns demonstrates a lack of transparency and accountability. 

Requested Resolution : Immediate Correction : Apply all misapplied payments since XX/XX/XXXX to the loan principal as originally intended. 

Formal Explanation : Provide a detailed explanation for why my payments were misapplied and why no follow-up occurred after repeated inquiries. 

Preventive Measures : Implement corrective measures to prevent this issue from recurring. 

I am submitting this complaint in the hope that the CFPB will investigate Sloan Servicings practices and hold them accountable for these potential violations.

I want assistance to get my money back and loans forgiven for loans meeting forgiveness as they are all unsubsidized loans and I have not missed any payments.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I went to the Dept. of Education site, and it was unbelievably messed up and I couldn't find history, payments, etc.. I saw a button to download the data. After reviewing it, I was horrified. Im a XXXX XXXX  and do auditing for a living. There were no payment details, large distributions over the loan amount, and a big unbelievable mess. I couldnt get any information, history, payments made, or any explanation of why this mess exists. 

I had to look at the data to even get the original amount originating in XXXX. I graduated in XXXX. I enrolled in the XXXX from XXXX to XXXX. The XXXX was {$6100.00}, total : {$16000.00}. The current lender is Nelnet. The current bill is {$220000.00} at 8.25 %. 

Nelnet had no previous history, so I had to go to the Dept of Ed. I saw 15 loans from 8 different lenders ( XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX, etc. ). I cant fathom the original amount going from {$16000.00} to {$220000.00}. I found massive amounts of unauthorized or extra distributions during my enrollment as well as after I graduated, including one for {$60000.00}, attached to my loan. 

I never authorized any loans, selling off my loans, and distributions. Why distributions? From whom and for what? I was never contacted or signed any documents other than the original one in XXXX and probably XXXX. 

According to Nelnet 's dashboard, I'm on the IDR ( IBR ) plan, and my loan is a XXXX XXXX with 283 qualifying payments out of XXXX ( XXXX left ) and a total of 340 payments made ( 57 not qualifying ). I assume these 57 payments were never attached to my loan. 

Nelnet has not responded after several complaints were filed and the Dept of Ed sent my complaints to Nelnet.

Consumer complaint narrative:
In XXXX, I had followed up with XXXX ( My previous LSP ) about correcting incorrect amounts reflected for my student loan balance ( including principal and interest ). I had made this request with XXXX and also filed a CFPB Complaint to help with XXXX ( since closed due to transfer ) and a congressional inquiry with my Senator ( XXXX XXXX ) who hand have XXXX XXXX on all my correspondence with EdFinancial and has had the case open prior to the loan balance being transferred. This issue has not been resolved and I am asking that my total loan amount be adjusted to reflect the total loan balance ( including principal and interest ) reflected on my XXXX account. 

I am reaching out because EdFinancial has been unable to address my issue despite continually following up. My loan balance of {$170000.00} on XXXX has inexplicitly increased to {$180000.00} today. No explanation or justification has been provided by EdFinancial for as to why my balance increased so significantly in such a short period of time. It is very frustrating that XXXX repeatedly appears to avoid addressing my complaint for almost 8 months now. I pray this can be addressed timely. 

On XX/XX/XXXX I reached out to EdFinancial because my loan balance still was not accurate. This is what I said in an email ( also attached ) : " I have outstanding inquiries with XXXX and Dept of Ed relating to checking my service account that remain unresolved and need to be addressed. Notably, I do not believe my monthly loan amount is correct because my total loan balance is not accurate. This number is about {$10000.00} more than the total loan amount plus interest balance reflected in my XXXX account. I have provided this information to XXXX and Department of Education and am still waiting for a response. '' On XX/XX/XXXX I got the following NON-response " Thank you for contacting Edfinancial Services. We hope this information finds you well. We apologize for any inconvenience this may cause, we recommend resubmitting your outstanding inquiries with Edfinancial so that we can ensure they are addressed. We look forward to assisting you to resolve these issues. 
XXXX Edfinancial Services '' On XX/XX/XXXX I again restated my issue in creater details providing specific information. In this correspondence I said, " Sent : Thu XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX ( Eastern Daylight Time ) To : XXXX Subject : Re : Billing Questions? WI XXXX or EdFinancial Services Customer Service, Today I received a letter Edfinancial Services dated XX/XX/XXXX for acct # XXXX Concerningly, the amounts indicated on this letter from EdFinancial are not accurate. These amounts directly contradict total loan balance including principal and interest with XXXX. As previously indicated, a raised concern with a sudden significant interest in my loan balance by XXXX, however this concern was not addressed with XXXX and ignored for months. My total XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX balance including principal and interest is {$170000.00}. The letter I received dated XX/XX/XXXX increases this total loan amount including principal and interest to the tune of over {$10000.00}! Please fix this error. 

Specifically, the correspondence dated XX/XX/XXXX from EdFinancial Services indicates that my loan Principal Balance is {$170000.00} and that my " unpaid interest to be capitalized is {$10000.00} and that my interest not capitalized is {$180000.00} I have provided a screenshot and printouts of my student loan account with XXXX from XXXX and correspondence with XXXX demonstrating that my total loan balance including principal and interest is {$170000.00}. 

Apologies for the delay. I am awaiting a response from Department of Education who has not provided the complete information necessary to meet your request or responded at all. Please see XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Request.pdf attached from XX/XX/XXXX which reflects the most recent communication on this request that remains outstanding. I have also provided notes following my last attempt to speak with my loan servicer to get my issue resolved, it's the word document attached with the XXXX title but reflects my follow up correspondence with the ombuds. I am awaiting my case details that i have requested received by their office on XX/XX/XXXX. 

Is it possible to make a request for you to do this for me? I have attempted to get this information together and made a request for necessary information from the Department of Education who has not responded to this request yet or even acknowledged that they had received this request made through the Office of Inspector General.

This has been incredibly frustrating and I haven't been able to get any answers or clarity on my outstanding issues. I want to make sure that everything that I have raised and that has been well documented is addressed fully and not missed. I do not believe I should be responsible for repeating myself. I can help provide some clarity and direction and some documents that may be helpful to you. I have attached these documents to this email. I have way too many documents to be able to attach here though due to size constraints, and some of the information I do not feel comfortable sharing over email. However, all of this information has been provided to Federal Student Aid and/or XXXX so you should be able to get it from them. If you need me to be the person making the request for that information, please let me know. I would appreciate assistance making that request. I look forward to a prompt resolution to this long outstanding issue. Sincerely, XXXX '' I spoke with a representative who indicated they are doing an account review and would get back to me. During this call the customer service representative indicated they would give me a call back. XXXX from Edfinancial Services replied : " Hello Xxxxx Thank you for contacting Edfinancial Services. I show, per the notes on your account, that you have spoken to a representative more recently than this e-mail on XX/XX/XXXX. As a friendly reminder, a request was sent to the appropriate department for further review. Please allow time for review and we will notify you if anything else is needed. Thank you, XXXX Edfinancial Services. 

I followed up on XX/XX/XXXX due to no response : " EdFinancial Services, A friendly reminder that I have been expecting a call back from a representative for over XXXX week, since XXXX. I feel that I am being ignored and that my inquiry is not being taken seriously. I am disappointed and frustrated that it does not appear you have attempted to follow up with me since this email. I pray you can do better than this. When can I expect a meaningful response? 
Sincerely, XXXX '' On XX/XX/XXXX I followed up because I have not received any response. In a phone conversation I was advised that a possible explanation for my balance having changed was incorrect. Ed Financial explained that they had noticed an error in my account balance because interest incorrectly was applied to my account. However, this still does not account for the nearly {$10000.00} unaccounted for discrepancy in my student loans balance. I explained that it was a mathmatical impossibility and went through the math with the representative on the phone. They indicated they still couldn't help me because their " calculator wasn't working '' on their computer so they referred me to their XXXX Department I followed up in an email at XXXX that day and Jahmelia XXXX XXXX ( presumably accounting ) followed up on XX/XX/XXXX : " From : Sent : Thu XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ) To : XXXX XXXX : Re : Billing Questions? WI XXXX update on my loans, but still appears there is some work to be done. It was discovered about XXXX interest on my loans capitalized when it should not have and my balance has been adjusted. However, there still is discrepancy in my total loan balance that is not accounted for. The balance on my Edfinancial account for my student loans remains incorrect. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I called to inquire on my student loans. I spoke with a customer service representative who informed me of a letter that noted that there was an error in my loans that resulted in capitalization of interest that should not have occurred. The balance was adjusted to a principal of XXXX and an interest of {$21000.00}. The letter also apparently says that if this doesnt resolve my issue that I would need to submit a new inquiry and provide additional information. 
I am grateful that a significant error was discovered with how my loans are being serviced, however this does not resolve my issue. There is no mathematical explanation for why my loan amount ( including principal and interest ) increased from {$170000.00} on XX/XX/XXXX, to what it currently reflects ( including principal and interest ) {$180000.00}. 
We went through my case history and located the information I sent including the photos of my portal reflecting the total principal and interest amount of {$170000.00}. This file is able to be seen by EdFinancial, although at first they were unable to find it. Additionally, they were ale to see my concerns and case notes from when I spoke with Edfinancial, including Edfinancial customer service representative named XXXX back in about the early XXXX timeframe. 
The Edfinancial customer service representative ( XXXX ) advised me that my loan could have capitalized interest since then and that would account for the increase of almost {$13000.00}. XXXX further explained that interest could have capitalized from XXXX until XXXX of XXXX. However, I was on the XXXX plan and making payments. Furthermore, even if the interest fully accrued during this time on my principal balance, this explanation by Edfinancial is mathematically impossible. I was again told that this could be accrued interest and that the letter that was sent to me has resolved my concern. 
I explained that it doesnt resolve my concern and the reason I am being given is mathematically impossible. When I explained that to XXXX, I was told that they are unable to calculate this now because they do not have access to a calculator that can do this math equation. Only once I went through a simplified version of the math equation with XXXX that I learned to do in my XXXX grade required personal finance class they agreed to agree to send my concern to finance so they could do this calculation. 

While not my primary concern, it is alarming to me that I would be provided explanations that are mathematically impossible by customer service representatives to what appears be an attempt to justify what looks very likely to be an incomplete resolution to my issue. I am shocked that customer service representatives are unable to complete a high school level math equation because a software isn't working without escalation to their financial department. 
It has been over 6 months since I sent this information to EdFinancial and this issue remains unresolved. I expect to get a follow up call back from XXXX by XX/XX/XXXX with an update on the status of my concern. 
I look forward to a prompt resolution to this concern. Thank you for your time addressing these issues with my loan service. While significant errors appear to have been discovered and corrected, there still appears to be some serious things wrong with my loan balance that still need to be resolved. '' XXXX said : " XXXX XXXX, Thank you for contacting Edfinancial Services. After reviewing your account, it concluded that the interest on the account is correct. The daily interest accrual is XXXX per day. There was an interest cap on XX/XX/XXXX that did not include loans XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX, So when the interest cap was reversed on XX/XX/XXXX those loans were not included. In addition to that from XXXX, you were in repayment but were not making payments so it had some interest accrual the benefit did not cover. 
Thank you, XXXX XXXX '' I expected a call back from XXXX, who left a note and then I have followed up to EdFinancial with an email on XXXX : " Thank you for your response. I have been expecting to get a call back from XXXX who I spoke with and did not receive a call. It is unacceptable that I would need to resubmit my claim because of how you choose to mishandle this situation. It obviously is not an issue with the interest rate calculation. Please fix the balance on my student loans. It is incorrect! '' I also called on XXXX and spoke with a customer service representative who reviewed my loan notes and explained that they calculated my interest capitalization and reversal of an interest cap which resulted in a difference of about {$180.00} in error on my loans. Good progress, but there still is over {$10000.00} unaccounted for. The representative noted that interest accrual has been accounted for. 

An explanation XX/XX/XXXX an incorrect interest capitalization was incorrectly applied, but an interest capitalization for other loans were not accurate. This still does not address how my loan principal and balance increased so significantly. 

The Edfinancial supervisor level representative I spoke with was XXXX. I explained that I my issue remains unresolved and that my current student loan balance reported by EdFinancial appears to be incorrect. The total balance plus interest has not increased from XXXX on XXXX to {$180000.00} due to forbearance periods and interest accrual. It is mathematically impossible. My understanding is interest accrual only occurred for a few days in XXXX of XXXX. XXXX indicated that they would request a explanation to correct this. XXXX indicated they would return my call once they had an opportunity to speak with the accounting department so they could provide me an explanation over the phone but that it would " take a while '' and be " depending on work schedules. '' This explanation is preferred, but this issue has remained unresolved since XXXX of XXXX with Ed Financial. I have respectfully worked with EdFinancial to address my concern, but need help from CFPB to make sure I have timely and meaningful response to my issue so it can be resolved.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Request for Resolution of Public Student Loan Forgiveness Employment Verification and Payment Count Update Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, I am writing to file a formal complaint regarding the lack of response and resolution from Federal Student Aid concerning my Public Student Loan Forgiveness ( PSLF ) Employment Verification submissions. 

I have submitted multiple Employment Verification forms, including one dated XX/XX/, to update my qualifying payment count. Despite these efforts, I have not received any correspondence or confirmation. As of now, I have over 120 qualifying payments and need these counts updated to proceed with a buyback of months placed into forbearance by a Texas judge. This situation occurred while I was, and continue to be, enrolled in the Saving on a Valuable Education ( SAVE ) Plan. 

On XX/XX/, I submitted another Employment Verification Form via both file upload on their website and fax, as advised by their representatives. Despite following their instructions, I have not received any updates. Additionally, I submitted formal complaints through their website twice, as directed by their staff, but no progress has been made. 

This lack of communication and action has left me unable to move forward with resolving my loan situation. I am seeking your assistance to ensure my Employment Verification is processed, my payment count is updated, and I can proceed with the buyback process. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to a resolution soon. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX
Company: Servicer under contract with Federal Student Aid

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem with forgiveness, cancellation, or discharge
Consumer complaint narrative:
We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXXaffiliated schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding Borrower Defense applications and provide full relief for those impacted. 
Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : * XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  The Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXX University misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within XXXX months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 

At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in XXXX states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts.

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : 1. Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions. 
XXXX. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans.

We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Request for Documentation and Proof of Interest Accrual Validity Dear Aidvantage, Thank you for your response regarding the interest accrual on my student loan account. I acknowledge your explanation ; however, I require further clarification and supporting documentation regarding your assertion that my 0 % interest rate eligibility did not begin until XX/XX/ XXXX. 

Given that I was enrolled in the Saving on a Valuable Education ( SAVE ) Plan, which explicitly states that interest does not accrue while monthly payments are {$0.00}, I find the reasoning provided in your response insufficient. Furthermore, statements made by XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX, indicated that all borrowers enrolled in the SAVE Plan would benefit from an interest-free forbearance during this period. 

I respectfully request documented proof or official guidance that demonstrates why my 0 % interest eligibility under the SAVE Plan did not begin until XX/XX/XXXX. This proof should include : 1XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  guidance or policy outlining the criteria used to determine the delayed start date of my 0 % interest eligibility. 

2. Specific justification as to why my account, which was placed in forbearance starting XXXX XXXX, XXXX, did not qualify for 0 % interest immediately. 

3. Any communication records or documentation sent to me informing me of this delayed eligibility date.

4. Documentation or Official Guidance : Any federal guidelines, court rulings, or instructions from XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX explicitly stating that my 0 % interest rate eligibility began on XX/XX/ XXXX, rather than XX/XX/ XXXX. 

5. Detailed Timeline : A clear breakdown of how and when the 0 % interest benefit was applied to my account, including any delays or actions taken by Aidvantage or FSA.

6. Account Records : Copies of all relevant communications or records from Federal Student Aid that directed the implementation of interest accrual on my account. 

It is my understanding that, as a borrower, I have the right to transparent documentation and explanations for any charges applied to my account. Without proof or further clarity, the interest charged during the stated forbearance period remains questionable. 

Please note that I expect a detailed and thorough response, along with all supporting documentation, within 15 business days. Should you fail to provide sufficient evidence, I will consider pursuing additional avenues, including legal action, to ensure compliance with federal student loan regulations and borrower rights. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
. I sent a letter requesting the following information : The name and address of the creditor to whom the debt is currently owed, the account number used by that creditor, and the amount owed.

If this debt started with a different creditor, provide the name and address of the original creditor, the account number used by that creditor, and the amount owed to that creditor at the time it was transferred. When you identify the original creditor, please provide any other name by which I might know them, if that is different from the official name. In addition, tell me when the current creditor obtained the debt and who the current creditor obtained it from.

Provide verification and documentation that there is a valid basis for claiming that I must pay the debt to the current creditor. For example, can you provide a copy of the written agreement that created my original requirement to pay, including signature pages for the debt?

If you are asking that I pay a debt that somebody else is or was required to pay, identify that person. Provide verification and documentation about why this is a debt that I must pay.

The amount and age of the debt, including : A copy of the last billing statement sent to me by the original creditor.

State the amount of the debt when you obtained it, and when that was.

Consumer complaint narrative: I applied for PSLF while working as an XXXX Farm to School Specialist last year, and my student loans ( that have been in repayment since XXXX ) were transferred to MOHELA. Prior, my student loans were serviced with XXXX, and then transferred to XXXX when XXXX went out of business. I have been using my XXXX XXXX XXXX to pay my student loans for about 2 years now, and I had no troubles doing so with XXXX. I always pay my loans a few weeks prior to their due date to ensure processing times do not interfere with paying my loans on time. Since switching to MOHELA, my student loan repayment has been an absolute nightmare. Every single month, they lose my payment, are not applying my payment to my account, are charging me interest for late payments, and are simply not even accepting my payment ( and letting it sit there without taking any action on my payment ) in some cases. I have had to call them every single month in order to have my money tracked down and account rectified and back-dated. On my XXXX  portal where I make payments to MOHELA, I can see if MOHELA has accepted, declined, or has not taken any action ( pending ) on my payment submission. They continuously accept my money, post it for a day prior to my loan due date ( which is the XXXX of every month ) and then I still end up with a notification that my payment is late. I provide receipts and have receipt of every single payment I have made, which has never once been late, and they have to open a case on my account every time to find the money. It usually gets found months later, but this takes hours of my time once a month and it is extremely difficult and frustrating to have to deal with this constantly. I am being penalized by MOHELA, getting interest tacked onto my account, and having my credit score affected when I have done absolutely nothing wrong and have the proof of that. Additionally, none of the customer service representatives are ever able to help me. I have been hung-up on and sent back into the pool of waiting customers seeking help because even when I choose the, " XXXX '' option from their menu selection upon calling, the customer service representative knows nothing about the XXXX process. I have done my due diligence and worked with XXXX as well when an issue arises each month, and they also confirm with me that this is a MOHELA problem that many customers are experiencing. Something needs to be done about this. This has been an absolutely horrible experience, and I am dealing with it yet again this month regarding my XXXX payments.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative:
I submitted an application for XXXX Student Loan Forgiveness in XXXX, XXXX to MOHELA. I never received confirmation that my application had been received. I called once in XXXX, waited on the phone for four hours, and was asked to call back a month later for a processing timeline. I called in XXXX, waited on the phone for four hours, and was told that the latest they would process my application would be XXXX XXXX 90 days after the application was submitted. They told me to call back in three weeks. I called back in XXXX and XXXX, each time waiting more than four hours to talk to a representative. They ensured me the application would be reviewed by XX/XX/XXXX. 

I called back on XX/XX/XXXX, waiting XXXX hours on the phone. They said that my application had not been reviewed and that it might take another few months. The person on the phone said she could expedite the review for me. 


The application was not reviewed until XX/XX/XXXX. The application was rejected because I have worked for multiple school districts. I called three times to follow up. Each time I called, the wait time exceeded four hours. There is no callback option, you have to hold the phone to your ear for four hours. The first customer service representative informed me that I need to have multiple people from multiple districts sign and date the same line, which is impossible. I called again, waited five hours, and was connected to a trainee who said she was not authorized to handle my case. It was too late to transfer me to an authorized representative. I called the next day, and waited five hours to talk to a representative. She informed me that I can submit multiple applications from districts, which I did the next day. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, my application was reviewed. However, even though I was informed by MOHELA to submit multiple applications, the reviewer only reviewed one of them. They rejected my application on the grounds that I have not taught for five years, when all three applications stated that I have. 

I have called three times to follow up. The first day, I waited six hours. I was connected to a trainee, who put me in another five hour cue to talk to someone with authority. By the time the call was transfered, the center was closed. That was an 11 hour day. I called again yesterday. I waited on the phone for 8 hours, talked to someone who was not authorized to review my case, and was told they were closed for the day and to try again the next day. I called again today. I waited on the phone for five hours, talked to someone who was not authorized to review my case, and was told to wait another 7 hours to talk to an authorized representative. That means they will call me back at XXXX at night, when I called at XXXX. They close at XXXX, there is no chance I will be able to talk to them. 

MOHELA is benefiting from not submitting my application. If the loan is not forgiven, they can keep collecting money from me. It is in their best interest to delay, reject, delay, reject. I have spent more than 50 hours holding my phone to my ear because they do not have a callback option. This can not continue. I need them to review my full application, give valid reasons for approval/denial, and forward my application to the federal government in a timely manner. I waited five months to be rejected because someone did not read my full application. I can not wait any longer. Every month I wait, MOHELA collects another {$350.00} from me in student loan payments.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX Consumer Financial Protection Bureau XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Improper Interest Accrual on Student Loan Dear XXXX XXXX I am filing a formal complaint regarding improper interest accrual on my student loan account, serviced by Nelnet, while I was enrolled in the Saving on a Valuable Education ( SAVE ) Plan. This complaint concerns XXXX, which was applied to my account despite the SAVE Plan 's provisions that guarantee no interest accrual during {$0.00} payment periods. 

Summary of the Complaint : Improper Interest Accrual Despite Eligibility for {$0.00} Payments. Under the SAVE Plan, borrowers eligible for {$0.00} payments should not accrue interest. This interest charge violates the program 's terms, which were implemented to protect borrowers from unnecessary debt accumulation. 

Inadequate Response from Loan Servicer Shortly after discovering the interest charge, I contacted Nelnet. A representative assured me that the interest would be removed. However, the charge remains on my account. Additionally, when I spoke with a supervisor, they could not explain the origin of the interest charge and promised a follow-up, which never occurred. 

Press Release by Education Secretary XXXX XXXX In response to the 8th Circuit Court of Appeals siding in favor of a lawsuit challenging the SAVE program, Education Secretary XXXX XXXX stated on XX/XX/XXXX, that borrowers enrolled in the SAVE plan will be placed in an interest-free forbearance. Despite this guarantee, interest has continued to accrue on my account. 

Violation of Federal Protections These actions may violate federal laws and regulations, including : The Higher Education Act of 1965, which governs student loans and protects borrowers rights. 

The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), which prohibits unfair debt practices. 

The Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ), which ensures accurate loan terms disclosure. 

Lack of Transparency [ XXXX XXXX XXXX ] has not provided adequate documentation or a clear explanation for the improper interest charges, leaving me without a resolution. 

Requested Resolution : I respectfully request the following : Immediate Refund of Improperly Charged Interest : Refund XXXX charged to my account.

Review of Loan Account : Conduct a full review of my account to ensure no additional improper charges. 

Detailed Explanation : Provide a written explanation of the interest charges and their origin. 

Preventative Measures : Ensure corrective actions to prevent similar issues for other borrowers. 

Conclusion : I believe Nelnet 's actions violate federal regulations and borrower protections. If this matter is not resolved promptly, I will pursue legal action and explore other avenues to ensure compliance with the SAVE Plan and federal guidelines. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. Please contact me if further information is needed. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX Loan Account Number : XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Immediate Action Needed : Approve Outstanding Borrower Defense Applications To the Departments Overseeing School & Loan Server Compliance, We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXX schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding Borrower Defense applications and provide full relief for those impacted. 

Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : * XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX The Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXX XXXX misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within six months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 

At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in 26 states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts. 

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : 1. Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions.

2. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans. 
XXXX. Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts. 

Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the American Dream, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it. 

We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays. 

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 

Sincerely, Students & Graduates of XXXX XXXX

I asked to be placed in forbearance in XXXX as I was supposed to be, and they said they would place me in forbearance. This forbearance ended on XX/XX/XXXX. At this point, I began receiving notices of upcoming payment due dates. I called to ask if this was accurate several times ( 3 times XX/XX/year> ) and the automated message on Mohelas end stated that if you had been approved for an XXXX  or had submitted an application, they were working on placing your account in forbearance and instructed callers to ignore any notices about upcoming payments. I was approved for XXXX through XXXX, and my repayment plan on the website says XXXX  plan. However, after I followed these instructions and did not pay, my account stated that I had a late payment. It now says that I owe two payments in XXXX. I work full time Monday-Friday XXXX, so I have had my mom call them several times. Neither of us has ever received an answer on the phone. We have each been given wait times of about 90 minutes and have never been taken off of hold. I have chosen the option of receiving a call back, but have never received a call back. I have submitted messages on Mohelas website, but have never received any responses and there is no confirmation sent by email, so there is no proof of these contact attempts. I have five days remaining until this will be reported as a late payment on my credit and there is nothing I can do about it, because there is no way to get in contact with Mohela. Consumer complaint narrative: I am writing to formally address a breach of the promissory note governing my federal student loans. I have been in active loan repayment since XX/XX/year>, and have made 147 consecutive, on-time payments. According to the terms outlined in the promissory note, my loans were to be discharged after 120 consecutive, on-time payments. Despite fulfilling these conditions, my loans remain undischarged. I have contacted my loan servicer, Netnet, who has directed me to StudentAid.gov. Conversely, representatives at StudentAid.gov have instructed me to reach out to the loan servicer, resulting in a continuous cycle of deflection and inaction. This lack of resolution constitutes a clear breach of the terms of the promissory note. I have demanded that StudentAid.gov immediately certify my compliance with the 120-payment requirement and notify my loan servicer to execute the discharge of my loans without further delay. I submitted a complaint to StudentAid.gov and their response was to contact my loan servicer.

Consumer complaint narrative: I currently have over XXXX in loans that continue to accure interest, and AidVantage is not giving me an option to reasonably pay this back. I currently make about XXXX dollars a year, and was hoping to make monthly payments so I could pay it off. I applied for Income Driven Repayment program, so I could make monthly payments. However, AidVantage is not currently processing applications. I asked them if there was any way I could make reasonable monthly payments. They said no. They placed me on processing forbearance that allows my loans to continue to grow in interest. I asked them if they could at least put my loans in administrative forbearance so my loans would not grow interest, and they also said no. Per the guidelines, people can be placed in administrative forbearance if your loan servicer time needs time to process a repayment plan. Other people with a similar situation have, so I feel this is unfair.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am submitting this formal complaint against MOHELA, my federal student loan servicer, due to their repeated failure to address a critical issue regarding the misallocation of my loan payments and their unacceptable customer service practices.For the past XXXX weeks ( since XX/XX/year> ), I have attempted to resolve this issue by calling MOHELA more than XXXX times. 

Each time, I am forced to wait XXXX hours for a callback, only to be told that I need to be transferred to another representative. This transfer results in another XXXX hold, after which the call inevitably drops. Despite these repeated failed attempts, MOHELA has refused to offer a direct callback from the person responsible for handling my issue. 

I also attempted to resolve this matter via email, but they informed me that assistance is only available by phonedespite the fact that their phone system has proven ineffective.The core issue is that MOHELA has been automatically applying my loan payments to my lower-interest loans instead of my older, higher-interest loans. This misallocation has cost me additional interest, and each day that this remains unresolved, I am incurring further financial harm.MOHELAs failure to address my concerns, the excessive hold times, their refusal to provide callbacks, and their lack of alternative resolution methods constitute unfair treatment and grossly inadequate customer service. 

As a federal loan servicer, they have a responsibility to assist borrowers in managing their debt effectively, and their continued inaction is a direct violation of that responsibility.I am requesting the CFPBs intervention to ensure that MOHELA : Immediately reallocates my past payments to my higher-interest loans. 

Provides written confirmation that the correction has been made. 

Ensures that future payments are applied according to my instructions. 

Improves its customer service processes to prevent excessive hold times and the refusal of direct assistance.

Since XX/XX/XXXX, I have been calling Mohela and FSA about several years of missing payments in my history. They would blame each other. Now FSA is in charge of the PSLF payment counts. 

The missing time period is XX/XX/XXXX through XX/XX/XXXX. That time period doesn't exist for my PSLF counter and my XXXX counter. It should be present for both. Picture attached. 

I was employed by a qualifying employer and made payments to consolidated FFELP loans during that time period. 

I consolidated again to get into PSLF which caused the payment count to reset. That was XXXX. 

The IDR One-Time Payment Adjustment, which was announced in XX/XX/XXXX, was supposed to restore those years of missing payments made with qualifying employer if you loans are currently held by FSA and are consolidated, which my loans are. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ) Recently, I resubmitted my ECF forms from that time period and they still aren't counting them. I have a boilerplate statement from them saying those payments don't count because they were FFELP at that time. That document is attached.

However, I was given credit for five months, XXXX when I was previously employed by another qualifying employer and held consolidated FFELP loans at that time ( that picture is attached ). I should have credit for those missing years in my payment history. 

I have filed several complaints ( XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX ) with FSA which go nowhere. I should have been at XXXX at XX/XX/XXXX and my loans should be forgiven. I have working to get this resolved since XXXX. Any help is appreciated. Mohela and FSA aren't providing the quality service their clients deserve.

I want NelNet to restart my payments. I want to be on PSLF, this way I can make payments, and begin the ten year clock for getting my loans forgiven.

Currently, my loans are in deferral. I have contacted Nelnet and told them that I want payments to be restarted under a PSLF plan ( which, being a municipal government employee, I qualify for ), and they will not do so. My loan payments were put on deferral sometime in mid XXXX until XXXX, XXXX. Today ( XX/XX/XXXX ), I just checked, and now payments will not begin until XX/XX/XXXX. 

I want scheduled payments to begin, so i can make my ten years of payments under PSLF and have my loans forgiven.

It is worth noting I have previously complained about a similar issue ( I believe it was under my other email, XXXX ). I went through the CFPB, and when I did they resumed my payments earlier. I would like the same thing to happen in this instance.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I graduated medical school in XXXX of XXXX with {$150000.00} of federal student loans through MOHELA. Proactively, before I graduated, I attempted to enroll in the SAVE plan XX/XX/XXXX so that I could waive my 6 month grace period and start counting payments towards the XXXX which would qualify me for PSLF loan forgiveness. This application was not processed for unclear reasons and I even attempted to resubmit an IDR plan request XX/XX/XXXX. This was also not processed because allegedly I had to consolidate my loans to " waive '' my new graduate grace period. Nonetheless, as such, I went ahead and consolidated my loans and timely applied for SAVE. This application has not been processed since early XX/XX/XXXX and I have accrued more than {$1900.00} in interest while working for a recognized underserved area in Florida as a resident physician. According to https : //www.ed.gov/higher-education/manage-your-loans/save-plan, " If servicers need time to process a borrowers IDR application, servicers will move the borrower into a processing forbearance for up to 60 days. Interest accrues during this short-term processing forbearance, and time in the processing forbearance is eligible for PSLF and IDR forgiveness. If the borrowers application is not processed by their servicer within 60 days, the borrower will be moved into a general forbearance that does not count toward PSLF or IDR until their application is processed. Interest will not accrue in this general forbearance. '' My loans have not been processed for XXXX months and have been actively accruing interest. I expressed this to my mohela representative XX/XX/XXXX while experiencing stress about my incoming loan payment of {$950.00} due on XX/XX/XXXX, and she had no idea about this forbearance policy that I quoted directly from ed.gov. Myself and several thousand other new physicians will not be able to pay close to 1,000 or so dollars per month on our resident physician salaries of ~ $ XXXX. In addition, this same representative stated that she could only place my account under administrative forbearance 3 times ( each 60 day periods ) within a 18 month window. I have already exhausted XXXX of my 60 day administrative forbearances. If this is the case, and the injunction and legal proceedings take XXXX months ( which is expected ), I will be ruined financially while working to serve the underserved in XXXX of the counties in XXXX  that have the greatest need for physicians. This would be disastrous for myself and every other resident physician that has graduated with student loans. As such, I would like to file a formal complaint so that myself and thousands of other new physicians can be protected from MOHELA 's negligence and active mishandling/misinformation regarding our student loans. Please help. This subset of XXXX graduates who have not been able to enroll in IBR plans due to mohela 's negligence is experiencing unjust circumstances that need to be investigated. 

This CFPB complaint regarding the above was closed with no tangible impact or help whatsoever. My balance is now {$150000.00} as of XX/XX/XXXX with a staggering {$960.00} due amount for XX/XX/XXXX showing that mohela is negligently charging and accruing interest on accounts that are in the midst of processing for the SAVE plan. Mohela has been unable to process this since early XX/XX/XXXX and thus after the XXXX  days of admin processing, I should no longer be accruing interest. My plan is still processing at this time and there should be no reason for a {$960.00} due balance as I should be in a general forbearance per " If the borrowers application is not processed by their servicer within 60 days, the borrower will be moved into a general forbearance that does not count toward PSLF or IDR until their application is processed. Interest will not accrue in the SAVE forbearance. '' found on XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXX schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding Borrower Defense applications and provide full relief for those impacted. 
Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX The Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXXXXXX XXXX misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX  falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within six months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 
At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in XXXX states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts.

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions. 
Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans. 
Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts. 
Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the XXXX XXXX, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it. 
We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays. 
Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 
Sincerely, Students & Graduates of XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally file a complaint regarding a potential data breach and unauthorized access to my student loan information. I have reason to believe that XXXX XXXX, or entities associated with him, may have gained access to my personal and financial data without my consent. This raises serious concerns about privacy violations, data security, and compliance with federal regulations, including the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( GLBA ) and the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ). 

My personal and financial information was compromised without any authorization. 

The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) protects the confidentiality of student records. This breach is a clear violation of FERPA and your responsibility to safeguard my information. 

I urge your office to investigate this matter to determine whether my student loan data has been improperly accessed and to hold any responsible parties accountable. Additionally, I request the following : A full disclosure of how my information was accessed and used. 
Immediate corrective action to prevent further unauthorized access. 
Assistance in protecting my personal and financial data from further exposure. 
Please confirm receipt of this complaint and provide any next steps regarding the investigation. I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter, as it is critical to protecting my rights and the security of my financial information.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I reached out to Mohela on more than one occasion. Like many, I am being harmed by the SAVE program being on hold. During this time, Im stuck in limbo collecting thousands in interest while they determine if I ( A ) qualify for this loan ( my understanding is I qualified by the very fact that I was approved ) or ( B ) the ridiculous lawsuits put my payments on hold while they are still accruing interest.

In addition to that, the SAVE plan is supposed to cover additional interest if the payment is lower than the total interest, which had yet to happen while the payments were active.

I feel I was lied to and have likely added at least 1-2 years of additional payments, or more, as a result.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
I started repaying my student loans to XXXX in XXXX of XXXX. I then consolidated my loans in XXXX of XXXX, which were transferred to Mohela. XXXX continued to automatically charge me for my loans into XXXX of XXXX before I was able to stop those payments. When I was able to speak with someone at XXXX about where the money went after my loans were no longer with them, I was told that all of the payments that I had made since XXXX of XXXX to XXXX were misallocated to another barrower. They would not tell me who the other barrower was and tried to blame me for allowing it to happen. Now, I have NEVER offered to pay for someone else 's loans, the only automatic payment I had set up were for my own loans. This was a mistake on XXXX end, and they would not own up to it. In XXXX of XXXX, I spoke with XXXX and requested that all of the misallocated funds be transferred to Mohela, my new loan servicer. They completed the request and told me it would take 60 business days for the funds to reflect on my account. It has been over 75 business days and the funds are still not reflected on my student loan account with Mohela. I spent over a week and over 20 hours on hold with Mohela to try and speak with someone who could help me. I was finally able to connect with someone on XX/XX/XXXX after being on hold for almost 7 straight hours. The person that I spoke to ultimately told me that they have no idea where the funds that were transferred from XXXX are and thus there needs to be an investigation. 
This is wholly unacceptable. First my money was given to someone else through no fault of my own, and now they can't even find the money that was transferred to them on my behalf. Due to the payments going to another barrower, this calls into question the credibility of my consolidation as well.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XX/XX/year> To : CFBP Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Data Breach, FERPA and Title IV Violations, and Request for Immediate Discharge of Student Loans Dear CFBP, I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the U.S. Department of Education ( DOE ) and the Department of Governmental Entities ( DOGE ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security. 
I recently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes but is not limited to : 1. My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ). 
2. My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including financial aid history and loan information. 
3. My IRS tax transcripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization. 
These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards. 
Given the severity of this breach and the direct impact on my financial security and privacy, I demand the following corrective actions : 1. Immediate discharge and cancellation of all my federal student loans due to the breach of my financial aid and tax records, which invalidates the integrity of my loan agreements. 
2. A formal investigation into this data breach, including details on how my records were accessed, who accessed them, and for what purpose. 
3. A full report on the extent of my data exposure and the corrective measures being implemented to prevent future violations. 
4. Immediate notification to all major credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX XXXX ) to place a fraud alert and investigate any unauthorized activity that may have resulted from this breach. 
This breach has caused significant distress and concern regarding the security of my personal and financial data. If my demands are not met within 30 days, I will be left with no choice but to escalate this matter through legal channels, including filing complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and pursuing legal action against the responsible parties. 
I request a written response addressing these concerns and outlining the immediate actions being taken to remedy this situation. Please direct all correspondence to the address listed above. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this urgent matter. I look forward to your immediate response and resolution. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Consumer complaint narrative: I applied to switch my repayment plan from SAVE to IBR repayment plan on XX/XX/XXXX so I can continue to pay my loans. I have seen no movement on that. I was told they only started processing applications on XX/XX/XXXX. While I understand that, I asked customer service about a recent email from the Department of Education that was sent on XX/XX/XXXX ( Subject line : Update on the Saving on a Valuable Education Plan ) that states : " If you submit an application to enroll in an IDR plan other than SAVE, but your loan servicer is unable to process your application within 10 business days of receiving the application or before your next billing statement will be sent, you will be moved into a processing forbearance for up to 60 days. During this period, you do not have to make your monthly payments on your student loans, interest is accruing, and time spent does provide credit toward PSLF* and IDR. '' I was told that MOHELA could not move me from SAVE forbearance, although this email from the Department of Education stated that my servicer should move me as it has been XXXX business days since XX/XX/XXXX ( when I first applied to IBR ) and XXXX business days since MOHELA says they were able to start processing applications. I was transferred to another customer service agent at XXXX XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX ( after being on hold for nearly two hours to even get to the first customer service representative ) to get further information. I was told the wait time would be XXXX hour and XXXX minutes. It is the close of the business day, and I have never received a call back. I will have to call again tomorrow, or the following day, and continue to wait hours on hold to try to get an answer.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Consumer complaint narrative:
This is a reply to the CFPB via # XXXX please be advised Under the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and Consumer Protection Act, the CFPB has the authority to take action against institutions violating consumer financial laws, including engaging in unfair, deceptive, or abusive acts or practices. The Bureau found that Edfinancial violated the Consumer Financial Protection Act by engaging in deceptive acts and practices. Edfinancial encouraged borrowers to reach out to it for help managing their student loans, and it indicated that it was an expert and could assist borrowers navigating complex student-loan repayment options. FFELP borrowers reasonably relied on Edfinancial to act in their best interests by providing them with complete and accurate information about how to qualify for PSLF and about all the available forgiveness options. Specifically, the company harmed student loan borrowers by : Misrepresenting that FFELP borrowers could not receive PSLF : When borrowers with FFELP loans asked about PSLF, Edfinancial, in many instances, told them they were ineligible, and the company did not tell them they could become eligible by consolidating their loans into Direct Loans and meeting other qualifying requirements. Sometimes, Edfinancial falsely told borrowers their FFELP loans could not be consolidated. These statements, misrepresentations, and omissions created the false impression for borrowers with FFELP loans that they could not obtain PSLF.

Misrepresenting that FFELP borrowers were making payments towards PSLF before loan consolidation : Edfinancial, in both explicit and implicit statements, told borrowers that their payments on FFELP loans would count toward the 10 years of monthly payments required to obtain PSLF. Many borrowers were likely led to believe they were making progress toward PSLF when in fact they were not because they had not consolidated their FFELP loans into Direct Loans.

Misrepresenting to borrowers that certain jobs were not eligible for PSLF : In numerous instances, Edfinancial explicitly stated that certain jobs would not qualify for PSLF when they in fact did. In other instances, Edfinancial failed to include entire job categories, such as non-profit work, when discussing PSLF qualifying jobs. Edfinancials statements likely caused many eligible borrowers to not consider PSLF as a forgiveness possibility.

Describing forgiveness programs to FFELP borrowers without mentioning PSLF : When FFELP borrowers asked about forgiveness options available to them, Edfinancial representatives often described forgiveness options available only for FFELP loans and failed to mention PSLF. The companys statements and omissions created the impression that PSLF was not an option for many FFELP borrowers. FFELP borrowers may have elected not to pursue PSLF because they were either unaware of PSLF or did not think the program applied to them.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I attended XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, previously owned by XXXX and feel I have been scammed with taking out my loans. The amount I owe is astronomical and am having a tough time paying it back. 


XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXX XXXX  misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within XXXX months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 

At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in XXXX states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Summary and Statements of Facts

Consumer complaint narrative:
To the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXX schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding XXXX XXXX applications and provide full relief for those impacted. 

Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : * XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX has XXXX found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXX XXXX  misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within XXXX months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 

At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in XXXX states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Summary and Statements of Facts. 

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : XXXX. Approve all outstanding XXXX XXXX applications for students who attended these institutions. 
XXXX. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans. 
XXXX. Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts. 

Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the XXXX XXXX, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it. 

We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays. 

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 

Sincerely, Students & Graduates of XXXX XXXX

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative: When my income based student loan payment ( IDR ) came up for renewal for the first time, I believe the summer of 2017, instead of getting an email ( or letter ) stating that a renewal application was due, I received only an email saying there was a new document available to be viewed in my online account. The wording in this email was so similar to the generic language included in my monthly billing statement, that I did not realize the document it referenced was a notice about the renewal process and deadline for continuing in IBR. I then received a billing statement for approximately {$2000.00} instead of the approximately {$500.00} I had been paying with IBR, as I had missed the renewal window. When I called Navient in a panic because I could not afford the higher monthly amount, the representative on the phone told me it would be no problem to pause my payments for a month or two so I could reapply for the IBR program. No warnings about the implications about the pause were provided and I agreed and was approved for IBR and back down to my normal payments within 2 months. At no time was I informed I was bring placed in a forbearance that would cause my entire loan balance to by recapitalized, increasing the cost of my loans but more than {$50000.00}. It wasn't until I was reviewing my loan details months later that I realized what had happened. The capitalization has essentially guaranteed that I will never cover more than the interest payments on my loans during the 20 years of payments I'll be making. I believe Navient engaged in misleading and predatory practices by offering a " pause '' at the push of a button over the phone with no explanation about the consequences and no paperwork spelling out the capitalization process that it would trigger.

Consumer complaint narrative: I am a student loan borrower who is serviced through MOHELA. I have been on the SAVE plan since it's introduction. I am currently in the SAVE forbearance due to litigation with the SAVE program. I have made no changes to my status, only filed my income recertification in XXXX of XXXX, while still applying to the SAVE program that I had already been on. I got word on XX/XX/XXXX that my autopay was set to resume on XX/XX/XXXX ( less than 30 day notice ). I got no notification of why this was happening, or if I was actually brought out of forbearance. According to everything online, SAVE litigation is ongoing and I have XXXX obligation to restart payments if I don't want to/did not request to change plans. I am working toward PSLF and going into repayment will not count towards my PSLF forgiveness, and as such, I do NOT want to be brought back into repayment. I did not ask for this, I did not file a new application for a new IDR plan. I have no idea why this is happening. I am writing this after having been on hold with MOHELA for almost 9 hours for the second day in a row with no resolution. The one time I got ahold of a representative, I was only told that it does apear that I am going back into repayment, but no one can tell me why or prevent it until I talk to an " advanced representative '' who I can not get ahold of. I removed my bank account from my MOHELA account and will dispute any charges.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I attended XXXX  XXXX XXXX ( XXXX campus and XXXX Campus ) XXXX XXXX and was approved for Pell Grant funds totaling {$1700.00} and {$2900.00}, which were released on XX/XX/year> per an email from XXXX XXXX on XX/XX/year>. Due to threats and discrimination by the campus director, I reported my concerns to XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, before returning to campus. On XX/XX/year>, XXXX confirmed the disbursement but instructed me to return to the XXXX location, where I felt unsafe. 

I attended classes that week but was later informed that my funds were for the school, not me. The following week, I was withdrawn without my consent and removed from campus. The police were falsely informed that I was never a student. On XX/XX/year>, XXXX XXXX ( Corporate Campus Director ) emailed me, stating my Pell Grant was refunded, showing four transactions : two received, two refunded. However, I never agreed to withdraw, nor was I given an option to use my aid for continued enrollment. 

Additionally : I was billed {$290.00} despite not receiving required materials such as a student U-Pass or textbooksonly printed copies, which were falsely categorized as books. 
The IRS records show two loans were paid off with a {$1700.00} W-2, contradicting the schools claim that my loan was canceled. Federal Student Aid ( FSA ) confirmed my loan was reported as canceled, yet I have documentation proving funds were paid and should have been disbursed to me. 
Instead, the school kept my funds and repaid them in cash, raising concerns of misallocation of federal funds and financial misconduct. 

Violations : Misuse or Misallocation of Federal Funds Pell Grant funds were received but improperly handled. 
Unauthorized Loan Processing or Fraudulent Activity My loan was reportedly canceled, yet records indicate payments were made.

Failure to Provide Required Financial Aid Information The school provided misleading and conflicting statements.

Wrongful Billing or Balance Discrepancies I was charged for materials not received.

Breach of Contract I was withdrawn against my will, preventing me from completing my education.

Falsification of Records The school misrepresented my enrollment status to police and financial institutions. 

I request a full investigation into XXXX  XXXX XXXX handling of federal student aid, a refund of any funds owed to me, and corrections to my student loan and financial records. 

I have videos, emails and text messages

Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/year>, the XXXX XXXX reported that XXXXXXXX XXXX  XXXX team was granted unauthorized access to the XXXX  XXXX XXXX student loan database, which contains personally identifiable information ( PII ) of federal student loan borrowers, including my Social Security number, date of birth, financial aid history, and loan balance. 

I was never notified that my student loan records would be accessed by third-party contractors, nor was I given the opportunity to approve or deny this access. This is a direct violation of the XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ), which prohibits the disclosure of student loan data without written consent. 

This unauthorized access has placed my financial and personal security at risk, raising concerns about identity theft, misuse of my student loan data, and potential fraud. 

Failure to address this violation would indicate gross negligence in protecting borrowers private financial data. I request that the CFPB investigate this matter, take corrective action, and hold the responsible entities accountable for mishandling my personal information.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
