Consumer complaint narrative:
I want EdFinancial to return the {$30000.00} to my home address. I also want direct contact with the person handling my case to complete this transaction. I have been waiting over a year for these checks to come through. I have submitted numerous complaints to the FSA website and one to CFPB. 
On XX/XX/XXXX, I submitted a complaint to FSA ( case # XXXX ). I received a response on XX/XX/XXXX, stating that their review determined that they located the two submitted checks amounting to {$30000.00} from XXXX and have issued a refund back to XXXX. I waited until XXXX to call EdFinancial for a status update, but the customer service representatives were no help, and there was no one else to talk to get an update. I have attached their XXXX response. 
On XX/XX/XXXX, I submitted a complaint to CFPB ( case # XXXX ) detailing the events that occurred. EdFinancial responded on XX/XX/XXXX, and stated an error was identified when processing the refund to XXXX. No one from XXXX reached out, saying there was an issue refunding the money to XXXX. Do they need wiring instructions or an account number? Instead, the solution was to send the money to XXXX, and XXXX would then send to XXXX. The letter from EdFinancial states the money was sent on XX/XX/XXXX, and will take about 60 days to complete. Sixty days from XX/XX/XXXX is on XXXX XXXX. I have attached their XXXX response. 
On XX/XX/XXXX, I submitted a complaint to FSA ( case # XXXX ). Since it was closer to the 60 days, I decided to get a status update on the refund to XXXX. Their review confirmed on XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX payments totaling {$30000.00} were sent to XXXX via the XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ). However, it can take up to 60 days from XX/XX/XXXX. I have attached their XXXX response. 
I called EdFinancial a couple of days after the XXXX XXXX since it was past the 60-day window EdFinancial stated in two separate letters. I spoke to the escalation team, who informed me that it was 60 business days, and I must wait for the transaction to go through. I can not speak to anyone at the XXXX XXXX XXXX and the XXXX Department. 
Sixty business days from XXXX XXXX were on XX/XX/XXXX, and there is no wire transfer from EdFinancial to XXXX. This is unacceptable! I need someone to be direct on the items required to resolve this situation instead of me waiting MONTHS to figure out that there was an issue.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I wanted my son to have a good education. The school he picked was expensive, so I took out parent plus loans. 

Then the government started a new program called XXXX. I tried to sign up for it. I was told my loans don't qualify because they are parent plus. But I was also by student aid.gov and nelnet told that if I consolidated those loans, I could apply. So I did. 

And was immediately told I could not apply for XXXX because my loans USED to be parent plus. 

I feel I was lied to about the situation, and it would have been easier for me to pay my loans if they were separate, but I consolidated for a shot at forgiveness. 

I have moved since taking out the loans, remarried. I have a severely XXXX stepson I care for, but all of the different forgiveness programs are barred to me. I am in worse shape now than when this started, and it's all because of misleading information ( never mind how predatory parent plus turned out to be after I took the loans ). 

Now my monthly payment don't quite cover the interest, so the balance is slowly growing instead of reducing. 

This is a massive case of " if I had only known ... ''

Consumer complaint narrative:
I had noticed that after my loans had transitioned from XXXX to Mohela that my payment counts weren't accurate. When I called about it, I was told that my loan had been placed in a short forebearance ( 2 months ) after I had started to make payments. However, they could not tell me why. They said that is likely why my PSLF payment counts didn't add up to my counts. 

When I called some time later, I was told that previously unaccounted for payments ( due to the presidentaly administration at the time ) would likely count once my account was reviewed. That was around XXXX Some time after that phone call, I XXXX XXXX XXXX. I had applied for several scholarships and to do that, I had to fill out another FAFSA form. That notified Mohela and they put my loan in deferrment. I called and asked that they be taken out of deterrent, but to keep the COVID payment suspension ( because I knew they counted for my PSLF payment count ). On advisement from one of Mohela 's representatives, I submitted a letter with the request. After the letter was received, my loan came out of deferment only for it to go back into deferment. I called again and told them that I requested for my loan to permanemntly come out of deferment. My request was granted again. 

Nevertheless, I continued making payments. I waited patiently for Mohela to update my payment counts, but they never were. Then the injunction occurred and my account went into forebearance again. I called in XXXX of XXXX asking again why payments did add up and was told it was because I didn't recertify my employment for XXXX. I was told that was I did that then my payment counts would be accurate. 

As of today, Mohela states I've only made XXXX of the XXXX payments needed for my PSLF obligation. However, I went through 10 years of my bank statements and documented every payment I made to the Department of Education and counted XXXX payments ( XXXX of those were under the COVID forebearance ). Additionally, the first 12 months of my loan, my monthly payment was {$0.00} because I had earned so little the previous year. All of this adds up to XXXX payments. 

I submitted my employment recertification in XX/XX/XXXX and it has yet to be processed. When I called to ask why it was taking so long, I was told it would be another 45 days for it to be processed. When nothing happened, I submitted a XXXX recertification in XX/XX/XXXX and that is still waiting to be processed. I tried to resumbit a third one, this time stating that I had made my XXXX payments, however, Mohela 's system would not allow my proceed with my online application. 

Then, when Mohela transitioned to the student.gov platform, all the correspondence between myself and Mohela went away, and my paytment is far from accurate. My account does not accurately reflect my records. We're not even close. 

With these federal loans in limbo, I am unable to make any other major financial purchases since I have absolutely clue when my account will become accurate. 

I have included an XXXX XXXX detailing every payment I made to Mohela ( including the months my XXXX amount was {$0.00}, the 2 months I was on an unknown forebearance, all the months during COVID forebearance ). Additionally, I have included the inaccuracies that Mohela is reporting on my account in terms of my payment history and payment counts. Since my correspondence history prior to XXXX has been wipe clean, I am submitting a copy of the letter I sent to Mohela requesting permanment in-school foreberance while requesting retroactively replacing COVID forebearance.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing a formal complaint against Nelnet and the U.S. Department of Education for allowing unauthorized access to my student loan records, violating my rights under the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ) and failing to properly protect my personal financial and loan information. 

I recently became aware that DOGE ( associated with XXXX XXXX office ) accessed student loan records, including mine, without my consent. This is a serious breach of data security and privacy, and both Nelnet and the Department of Education are responsible for failing to prevent this unauthorized access. 

Key Issues & Violations : Unauthorized Access to My Loan Records My student loan data was accessed by unauthorized personnel who are not legally permitted to view or handle my records. 
FERPA requires written consent before student loan records are shared with any party. I never authorized this access. 
Failure to Secure My Private Loan Information Nelnet and the U.SXXXX Department of Education failed to implement the necessary data security measures to prevent unauthorized individuals from viewing, using, or sharing my personal financial details. 
This puts me at risk for identity theft, fraud, and financial harm. 
Potential Data Sharing on Public or Shared Documents There is concern that my student loan records may have been included in shared databases, public repositories, or mailing lists, exposing my information beyond authorized use. 
Negligence in Handling My Student Loan Account As a result of this data mishandling, I am unable to trust that my loan balance, terms, and records have been properly maintained by Nelnet and the Department of Education. 
This has directly impacted my ability to manage and make informed decisions regarding my student loans. 
Actions I Have Taken : I am reporting this issue to the U.S. Department of Education, the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and my state Attorney Generals Office for further investigation. 
I am requesting a full review of Nelnet and the Department of Educations data security policies to determine how this breach occurred and what steps will be taken to prevent future unauthorized access.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Immediate Action Needed : Approve Outstanding Borrower Defense Applications To the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXXaffiliated schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding Borrower Defense applications and provide full relief for those impacted. 
Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  The Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXXXXXX XXXX misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within six months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 

At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in 26 states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts. 

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : 1. Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions.

2. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans.

3. Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts.

Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the XXXX XXXX, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it. 

We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays. 

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 

Sincerely, Students & Graduates of XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Immediate Action Needed : Approve Outstanding Borrower Defense Applications To the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  Compliance, We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and XXXX  who attended XXXX XXXX, urging immediate action to approve outstanding Borrower Defense applications and provide full relief for those impacted. 

Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : * XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX The Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXXXXXX XXXX misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within six months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 

At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in XXXX  states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts. 

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions.

Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans.

Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts.

Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the American Dream, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it.

We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays.

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX & XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I submitted an application to change my Income Driven Payment plan on XX/XX/year>. The application went from XXXX to my loan servicer, EdFinancial. I received confirmation from EdFinancial that they received the application and it is showing as processing in their system. According to the FSA guidance to loan servicers, they are supposed to place accounts in a Processing Forbearance that counts towards PSLF progress while the application is being processed ( see website linked below and quote from website ). I have submitted multiple requests over email with EdFinancial to be placed in Processing Forbearance while my application is being processed. In my latest correspondence, they said the request was denied, and refuse to provide any explanation for why the request is denied. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX " If servicers need time to process a borrowers IDR application, servicers will move the borrower into a processing forbearance for up to 60 days. Interest accrues during this short-term processing forbearance, and time in the processing forbearance that does provide IDR and PSLF credit. ''

Consumer complaint narrative:
U.S. Department of Education XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX Subject : Dispute of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  Discharge Denial Dear Department of Education , I am writing to dispute the denial of my application for XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ( XXXX  ) discharge of my student loans. This form, XXXX XXXX. XXXX, designates myself as my representative. 

I believe the denial of my application is unwarranted. I have provided documentation from [ Name of Physician/Medical Professional ] demonstrating my XXXX and its impact on my ability to engage in substantial gainful activity. [ Specifically mention the disabling condition ( s ) as documented in the application and any subsequent correspondence. For example : " My disabling conditions include [ List conditions ] which severely limit my ability to [ Explain specific limitations, e.g., stand for extended periods, concentrate, perform repetitive tasks, etc. ]. '' ] [ Clearly and concisely explain the reasons you believe the denial was incorrect. Provide specific examples and refer to the supporting documentation you have submitted. For example : " The denial letter stated that my medical documentation was insufficient. However, I submitted [ Mention specific documents, e.g., doctor 's reports, medical evaluations, diagnostic test results ] which clearly outline my diagnosis and the functional limitations resulting from my XXXX. These documents demonstrate that my condition meets the criteria for XXXX  discharge as defined by the Department of Education. '' ] If you have any additional documentation that you did not include in your original application, include copies of those documents with this letter. Clearly state what each document is and how it supports your claim. For example : " I am also including [ XXXX XXXX XXXX ] which provides further evidence of [ Specific aspect of XXXX ] and [ XXXX XXXX XXXX ] which clarifies [ Another aspect of XXXX ]. '' ] I respectfully request that you reconsider my application for TPD discharge. I am confident that the documentation I have provided, both in my original application and with this dispute letter, sufficiently demonstrates that I meet the criteria for discharge due to my XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. 

Please acknowledge receipt of this dispute and inform me of the next steps in the review process.

Consumer complaint narrative:
My name is : XXXX XXXXk & my daughter is : XXXX XXXX. She attended XXXX XXXX and that is whom the borrower 's defense against repayment complaint is against. I did XXXX weeks ago submit a complaint on this issue. The complaint number is : XXXX. The reason for a follow-up complaint is that the Department of Education and XXXX and ombudsman, ... .... NEVER respond or take responsibility for adjudicating individual complaints. My XXXX XXXX XXXX to XXXX XXXX # is : XXXX. My daughter, XXXX XXXX also has a case. 
Our complaints remain unanswered and in jeopardy while class groups with XXXX claims in commom continue to be processed and discharged at an expedited rate. This is disparate treatment and it is IMPERATIVE at this point, considering the political climate and threats of closing the Department of Education create insurmountable harm. 
Treatment of Individual XXXX Claims : Despite submitting multiple complaints, contacting the FSA Ombudsman three times ( only to receive incorrect and misleading information ), leaving five messages for my caseworker without a single response, and escalating my concerns repeatedly, I have received no substantive update on my case. This is a clear failure of due process and a denial of my rights to fair and timely adjudication under the XXXX program. 

*I recognize that the Department of Education has up to three years to process XXXX applications. However, the current prioritization of class action XXXX  cases over individual cases is fundamentally inequitable and discriminatory in its impact. The Department has demonstrated that it can adjudicate XXXX  claims in significantly less time than XXXX years when addressing class action settlementsyet individual cases, such as mine, are left in indefinite uncertainty. This selective and disproportionate allocation of resources is unjust, unreasonable, and must be corrected immediately. 
The continued delay in processing my application has caused substantial and measurable harm including : *Illegally accrued interest exceeding {$20000.00}, despite clear regulatory provisions that interest should not accrue beyond XXXX months after a XXXX application is submitted or during in-school deferment. 

*Severe emotional and financial distress, as my daughter faces unjust and crushing debt for an education she never truly received due to XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
XXXX and lasting harm to my daughters mental health, as a direct result of the abuse and illegal actions perpetrated by XXXX XXXX XXXX *My legitimate concern is that it is seemingly discriminatory, at least unequitable * The indefensible position of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX actions, marked by the firing of a Director to the President of the College, for creating a hostile work environment, yet my daughters suffering remains unaddressed.

*The risk of losing rightful discharge due to administrative and political shifts, leaving us without relief solely because our case is being handled unfairly compared to mass claims.

Given these violations of fairness, I am formally demanding : 1. Immediate adjudication of my Borrower Defense case to rectify the inequitable delays that have unfairly burdened my family. The ongoing failure to act constitutes administrative negligence and a violation of my civil rights.

2. A detailed, written explanation as to why class action XXXX claims are prioritized over individual claims and how this aligns with the Departments obligation to fairness. 
XXXX. A formal response providing the exact status of my case and an estimated timeline for adjudicationa right that should not require persistent, unanswered outreach to obtain. 
XXXX. Confirmation that all unlawfully accrued interest will be removed in accordance with BDTR provisions. 

The Department of Education FSA operates under a systemic obligation to fairness. Failure to process individual XXXX applications equitably constitutes discriminatory treatment by the Department of Education and places undue hardship on borrowers who are not part of mass claims. The three-year processing window is no longer relevant when class action claims are being resolved in a fraction of that time, leaving individual borrowers in an indefensible position of delay and uncertainty. 

If I do not receive a timely and substantive response, I will escalate this matter further, including seeking legal representation. 
A formal response providing the exact status of my case and an estimated timeline for adjudicationa right that should not require persistent, unanswered outreach to obtain. 
Confirmation that all unlawfully accrued interest will be removed in accordance with XXXX  provisions. 
This systemic failure to process individual XXXX  applications equitably constitutes discriminatory treatment by the Department of Education and places undue hardship on borrowers who are not part of mass claims. The three-year processing window is no longer relevant when class action claims are being resolved in a fraction of that time, leaving individual borrowers at a disadvantage and in danger of losing their rights to a discharge, especially in this mess! 
If I do not receive a timely and substantive response, I will escalate this matter further, including seeking legal intervention, engaging with elected representatives, and pursuing media exposure of this clear failure to ensure due process for all borrowersnot just those benefiting from class action settlements. 

I expect written confirmation of receipt and a formal response upon receipt of this letter. Please direct all correspondence to my email at XXXX or my phone at XXXX. 

I trust that the Department will act in accordance with its duty to protect borrowers, uphold its own policies, and ensure the XXXX administration of the XXXX program. 

Sincerely,

Consumer complaint narrative:
NOTICE TO AGENT IS NOTICE TO PRINCIPAL AND NOTICE TO PRINCIPAL IS NOTICE TO AGENT To whom this may concern This is a reply to the CFPB via # XXXX please be advised Under the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act, the CFPB has the authority to take action against institutions violating consumer financial laws, including engaging in unfair, deceptive, or abusive acts or practices. The Bureau found that Nelnet violated the Consumer Financial Protection Act by engaging in deceptive acts and practices. Nelnet is on record via CFPB stating and quote On behalf of your lender, the U.S. Department of Education ( the Department ). Your comp has be sued by the CFPB for the same reason before. 

That violates FDCPA 15 U.S.C 1692e ( 1 ) by falsely representing or implying that Nelnet are affiliated with the United States of America.

Nelnet is a loan servicer which in fact is a third party individual company that has no ownership nor common control by the U.S. Department of education.

15 U.S. Code 1692f - Unfair practices A debt collector may not use unfair or unconscionable means to collect or attempt to collect any debt. Without limiting the general application of the foregoing, the following conduct is a violation of this section : 15 U.S. Code 1692e ( 12 ) - False or misleading representations ( 12 ) The false representation or implication that accounts have been turned over to innocent purchasers for value. 

15 U.S. Code 6809 - Definitions ( 5 ) Nonaffiliated third party The term " nonaffiliated third party '' means any entity that is not an affiliate of, or related by common ownership or affiliated by corporate control with, the financial institution, but does not include a joint employee of such institution. 

Nelnet, XXXX, XXXX and XXXX are not affiliates of the U.S Department of Education nor are they " bureaus. The only true credit bureau is the CFPB and they DO NOT furnish consumer reports as stated in federal law. I have a right to privacy and Per the Privacy Act of 1974 as a federally protected consumer I am now revoking any and all authorization I the consumer may have given the U.S. Department of Education written, non written, verbal, and nonverbal per 5 U.S. Code 552a. Per the FCRA as a federally protected consumer. I am now opting out of any and all authorization I the consumer may have given you CitiBank, non written, verbal, and non verbal per 15 USC 6802. I shall also point out their responsibility pursuant 15 U.S. Code section Students ' financial records are confidential in accordance with the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ). FERPA is a federal law that protects the privacy of student education records, including financial record. So your company can not take my nonpublic personal information and furnish it on a public forum like XXXX XXXX and XXXX for everyone to see. 

The confidentiality of my nonpublic personal information is very important and prohibited by federal laws. FERPA protects the privacy of students ' education records, FERPA prohibits the disclosure of personally identifiable information without the student 's consent. 

The records covered by FERPA Financial aid applications Student account information Federal work-study payroll records Cost of attendance information Financial aid history information Documentation of professional judgment decisions 15 U.S. Code 1692k ( a ) AMOUNT OF DAMAGES Except as otherwise provided by this section, any debt collector who fails to comply with any provision of this subchapter with respect to any person is liable to such person in an amount equal to the sum of. 

By taking nonpublic personal information and attempting to collect a debt you have no legal right too and that I clearly dont owe and making a false statement and furnishing a consumer report is a direct violation that goes against the FDCPA AND FDCPA.

Consumer complaint narrative: I started attending XXXX in XXXX, XXXX for grad school. I never completed the first semester due to the administration office accusing me of plagiarism. They were terminating me from the program with a letter of termination. I was devastated because I assured them that it was untrue. I received the dismissal letter on XX/XX/scrub>XXXX XXXX XXXX and on XXXX XXXX XXXX  it was recanted. It was a glitch in their system so now they reinstated me. I was humiliated, discouraged, mentally dismayed, my dignity, my pride, my integrity insulted and several other things. You want me to continue in your program as if nothing happened. I felt away as anyone would and discontinued with the program. Now, they charged me the full semester ( or ) semesters charges for their XXXX program which i feel I should not be liable for due to their false accusations. I believe that they should have investigated first and had their facts straight. Instead they shook my world with that devastating blow and I never returned to any college due to that situation. I have proof of this incident with both letters if needed. I thank you for your time and cooperation in this matter. P.S. if you are wondering why bring it up after all these years? I tried and ran into blocks, I really didn't know where to go. I'm unsure if you guys can help but what do I have to loss. Praying that you guys can help or send me to where I can receive help in this matter. Thank you again.

Consumer complaint narrative: I signed up for Auto pay with ED Financial Services in XX/XX/XXXX. ( XX/XX/XXXX ) my payment was due on the XXXX and the date that was on the sign up page for that auto pay was XX/XX/XXXX due date. I was under the impression that auto pay was automatic, this company failed to inform me that it needed time to verify with my bank ( The XXXX I talked to XX/XX/XXXX told me that it takes time to kick in ) .The payment didn't get taken out of my account on XX/XX/XXXX and I realized it on XX/XX/XXXX. I logged in to find that not only was i NOT charged, but I was delinquent in my loan. I signed up for auto pay again after making my payment on XX/XX/XXXX and I asked about it in my call on XX/XX/XXXX and it STILL wasn't set up. NOWHERE on the sign up did it say that it was going to take a few months to sign me up for auto pay and that I needed to make any payments manually until auto pay " kicked in. '' So not only was I delinquent, but there was no interest rate reduction. How is it that I did everything right, but the company didn't let me in on auto pay not being automatic? This is a threat to my Credit report and my bank account. The XXXX I talked to wanted to Sign me up for auto pay again ... a THIRD time because she said it doesn't work to do it on the website ( the option to do so is still on their website ) there is nothing on the website that tells me I am enrolled or not. I asked to speak to a supervisor, but XXXX wasn't provided. This feels like a SCAM.

Consumer complaint narrative:
My loan servicer refuses to give me credit and cancel my debit. The number of credits needed for IDR loan forgiveness is 240 payments. They insist that the number of IDR credits of payment is 166 and that I owe 74 payment credits to qualify for loan forgiveness under the one-time-IDR adjustment. I sumitted proof that I was in repayment as of the year XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX copy of XXXX tax stub showing payment that I made payment. At the time my loans were direct loans and I was in the re-payee IDR plan. They sent me an email with a letter stating that while they acknowledge that I was in repayment since XXXX they can not give me credit for those payments because I was not in a qualifying plan at the time when the payments were made and that the payments made do not qualify towards this loan forgiveness. 

I have a direct loan that was in repayment since the year XXXX and I believe that the payment should reflect payments from that year. I consolidated the loan in XXXX of XXXX to ensure that I get credit for the IDR adjustment. My loan servicer ( Aidvantage ) says that the payments do not qualify in this IDR adjustment count, but the Student Aid website states that any loan that is a direct loan and that is in repayment and consolidated before XXXX XXXX XXXX qualifys for the One-time-Loan adjustment. The loan Servicer ( Aidvantage ) states that my loan do not qualify because they were not enrolled in a qualifying plan and due to not having a plan the payments made on the account are not counted towards forgiveness. I strongly disagree. The one-time account adjustment was implemented to take care of the errors and the repayment account can go back as far as XXXX. This is what I saw on the Student Aide.Gov website.

Issue: Improper use of your report

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute the legitimacy of my student loan obligations currently held by Nelnet. Due to serious legal violations and breaches of federal privacy laws, including the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and the Privacy Act of 1974, I hereby demand the immediate cancellation of all financial obligations and accrued interest related to these debts. 

It has come to my attention that my personal, educational, and financial information has been improperly accessed by unauthorized third parties, including XXXX, XXXX XXXX, and affiliated entities on XX/XX/XXXX. This unauthorized access constitutes a gross violation of my federal privacy rights and nullifies any enforceable loan agreements under federal law.

Legal Grounds for Discharge : FERPA Violation : The exposure of my educational records without my expressed written consent is a direct breach of FERPA, which mandates the protection of personally identifiable information of students.

Violation of the Privacy Act of 1974 : The mishandling and unauthorized disclosure of my personal information contravenes federal requirements that safeguard the privacy of individuals data managed by federal agencies and contractors.

Breach of Contract and Data Security Obligations : By failing to protect my sensitive information, Nelnet has breached contractual terms and obligations, rendering these debts unenforceable.

Consumer complaint narrative: I applied for PSLF loan forgiveness back through my servicer XXXX in early XXXX. However, it was delayed because the Federal Student Aid ( Department of Education ( DOE ) was now going to take over the PSLF process. None of my paperwork was transferred over and I had to start the process all over again and resubmit everything in XXXX of XXXX  now to DOE. My PSLF applications just sat there. So, I resubmitted my PSLF forms again in XXXX, and they were approved. However, DOE approved the forms to show them as complete even though they didn't complete the payment counts. I have made numerous phones calls, submitted numerous complaints and nothing has moved since XXXX. Every time I spoke with someone, I was given different information and different deadlines and excuses on how and why they're not evening meeting the timelines that they have set for themselves. As a struggling veteran this process has caused me undue hardship and an increase in fees and interest on my loans when my loans should have been discharged through the PSLF program. I have been a XXXX  employee for XXXX years now outside of my XXXX XXXX time. I just want what I qualify for and my student loans to be discharged.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Loan was transferred from XXXX to CRI. I have made on time payments since 2010. I make automatic payments. CRI sent a past due invoice. CRI notes that I am already signed up for automatic payments. I called CRI. Both the automated systems & later XXXX 's first questions was if I was going to make a payment on this past due amount. After much inquiry about this PAST DUE invoice they are telling me that it will be put forbearance at some point in the future. 

My complaint is this. My account is not past due. My account was transferred. The transfer forbearance should have been the first action taken by CRI, not the last. CRI sent me no notice that they are my new loan servicing company. My only paperwork from them is a past due invoice. The CRI invoice does not have any information on where to file a complaint with CRI. Their employees have no idea where to file a complaint -- so they must not have a written policy on complaints. The supervisor said that XXXX sent an email notice. Email is not a secure method of notification, and should have provided written notice.

Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, I received a letter in the mail stating that my XXXX loan was placed in default and sent to the national debt collection agency. I was appalled as I am currently in graduate school and all my loans shouldve been in forbearance beginning in XXXX of XXXX. I spoke with an agent about the options and alerted him that I am currently in school and not understanding how this happened. I chose the option to do a loan consolidation on the student.aid.gov website where I opted to send it to my other loan servicer for approval. 

I contacted XXXX ( the original servicer ) to inquire why this happened. I explained to the agent that Ive been enrolled since XXXX for grad school. He looked into it and stated that they never got the notification that I had enrolled in school therefore, they sent the loan to debt collection. He stated that they cant reverse it and XXXX have to speak with the debt collection agency for options.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/XXXX- I applied for XXXX. Submitted employment certification from XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX covering employment from XXXX. 

XX/XX/XXXX - PSLF payment tracker showed XXXX/XXXX qualifying payments. 39 months from XXXX were missing ( not eligible/ineligible - just missing entirely from account ). FSA advised that this would be corrected under one-time XXXX adjustment. 

XX/XX/XXXX - No update to account. Followed up with FSA in regard to the one-time adjustment. Was advised that the reason the months were missing was because I DIDN'T HAVE LOANS UNTIL XXXX ( despite graduating in XXXX ). Advised to reach out to provide documentation of the EXISTENCE of my loans and their repayment status during the missing months. 

XX/XX/XXXX - Submitted proof of loans and status ( economic hardship forbearance ) from XXXX to FSA along with a complaint. In all, four complaints were closed with no reason or resolution. My FSA records were not updated. Payment counts were not adjusted. Advised that my next step was to " just wait '' for the adjustment which would occur by XX/XX/XXXX. 

XX/XX/XXXX - Followed up with FSA. Was advised that the missing months were the result of a system error that would NOT be corrected by the one-time adjustment. Advised to submit reconsideration request and documentation of my loans during the missing months. 

One week later - Reconsideration closed with no resolution or reason. 

XX/XX/XXXX - Per the advice of FSA, submitted another reconsideration request. 

XX/XX/XXXX - Received notification that the one-time adjustment was complete. The months missing from my counts were NOT corrected. Told by FSA that the missing months qualify and should be accounted for in my counts, and to just keep waiting. 

XX/XX/XXXX - FSA rep confirmed that there is a system error impacting my counts and that my reconsideration had been sent for review. She could not provide a timeline for resolution. 

XX/XX/XXXX- Officially been waiting two years and three months for my account to be correctly credited for XX/XX/XXXX through XX/XX/XXXX. My loans were in a temporary economic forbearance for more than 36 months cumulatively. Per law, these months need to be applied as qualifying payments to my account.

Servicers will also process applications for recalculations for XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX. Servicers will have applications in the queue that will take some time to work through. XXXX for all other applications, including applications for XXXX ( formerly known as XXXX ) and applications where borrowers selected lowest monthly payment, will remain paused. Borrowers should check back here for updates. If servicers need time to process a borrowers XXXX application, servicers will move the borrower into a processing forbearance for up to 60 days. Interest accrues during this short-term processing forbearance, and time in the processing forbearance is eligible for PSLF and XXXX forgiveness. If the borrowers application is not processed by their servicer within 60 days, the borrower will be moved into a general forbearance that does not count toward XXXX or XXXX until their application is processed. If you fail to provide the requested documentation, your continued reporting and handling of this account will be a clear violation of federal law, including the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and other applicable regulations. I take this matter very seriously and will escalate my complaint to the highest level of authority, including the additional complaint With the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), the U.S. Department of Education, and any other relevant regulatory bodies. Please provide the requested documents within **15 days** of receiving this letter. If you fail to comply, I will take further legal and regulatory action against your company. Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX Social Security XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and XXXX  who XXXX  XXXX schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding XXXX XXXX applications and provide full relief for those impacted. 

Many of us XXXX  the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : * XXXX University XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX The Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXX XXXX  misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that XXXX XXXX of XXXX  secured jobs in their field of study within XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded XXXX  who found employment outside their field of study. 

At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in XXXX states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts. 

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : 1. Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions.

2. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans.

3. Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts. 

Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the XXXX XXXX, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it. 

We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays. 

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 

Sincerely XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

My borrowers defense information : XX/XX/XXXX Borrower Defense Application XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Borrower Defense Applications School : XXXX XXXX Dear XXXX XXXX XXXX : You are receiving this letter because you are a member of the class of Federal student loan borrowers covered by the recent settlement of the XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ) lawsuit. Consumer complaint narrative:
I have direct federal loans that were taken out for my XXXX XXXX in XXXX. My current balance is XXXX XXXX given the accrual of interest over time. I am a XXXX  XXXX  in a XXXX XXXX  XXXX, finishing my XXXX  year of employment, and my loans are eligible for forgiveness through the public service loan forgiveness program. In XXXX, my loans were put into administrative forbearance due to the lawsuits against the SAVE plan, which I was enrolled in for payment. During these months, I did not gain credit toward my PSLF despite continuing to work in the public sector. On XX/XX/XXXX, as soon as the option became available through the website, I applied to change to the XXXX  payment plan which, although would increase my monthly payment dramatically, would afford me the opportunity to make payments that counted towards my PSLF. My application has sat pending since XX/XX/XXXX with no additional follow up information, despite the website indicating that processing can take up to 30 days, or as many as 60 days in busy times. I reached out to FSA regarding the stall in processing in early XXXX and was told the concern was on Mohela 's end. I was unable to connect with a representative when I called due to extremely long wait times, and sent a help email through Mohela 's website, which was never responded to. 

Recent communication ( XX/XX/XXXX ) indicated that SAVE borrowers could switch to an XXXX plan and requests would be processed within 10 days, or you would be put into a forbearance for up to 60 days during processing that would count toward PSLF. Since then, I have filed a complaint via the website, attempted to call Mohela on three occasions ( quoted at a 4 hour and 25 minute wait each time ), and have submitted a new application to switch payment plan ( which went missing from my account the next day, and was not accompanied by the typical letter of receipt ). Consumer complaint narrative:
I am currently on the student loan SAVE plan, and was placed on the 0 % interest SAVE forbearance due to the pending court rulings. 

My initial income recertification date was due by XX/XX/XXXX, and I received notifications from Mohela to submit my income recertification form ( screenshot attached ). I electronically submitted my income recertification form via the Student Aid website by the due date ( screenshot attached ). My total student loan balance at this time was {$180000.00} ( screenshot attached ).

About 2 weeks after I submitted my income recertification form, Mohela sent me a notice on XX/XX/XXXX that my income recertification date was actually pushed out to XX/XX/XXXX. I immediately messaged Mohela to request canceling my income recertification form since I did not need to recertify in XXXX anymore. I messaged them, because I wanted paper trail of our conversation. Mohela messaged me back requesting to call them instead ( screenshot attached ). 

I then called both Student Aid and Mohela in mid-XXXX XXXX to again request them to cancel my income recertification form. There was no electronic option or other way to cancel the form, except to call them. Student Aid told me they did not have control to the cancel the form, and to contact my servicer, Mohela, instead. Mohela told me on XX/XX/XXXX that any form processing had been put on hold, and that my form had had not yet been processed. The Mohela representative told me that they would put a note in my file to not process the form and have it cancelled. I asked for a confirmation email other some sort of proof of this conversation, but they told me they could not send any. The representative reassured me that my form would not be processed, since forms were not being processed at the time anyways. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I checked my student loan portal and was surprised to see my balance had increased from {$180000.00} to {$180000.00}, since I was supposed to be on the 0 % interest SAVE forbearance. 

I called Mohela on XX/XX/XXXX to inquire why this happened, and they told me that my account had mistakenly started accruing interest again. I asked if my balance would be reverted back to the original {$180000.00}, but the Mohela supervisor, XXXX, told me no. Mohela told me that because my income recertification form that I submitted at the end of XX/XX/XXXX had been processed, I was placed on a 60 day processing forbearance, which accrues interest. 

I told the Mohela supervisor, XXXX, that I had called in XX/XX/XXXX and requested to have my income certification form cancelled since my income recertification date had been pushed to XX/XX/XXXX. The form was not supposed to be processed or on my file since I had asked them to cancel it. 

The Mohela supervisor told me that there was no way to cancel the form in XX/XX/XXXX since all form processing was put on hold. I told the Mohela supervisor I understood that, but that a Mohela representative was supposed to put a note on my file in XX/XX/XXXX to not process the application and have it cancelled. But Mohela just went ahead and processed my form anyways 2 months later, without allowing me to cancel it, even though I requested to cancel my income recertification form submission early on. Again, there was no electronic option to cancel the form. 

Long story short, the Mohela supervisor told me she was not sure why my application was still processed if I had requested to cancel it, but that it had been anyways. Mohela told me on XX/XX/XXXX that they would cancel my income recertification application, but that I would need to keep the interest accrued from this processing forbearance, even though I am on the 0 % interest SAVE forbearance. Again, I had requested to cancel my income recertification form couple months prior in XX/XX/XXXX, and the only way to do so was on the phone. And the Mohela representative told me in XX/XX/XXXX, that they would put a note in my file to not process and cancel the application. 

Mohela ultimately reverted my balance to {$180000.00}, when it should be at my original balance of {$180000.00}. That is {$1600.00} extra that Mohela is charging me for a form that should never have been processed anyways. The process of cancelling a form is very tedious ( only via phone call without an electronic option or any receipt of confirmation ). In addition, Mohela representative either falsely told me they put a note in my file to cancel my application, forgot to do it, or ignored my request.

I believe that as of XX/XX/XXXX I had put in my 10 years of service to the community and should receive credit for that work. After having to re-consolidate loans to qualify for PSLF because I was in bankruptcy from XXXX I have been told that I am now going to be paying on all my loans for the next 30 years.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Complaint Against Nelnet for Removing Me from SAVE Forbearance and Accruing Interest in Error Issue : I am filing a complaint against Nelnet regarding a wrongful removal from the SAVE forbearance program, resulting in unauthorized interest accrual on my student loans.

Details : I was originally in the SAVE forbearance, meaning my loans were not accruing interest. In XX/XX/XXXX, I received a notification stating that I needed to recertify my income before XX/XX/XXXX to remain in the SAVE plan. Concerned that recertification might impact my current forbearance, I proactively contacted Nelnet to confirm whether I needed to take action. I was assured that recertification was necessary. However, after completing the process, I was removed from SAVE forbearance, and my loans began accruing interest. 

Starting in XX/XX/XXXX, I made eight calls to Nelnet to resolve this issue : XX/XX/XXXX ( three times ) I inquired about why my interest was accruing. I was informed that my removal from forbearance caused this. I asked why I was removed and was not given a clear answer. I was told a request had been submitted to reinstate my forbearance and that interest accrued due to this error would be credited back. I called twice more that day to confirm the request was properly submitted. 

XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX Each time I called, I was reassured that my reinstatement request was in progress and that my accrued interest would be credited back. 

XX/XX/XXXX I was suddenly informed that no such request showed in my account and that I would have to wait until XX/XX/XXXX, to re-enter SAVE forbearance. I was also told that the interest accrued due to their mistake would not be refunded.

Consumer complaint narrative:
The 'do no harm ' decision to place SAVE borrowers in a mandatory forbearance they can not leave DOES harm a large section of public servants, especially those of us who should have been granted PSLF forgiveness in this time period. The buyback program is supposed to be our way out, but it is not being serviced or processed. 

I have worked in public service for XXXX months, XXXX more than is required for PSLF, but because of the inaction of the Department of Education, I have no recourse or avenue to forgiveness. Every month they refuse to process my buyback request is another month I do not have the option to leave the public sector for a job that pays market rate. This is a form of harm. 

I am stuck at XXXX qualifying payments, though there are XXXX qualifying employment periods, or a total of XXXX eligible for buyback once the XXXX for XXXX is processed. 

I was placed into the SAVE forbearance in XX/XX/year>, which does not count toward PSLF. I immediately attempted to switch to another IDR plan so I could keep making payments, submitting forms in XXXX and XXXX. I was just informed, after waiting XXXX months, that one has been rejected, and the other has not been processed. 

After not hearing back, I submitted a buyback request via the reconsideration process on XX/XX/year>. Notably, there is no way to track the status of this process, and I was just given a case number. This request has not been processed, though official letters have listed the expected time frame to be " up to 45 days. '' So, to sum up, I was moved from the REPAYE program to SAVE without requesting it. Then my loans were placed in a forbearance I CAN NOT LEAVE. 
I can not make payments. 
I can not switch to another payment plan. 
I can not get buyback to make payments. 
There is no indication of when this SAVE forbearance will lift.

I earned PSLF forgiveness months ago, but the Department of Education, through their mismanagement and lack of action, is making what was promised to me before I entered public service impossible to attain. Had I instead worked outside of public service, I would have been able to repay my loans many years ago because I would have been paid at market rate. Fulfill your promise.

Consumer complaint narrative: EdFinancial assumed faulty loans from XXXX and has not attempted to fix the issue on loans they assumed : Starting in XXXX of 2024 while XXXX owned my loans, there was an error in the amount on the single loan left that had not been paid off. I paid down that remaining loan to {$5900.00}. I had noticed in XX/XX/XXXX that the balance on this loan had drastically risen and that old loans of mine had returned with varying amounts. I had called over a dozen times to XXXX while they owned my loans and they have admitted to the mistake several times and kept saying that they would get it fixed and they never did. After they made some corrections they ended up with the old paid off loans that returned being rightfully wiped from the account but the remaining loan that I owed almost {$6000.00} to had risen to {$6900.00}. They essentially added XXXX on to the remaining loan balance and neglected to fix changes they were aware of. Later in the summer of 2024 they sold my loans to EdFinancial without fixing them. Ever since they sold my loans both XXXX and EdFinancial have been saying it's the other company 's responsibility to have this issue fixed. XXXX advised me to stop paying on the loan since it would cause confusion while they were sorting out the issue and said they would forgive the interest built on the loan ( this was prior to the transfer to EdFinancial ). The loan is now at EdFinancial sitting around {$7200.00}.

I must have XXXX  plan removed immediately from NELNET XXXX selection as a plan for me. I never asked Nelnet to be placed on forbearance and/or XXXX plan. I was on PAYE plan originally when NELNET unlawfully moved me to XXXX  plan.

We are sending this reply to verify we have received your document and forwarded it to the correct department. Please allow processing time. Once your request has been processed communication will be sent to you letting you know it has been completed.

Questions? Were here for you. Log in to your nelnet.studentaid.gov/account or reach out to us at XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Data Breach, FERPA and Title IV Violations, and Request for Immediate Discharge of Student Loans I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the XXXX Department of Education ( DOE ) and the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security.

I recently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes but is not limited to : 1. My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ).

2. My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including financial aid history and loan information.

3. My IRS tax transcripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization.

These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards.

Given the severity of this breach and the direct impact on my financial security and privacy, I demand the following corrective actions : 1. Immediate discharge and cancellation of all my federal student loans due to the breach of my financial aid and tax records, which invalidates the integrity of my loan agreements.

2. A formal investigation into this data breach, including details on how my records were accessed, who accessed them, and for what purpose.

3. A full report on the extent of my data exposure and the corrective measures being implemented to prevent future violations.

4. Immediate notification to all major credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX XXXX ) to place a fraud alert and investigate any unauthorized activity that may have resulted from this breach.

This breach has caused significant distress and concern regarding the security of my personal and financial data. If my demands are not met within XXXX days, I will be left with no choice but to escalate this matter through legal channels, including filing complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and pursuing legal action against the responsible parties. 
I request a written response addressing these concerns and outlining the immediate actions being taken to remedy this situation. Please direct all correspondence to the address listed above. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this urgent matter. I look forward to your immediate response and resolution.
Company: Servicer under contract with Federal Student Aid

Dear Dispute Department, I am writing to formally dispute the reporting of student loan accounts associated with Nelnet on my credit report. These accounts are inaccurate and unenforceable due to severe legal violations involving breaches of privacy and federal law, including the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ), the Privacy Act of 1974, and the Higher Education Act. 
It has come to my attention that my personal information associated with these loans was improperly accessed by unauthorized third parties, including XXXX XXXX and/or his affiliated entities. This unauthorized access constitutes a breach of my privacy rights and voids the validity of these debts. 
Disputed Accounts : Nelnet, Account # XXXX Legal Basis for Removal : 1. FERPA Violation : The improper handling and unauthorized disclosure of my educational and financial records violated FERPA regulations, which protect the privacy of student loan borrowers. 
2. Privacy Act of 1974 Violation : The exposure of my personal information contravenes the protections guaranteed under the Privacy Act, requiring federal contractors and loan servicers to safeguard borrower information. 
3. Breach of the Higher Education Act : The mishandling of my student loan information and unauthorized transfer without proper consent breached federal obligations to maintain the integrity of educational loan servicing. 
Given these violations, the continued reporting of these accounts is inaccurate and harmful to my credit profile. 
Requested Resolution : I formally request that these : 1. Immediately remove all references to these student loan accounts from my credit report. 
2. Provide written confirmation of the removal within 30 days. 
Failure to address this dispute in compliance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) may compel me to pursue legal action. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Subject : Formal Complaint for Removal of Student Loans from Credit Report and Review of Forgiveness Eligibility To Whom It May Concern, I am submitting this formal complaint regarding the mismanagement and continued reporting of my student loans, which have caused significant financial and emotional distress. I am requesting the immediate removal of these student loans from my credit report and a full review of my eligibility for loan forgiveness under federal law. 

Details of the Complaint : XXXX. Long-Term Participation in Income-Driven Repayment ( IDR ) Plans : I have been enrolled in an Income-Driven Repayment ( IDR ) program for several years, consistently making payments as required. 

Despite my consistent participation, none of my student loan balance has been forgiven, in direct contradiction to federal guidelines that promise forgiveness after XXXX years of qualifying payments. 

This is a violation of the Higher Education Act of 1965 and the terms outlined in IDR programs, which mandate forgiveness after a designated period of repayment. 



XXXX. Bankruptcy Filing and Undue Hardship : I have filed for bankruptcy, which further demonstrates the undue hardship caused by these student loans. 

Under 11 U.S.C. 523 ( a ) ( 8 ) of the Bankruptcy Code, student loans can be discharged in bankruptcy if they create an undue hardship. 

My financial situation meets the XXXX XXXX standards : Poverty : Repaying these loans prevents me from maintaining a minimal standard of living. 

Persistence : My financial hardship is ongoing and unlikely to improve. 

Good Faith : I have made good faith efforts to repay my loans through consistent participation in repayment programs. 




XXXX. Negative Credit Reporting : These student loans are negatively affecting my credit, preventing me from accessing essential financial opportunities. 

Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) 15 U.S.C. 1681, lenders are required to report accurate and complete information. The continued reporting of these loans without honoring forgiveness programs or considering my bankruptcy filing is a violation of this law. 



XXXX. Violation of Consumer Rights : As a United States citizen, I have the right to fair treatment under federal law. 

The mishandling of my student loan repayment and forgiveness eligibility violates my rights and hinders my ability to live freely and pursue financial stability. 




Relevant Legal Violations : Higher Education Act of 1965 : Failure to administer loan forgiveness as promised under IDR plans. 

Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) 15 U.S.C. 1681 : Reporting inaccurate or outdated information. 

Bankruptcy Code 11 U.S.C. 523 ( a ) ( 8 ) : Ignoring eligibility for loan discharge due to undue hardship. 

Consumer Financial Protection Act ( Title X of Dodd-Frank Act ) : Unfair and deceptive practices by loan servicers.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am contacting the CFPB regarding my student loan payments, which are currently due with MOHELA as my servicer. In XX/XX/XXXX, I applied for an Income-Driven Repayment ( IDR ) plan through the U.S. Department of Education . However, I have yet to receive a determination due to the SAFE Payment Plan being placed on hold by a federal court. 

Despite my pending application, MOHELA continues to report that I owe payments and am late. I have attempted to contact MOHELA to address this, but the wait times to speak with a representative EXCEED XXXX HOURS. Additionally, I recently filed for bankruptcy, and my case was discharged on XX/XX/XXXX, which should have placed my payments on hold. My concern is that these reported late payments may negatively impact my credit and overall financial well-being.

As a public school teacher, I qualify for an IDR plan, and eventually forgiveness under the PSLF program but I am currently unable to take any action due to the delays. I would appreciate any guidance or assistance you can provide in resolving this matter. 

Thank you for your time and support. I look forward to your response.

My name is XXXX XXXX, my address is XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, Ny, XXXX my phone number XXXX. My account number with Nelnet is number is XXXX. 

I am concerned that my personal financial information held by Nelnet may have been compromised due to a data breach. I am concerned because of the recent public announcement of DOGE mblembers seizing the Department Of Education, specifically XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX. 

A data breach involving my personal financial information is a serious matter and could expose me to identity theft, financial fraud, and other harms. This information is highly sensitive and must be protected. Nelnet falls under the jurisdiction of the CFPB because They are a financial institution. 

I request that the CFPB investigate this matter thoroughly and take appropriate action to ensures Nelnet 's compliance with relevant consumer financial laws and regulations regarding data security. Specifically, I request that the CFPB : * Confirm whether a breach occurred. 
* Identify the extent of the breach and what specific data was compromised. 
* Ensure that Nelnet takes appropriate steps to rectify the situation and prevent future breaches. 
* Inform me of the specific actions I should take to protect myself from potential harm. 
* Provide information about any credit monitoring or identity theft protection services that will be offered. 
I expect a written response within 30 days outlining the steps the CFPB will take to address this complaint. I can be reached at XXXX or XXXX if you require further information. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX I received a letter from Federal Student Aid thanking me for my public service and that my student loans had 192 payments and the effective date of forgiveness was XX/XX/XXXX. This letter stated, " Your loan servicer will send you communication about PSLF/TEPSLF forgiveness within 30 business days.

It has been 6 months and I have not received anything from my servicer XXXX as this letter stated I would. 

I have contacted Federal Student Aid three times from when this letter was sent starting in XXXX, XXXX and as recent at XX/XX/XXXX. Each time I have contacted Federal Student Aid they have told me that my loans have been forgiven but I just need to wait. 

What am I waiting for, it has been 6 months. In addition they can't tell me why I continue to have a balance and what the problem is. 

How can they send me a letter telling me my loans have been forgiven and I would receive communication within 30 days and then for 6 months tell me to just wait without telling me what the problem is? This is completely fraudulent. 

I have contacted my servicer XXXX and they tell me to contact Federal Student Aid. 

I continue to have a loan balance and a monthly payment. I now have 195 qualifying payments towards this loan.
Company: Servicer under contract with Federal Student Aid

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/year>, a Direct Consolidation Loan Application was submitted for my student loans. The application was for the Saving on a Valuable Education ( SAVE ) Income-Driven ( IDR ) Repayment Plan Type and PSLF. The loans were consolidated and moved from XXXX to MOHELA due to the PSLF request given that at the time MOHELA was serving as the federally authorized PSLF servicer. 

A letter was subsequently received from MOHELA dated XX/XX/year>XXXX  stating that my loans had been consolidated and moved to them under a Standard payment plan. This Standard payment plan that I was placed on by MOHELA was not the IDR SAVE payment plan I had requested and did not meet the IDR standards for PSLF qualifying payment plans, negating the whole reason for the account being moved to MOHELA. 

Upon noticing that the repayment plan was Standard and not SAVE as requested, I called MOHELA to determine why my application was not processed correctly and to determine how to get into the eligible PSLF qualifying plan as I had requested. I was told that they did not receive the IDR application for processing and that I needed to resubmit a new IDR application. 

As directed by MOHELA, I submitted a new IDR application for the SAVE Plan on XX/XX/year>. On that same day, XX/XX/year>, the original SAVE Plan application was closed in the Student Aid portal, which means that they mislead me by saying that they could not see the original application, otherwise they could not have closed out my original application. 

By XXXX, all SAVE Plan applications were put on hold due to litigation. As a result, I have become one of the many student loan borrowers that is in eternal limbo without clear direction on how to resolve the issues that have been caused by no fault of my own. 

When going through the consolidation process, the student aid site ensured borrowers that payment counts would not be reset. But as my account now stands, previous years of IDR payments for over a decade that were made towards the 25 years of payments for the IDR forgiveness milestone have been reset. I have also lost 9+ months and counting of working for a qualifying PSLF employer and not being in a qualifying PSLF repayment plan due to negligence of MOHELA and their delay of processing my application. 

Through no fault of my own, my account has been moved to a servicer that is incompetent, has been misguiding countless borrowers, and placing them into plans incorrectly with no path forward. Because of being incorrectly placed on an ineligible PSLF plan by MOHELA despite my request, and being placed on an extended forbearance pending litigation, I am losing qualifying PSLF payment time with no guidance on how to resolve these issues. 

Please also note that as of XX/XX/year>, MOHELA was removed as the only PSLF servicer. This was 2 days after my consolidation application was submitted. The loans should not have been moved to MOHELA, there were already known issues with MOHELA as a PSLF servicer at this time.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Dispute Regarding Student Loan Payment I was contacted by Ed Financial in XX/XX/XXXX regarding a student loan balance of {$3100.00} They informed me that I needed to pay the amount, or my wages would be garnished. This loan had not appeared on my credit report for over XXXX years, but it was added back after I filed for bankruptcy. 

When I reviewed my credit report prior to filing for bankruptcy, the loan was not listed and, therefore, was not included in the bankruptcy filing. However, after the bankruptcy was filed, the loan company contacted me about this debt. 

I explained the situation to the loan company, but they did not address my concerns. To avoid having my wages garnished, I was forced to agree to a debt consolidation on XX/XX/XXXX. I explained to the company that I had filed for bankruptcy, was facing financial hardship due to medical reasons, and was in between jobs. I also mentioned that the loan was originally taken out in XXXX and asked if there was a statute of limitations that applied to it. 

Despite my efforts to communicate my situation, the company did not listen, and now I am struggling to make payments for this unexpected and burdensome expense. I would like to speak to someone to understand my rights and explore whether this loan can be discharged. 

Please contact me at your earliest convenience. 

Thank you, XXXX XXXX

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
I was automatically enrolled in the SAVE plan from the REPAYE, and there has been a court injunction that have put a stop to payments or qualifying payments to the PSLF program since the court injunction has been in place. I am serviced by Mohela. On XX/XX/XXXX I was given a letter by Mohela that there was a platform change. On XX/XX/XXXX I was given a letter stating I was on the SAVE plan, that I was in forbearance, and that this time does not qualify for credit toward IDR or PSLF. On XX/XX/XXXX I was given a notice there was a repayment schedule change for some of my loans to go to an IDR plan, and some to go to a Standard repayment plan. I made a call on XX/XX/XXXX to ask about this, and was reassured that I was on " forbearance '' and assumed this was the natural next step of being on the SAVE plan, I didn't have a reason at this point not to trust them. On XX/XX/XXXX, I was given a notice there was a repayment schedule change for all of my loans into the Standard repayment plan. I work in a school district and the last week of school I didn't have an availability to call, so I called as soon as I could on XX/XX/XXXX to ask about the repayment schedule change. I was told that this was a Mohela system error due to the platform change on XX/XX/XXXX, and they needed to make the correction to change me from the Standard repayment plan back to the SAVE repayment plan. On this call I was told they would backdate any interest accrual to the platform change on XX/XX/XXXX, and that I would be put back on the SAVE repayment plan, and they would communicate with me in 5-10 business days when this correction would be made. 10 business days came and went, I didn't receive any communication. I called back on XX/XX/XXXX, and was told I was on the SAVE repayment plan, they just can't correct it on my account, or send me any communication because of the court injunction. They assured me that no interest would accrue, I wouldn't owe anything, and my account wouldn't be delinquent or go into default if I didn't pay anything, and that I was in the SAVE forbearance until at least XX/XX/XXXX. They said they couldn't give me a confirmation number, I just basically had to take their word for it. I received an auto-debit notification on XX/XX/XXXX. At this point I trusted them, and didn't have a chance to call with a long wait time until XX/XX/XXXX. On that call, it failed after over an hour of waiting, and I called back. I spent over XXXX hours on the phone waiting. I was connected and told that I was given misinformation on XX/XX/XXXX, that I wasn't on the SAVE plan, I was on the Standard repayment plan and I had a bill due that would auto-debit. I was furious. The customer representative could not cancel the auto-debit. They said that they can't re-process me into the SAVE plan because of the court injunction. The supervisor office was closed by the time I was connected, so they said a supervisor would call me back on XX/XX/XXXX. Over the weekend, I removed my bank from my Mohela account, or so I thought. I didn't receive a call on XX/XX/XXXX, I called Mohela on XX/XX/XXXX and waited for 5 hours before I was connected to a " resolution team ''. I recorded parts of the conversation because I was told they couldn't send me notes. I requested a letter summarizing their internal error and failure to put me back on the SAVE plan. they said that they can attempt to re-process me back onto the SAVE plan after XX/XX/XXXX when my forbearance ends. They also said they cancelled the auto-debit. On XX/XX/XXXX I received the callback from a supervisor from the task that was started from the XX/XX/XXXX call. They said that a letter detailing the error had been drafted and sent to me, I received it, and it does not include the admission of fault by Mohela, nor their plan for how to correct their error and put me back on the SAVE plan with interest backdated. I requested an ACH company ID so that I can issue a stop payment from them for the next 6 months on my bank, they put in that request and we scheduled a callback to ensure I get that ACH number and to review the letter. I never received a call back. I called after XX/XX/XXXX as soon as I could on XX/XX/XXXX. I spent 8 hours on the phone waiting to be connected to someone. At which point I was told I couldnt be re-processed onto the SAVE plan due to the court injunction. I was told I was on the Standard repayment plan, and my account would become delinquent if I didnt pay. I was told that I could elect to be put on a processing forbearance. There was no admittance of fault, or resolution offered for Mohelas error of putting me unauthorized onto the Standard plan, and what they were going to do to correct this error and put me back on the SAVE repayment plan. The call was dropped when they said they were going to put me in a processing forbearance, and connect me to a supervisor.

My complaint is after reviewing the AFT lawsuit, and a report put out by 50 of our Senators and Congressmen, what I have been the victim of seems like an intentional scheme to get customers on a high repayment plan. My fear is that I won't be able to be put back on the SAVE repayment plan because it will no longer be an option. I don't want to be put on a different IDR plan. I am okay with not getting credit towards PSLF at this time in exchange of continuing to be on the SAVE forbearance with no interest. I am about to go on maternity leave and do not know what my reportable income will be, and would prefer to be on the SAVE forbearance because Federal Student Aid has stated on their website that those in the SAVE repayment plan will not have to go into repayment earlier than fall XXXX, and re-certify their income no earlier than XX/XX/XXXX. I want to be back on the SAVE plan. If they have had a lawsuit, and a report for over a year alleging this same misconduct, it is intentional.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
