Consumer complaint narrative:
Automatic payments are still not being processed by due dates despite repeated calls to the servicer, Mohela. I also believe I have been missing interest rate discounts. This has been going on since I changed bank accounts in XX/XX/XXXX. After my last phone call with Mohela, they suggested that I refrain from re-enrolling in auto payments since they say it takes XXXX billing cycles for auto-payment to go into effect. I have done that and auto-payments still are not being processed. Most recently, an automatic payment that was due XX/XX/XXXX was not processed automatically. 

The following is correspondence from myself to XXXX. The XXXX XXXX XXXX. closed my case on XX/XX/XXXX with no resolution : Case Information Date Submitted XX/XX/XXXX Category Repaying My Aid Subcategory Dealing with XXXX XXXXrvicer Case Description Auto payment was debited on XX/XX/XXXX from a checking account that I no longer use instead of my new checking account. Payment went delinquent due to insufficient funds. New login to Mohela was required to be set up since they transitioned to a new loan servicing platform. My new checking account was not listed in the auto payment after setting up the new login. I can not reach any customer service representative at Mohela to resolve this in a reasonable amount of time because wait times on the phone have been up to an hour long with no option for a call back. 

XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX have email confirmations of auto pay enrollment dated XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, and today, XX/XX/XXXX. No automatic payments have successfully been been processed on time since then. 

XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX received another past-due email notification. Auto-payment was not processed again. XXXX was due on XX/XX/XXXX and I made a manual payment on XX/XX/XXXX. I also re-enrolled in auto-payment. Since I've enrolled with the new bank account, every payment has been missed on the due date. 

XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX Another payment was missed on the date it was due despite verifying having been enrolled in automatic payment after calling Mohela last month. Another one-time payment was made today, and auto-payment was re-enrolled. This is now a persistent issue. 

XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX  Another payment that was due on XX/XX/XXXX was not processed on-time even though the new Mohela XXXX on XXXX stated that the amount due would automatically be debited on the due date. I also ensured that my old checking account had sufficient funds. I manually made the payment today XX/XX/XXXX. The Mohela portal still says that a payment is scheduled for XX/XX/XXXX from my old checking account. There are more than sufficient funds in both my old and new accounts. This is now 2 payments that I am not sure will qualify towards PSLF forgiveness because they were not processed automatically on their scheduled due dates. 

XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX  After an hour on hold with Mohela, they did confirm that my payment was processed and would not be reported to credit bureaus. However the representative stated that only XXXX XXXX XXXX could validate that the payment would be credited towards qualifying PSLF payments. Furthermore, they informed me that my new account would not take effect for 2-3 billing cycles and I would have to make payments manually until then. When I asked if being forced to make manual payments would cost me the 0.25 % interest rate discount for auto payment, they said that it unfortunately would until automatic payments took effect. This does not strike me as a fair business practice compared to most automatic billing agreements.

Processing time can take from 2-4 business days to reflect posted to your student loan balance. Please note going forward when payment is not received on your due date a past due notice is generated and sent. Negative credit reporting only occurs when your account is delinquent 90 days or more.

Consumer complaint narrative:
At the beginning of COVID, I was informed that making payments and being on the forbearance would count twice for the time period towards PSLF forgiveness. In XXXX XXXX, MOHELA advised differently and I requested a refund of all payments made to both of my loans. I followed up by phone on a regular basis and was told it's a process and to be patient. The first payment was received XX/XX/XXXX and separate checks continued up until XX/XX/XXXX. There has not been any money returned since those last checks. 

The amount outstanding is {$11000.00} based on my calculations. During the last year, I have continued to contact MOHELA requesting the remaining amount and it has been a circle that has yet to receive an outcome. The hours spent on the phone, sending emails, providing the requested documentation has been a consistent waiting game. Then when I do get to talk to someone, that conversation does not yield anything better. I have to explain the situation over and over to each new person answering the call, wait while they read up on the history, then to be told I need to speak to a supervisor. I get transferred and voice mail picks up EVERY time. I leave a voice mail, wait for return call which has only occurred once. I understand their 'business hours ' are also my business hours ; but I make myself available, pausing from my job. 

I sent an request to the Ombudsman last year and did not hear anything, not even acknowledgement of my complaint. I have voiced my complaints, frustration, and time spent on this topic repeatedly to MOHELA to not receive any acknowledgement or urgency or consistency. 

During COVID, the loans were at different servicers. MOHELA continues to tell me that they can not refund money not paid to them ; yet they did refund some payments made to a few of the servicers, just not all. The time I was making payments to XXXX seems to be outstanding amounts. I have sent in bank statements, I contacted XXXX myself and they provided the history to me which I then gave to MOHELA. And then had to give them again when they moved to a new system. At times MOHELA has explained it is FSA holding up the amount, then at another time, it's because the payments were made at another servicer. How the story can keep changing is beyond my grasp.

The amount owed is not a few hundred dollars, even if it was - it is still owed to me. My loans continue to be in good standing, making payments ahead of scheduled due dates. The other issues I've experienced with MOHELA are small in size compared to this amount outstanding. How my current payments are applied do not make sense since the increase to my loans was before I received the refund. When I mentioned it to a representative at MOHELA, they assured me that recalculation would occur once all refunds are received. Which makes me think they realize all money has not been returned.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the U.S. Department of Education ( DOE ) and the Department of Government Efficiency ( DOGE ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security.

I recently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes but is not limited to : My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ).

My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including financial aid history and loan information. 
My IRS tax transcripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization.

These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
For the past 6 months, since the court injunction that blocked certain aspects of the XXXX plan, XXXX and XXXX have been misleading student loan borrowers about the state of their accounts and their options for remedy. I understand that the transition of XXXX administration from XXXX to XXXX caused a backlog, but it is not acceptable for a company that controls such an important part of their customers to be so poorly managed. Misleading and confusing letters and website information, tech glitches, and long wait times for customer service are the hallmark not just of XXXX ( as is already well documented ), but also XXXX. I have two issues that have remained unresolved for months. 

ISSUE XXXX : XXXX XXXX & XXXX My payment date is the XXXX of the month. On XX/XX/XXXX, I made a full payment ( Exhibit A ). I had been told that a forbearance was coming because of XXXX platform transition and that it would count toward XXXX, but it never showed in my account and my account had already transitioned by my due date, XX/XX/XXXX ( Exhibit B ). 

In XXXX I submitted an Employment Certification Form, and at that time my payment count was updated on the XXXX website. However, the month of XXXX was not included. The list of months included XXXX ( qualifying ), XXXX ( ineligible ), and XXXX ( ineligible ). 

In XXXX, after XXXX updated the system, XXXX appeared in the list, but it was marked ineligible due to a forbearance on my due date. I called XXXX to question this, and I was told to file a reconsideration request. I did so on XX/XX/XXXX ( Exhibit C ). 

It is worth noting that hundreds of people in the XXXX XXXX support group and XXXX subreddits have also experienced this problem. As of XX/XX/XXXX, I have not gotten a response to my reconsideration request. 

ISSUE 2 : Legality of the XXXX XXXX XXXX by Dept. of Ed. 
I have been told by XXXX that the XXXX has told them to pause processing the XXXX applications of borrowers currently on the XXXX plan. IBRs calculation has never been part of the injunction, and stalling my XXXX application interferes with my statutorily delegated ability to switch my repayment plans. Additionally, there has been no official transparency on the matter. None of this has been communicated to borrowers and in fact numerous misleading statements can be currently found on various XXXX websites. Here is my situation. 

When I and all other borrowers on the XXXX plan were forced into forbearance because of the court injunction, XXXX said there were XXXX remedies for people in PSLF ( Exhibit D, screenshot of XXXX website. ) Either borrowers could buy back the months when they hit 120 months of qualifying employment, or they could enroll in a different repayment plan. I decided to enroll in a new repayment plan. I had been on XXXX for almost all of my student loan repayment, and unfortunately I moved to the XXXX plan in XX/XX/XXXX to try and keep my costs down for my final year of repayment. 

XXXX reinforced this notion about applying for a new XXXX plan in a letter they sent on XX/XX/XXXX ( Exhibit E ). 

When the online IDR application opened again in XX/XX/XXXX, I immediately applied for XXXX ( Exhibit F ). At no point was I advised that processing was paused, which should have been a standard response to submitting an application. The solutions to the XXXX forbearance for XXXX borrowers still suggested switching plans. 

According to the XXXX website ( Exhibit D again ), If servicers need time to process a borrowers IDR application, servicers will move the borrower into a processing forbearance for up to 60 days. Interest accrues during this short-term processing forbearance, and time in the processing forbearance is eligible for XXXX  and XXXX forgiveness. This was never done in my case, and in fact when I contacted XXXX, several levels of employees were unable to understand this idea, despite waiting XXXX hours per call to be escalated. This should have happened in XXXX, giving me 2 at least 2 additional months of XXXXeligible payments. 

The insult added to all of this injury is that wait times with XXXX are typically over XXXX hours, questions are met with canned responses that dont make sense and send borrowers into illogical loops, and no one is able to answer anything ( Exhibits H.1, H.3 ).
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

I tried XXXX again with a new job which didn't work out. I then tried graduate school again to dig out from under-employment. My loans were deferred during my second round of graduate school ( and at the time, Direct Loans showed that I'd need a job paying approximately $ XXXX to pay off my loans timely! ). After the second round of graduate school, I was unemployed from late XXXX - early XXXX and XXXX XXXX told me I'd used up my forbearance allowances and defaulted my loans- despite me having no income- when they could've put me in {$0.00} or $ 5 monthly payments ( common now ) - and proof of no income ( no tax returns filed ). It resulted in tax refunds and my pittance of a paycheck being garnished when I started working again in XXXX all because of XXXX XXXX refusal to give me {$0.00} or {$5.00} payments. Another try at XXXX from XXXX working for the federal government, but we were on a student loan pause and I paid off other debts, and then Direct Loans/Mohela DENIED my XXXX because I couldn't get former XXXX employers to sign the needed forms. They refused copies of my XXXX and e-OPF to prove federal employment. ( The IRS has no records past 10 years, so I am unable to even get XXXX forms before XXXX and I no longer have those documents due to changes in computers over the years. ) I had no way to go back to federal agencies I no longer worked at to get signatures. 
****** Mohela said the only thing acceptable was paystubs, which I didn't have, and no access to the government systems to get them. I'd calculated approximately XXXX of eligible XXXX payments. I gave up and left federal employment because I couldn't keep being under-employed if Mohela refused to accept my XXXX  or XXXX as proof of eligible federal employment for loan forgiveness. Now, Mohela and XXXX refuse to give me payment counts to tell me how many months I have left to pay. I have proof I was unemployed from late XXXX - early XXXX ( no income = no tax returns filed those years but uneligible for unemployment because I was out of the country ) and should never have been negatively defaulted on my student loan history ( which will affect overall eligibility for forgiveness ). 
****** I also have been denied a payment count multiple times despite complaints to Mohela and XXXX to know how much longer I may have paying and have to work well past retirement age. I have filed multiple complaints with StudentAid.gov to no avail ( no response given other than a canned form response that they're looking into it ). I have received NO ANSWER from Mohela despite multiple requests to know why only the unsubsidized loans were put into forbearance from XXXX - XX/XX/XXXX with no reply or explanation. I can't sit on hold for XXXX or more a day trying to find out. I filed for help with my XXXX in XX/XX/XXXX to no avail- they only told me to apply for XXXX. I was already on XXXX as of XX/XX/XXXX. If XXXX goes away ( likely ), the proposed payments sent by Mohela exceed my current New York XXXX rent. I will be homeless. Mohela has sent me XXXX repayment schedule changes since XXXX- and sent XXXX alone in XX/XX/XXXX ( I have attached the most recent ). 
****** I want a payment count of how many payments I've made and have left for forgiveness AND I want my XXXX eligibility recalculated as I have proof of federal and non-profit employment from XX/XX/XXXX - XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX - XX/XX/XXXX and again from XX/XX/XXXX - XX/XX/XXXX, my default cured/removed from my record because I was unemployed late XXXX - early XXXX and was denied {$0.00} or {$5.00} payments, and a correct and accurate timeline for payoff and/or forgiveness given. I also want all my statements from MOHELA from XXXX XXXX XXXX and an explanation as to WHY my subsidized loan was in forbearance those months ( but the unsubsidized portion was not ). 

****** First, their generic response took 60 days and is clearly a cut and paste reply doesn't address any of the questions or issues above and doesn't recognize that I have tried repeatedly to appeal the XXXX XXXX, among many other issues : ****** Dear XXXX XXXX : MOHELA has reviewed your complaint made with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) regarding your qualifying payment count toward XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX  ). Beginning XX/XX/XXXX, the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( PSLF ) and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX programs are no longer managed through a designated loan servicer. As of XX/XX/XXXX, the XXXX XXXX is fully managed by the XXXX Department of Education on XXXX. Borrowers seeking XXXX can submit XXXX forms, track the status of their forms, view correspondence, and access payment counts through their XXXX account. If you disagree with your qualifying payment count toward XXXX, you have the option to file a reconsideration request to initiate XXXX re-review of your loan history at XXXX XXXX XXXX Please note that MOHELA is unable to either determine or expedite the qualification of payment periods for XXXX. If you have any other questions or concerns, please dont hesitate to contact a member of our Customer XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX from XXXX to XXXX Mondays, XXXX to XXXX Tuesdays and Wednesdays, or XXXX to XXXX Thursdays and Fridays, Central Standard Time. You can also visit XXXX. Sincerely, MOHELA ****** Second, I have previously complained about MOHELA 's response to my XXXX count. They ( at the time ) stated I was ineligible because they would only accept PAYCHECK STUBS OR XXXX statements from employers ( even the IRS no longer has the information because it is older than 10 years ) and required an employer signature ( which I am no longer able to get because I no longer work at those companies ). ****** XXXX, they have refused to provide an official, accurate payment count. ****** XXXX, they have refused to provide old statements from XX/XX/XXXX- XX/XX/XXXX to me and the statements are no longer available on the website as they re-did their website in XX/XX/XXXX and information and older information is no longer available. 
****** MOHELA continues to lie, deceive, and delay information and only provides half-information and half-truths to borrowers, myself included, as it is apparent they are even avoiding the complaint I have filed by not answering completely and only providing a scripted canned response to one of many issues.

Consumer complaint narrative: My application for the IDR plan was submitted and approved with FSA in XX/XX/year>. Due to the recent court rulings my loan servicer ( MOHLEA ) was unable to process my approved application. " If servicers need time to process a borrowers IDR application, servicers will move the borrower into a processing forbearance for up to 60 days. Interest accrues during this short-term processing forbearance, and time in the processing forbearance does provide IDR credit and PSLF credit ( with certified employment ). If the borrowers application is not processed by their servicer within 60 days, the borrower will be moved into a general forbearance that does not count toward PSLF or IDR until their application is processed. Interest will not accrue in the SAVE forbearance. '' This is the process that my loan servicer ( MOHELA ) should be following, and they're failing to do so. As a result my account with MOHELA has inaccurately accrued XXXX XXXX XXXX of dollars of interest over the past couple months. I have attempted to reach out to MOHELA on multiple occasions and I have waited on hold for multiple hours leading to no one ever answering the phone. On the few occasions that I have had someone answer the phone, they have told me they're unable to put me in a general interest free forbearance despite what the court rulings say. They're refusing to acknowledge what the SAVE Plan Court Actions has agreed upon and it is costing me XXXX XXXX XXXX of dollars. I have reached out to FSA about MOHELAS incompetence and they have failed to address the issue as well.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I have made numerous attempts to enter into IBR repayment plan towards PSLF. My loan service was switched to Mohela in XXXX of XXXX and I was placed on the " SAVE '' repayment plan. Due to pending litigation, MOHELA placed my in forbearance. Since then, I have tried to enroll back into an IBR repayment plan. I submitted Income Based Repayment Plan Request in XX/XX/XXXX. Mohela did not process. I submitted two applications in XX/XX/XXXX and Mohela did not process. I received a letter from Mohela 30 days later that confirmed my IDR request was recieved, but when I check back to studentaid.gov it states that my application is closed. I submitted another application XX/XX/XXXX and it shows under review. 

For the past few months, I have not been credited towards PSLF forgiveness because I am in forbearance. Additionally, I have been denied an important home loan/mortgage, because I can not verify my payment plan for my bank because Mohela will not process my IBR repayment plan request. 

I have called Mohela daily for weeks regarding this issue. No matter the time or the day, it is impossible to reach an agent. I call first thing in the morning and get in line for a return phone call. IF I get return phone call it is anywhere from 3-6 hours later. Then I talk to an agent who merely confirms my personal and account information and tells me I need to speak to an " advance agent. '' I am then transferred to another automated line with wait times for the same time frame or longer. Sometimes, the automated line gives me the option to press 1 for a return call. Sometimes it does not. When it does not give me the option to press 1 for return call, I wait on hold for 1-2 hours as long as I can without disrupting my job duties. But, often I have to end the call because I can not spend hours on hold. When I do have option 1 for return call, I several more hours for return call. Most of the time I do not get a return call. I have received one return call with over weeks of trying. The advanced agent I spoke to essentially told me that their processing times are delayed with no further insight or resolution. 

I just want to resume payment under IBR repayment plan so that I can : ( 1 ) remain on track towards PSLF forgiveness and ( 2 ) have written documentation of my payment plan for loan purposes. 

This has been a nightmare with no end in sight.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Background : My original loan of approximately {$35000.00} began in XXXX and has now grown to {$230000.00}. Throughout the life of this loan, I have never received any other financial aid and have never been in default. I entered XXXX in XXXX and have never missed a payment since entering XXXX, except during the XXXX pause. 

Loan Issue : In XXXX, I was advised to consolidate my loans to bring me closer to forgiveness, as more months would qualify. Consequently, I consolidated my loans, but at that time, payment counts were not available for me to verify which payments qualified. 
Prior to consolidation, I attended graduate school at XXXXXXXX XXXX from XX/XX/XXXX - XX/XX/XXXX and was placed in an in-school deferment without my knowledge or consent. I did not receive any financial aid during this time. Additionally, I have been informed that I was in school from XX/XX/XXXX - XX/XX/XXXX ; however, I am unaware of which school this refers to. I am unable to reach out to this institution that is being referenced as to why I was put in deferment. 
I have been employed full-time with a XXXX XXXX since XXXX and have made XXXX qualifying payments under an eligible repayment plan. 
Mohela provided me with an in-school deferment waiver, which I signed and returned. It was approved to waive my in-school deferment. Before the pause, I spoke with multiple representatives who assured me that I was good to retire, as I had planned to do that summer, and that my payment counts would update over the summer, reflecting that I had met the XXXX requirement for XXXX forgiveness. After the pause, my loans transferred to XXXX XXXX and are no longer with Mohela. XXXX says they can not help me because this happened prior to them being my servicer. 
I retired on XX/XX/XXXX under the belief that I had the qualifying XXXX payments, as I was repeatedly assured by Mohela. However, after the payment count update, my in-school deferment periods prior to consolidation were still not included. I was informed that this was due to those periods occurring before my consolidation. This was contrary to the information I had received from Mohela. Had I been provided with accurate information, I could have delayed my retirement and continuing working for my qualified employer until my loans were forgiven. 
I am now XXXX XXXX XXXX and facing the reality of carrying this loan for the remainder of my life, or come out retirement due to misinformation. I was not required to consolidate my loans, and Mohela 's misleading guidance led me to make a decision that has negatively impacted my financial future.

Consumer complaint narrative:
As a result of the court injunction halting SAVE repayment plans, I have been placed on administrative forbearance since XXXX of XXXX. I've been looking to switch to a different IDR plan to finish making my payments and qualify for PSLF. I submit an IDR application on XX/XX/. 

According to the latest correspondence I've received from the ED, " If you submit an application to enroll in an IDR plan other than SAVE, but your loan servicer is unable to process your application within 10 business days of receiving the application or before your next billing statement will be sent, you will be moved into a processing forbearance for up to 60 days. During this period, you do not have to make your monthly payments on your student loans, interest is accruing, and time spent does provide credit toward PSLF* and IDR When you are moved into forbearance, your loan servicer will notify you about which type of forbearance you are in and which previous months were covered by which type of forbearance. They will also notify you when you have been placed in a new IDR plan. '' It has been more than 10 business days since I've submit my application ( and MOHELA verified receipt of the application ), but I haven't heard any information about whether or not I've been placed on processing forbearance.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

I need the following to happen ASAP : Please remove the forbearance on my account and put me back into the repayment IBR/IDR plan I had before SAVE. Previously, I had to cancel my autopay because Mohela was collecting roughly {$70.00} from my bank account which should have never came out and MOhela didn't know where it went. I want the autopay back on but the forbearance status is preventing me from doing so, and i want my IBR/IDR payments to resume for PSLF credit. 

I am being forced into a low paying PSLF job because i can't set up payments. I'm very upset as this issue impacts my income.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
Background : I was enrolled in XXXX and placed in the XXXX XXXX  I submitted an XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) XXXX XXXX to enroll in a different plan on XX/XX/XXXX. My goal was to make payments that qualified for XXXX as the XXXX XXXX did not. On XX/XX/XXXX, the XXXX XXXX XXXX announced that XXXX applications were again being processed. On my XXXX  account, the page states Your loan servicer has received your application. Theyll start reviewing it, including any documentation of income provided, and will notify you once their review is completed. As my XXXX  application can now be processed and I am not receiving XXXX credit due to the XXXX XXXX, I wanted to be placed on a processing forbearance. 
I called Mohela on XX/XX/XXXX at XXXX XXXX and requested to speak to a representative regarding my XXXX application and a processing forbearance. The wait time was approximately XXXX minutes and I requested a call back. I received a call back approximately XXXX hours and XXXX minutes later and spent and additional XXXX hour and XXXX minutes on the phone with Mohela. 
I first spoke to a representative who was unable to help me and transferred me to some sort of advanced representative. I was placed on another long hold. The advanced representative stated that rules and regulations prevented me from being placed on a processing forbearance. I asked what the rules and regulations were and the advanced representative directed me to this website : https : //studentaid.gov/announcements-events/save-court-actions and, specifically, the XXXX does forbearance affect me? section. I read it and stated that there is no rule or regulation that prevents me from entering a processing forbearance. The advanced representative placed me on another lengthy hold and connected me with a dispute resolution XXXX. 
The dispute resolution XXXX did not state that there was a rule or regulation preventing me from being put on a processing forbearance. Instead, the dispute resolution XXXX stated that I couldnt be put on a processing forbearance because Mohela had not received guidance from the Department of Education and/or XXXX  on whether they could start processing XXXX applications for borrowers in XXXX XXXX I stated that according to the Department XXXX XXXX website, https : XXXX, as of XX/XX/XXXX, Borrowers who do not want to be in this forbearance can contact their servicer to change repayment plans. There XXXX still be forbearance associated with changing to certain repayment plans. See below for more information. 
Further, Servicers will also process applications for recalculations for XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX. Servicers will have applications in the queue that will take some time to work through. XXXX for XXXX ( formerly known as XXXX XXXX applications and applications where borrowers checked lowest monthly payment will remain paused. Borrowers should check back here for updates. If servicers need time to process a borrowers XXXX application, servicers will move the borrower into a processing forbearance for up to 60 days. Interest accrues during this short-term processing forbearance, and time in the processing forbearance is eligible for XXXX and XXXX forgiveness. If the borrowers application is not processed by their servicer within 60 days, the borrower will be moved into a general forbearance that does not count toward XXXX or XXXX until their application is processed. Interest will not accrue in this general forbearance. 
The XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX website clearly states that applications can be processed and that a processing forbearance is permitted. The Dispute Resolution XXXX reiterated they had not received approval from the DXXXX XXXX XXXX  to process an XXXX application for a borrower that is in XXXX fXXXX  The Dispute Resolution XXXX could not point to any information that stated Mohela was justified in this view but continued stating this despite public information put out by the XXXX XXXX XXXX  to the contrary. Mohela is taking an absurd and indefensible position here that hasand continuesto harm me. I am confident that others in a similar position are also being harmed. 
In fact, this position is so outlandish I wouldnt be surprised that they have some sort of monetary gain in refusing to move me out of the XXXXXXXX XXXX  They are, of course, part of the litigation that caused the XXXX plan to be halted and have provided notoriously underwhelming service historically. 
If Mohela can not read and apply simple and straightforward guidance from the XXXX XXXX XXXX to the detriment of borrowers, why are they permitted to service loans? I am extremely dissatisfied with Mohela and believe they are acting in bad faith and unlawfully.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally address a matter concerning a loan originally associated with my sons financial aid at XXXX XXXX, a school that has been closed for over 10 years. I had previously provided my personal information to the creditor in order to assist my son with securing financial aid and a loan. However, I was informed that the account related to XXXX XXXX had been removed from my credit report due to the closure of the institution and any associated debts not being pursued.

Recently, I have noticed that this account has resurfaced, and I am now being contacted relentlessly for payment. I had consistently reminded them that the school has been shut down for more than a decade, and, as I mentioned, this account was previously removed from my credit report.

Given these circumstances, I respectfully request a full review of this account. Additionally, I requested that they cease the constant phone calls, as they have become an undue burden and are causing significant distress.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this issue.

Consumer complaint narrative:
My loan servicer is Mohela and in summer XXXX they underwent a platform transition as they moved their online portal to mohela.studentaid.gov. I submitted my XX/XX/XXXX payment via check since my portal was unavailable. I sent it on XX/XX/XXXX to the address provided to me by customer service : XXXX XXXX XXXX - Mohela, XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, MO XXXX. My bank statement shows that Mohela deposited this check on XX/XX/XXXX. On my bill due date XX/XX/XXXX I had access to my portal and my account showed my payment as past due. 

I called Mohela on XX/XX/XXXX and provided copies of the check I sent as well as my bank statement. I have called countless times to follow-up on the status of the processing of my payment. I have been told wait times ranging from 14 to 90 days. On XX/XX/XXXX I was told that the original ticket type my problem was submitted under on XX/XX/XXXX was incorrect and had to be resubmitted. I have waited on hold on average XXXX hours each time to wait to speak to an advanced representative who can provide no guidance and only states that I have to wait for accounting adjust my account. This delay is costing me a valuable month towards my Public Service Loan Forgiveness count. This processing time for reflecting a simple one-time payment by check is unacceptable.

Consumer complaint narrative:
We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXX schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding XXXX XXXX applications and provide full relief for those impacted. 
Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : * XXXX University XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX University XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX University XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX University XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX University XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Department of Education has XXXX found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXX University misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within XXXX months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 
At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in XXXX states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Summary and Statements of Facts. 
We are asking you to take immediate steps to : XXXX. Approve all outstanding XXXX XXXX applications for students who attended these institutions. 
XXXX. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans. 
XXXX. Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts. 
Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the XXXX XXXX, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it. 
We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays. 
Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Mohela customer service has made it nearly impossible to correct issues with my parent plus loans. 

-I hired a 3rd party company to manage my parent loans and 3 kids student loans as the rules and requirements became too complex for a non-expert.

-proper paperwork was filled out to allow them to act as my surrogate for the loans.

-paperwork was submitted and payments were supposed to start early last year.

-Mohela calculation was wrong due to me retiring in that time. We estimate an approximate {$400.00} per month error. Appropriate paperwork was filled out.

-Notified by Mohela of a forbearance being put into place -On XX/XX/year> I was notified by Mohela that my forbearance would end in 45 days. Still new estimate on completion of my re-calculation. 

-A new forbearance was requested for XXXX through XX/XX/year> as it is only allowed for two months at a time. ( Even though I believe it should have been automatic since I was still waiting for their delay ) -On XX/XX/year> I was informed that my payment for XXXX was overdue. Although I had submitted a longer term forbearance, I was told it would take 90 days to process and I would have to call directly to Mohela to have a 2 month forbearance go into effect immediately and not be late in payments. 

-myself and the third party company spent hours waiting online to speak with a Mohela representative. Once the third party got through, they then called me to be on the line as required by Mohela. We did the same thing for XXXX and XXXX. 

-Received a message that my next payment was due on XX/XX/XXXX. We contacted Mohela on XX/XX/XXXX. There was a multi-hour wait to speak to a representative. Once we did speak to a representative, we were told that we were currently under a forbearance through the remainder of XX/XX/XXXX and I would have to contact them the next day to request another forbearance. We waited another few hours and talked with a person who then forwarded us to another part of Mohela with another multi-hour wait. 

-Two weeks ago, I received another late payment notice because the 60 day forbearance had expired. Another longer term forbearance was submitted with the proper forms to Mohela. The response back was that it will take 90 days to process. That would put me nearly 5 payments behind. ( Still no progress on the relcalculation submitted nearly a year ago. 

-Third party is now not allowed to call them, so I have to call and wait on the line for the phone forbearance. Contacted them on XXXX. Was told by recording that there would be a 2 hour wait. Waited on the line for 3 hours and 33 minutes and someone answered and confirmed my information for billing purposes and told me I was late on my payment. I explained what I needed and she understood and transferred me to another Mohela department. The recording said it would be at least another 3 hour wait time on hold. At that point I could be on the phone for another 3 hours. I then called today ( XXXX ) just before XXXX and was told it would be a 2 hour wait. I chose the callback option which was not offered the day before. After selecting that option a recording said the wait time was 2 hours. It is now 6 hours later with no call. Once they do call, I will have to repeat being transferred and be on hold for multiple hours again. 

-A second IDR recalculation request was made in XXXX for the recalculation. 

-It currently shows that I owe {$16000.00} more than I did when this all started because of compounding interest that supposedly is going to be corrected at some point. 

While I understand the changes that are taking place. All of the recording messages from Mohela say they are a dept collector. A situation has been created that makes it impossible to stay above water with this thing and not be delinquent, even though they are a contractor with the government to manage these loans. Not only do I think their actual rules are not being followed, I feel there is willful delay tactics and potential fraud occurring with Mohela and these loans. 

In addition to filing complaints with multiple organizations, I have also contacted my Senators and Representatives with this same information as I believe it is either intentional or extremely poor management by Mohela and I am the ultimate recipient of those failures. Not only have I kept all correspondences on this matter, but the 3rd party I hired has also saved their documents.

-
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Consumer complaint narrative:
I did submit all signed documents required for the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX from the XXXX XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX in PDF format. I received an encrypted message back from NELNET saying the following : Dear XXXX, Thank you for your service to our country. 

This email is to confirm that your XXXX student loan verification form has been received and processed. A copy is attached for your records. The original, along with a copy of your Master Promissory Note ( XXXX ), has been mailed to the address provided in section XXXX of your form. 

Just know that were here for you when you need us. If you have any questions, please call us at XXXX or visit XXXX. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX. 
Nelnet XXXX # XXXX -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- The information contained in this message is confidential proprietary property of Nelnet XXXX XXXX and its affiliated companies ( Nelnet ) and is intended for the recipient only. Any reproduction, forwarding, or copying without the express permission of Nelnet is strictly prohibited. If you have received this communication in error, please notify us immediately by replying to this e-mail. 

-- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- After months of waiting, continuing to make my {$78.00} payments on my loan and no change to the loan amount ( no reduction in the loan amount ), I emailed NELNET on XX/XX/XXXX saying : XXXX, XXXX sent in documentation to have the SLRP program pay a portion of my student loans, but I have not seen it approved or any of the loan amount diminished. Can someone please update me, I believe the information # for the request was XXXX. Please let me know if there is anything further I can do. 

Thank you, XXXX XXXX -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- I received a response on XX/XX/XXXX Dear XXXX, We have received the documentation you recently sent. However, we are only able to open documents in a, .PDF, or .TIF format XXXX Please resend all of your documentation in XXXX of these formats so we can begin processing your request. 
We are unable to open password protected attachments, however, if you reply to this email, your response will be encrypted for security. 
Were here for you when you need us. If you have any questions, please call us at XXXX, visit XXXX, or connect with us at Facebook.com/Nelnet or Twitter.com/Nelnet. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX. 
Nelnet -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- - I then resent the PDF documents immediately to be told again that the documents were not in PDF format. 


The documents were in pdf format and were not encrypted or sent with a password protecting them. I will attached them to confirm

Consumer complaint narrative:
Edfinancial Services XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, TN XXXX NOTICE TO AGENT IS NOTICE TO PRINCIPAL AND NOTICE TO PRINCIPAL IS NOTICE TO AGENT To whom this may concern This is a reply to the CFPB via # XXXX please be advised Under the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act, the CFPB has the authority to take action against institutions violating consumer financial laws, including engaging in unfair, deceptive, or abusive acts or practices. The Bureau found that Edfinancial violated the Consumer Financial Protection Act by engaging in deceptive acts and practices. Edfinancial is on record via CFPB stating and quote regarding the student loan account we service for you on behalf of the U.S.

Department of Education ( the Department ).

That violates FDCPA 15 U.S.C 1692e ( 1 ) by falsely representing or implying that Edfinancial are affiliated with the United States of America.

Edfinancial is a loan servicer which in fact is a third party individual company that has no ownership nor common control by the U.S. Department of education.

15 U.S. Code 1692f - Unfair practices A debt collector may not use unfair or unconscionable means to collect or attempt to collect any debt. Without limiting the general application of the foregoing, the following conduct is a violation of this section : 15 U.S. Code 1692e ( 12 ) - False or misleading representations ( 12 ) The false representation or implication that accounts have been turned over to innocent purchasers for value.

15 U.S. Code 6809 - Definitions ( 5 ) Nonaffiliated third party The term " nonaffiliated third party '' means any entity that is not an affiliate of, or related by common ownership or affiliated by corporate control with, the financial institution, but does not include a joint employee of such institution.

Edfinancial, XXXX, XXXX and XXXX are not affiliates of the U.S Department of Education nor are they " bureaus. The only true credit bureau is the CFPB and they DO NOT furnish consumer reports as stated in federal law. I have a right to privacy and Per the Privacy Act of 1974 as a federally protected consumer I am now revoking any and all authorization I the consumer may have given the U.S. Department of Education written, non written, verbal, and nonverbal per 5 U.S. Code 552a. Per the FCRA as a federally protected consumer. I am now opting out of any and all authorization I the consumer may have given you XXXX, non written, verbal, and non verbal per 15 USC 6802. I shall also point out their responsibility pursuant 15 U.S. Code section Students ' financial records are confidential in accordance with the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ). FERPA is a federal law that protects the privacy of student education records, including financial record. So your company can not take my nonpublic personal information and furnish it on a public forum like XXXX XXXX and XXXX for everyone to see. 
The confidentiality of my nonpublic personal information is very important and prohibited by federal laws. FERPA protects the privacy of students ' education records, FERPA prohibits the disclosure of personally identifiable information without the student 's consent.

The records covered by FERPA Financial aid applications Student account information Federal work-study payroll records Cost of attendance information Financial aid history information Documentation of professional judgment decisions 15 U.S. Code 1692k ( a ) AMOUNT OF DAMAGES Except as otherwise provided by this section, any debt collector who fails to comply with any provision of this subchapter with respect to any person is liable to such person in an amount equal to the sum of.

By taking nonpublic personal information and attempting to collect a debt you have no legal right too and that I clearly dont owe and making a false statement and furnishing a consumer report is a direct violation that goes against the FDCPA AND FDCPA.

15 usc 1692j furnishing certain deception forms ( a ) It is unlawful to design, compile, and furnish any form knowing that such form would be used to create the false belief in a consumer that a person other than the creditor of such consumer is participating in the collection of or in an attempt to collect a debt such consumer allegedly owes such creditor, when in fact such person is not so participating.

According to 15 U.S.C. ( the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, FDCPA ), a debt collector does not have the legal right to a debt itself ; instead, the law outlines specific restrictions on how a debt collector can attempt to collect a debt, prohibiting them from using abusive, deceptive, or unfair practices to do so.

Key points about 15 U.S.C. and debt collectors : No inherent right to the debt. The law does not grant debt collectors ownership of the debt ; they are only allowed to try to collect it on behalf of the original creditor, following specific guidelines like common ownership or control, not third party debt collectors.

Prior Written Consent to Disclose the Students Records a student must provide written consent before an education agency or institution may disclose personally identifiable information from the students education records. The written consent must state the purpose of the disclosure, specify the records that may be disclosed, identify the party or class of parties to whom the disclosure may be made, and be signed and dated.

15 U.S. Code 6801 - Protection of nonpublic personal information ( a ) Privacy obligation policy It is the policy of the Congress that each financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of its customers and to protect the security and confidentiality of those customers nonpublic personal information.

A service provider is any person or entity that receives, maintains, processes, or otherwise is permitted access to customer information by providing services directly to your school. Your school must take reasonable steps to have service providers that are capable of maintaining appropriate safeguards for customer information, and you must require your service providers by contract to implement and maintain such safeguards. FTC regulations : 16 CFR 313.3 ( n ) and 16 CFR 314.15 Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act : Sections 501 and 505 ( b ) ( 2 ) U.S. Code : 15 USC 6801 ( b ), 6805 ( b ) ( 2 )

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem with your payment plan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I consolidated my loans for PSLF purposed on XX/XX/XXXX. Mohela received my consolidated loans including an IDR request on XX/XX/XXXX or XXXX, XXXX. Since their receipt of my consolidated loans my account has had a pending IDR request for the SAVE repayment plan that was an option at that time. Despite filing this request in XXXX, Mohela never processed the IDR application, so my loans have been in limbo. They were not classified as SAVE nor placed in a SAVE forbearance because Mohela did not process my XXXX IDR application prior to the XXXX court stay. Since XXXX, my loans have been in a non-SAVE forbearance. This forbearance was extended in XXXX. I requested a processing forbearance to reflect that I had a pending IDR application; however, I never received any final confirmation about what type of forbearance my loans were placed in despite numerous calls and complaints. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I filed a new IDR application through the Dept. of Ed. requesting a non-SAVE IDR payment plan, so that I can resume accruing PSLF qualifying payments. The application went through and I received confirmation at the time of application that my IDR request was forwarded to MOHELA for processing. When I filed the IDR application on XX/XX/XXXX, my loans were still in the unknown type of forbearance. In the application I requested that my loans be taken out of that forbearance once the IDR application is processed. I also understand, after years of managing my student loans and always completing IDR applications, that when a Servicer receives a new or updated IDR application, that the Servicer automatically places the loans in a processing forbearance until the new IDR application is processed. I know this not only from experience, but the IDR application itself states this will happen upon receipt of the IDR application. 

Unbeknownst to me, apparently Mohela processed my XXXX IDR request in early XXXX pursuant to my account information on Federal Student Aid. This early XXXX processing never appeared on my Mohela account. To date, this information does not appear on my Mohela account. I did not received any correspondence until XX/XX/XXXX, when I received a letter in my Mohela inbox entitled Your Student Loans Have Been Placed In A Forbearance. The letter indicated that my loans were placed in a SAVE forbearance. However, I did not receive any additional correspondence stating when the SAVE forbearance would start. My account online continues to show the forbearance placed in XXXX and showed that my loans are in a standard repayment plan, with the first payment due XX/XX/XXXX. My account online has never shown that my loans were placed into a SAVE forbearance. 

On XX/XX/XXXX I received a message in my inbox entitled Your Electronic IDR request was received. I contacted The Department of Educations Federal Student Aid and asked about the timeframes Servicers must follow regarding 1. When a Servicer must update/place student loans into a forbearance after receipt of an IDR application and 2. When a Servicer must process an IDR request. Federal Student Aid informed me that after a Servicer receives an IDR application, if they have not processed it in 10 days the Servicer must automatically place the borrowers student loans into a forbearance reflecting that a new IDR application has been received and is pending processing. 

On XX/XX/XXXX I received a notice that I had a message in my Mohela inbox. The notice, which is actually dated XX/XX/XXXX states that my loans are on a standard repayment plan and the first payment will be due XX/XX/XXXX. 

As stated, I received a message in my Mohela inbox stating that Mohela received my IDR application on XX/XX/XXXX. As of today, XX/XX/XXXX, I have not received any update about my loans being placed into forbearance that reflects my IDR request is pending processing. My account online continues to show that a payment is due on XX/XX/XXXX at the standard repayment plan amount. My account shows that my loans are in forbearance, however, this is the same forbearance my loans were placed into in XXXX, prior to the XX/XX/XXXX update that my loans were place in a SAVE forbearance. Critically, the current forbearance does not reflect either the SAVE administrative forbearance or the new forbearance that my loans should have been placed in 10 days after the receipt of my new IDR request Mohela received on XX/XX/XXXX. 

I emailed Mohela using the messaging platform on my account 's inbox/correspondence page requesting that that Mohela places my loans in the correct forbearance to reflect that there is a new pending IDR application. Mohela has not responded. Also, it is now past the 30 day processing time for Mohela to process my XX/XX/XXXX IDR application. I have not received any updates.

For reference, I have attached a copy of the IDR application page that states that Servicers will place loans into a forbearance while they are processing the IDR application, a copy of my Mohela inbox showing the limited correspondence I have received, a copy of the XX/XX/XXXX general SAVE forbearance letter, a copy of the XX/XX/XXXX receipt of IDR application letter, and the XX/XX/XXXX though uploaded on XX/XX/XXXX letter regarding my loans being on a standard repayment plan with the first payment due XX/XX/XXXX.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Formal Request for Student Loan Cancellation Due to FERPA, Privacy Act, and Data Security Violations To whom it may concen, I am writing to formally request the cancellation and discharge of my student loans serviced by Nelnet due to multiple violations of federal laws, including : The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) The Privacy Act of 1974 The Higher Education Act Failure to Secure Student Data ( Data Security Breach or Mishandling ) Legal Violations & Supporting Evidence Unauthorized Disclosure of My Educational and Financial Information It has come to my attention that my personal educational and financial information has been improperly accessed by unauthorized third parties, including XXXX XXXX or affiliated entities. This unauthorized access constitutes a gross violation of my federal privacy rights and nullifies any enforceable loan agreements under federal law. 
FERPA Violation : The exposure of my educational records without my express written consent is a direct breach of FERPA, which mandates the protection of personally identifiable information. 
Failure to Protect Personally Identifiable Information ( PII ) Breach of Contract and Data Security Obligations : By failing to protect my sensitive information, NELNET has breached contractual terms and obligations, rendering these debts unenforceable. 
Nelnet failed to secure my sensitive information, leading to possible identity theft, fraudulent loans, or other financial harm. 
Negligence in Complying with Federal Regulations on Student Privacy Violation of the Privacy Act of 1974 : The mishandling and unauthorized disclosure of my personal information contravenes federal requirements that safeguard the privacy of individuals ' data managed by federal agencies and contractors. 
Breach of the Higher Education Act : The Higher Education Act requires servicers to maintain strict confidentiality and compliance in loan transfers. The transfer of my loan to NELNET and subsequent data breaches demonstrate clear negligence. 
These violations constitute a serious breach of federal law, affecting my financial security and legal rights. As a result, I demand the following actions : Requested Actions : Immediate Discharge of My Student Loans Complete Removal of all NELNET related entries from my credit report and any Related Negative Credit Reporting A Written Confirmation of Loan Cancellation Within 30 Days Failure to comply with this request will result in immediate action, including formal complaints to the U.S. Department of Education, the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and my State Attorney Generals Office. If necessary, I will also pursue legal remedies. 
Please confirm receipt of this letter and provide a written response within 30 days. I expect a resolution of this matter promptly.

Subject : Immediate Action Needed : Approve Outstanding Borrower Defense Applications To the Departments Overseeing School & Loan Server Compliance, We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXXXXXX XXXX, urging immediate action to approve outstanding Borrower Defense applications and provide full relief for those impacted.

Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : * XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX The Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXX XXXX  misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within six months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 

At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in 26 states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts.

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : 1. Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions.

2. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans.

3. Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts.

Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the American Dream, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it.

We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays.

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter.

Sincerely, Students & Graduates of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

On or around XX/XX/year>, I became aware that individuals associated with XXXX XXXX and his employees accessed databases maintained by the Department of Education containing my personal and financial records related to my student loans. These individuals are neither school officials nor authorized representatives, and I did not provide any authorization for such access. 

This unauthorized access constitutes a violation of my privacy rights under the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and may also violate consumer protection laws governing student loan data security.

Upon learning of this breach, I reached out to Federal Student Aid ( FSA ) to request an investigation and secure my personal records. However, I have not received a satisfactory response regarding how my information was accessed or what steps will be taken to prevent further breaches. Given that student loan servicers and the Department of Education are responsible for protecting borrowers sensitive data, this represents a significant security failure. 

I am filing this complaint with the CFPB because my personal and financial records have been compromised, and I need assurance that my data is secure and that appropriate corrective actions are taken.

All of this given that they told me it would be an estimated XXXX hour wait time, not XXXX hours. 

In the past when I've been able to get through to someone, they make you talk to a triage agent who just confirms your personal information. It can take XXXX hours to get in touch with this first person but they make no attempts to help with your issue. Then they put you on another XXXX hour hold to get to their advanced agent who can help. These tactics make it nearly impossible to get in touch with someone to have your issue resolved.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Sir/Madam, I hope this letter finds you well. I am writing to bring to your attention a critical issue regarding the calculation of payments under the Public Service Loan Forgiveness ( PSLF ) program. Despite my extensive and uninterrupted service of over 13 years with XXXX XXXX XXXX , a qualified employer for PSLF, my payment count towards loan forgiveness remains incomplete.

I have diligently served as a full-time employee for more than a decade, providing essential care and support to individuals and families in need. Throughout this time, I have made consistent efforts to ensure that my payments towards student loan forgiveness are accurately recorded. However, despite exceeding the required threshold of 120 qualifying payments or ten years of service, my loan balance persists, and the burden of monthly payments continues to weigh heavily on me. As the sole provider for two families, the financial strain of ongoing student loan payments is substantial and increasingly challenging to manage. I firmly believe that my diligent service and consistent payments warrant the completion and payoff of my student loan, in accordance with the PSLF program guidelines.

I

kindly request your immediate attention to rectify this discrepancy and ensure that my payment count accurately reflects my years of service and dedication to public service. It is my sincere hope that by correcting this oversight, I can alleviate the financial burden I currently face and achieve the long-awaited relief of student loan forgiveness. I urge you to expedite the review and correction of my payment count, as every month of continued repayment adds to the financial strain I endure. Your swift action in resolving this matter will not only provide much-needed relief but also restore my faith in the integrity of the PSLF program. Please feel free to contact me at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  or XXXX, if further information or clarification is required to facilitate the resolution process. I sincerely appreciate your attention to this matter and look forward to a favorable outcome.

Thank you for your understanding and assistance. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

The Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXXXXXX XXXX misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within six months of graduation. At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXXXXXX XXXX across campuses in 26 states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts.

Consumer complaint narrative:
This is a follow-up to my previous complaint ( XXXX ). My IDR Application has still not been processed. I have had to call Mohela, waiting on hold for hours each time, every 60 days since XXXX of XX/XX/XXXX to have my forbearance renewed, despite the information provided by the studentaid.gov site stating that I should have been placed on the same forbearance as those enrolled in SAVE after the first 60 days had passed. 

On XX/XX/2024 and again on XX/XX/2024, I received an electronic document from Mohela stating that they had been directed by the Department of Education to place my loans in a general forbearance due to the SAVE litigation. There was no end date for this forbearance given on either letter, and every source I can find indicates that this forbearance is not scheduled to end in the near future. However, the day after the second letter, XX/XX/2024, I received a billing statement, due on XX/XX/2024. 

My most recent forbearance ended on XX/XX/2024, the day before my payment was due according to the statement I received on XX/XX/2024. I have previously waited for hours on hold on the day my forbearance was due to end, only to be told that they can not put me in forbearance again until the current one has already ended, meaning I would have had to call on my payment due date to get a forbearance. This was impossible, however, as my due date was on a Saturday, and I could not attempt to reach anyone until the following Tuesday, due to the federal holiday. 

If Mohela had processed my IDR application within the expected timeframe of 60 days, I would not have had to deal with any of these problems. Because they did not, I have had to deal with a constant source of stress and invested numerous hours in trying to avoid having my loans go into default.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I believe that Experian is not complying with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically 15 U.S. Code 1681s-2, which mandates that data furnishers report accurate and complete information. In my case : The account, after its transfer, should not reflect any late payments. However, it inaccurately shows that I have late payments recorded.

The reported payment status contradicts the history of late payments, which misleads potential lenders and adversely affects my creditworthiness.

Under FCRA 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ), I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information, and credit bureaus, including Experian, are obligated to investigate and correct or delete any inaccuracies within 30 days.

Despite my efforts to rectify this situation, the inaccuracies remain, causing significant distress and hindering my ability to secure a home loan. I urge the CFPB to investigate this matter and ensure that Experian complies with its obligations under the FCRA. 

I am submitting a formal complaint under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) regarding inaccurate information on my credit report by XXXX, XXXX, and Experian student loan accounts ; that have been consolidated into the XXXX Department of Education. 

Upon reviewing my credit report, I noticed that this account XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX is incorrectly marked as 120 days late, XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX in payments. Despite being transferred and reported as paying as agreed In payment status and at the time of the consolidation. This information is inconsistent and misleading, which negatively impacts my credit standing. 
My report Also reflects multiple student loan payments listed under separate accounts, despite the fact that my loans were consolidated into one loan. This misrepresentation is Disputed Account Details : XXXX XXXX for XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX date of last activity XX/XX/XXXX date opened XX/XX/XXXX account open For Experian date opened XX/XX/XXXX {$80000.00} date of lat activity XX/XX/XXXX This information is inconsistent and misleading, which negatively impacts my credit standing. There are four extra loans reporting apart when they are in fact included in the XXXX that was billed to me. I listed them along with the other that I hoping late and inaccurate as it was consolidated. To one payment not multiple payments Creditor Name XXXX XXXX XXXX payment {$11.00} XXXX XXXX ( should be no payment on this payment ) {$16.00} XXXX XXXX {$33.00} payment XXXX XXXX {$19.00} There can't be payments reported by themselves for this they are included in XXXX XXXX loan XXXX I am wondering when this was verified for accuracy none of the Information is showing accurate. And true and I misleading. 
Creditor Name : [ XXXX ] Account Number ( Last Four Digits ) : [ XXXX ] Date of Reported Late Payment : [ XX/XX/XXXX / XX/XX/XXXX ] Reported Status : Transferred/Paid as Agreed Issue : Late payments are inaccurately reported despite consolidation Amount owed I not the amount reported FCRA Violations : According to 15 U.S. Code 1681s-2, data furnishers are required to report accurate and complete information. In this case : 1. The account was transferred/consolidated and should not reflect late payments post-transfer..

2. The payment status contradicts the late payment history, which misleads lenders and affects my creditworthiness.

3. Under FCRA 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ), I have the right to dispute any inaccurate or incomplete information, and the credit bureaus must correct or delete inaccurate data within 30 days. This raises serious concerns about their practices and their commitment to adhering to the legal standards set forth under federal law.

Given these ongoing legal issues, it is imperative that my complaint be taken seriously, as it reflects a broader pattern of potential non-compliance that could affect many consumers.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Aidvantage improperly processed my Income-Driven Repayment ( IDR ) request, causing my federal student loans to be placed in forbearance instead of a qualifying repayment plan. This has resulted in the loss of Public Service Loan Forgiveness ( PSLF ) credit, as confirmed by an Aidvantage representative in writing. 
XX/XX/year> : I submitted an IDR application, selecting the lowest available repayment plan to maintain PSLF eligibility. 
XX/XX/year> : Aidvantage sent a letter stating my request was not processed and placed my loans into forbearance. 
XX/XX/year> : I contacted Aidvantage via chat and was informed : My PSLF credit is not accruing due to this error. 
I must reapply instead of Aidvantage fixing the mistake internally, delaying PSLF further.

PSLF credit will not be backdated once the issue is resolved. 
XX/XX/year> : I filed a complaint with the Federal Student Aid Ombudsman ( Case # XXXX ), but Aidvantage has yet to provide a solution.

Issues 1. Aidvantage mishandled my IDR request, placing my loans into forbearance instead of an IDR plan.

2. I am losing PSLF credit monthly, with no resolution or backdating offered.

3. Aidvantage refuses to correct their mistake, forcing me to reapply and restart the process.

Resolution Requested 1. Immediate processing of my original IDR request so PSLF credit resumes accruing. 
2. Backdating of PSLF credit to cover the months lost due to Aidvantages error.

3. Formal written confirmation from the Department of Education ensuring my PSLF eligibility is not negatively impacted.

This mishandling is actively delaying my loan forgiveness. I request the CFPBs intervention to hold Aidvantage accountable and ensure this is corrected without further delay.

The SSN social security number provides and serves as the full faith and credit confirmation through the U.S. acting through the United States Treasury to settle the debts.
