Consumer complaint narrative:
Formal Complaint Regarding Borrower Defense, Credit Reporting Violations, Harassment, Loss of Wages, and Emotional Distress Subject : Fraudulent Reporting, Continuous Violations of Borrower Defense, Credit Reporting Errors, Harassment, and Claim for Loss of Wages and Damages To : Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) Introduction : I am filing this formal complaint due to the long-term and ongoing violations of my rights concerning fraudulent student loans obtained from XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX . Despite my eligibility for loan forgiveness under the Borrower Defense to Repayment program ( 20 U.S.C. 1087e ( h ) ), these loans remain on my credit report. As a result, I have faced significant financial, emotional, and psychological harm. This complaint outlines the numerous violations of federal and Pennsylvania state laws, the financial hardship caused by these violations, my loss of wages, and the emotional and physical damage that has resulted from more than 20 years of wrongful credit reporting and harassment by loan servicers. I seek immediate rectification and substantial financial compensation for the extreme and lasting damage these fraudulent actions have caused to my life. Deceptive Enrollment and Fraudulent Loans I was fraudulently enrolled in XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX under the promise of career opportunities that never materialized. These institutions engaged in deceptive practices, violating Pennsylvanias Unfair Trade Practices and Consumer Protection Law ( UTPCPL ) ( 73 P.S. 201-1 et seq. ), which prohibits misleading consumers into contracts under false pretenses. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX I have never been able to secure employment in that field. Under Borrower Defense to Repayment ( 20 U.S.C. 1087e ( h ) ), I should have been granted forgiveness for these loans when it was established that I was misled into obtaining them. Yet, the loans remain on my credit report, and I have been subjected to continued financial and emotional harm every single day since XXXX XXXX XXXX. Multiple Loan Servicers and Harassment Over the last 20 years, my loans have been transferred between multiple servicers, each of whom has subjected me to constant harassment. Despite the fraudulent nature of these loans, I have received countless phone calls, emails, and letters demanding payment and threatening wage garnishment. This harassment violates the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1692 ), which explicitly forbids abusive and deceptive collection practices. This relentless harassment, combined with the wrongful reporting of my loans, has caused irreparable damage to my credit score, my financial well-being, and my ability to maintain peace of mind. I am legally entitled to compensation for each incident of harassment and wrongful reporting. Continuous Credit Reporting Violations Since XX/XX/XXXX, these fraudulent loans have been reported daily to all three major credit bureausXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXdespite the fact that they were obtained through fraud. This is a clear violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 ), which mandates accurate and fair reporting of consumer information. The wrongful reporting of these loans has destroyed my credit score, leading to severely high interest rates on my home and car loans, preventing me from accessing credit cards, and barring me from obtaining business financing. Every day that this false information remains on my credit report has caused ongoing and compounding financial damage. Loss of Wages Due to Financial Hardship The damage to my credit has significantly impacted my ability to earn a living. I currently make approximately {$4000.00} per month, but without the financial hardship caused by these fraudulent loans, I would be able to earn an estimated {$11000.00} per month based on my education, skills, and potential employment opportunities. The difference of {$7100.00} per month represents lost wages due to the financial and credit barriers created by these loans. Over the past XXXX days ( from XX/XX/XXXX, to today ), this financial loss has accumulated as follows : Difference in monthly income : {$11000.00} ( expected earnings ) - {$4000.00} ( actual earnings ) = {$7100.00}. Loss per day : {$7100.00} 30 days = approximately {$230.00} per day in lost wages. Total loss of wages : {$230.00} XXXX days = {>= $1,000,000}. Emotional and Physical Damages For more than 20 years, I have lived under extreme eXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX due to the wrongful reporting of these loans and the continuous harassment from loan servicers. The financial instability caused by my damaged credit score has forced me to live in unsafe neighborhoods, endure high-interest loans, and be denied opportunities to grow my business. These circumstances have caused physical and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. Under Pennsylvania law and federal consumer protection laws, I am entitled to compensation for these emotional and physical damages. Based on industry standards and precedent cases, emotional and physical distress damages typically range from {$1000.00} to {$5000.00} per day, depending on the severity of the harm caused. Given the ongoing and extreme nature of the distress I have endured, I am claiming {$3500.00} per day in damages for emotional and psychological harm. Damages per day for emotional and physical distress : {$3500.00}. Total days : XXXX days. Total compensation for emotional and physical damages : {$3500.00} XXXX days = {>= $1,000,000}. Punitive Damages In addition to compensatory damages, I am seeking punitive damages to hold the responsible parties accountable for their egregious actions. The fact that I have had to endure over two decades of financial hardship, harassment, and emotional distress due to fraudulent loans demands a punitive response to deter similar misconduct in the future. Punitive damages are awarded in cases of willful and reckless conduct, such as the repeated harassment and violation of consumer protection laws in my case. I am seeking punitive damages equivalent to three times the compensatory damages calculated above, in accordance with legal precedent. Punitive damages : 3 ( {>= $1,000,000} total compensatory damages ) = {>= $1,000,000}. Detailed Calculation of Violations and Damages The following is a comprehensive breakdown of the damages owed, based on legitimate legal statutes, with references to daily violations and accrued losses : Violation Rate per Day/Incident Number of Days/Incidents Total Borrower Defense Violation ( 20 U.S.C. 1087e ) $ XXXX XXXX days {>= $1,000,000} FCRA Violation ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 ) $ XXXX ( XXXX bureaus ) XXXX days {>= $1,000,000} XXXX Harassment ( 15 U.S.C. 1692 ) $ XXXX XXXX incidents {>= $1,000,000} XXXXL Violation ( XXXX P.S. XXXX et seq. ) $ XXXX XXXX days {>= $1,000,000} Loss of Wages $ XXXX XXXX days {>= $1,000,000} Emotional and Physical Distress $ XXXX XXXX days {>= $1,000,000} Total Damages to Date {>= $1,000,000} Punitive Damages : {>= $1,000,000}. XXXX XXXX Damages : {>= $1,000,000}. Ongoing Damages The damages outlined above reflect violations and financial harm up to today, XX/XX/XXXX. However, these damages will continue to accrue daily until this matter is fully resolved. The cost of each violation will continue to increase, and the emotional and financial burden on me will persist. Conclusion and Request for Immediate Action As of today, I am owed a total of {>= $1,000,000} in compensatory and punitive damages. This figure continues to increase each day as the violations and harm persist. I demand the immediate removal of these fraudulent loans from my credit report, the cessation of all collection activities, and full financial compensation for the extensive and irreparable damage done to my life over the past 20 years. I expect the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to take swift action to rectify these egregious violations of the law. Please acknowledge receipt of this complaint and provide guidance on the next steps. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute and request an immediate review of my student loan account due to an unauthorized breach of my personal and financial information. Specifically, my data has been accessed by the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, an entity that is not an official government agency, violating federal privacy laws. This constitutes a severe breach of my rights under FERPA ( Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ) and other data protection regulations.

Nature of the Breach : My student loan records, including sensitive financial and personal details, have been accessed without my consent. 
The entity known as the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXwhich is not a recognized government agencyhas gained access to this sensitive & private information, raising serious legal and privacy concerns. 
Due to this unauthorized access, I no longer feel safe or confident in the security of my financial data, and I am at risk of identity theft, fraud, and further privacy violations. 
Legal Violations and Concerns : 1. FERPA Violation Student loan and financial records are protected under the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ), which requires proper authorization before disclosure to any third party. This breach is a direct violation of these protections.

2. Breach of Trust and Confidentiality My loan servicer and associated federal agencies have a duty to safeguard my private information, which has not been upheld.

3. Potential Consumer Protection Violations Under the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) guidelines, financial institutions must ensure consumer data security.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, MO XXXX XXXX XX/XX/year> Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Data Breach, FERPA and Title IV Violations, and Request for Immediate Discharge of Student Loans To Whom it may concern, I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the XXXX Department of Education ( DOE ) and the Department of Governmental Entities ( XXXX ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( XXXX ) and Title IV regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security. 
I recently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes but is not limited to : My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ). 
My Free Application for XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) data, including financial aid history and loan information. 
My IRS tax transcripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization. 
These actions violate my rights under XXXX ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards. 
Given the severity of this breach and the direct impact on my financial security and privacy, I demand the following corrective actions : Immediate discharge and cancellation of all my federal student loans due to the breach of my financial aid and tax records, which invalidates the integrity of my loan agreements. 
A formal investigation into this data breach, including details on how my records were accessed, who accessed them, and for what purpose. 
A full report on the extent of my data exposure and the corrective measures being implemented to prevent future violations. 
Immediate notification to all major credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX XXXX ) to place a fraud alert and investigate any unauthorized activity that may have resulted from this breach. 
This breach has caused significant distress and concern regarding the security of my personal and financial data. If my demands are not met within XXXX  days, I will be left with no choice but to escalate this matter through legal channels, including filing complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and pursuing legal action against the responsible parties. 
I request a written response addressing these concerns and outlining the immediate actions being taken to remedy this situation. Please direct all correspondence to the address listed above. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this urgent matter. I look forward to your immediate response and resolution. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
MOHELA- My student loans were issued and managed under circumstances that violate federal laws and regulations, and I am formally requesting their full cancellation. As a full-time student, my loans should have remained in deferment per 20 U.S.C. 1087e ( f ). However, my servicer falsely took these loans out of deferment, violating my rights under federal law. The reported amounts, dates, and statuses are also inaccurate and misleading, compounding the harm caused by their improper management. 

Furthermore, I was misled by representatives who provided contradictory information regarding the terms and use of these loans. I was explicitly told that these loans would support my education and related expenses, but their terms prohibit such use. This constitutes a clear case of misrepresentation, violating the Truth in Lending Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1638 ) and Unfair, Deceptive, or Abusive Acts and Practices ( UDAAP ) standards. 

The loan terms are also predatory and unconscionable. The excessive interest rates and fees are designed to trap borrowers in perpetual debt. These practices, combined with the servicers failure to comply with federal deferment requirements, have caused me significant financial and emotional hardship. 

I demand the immediate cancellation of these loans and removal of all negative information from my credit report. If my request is not honored, I will escalate this matter to the Department of Education, Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, and any other relevant regulatory agencies for further investigation and enforcement.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Immediate Action Needed : Approve Outstanding Borrower Defense Applications To the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXX schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding Borrower Defense applications and provide full relief for those impacted. 

Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : * XXXXXXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX The Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXXXXXX XXXX misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within XXXX months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 

At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in XXXX states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts.

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : 1. Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions.

2. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans.

3. Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts.

Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the XXXX XXXX, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it. 

We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays. 

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 

Sincerely, Students & Graduates of XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
Student Loan amount : XXXX Please consider the following : Issue : Did XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, later renamed XXXX XXXX XXXX, breach its agreement with XXXX XXXX regarding employment placement and opportunities after graduating with a XXXX XXXX in Accounting and Business Management? 
Rule : 16 CFR 254.4 - Misrepresentation of facilities, services, qualifications of staff, status, and employment prospects for students after the training. 
( a ) It is deceptive for an Industry Member to misrepresent, directly or indirectly, expressly or by implication, in advertising, promotional materials, recruitment sessions, or in any other manner, the size, location, services, facilities, curriculum, books and materials, or equipment of its school or the number or educational qualifications of its faculty and other personnel. For example, an Industry Member should not : ( 3 ) Misrepresent the availability of employment or the role of the school in providing or arranging for said employment while the student is undergoing instruction.

( 8 ) Misrepresent the nature and extent of any personal instruction, guidance, assistance, or other service, including placement assistance and assistance overcoming language barriers or XXXX  XXXX, it will provide students either during or after completion of a course ( XXXX ) It is deceptive for an Industry Member, in promoting any course or program of instruction in its advertising, promotional materials, or in any other manner, to misrepresent, directly or indirectly, expressly or by implication, whether through the use of text, images, endorsements, or by other means, the availability of employment after graduation from a school or program of instruction, the specific type of employment available to a student after graduation from a school or program of instruction, the success that the Industry Member 's graduates have realized in obtaining such employment, including the percentage of graduates who have received employment, or the salary or salary range that the Industry Member 's graduates have received, or can be expected to receive, in such employment. 
Analysis : Before XXXX enrollment in XXXX XXXX, she was a wife, mother, and successful businesswoman looking to elevate her career to the next level to further provide for her family. She frequently heard the radio, saw television, billboards, etc. advertisements about XXXX XXXX success rate in job placement and opportunities after attending and graduating with a degree from XXXX. It was because of these claims that were abundantly advertised, that XXXX decided on XXXX XXXX  to further her education. In XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX enrolled in the XXXX XXXX XXXX : in Accounting and Business Management. 
Since her graduation from the program in XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX has not been able to be gainfully employed nor has she received any assistance or job leads in her field of study. 
According to an article that was published by the Department of Education on XX/XX/XXXX, After a review of voluminous amounts of evidence, the Department found that from XXXX to XXXX DeVry repeatedly misled prospective students across the country with claims that XXXX percent of XXXX graduates who actively seek employment obtained jobs in their field of study within XXXX months of graduation. This claim was the foundation of a national advertising campaign called, We Major in Careers to brand DeVry as a XXXX XXXX University where it used the XXXX percent placement statistic as the way to convince prospective students to enroll. 
In fact, the institutions actual job placement rate was around XXXX percent. The Department found that more than half of the jobs included in the claimed XXXX percent placement rate were held by students who obtained them well before graduating from XXXX and often before they even enrolled. These jobs were not attributable to a XXXX education and their inclusion was contrary to the plain language of the XXXX percent claim. Moreover, XXXX excluded from its calculation large numbers of graduates who were in fact actively looking for work simply because they did not conduct a search in the manner that the XXXX XXXX XXXX department preferred. 
The Department also found that senior XXXX officials knew of the problems with the XXXX percent statistic for years, in part due to concerns about its accuracy raised by alumni. 
In XXXX, the FTC reached a {$100.00} XXXX settlement with XXXX around similar allegations. The Department also reached a settlement with XXXX related to older job placement rate statistics in XXXX. The attorneys general of New York and Massachusetts also reached agreements with XXXX in XXXX to resolve allegations of misleading job placement rates. 
During this period of misrepresentation, XXXX was a publicly traded company owned by XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, which was later renamed XXXX XXXX XXXX. Senior leaders at XXXX during this time included XXXX XXXX, who served as President and CEO from XXXX through XXXX and XXXX XXXX, who served as the XXXX vice president and/or president of XXXX University XXXX XXXX through XXXX. XXXX sold XXXX in XXXX. 
Conclusion : In conclusion, to date, the Department has identified approximately XXXX borrowers who will be eligible for approximately {$71.00} XXXX in discharges because they relied on XXXX misrepresentation in deciding to enroll. The number of approvals is anticipated to grow as the Department reviews outstanding claims from former XXXX students. All borrowers with approved claims will receive full relief. It is self-evident that XXXX is XXXX student that was harmed by the fraud XXXX has XXXX been proven to have committed and respectfully asks her student loan debt be XXXX.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX waived my application into Full Class for XXXX v XXXX XX/XX/XXXX. 
I have checked in via chat on numerous occasions to check the status of my discharge. MOHELA representatives kept saying they didn't have any information or that XXXX did not send information yet. Meanwhile XXXX says they did send the information. 
On XX/XX/XXXX a new message appeared on my online account saying there is a " discharge application pending. '' Today XX/XX/XXXX I messaged with XXXX who's says " we filed discharge claim with the guarantor on XX/XX/XXXX please allow 90-120 business days to process. '' Why in this age of technology would it take over 3 months to process when others who went to the same school and did the same application and have the same servicer in this situation have already been discharged? ( Not to mention that other servicers are moving at a much faster pace for these discharges... ) Why did it take them 3 months just to get the information to process it in the first place?

Consumer complaint narrative: Today I have spent over an hour and a half on the phone, the entirety of my call was recorded according to the agent i spoke with. The date of this call is XX/XX/XXXX and the time frame is approximately XXXX through XXXX. I have received an email on XX/XX/XXXX directly from federal student aid that explicitly authorizes SAVE borrowers, like myself, presently on a general forbearance ( which I never requested and was place in without my consent ), to apply for any other income driven repayment plan. I in fact applied for the XXXX plan on XX/XX/XXXX, which Mohela received on XX/XX/XXXX. To date they have not processed my application. Today, my call was eventually escalated to an agent with Mohela 's resolution department. Her name is XXXX and her employee ID number is XXXX. She informed me that Mohela has been instructed by the department of education to NOT PROCESS XXXX APPLICATIONS FOR THOSE PRESENTLY ON SAVE. She later acknowledge this was incorrect information and she was mistaken but that its hard to keep up with federal changes. It is Mohelas obligation to be up to date on federal updates. She further informed me the department of education instructed Mohela to NOT PLACE BORROWERS PRESENTLY STUCK ON SAVE WHO REQUEST A DIFFERENT XXXX PLAN IN A PROCESSING FORBEARANCE THAT COUNTS TOWARDS public service loan forgiveness. She was adamant about this. That position is in direct contradiction to an email I received from federal student aid on XX/XX/XXXX, which I can provide you. It is also in direct contradiction to information on XXXX 's website, which does not indicate ANYWHERE that SAVE BORROWERS are not entitled to the processing forbearance and are not entitled to have their XXXX applications reviewed or acted upon -- both of which XXXX told me today. Moreover, such an instruction from the department of education would be in direct violation of federal CMRs which state : " ( i ) Changing repayment plans. A borrower who is repaying under an IDR plan XXXX change at any time to any other repayment plan for which the borrower is eligible, except as otherwise provided.... '' This plainly allows borrowers to access and apply for income driven repayment plans at any time, but according to XXXX at Mohela, the Department of Education has told Mohela to not process XXXX applications for borrowers presently stuck on XXXX against their will and not allow a processing forbearance. XXXX informed me the only way I am entitled to a processing forbearance is if I requested to be placed on the standard repayment plan, which would require me to pay over {$2000.00} a month, which I can not afford, nor am I obligated to pay when on an income driven repayment plan. XXXX has been unable to provide me with any documentation, from anywhere, that states that the department of education instructed Mohela or any other agency to not place borrowers with a pending IDR application on a processing forbearance. I would encourage you to request to listen to the recorded call and review the federal student aid website which instructs SAVE borrowers that they are entitled to apply for an income driven repayment plan, they they are entitled to have mohela review that application, and that they are entitled to a processing forbearance.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, California, XXXX ( XXXX ) XXXX XX/XX/year> Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Data Breach, FERPA and Title IV Violations, and Request for Immediate Discharge of Student Loans To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the U.S. Department of Education ( DOE ) and the Department of Governmental Entities ( DOGE ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security. 

I recently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes but is not limited to : XXXX. My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ). 
XXXX. My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including financial aid history and loan information. 
XXXX. My IRS tax transcripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization. 

These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards. 

Given the severity of this breach and the direct impact on my financial security and privacy, I demand the following corrective actions : XXXX. Immediate discharge and cancellation of all my federal student loans due to the breach of my financial aid and tax records, which invalidates the integrity of my loan agreements. 
XXXX. A formal investigation into this data breach, including details on how my records were accessed, who accessed them, and for what purpose. 
XXXX. A full report on the extent of my data exposure and the corrective measures being implemented to prevent future violations. 
XXXX. Immediate notification to all major credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX XXXX ) to place a fraud alert and investigate any unauthorized activity that may have resulted from this breach. 

This breach has caused significant distress and concern regarding the security of my personal and financial data. If my demands are not met within 30 days, I will be left with no choice but to escalate this matter through legal channels, including filing complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and pursuing legal action against the responsible parties. 

I request a written response addressing these concerns and outlining the immediate actions being taken to remedy this situation. Please direct all correspondence to the address listed above. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this urgent matter. I look forward to your immediate response and resolution. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX
Company: Servicer under contract with Federal Student Aid

Consumer complaint narrative: As of XXXX, I reached my XXXX years or XXXX months of qualifying employment and submitted what should have been my final XXXX. However, my payment counts stopped at XXXX out of XXXX and seemed to remain that way. No more movement was made on my account or payment amounts and I had a few months of payments that did not qualify due to the SAVE injunction placing everyone into administrative forbearance. On XX/XX/XXXX I submitted a buyback or reconsideration request for my PSLF in hopes of getting those payments to qualify or recieve credit for at least two more months so I could receive my forgiveness, which should have been granted in XXXX. I received word about this application and contacting StudentAid.Gov returned no useful results. Around XX/XX/XXXX I checked Student Aid 's website to see that my payment counts had been updated and suddenly, I was now at XXXX. Excitedly, I submitted a request to change my repayment plan, hoping to switch from the SAVE plan to a regular IDR plan so I could get my final payment to count and trigger my forgiveness finally. There was no confirmation about this. I contacted my servicer, XXXX, and StudentAid.gov, who confirmed the application is in, but currently in processing limbo. I have not been given any further updates about my request nor have I been placed in a processing forbearance, which would also allow my payments to count. On XX/XX/XXXX I tried calling StudentAid.gov yet again to find out any information I could about my options, my pending requests and was told that I would see an update from them in the following week or the first week of XXXX about my applications and forgiveness. On the XXXX is when I discovered that my payment count had been rolled back yet again to XXXX, I was extremely confused and disheartened, leading me to reach out once more to StudentAid.gov to find out what had happened and if there was anything that could be done. Yet again I was offered no useful information, only that both applications were still pending and had not yet reached 90 days, so to wait until that time. I am feeling frustrated, misled, and deeply misinformed. This is beyond unacceptable and needs to be rectified.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I believe Navient misled me regarding the management of my student loans and the income-driven repayment ( IDR ) options available to me. Throughout my interactions with Navient, I was provided with inaccurate or incomplete information about the terms and benefits of IDR plans, including their potential to lower my monthly payments and lead to eventual loan forgiveness after a set period.

Instead of being guided toward income-driven repayment plans, I was directed to forbearance or other options that increased the overall cost of my loans through additional interest accrual. Had Navient provided accurate guidance, I would have pursued IDR plans earlier, reducing my financial burden and aligning my repayment strategy with my financial situation.

These actions have caused unnecessary financial hardship and delayed my progress toward resolving my student loan debt.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I have an XXXX loan that is now with AES. I have a graduate loan that is now with XXXX. I am trying to get the loan that is with AES to be registered on the student loan.gov website so I can accurately develop a payback plan. The loan with AES originally dates back to XXXX. I consolidated it with my husband at the time ( who died in XXXX ). Because he was a deadbeat, after our divorce, I was the only one who paid back our student loans. There were times I had to put the loans in forbearance or deferment because I didn't have enough money to make the payments. I have been paying on this loan for years and my balance is still growing and growing. I declared bankruptcy in XXXX, and my attorney said that student loans were not covered in the bankruptcy. I'm trying to get copies of the documents from this bankruptcy to see if they were even listed as a debtor. 

I want to consolidate my XXXX and XXXX  loans and get on the payment plan for PSLF. I have been employed at non-profit organizations since XXXX. However, I don't want to consolidate them if I'm eligible to have the loans forgiven because of how long I've been paying on them or for any other reason. I don't trust the loan companies. I feel like every time I've spoken to AES, they give me incorrect information because they don't want me to know what I'm truly eligible for. I just want straight answers, and I want to pay back the loans without constantly seeing my balance increase despite my payments. Can someone please help me? 
XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/XXXX - Medical student loans were successfully consolidated and received by MOHELA for a principal amount of {$310000.00}. 

XX/XX/XXXX - federal judges block portions of SAVE prompting the Department of Education to put SAVE borrowers and those who applied on an indefinite forbearance XX/XX/XXXX - MOHELA sends me a XXXX  stating a payment for {$1900.00} is due on XX/XX/XXXX. I call them to be put on forbearance and delay payments while waiting to be put on the SAVE plan. 

XX/XX/XXXX - I call MOHELA again, twice, to be put on the forbearance as I have not seen anything in my account change XX/XX/XXXX - I call MOHELA again to try to be placed on forbearance XX/XX/XXXX - MOHELA sends me XXXX  reminding me of payments due soon for {$1900.00} on XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX - call MOHELA again to be put on SAVE processing forbearance XX/XX/XXXX - MOHELA sends me a XXXX  reminding me of payment due on XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX - No communication this day, but it has been 60 business days after XX/XX/XXXX meaning I should be placed on 0 % interest forbearance for SAVE appliers from this date onward ( reference for the 0 % interest forbearance : https : //studentaid.gov/XXXX  ) XX/XX/XXXX - I MOHELA call to extend forbearance ( was scheduled for repayment on XX/XX/XXXX ). Subsequently placed on a forbearance still building interest. 

XX/XX/XXXX - MOHELA sends me XXXX  reminding me {$1900.00} payment is due on XX/XX/XXXX. Interest is still accruing. 

XX/XX/XXXX - MOHELA sends me XXXX reminding me {$1900.00} payment is due on XX/XX/XXXX. Interest is still accruing. 

XX/XX/XXXX - MOHELA sends me XXXX  reminding me {$1900.00} payment is due on XX/XX/XXXX. Interest is still accruing. 

XX/XX/XXXX - MOHELA sends me XXXX reminding me {$1900.00} payment is due on XX/XX/XXXX. Interest is still accruing. 

XX/XX/XXXX - MOHELA sends me XXXX  stating XXXX has directed MOHELA to put my account into the 0 % interest forbearance ( reminder : this should have been done by MOHELA on XX/XX/XXXX ). Even though I receive this message, interest continues to build on my loan daily through MOHELA and my loan summary through the MOHELA portal does not change to indicate I am in any form on 0 % interest forbearance. 

XX/XX/XXXX - MOHELA sends me XXXX  reminding me {$1900.00} payment is due on XX/XX/XXXX. Interest is still accruing. 

XX/XX/XXXX - I call MOHELA to attempt to clarify why I received a message stating I would be in the properly triggered 0 % interest forbearance ( albeit 2 months late ) and then subsequently I receive a message stating my payment is still due on XX/XX/XXXX and interest is still accruing on my loans. No clarification is given and I am ultimately told to wait until it gets sorted out behind-the-scenes. I request a forbearance extension again which is given ( but not the 0 % interest forbearance ) XX/XX/XXXX - I receive a XXXX  from MOHELA titled " Loan Update '' reminding me interest is building on my loan while in forbearance noting accrued interest to date is {$9500.00}. Note : if I was correctly placed on the 0 % interest forbearance on XX/XX/XXXX my total interest should only be {$4700.00}. Calculation below for reference. 

XX/XX/XXXX - XX/XX/XXXX is 90 days. 6.125 % interest annually on a principal of {$310000.00} is roughly {$53.00} a day. {$53.00} x 90 = {$4700.00}. 

XX/XX/XXXX - I call MOHELA trying to sort out my situation again reminding them I should be in 0 % interest forbearance. I try to figure out again why I was supposedly told Federal Student Aid ( albeit 2 months late ) directed MOHELA to place me on the 0 % interest forbearance back in XXXX, but it never truly happened on MOHELA 's end. Ultimately, I am told to wait and there is nothing they can do. 

XX/XX/XXXX - MOHELA sends me XXXX stating Federal Student Aid has directed MOHELA to put my account into the 0 % interest forbearance ( reminder : this should have occurred on XX/XX/XXXX and is now the 2nd time I have received this notification ). Even though I receive this message, interest continues to build on my loan daily through MOHELA and my loan summary through the MOHELA portal does not change to indicate I am in any form on 0 % interest forbearance. 

XX/XX/XXXX - I call again to try to clarify why I was told ( for the 2nd time now ) my account was directed to be placed on 0 % interest by the Department of Education to MOHELA, but interest continues to build. Wait 3 hours, put my number down and get called back later. In-between the call-back I receive a XXXX  from MOHELA stating a payment of {$1900.00} is due on XX/XX/XXXX. 
I receive my call-back and ask why for the 2nd time now I have been told I will be placed on 0 % interest forbearance that was directed by the Department of Education to MOHELA with no action on MOHELA 's end. I attempt to ask clarifying questions on why this is happening, what I should do differently, and how to resolve this with MOHELA. Ultimately, I am told to wait and there is nothing they can do. 

XX/XX/XXXX - I receive a XXXX  from MOHELA stating {$1900.00} is due on XX/XX/XXXX, with no indication I am on a 0 % interest forbearance. This document incorrectly states I now have {$9700.00} in interest accrued when it should be {$4700.00} as noted above. 

XX/XX/XXXX - I submit a complaint through CFPB to try to finally get this all sorted out as I am tired of my loan being thoroughly mishandled.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Immediate Action Needed : Approve Outstanding Borrower Defense Applications To the Departments Overseeing School & Loan Server Compliance, We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXXaffiliated schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding Borrower Defense applications and provide full relief for those impacted. 

Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : * XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX The Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXX XXXX  misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within six months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 

At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in XXXX states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts.

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : 1. Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions.

2. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans.

3. Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts.

Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the American Dream, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it. 

We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays. 

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 

Sincerely, Students & Graduates of XXXX XXXX

Today, XX/XX/XXXX, I still haven't received confirmation about the loan repayment plan change, and the account doesn't show a change. It just shows payment due XX/XX/XXXX on the standard payment plan. I called again today, and after waiting for five hours for a call-back, they claimed they couldn't do anything for me in that department and I had to be transferred. I understand there are different departments in call centers and customer service, however, after transferring, it said there was an additional five hour wait time ( without a call-back ) and then the call dropped after an hour of waiting.

Throughout these four months, there has been no correspondence from Mohela about any status updates or approvals/denials, and I have needed to call several times on different occasions to be able to speak to someone about these issues. It takes several calls and/or several hours [ of waiting ] to be able to speak to someone, and the account doesn't show any correspondence that I have sent to them in the respective section nor any evidence they've tried to send me correspondence.

My account was placed in special forbearance for 60 days in XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX to allow MOHELA to process my XXXX application, which they neglected to do. Then, on XXXX XXXX I received notice from MOHELA stating my account was placed in forbearance and no further action was needed. Then, on XXXX XXXX I was notified by MOHELA that I missed my payment that was due on XXXX XXXX. I received a reply from MOHELA on XXXX XXXX that appeared to imply my complaint was an application for forbearance, stating that once my application for forbearance was processed the delinquent payment ( XXXX ) would be resolved, seeming to ignore entirely that my account was/should already be in forbearance status. The letter went on to report a completely different amount owed, {$400.00}. compared to the {$1400.00} reported on the website and in previous letters, seeming to imply an XXXX payment plan as opposed to the Standard Plan. 

I attempted a second time to rectify this issue with Mohela via a phone call on XXXX XXXX in which after explaining the above to the representative, I was transferred to an " advanced '' representative where I was placed on hold for almost XXXX hours before opting for the call-back feature. I have yet to have been called back by MOHELA. 

I submitted a second complaint today requesting the XXXX and now XXXX missed payments be removed from my account, that my account be placed into forbearance, and that MOHELA process my XXXX application as soon as possible. 

It appears that MOHELA has already processed my XXXX plan application evidenced by the {$400.00} amount due noted in the XXXX XXXX reply to my complaint, yet continues to send bills for {$1400.00} under the XXXX XXXX plan. 

MOHELA has negligently handled the processing of XXXX applications, mishandled the processing of forbearance, all while hiding behind a federal injunction on the XXXX XXXX  in an attempt to maximize their profit at the expense of myself and other borrowers. Of Ed announced that they were extending to deadline to XX/XX/XXXX ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ), and if a recertification submitted early and payments were increased, the servicer would revert payments to the previous monthly amount until the new deadline ( We will return you to your previous monthly payment amount until your new recertification deadline ).

I was informed that they were working on it and to call back in a month. I called again, and was informed to keep calling monthly to ensure the payments would return to {$0.00} - each representative put my repayment on an administrative forbearance until the issue was resolved. Consumer complaint narrative:
I recently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. Major news media sources report that on XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX, at the behest of XXXX XXXX and the DOGE, gained access to sensitive DOE information. This includes but is not limited to : XXXX. My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ). 
XXXX. My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including financial aid history and loan information. 
XXXX. My IRS tax transcripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization. 
This data breach represents departmental negligence, breach of contract, violations of statutory rights, and potential unjust enrichment. The unsanctioned accessing of these records without my consent represents potential alteration to my financial aid package, loan details, and/or servicing history. DOE & DOGE compromised the integrity of the loan process, undermined the legitimacy of loan records, and thus invalidated the loan terms as supported by the following : Breach of FERPA ( Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act of XXXX, XXXX. XXXX XXXX. XXXX, XXXX XXXX. XXXX ( XXXX ) ( codified as amended at 20 U.S.C. 1232g ) which grants me the right to control access to my educational records. FERPA violations, such as unauthorized access or disclosure of a borrower 's educational records ( e.g., loan details, financial aid history ), undermine the integrity of the loan process. 
Failure to Comply with Title XXXX of the HEA ( Higher Education Act of XXXX, Pub. L. No. 89-329, 79 Stat. 1219 ( 1965 ) ) ( codified as amended at 20 U.S.C. 10701099d ) which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information and requires the Department of Education and its contractors to protect borrower information. Violations, such as improper use of FAFSA data or failure to secure borrower records, could undermine the legitimacy of the loan process. 
Violation of the Privacy Act of XXXX ( Privacy Act of XXXX, XXXX. XXXX XXXX. XXXX, XXXX XXXX. XXXX ( XXXX ) ( codified as amended at 5 U.S.C. 552a ) which ensures that federal agencies, including the DOE, handle personal information responsibly. Unauthorized access or misuse of borrower data ( e.g., IRS tax transcripts, Social Security numbers ) constitutes a violation. Failure to protect borrower data which included IRS tax data, compromised loan servicing, exposed borrowers to identity theft, fraud, or other harm, and compromised the ability to repay the loan. 
The Department of Education is required to follow federal cybersecurity standards ( Federal Information Security Management Act of XXXX, Pub. XXXX XXXX. XXXX, XXXX XXXX. XXXX ( XXXX ) ( codified as amended at 44 U.S.C. 35413549 ) to protect borrower data. A data breach that exposes sensitive information could constitute a failure to meet these obligations.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Complaint Regarding Data Breach, FERPA/Title IV Violations, and Loan Discharge Request Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau , I am filing a formal complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the U.S. Department of Education ( DOE ) and Department of Governmental Entities ( DOGE ). This breach violates the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ), Title IV regulations, and federal data security standards, compromising my personal privacy and financial security. 

The following records were accessed without my consent : My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ). 
My FAFSA data, including financial aid and loan history. 
My IRS tax transcripts. 
These unauthorized actions have raised serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and the integrity of my loan agreements. Therefore, I demand the following corrective actions : Immediate discharge and cancellation of all federal student loans due to this breach. 
A formal investigation into the breach, including details on who accessed my data and for what purpose. 
A full report on the extent of my data exposure and measures to prevent future breaches. 
Immediate notification to major credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, XXXX ) to place a fraud alert and investigate potential unauthorized activity. 
This breach has caused significant distress. If my demands are not met within 30 days, I will escalate this matter by filing complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and pursuing legal action. 

Please provide a written response detailing the immediate actions being taken. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XX/XX/year> Consumer Financial Protection Bureau XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Subject : Complaint Regarding Inaccurate Credit Reporting Following Loan Forgiveness Dear CFPB Representative, I am writing to file a formal complaint regarding inaccurate information on my credit reports maintained by XXXX, Experian, and XXXX. Despite providing all three credit bureaus with documentation that my loans were forgiven, this information has not been accurately reflected on my credit reports, negatively impacting my credit score. 

I have contacted the credit bureaus directly, submitted a dispute with supporting documentation, and allowed the legally required 30-day period for an investigation and correction under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). However, my reports still show the incorrect loan status, which is not only inaccurate but also a violation of my consumer rights under the FCRA. 

The inaccurate reporting is causing significant harm to my financial well-being, including but not limited to : Lowering my credit score. 
Hindering my access to fair credit opportunities. 
Causing undue stress and financial instability. 

I am requesting the CFPB to intervene and assist in ensuring that my credit reports are promptly updated to reflect the correct informationspecifically, that the forgiven loans show a {$0.00} balance or are removed as appropriate. I am also seeking confirmation of the corrective actions taken by the credit bureaus and the creditors involved. 

Enclosed are copies of : The loan forgiveness documentation. 
Correspondence with the credit bureaus. 
Dispute submissions and responses received Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to a swift resolution to correct my credit reports and protect my consumer rights. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX [ Phone Number : XXXX ] XXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative: I have been on the PAYE plan since XXXX for my graduate school loans and switched to the SAVE plan for income driven repayment ( IDR ) in XX/XX/XXXX. I began a full time position that qualified for Public Service Loan Forgiveness ( PSLF ) in XXXX XXXX in order to make payments under PSLF , your loans need to be consolidated and you need to be on an IDR plan. My loans were not consolidated at the time but I have always been on an IDR plan. Per the Dept of Ed recommendations now that I qualified for PSLF, I consolidated my loans which my servicer Mohela processed in XX/XX/XXXX which then automatically moved me from my SAVE IDR plan to a standard repayment plan. I had also applied multiple times in XX/XX/XXXX to switch my IDR plan from SAVE to IBR, which did not go through as they were processing the consolidation of my loans. I was able to successfully apply for IDR on XX/XX/XXXX and received a confirmation email from Mohela that they were processing my application. I am now receiving a bill from Mohela for over {$1200.00} under a standard repayment plan that is due on XX/XX/XXXX, which I can not afford this payment as I have never been on a standard repayment plan and was only put on one when I consolidated my loans per the rules and regulations of the US Dept of Ed. I have requested from Mohela multiple times to either process my IDR application or apply the processing forbearance, as I was supposed to be switching from the SAVE plan to another IDR plan, and not put on a standard repayment plan. Mohela has done neither of these things and has failed to respond appropriately to my messages and requests. I have been on hold with Mohela for hours with wait times of 3-4 hours with no resolution. Again, I am unable to make these payments under a standard repayment plan and Mohela has refused to process my IDR application and has also not placed my consolidated loan in forbearance as it works on processing applications. Mohela offers no other solutions to this problem and I know many people are having the same difficult experiences with them.

XX/XX/XXXX Borrower Defense Application # : XXXX Borrower Defense Application School : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
XXXX XXXX Dear XXXX : You are receiving this letter because you are a member of the class of federal student loan borrowers covered by the recent settlement of the XXXX XXXX XXXX ( " XXXX '' ) lawsuit. You submitted a XXXX XXXX to Repayment discharge application relating to your federal student loan ( s ) on or before XX/XX/XXXX, and you attended a school listed on Exhibit C ( " School '' ) of the settlement agreement. 
Pursuant to the Sweet settlement, the Department of Education will do the following : discharge your federal student loan ( s ) taken out for your enrollment in the XXXX University ( " Relevant Federal Student Loan ( s ) '' ) ; provide a refund for any payments made to the Department of Education on your Relevant Federal Student Loan ( s ), including Relevant Federal Student Loan debt that you previously paid off ; and delete the credit report tradeline associated with the discharged loan ( s ). 
The benefits described in this message apply to your Relevant Federal Student Loan ( s ). The benefits do not apply to private loans. The discharge of your Relevant Federal Student Loan ( s ) means that you will no longer owe the debt.

You also may receive a refund for prior payments made to the Department on your discharged loan ( s ) related to XXXX University. Your loan servicer will let you know if you are eligible for a payment refund, which would be mailed to you. 
Please check your online account with your loan servicer to ensure your address is correct so you can receive any refund. 
XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX - Approval of Your Borrower Defense Case Under Exhibit C of the SXXXX XXXX XXXX Settlement https : XXXX? XXXX & XXXX & XXXX & XXXX & XXXX XXXX Other than confirming your address, you do not have to take any further action to receive your discharge. Your servicer will send you more details about the discharge, including which loans will be forgiven. Your Relevant Federal Student Loan debt will remain in forbearance and collections will be stopped until you receive relief. Your credit report will also be updated to reflect this discharge when it is complete.

Consumer complaint narrative:
My name is XXXX XXXX and I attended XXXX University XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. I am asking that you take immediate action to ensure relief for myself and hundreds of thousands of defrauded borrowers. Please do not leave me and hundreds of thousands of defrauded students in the lurch, with our financial freedom and ability to live a full life hanging in the balance. A majority of us went to schools that have a history of misconduct well known to the Department of Education. We know that the Department of Education has findings for many of these schools, and that there is a preponderance of evidence to justify approval of the majority of outstanding Borrower Defense applications. I am asking you to act now, before it is too late. I am sure you know quite well that Borrower Defense and the Department of Education itself are at risk. All students who are suffering under the extreme weight of this fraudulent debt should have their Borrower Defenses approved immediately so we can finally be free to work toward our American Dream, a dream that has been stolen from us by often notoriously predatory companies. 
When I was a XX/XX/XXXX in XXXX attending XXXX XXXX University, I applied to multiple veterinary schools. I immediately received an acceptance to XXXX University along with a few other schools both international and in the states later on. However, XXXX changed my acceptance date to XXXX instead of XXXX and stated that I must attend or lose my seat. At that time I was upset because I did not apply for that class and had well above the accepted GPA and requirements to attend XXXX. I was forced to attend prior to hearing from other schools which now that I know more students stories, I was not the only one. XXXX has done this with countless students they fear of losing, if they allow us to hear back from other schools. Next was the education once arriving. XXXX promotes being a hands on school and allowing students to graduate practice ready. However, when COVID happened they did the opposite. At that time they made bugs get cuts for labs and staffing while increasing our cost of education and removing necessary laboratories and practicals despite government approval to allow them. This has directly impacted me as a practitioner, my patients, and my financial health. As a result of their lack of education I was not practice ready and needed to take extra courses, do extra training, and make less income as a result. This is not just the case for me but for many others. I understand the hardship of Covid but XXXX elected to neglect students, raise tuition, and the results have been clear and statistically proven on the XXXX. The XXXX is the board exam for veterinary practitioners and XXXX pass rate has dropped significantly below average and potentially losing XXXX accreditation. To help stop this XXXX has encouraged students from not taking the XXXX immediately because they fear their pass right will be low. The pass rate they advertise is for students taking the exam twice while the majority of schools post a first time pass rate. Overall XXXX has clearly taken a step back in their quality of education to have better profit margins and it has impacted the lives of thousands of students. As I result I am now in almost half a XXXX XX/XX/XXXXin debt, unable to get a mortgage, and struggling financially despite what is considered a good salary compared to the general public. This can very well be contributed to XXXX XXXXXX/XX/XXXXteam that encouraged a large student loan be taken out each semester rather than taking a minimal loan. At they time they teach as if they doing it for the students benefit but in hindsight it is clear it is for nothing more than their own benefit.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally file a complaint regarding the unauthorized access to federal student loan data by individuals associated with the Department of Government Efficiency ( DOGE ). Recent reports have revealed that DOGE personnel improperly accessed sensitive borrower information from the Department of Educations student financial aid databases, violating federal privacy protections and jeopardizing the security of my personal and financial data. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ) As a federal student loan borrower, I entrusted the Department of Education with my Social Security number, financial records, and other confidential data under the expectation that it would be safeguarded against unauthorized access. This breach constitutes a severe violation of my rights, and I am deeply concerned about the potential misuse of my information. 



Given the gravity of this breach, I am requesting the immediate voiding of all student loan payments for affected borrowers, including myself, as the Department of Education has failed to uphold its duty to protect our sensitive financial data. The unauthorized access by DOGE personnel has compromised the legitimacy of loan servicing and borrower agreements, warranting full loan cancellation as an appropriate remedy.

Additionally, I request : 1. A thorough investigation into the extent of the data breach.

2. Confirmation that my personal data has not been misused or further shared.

3. Immediate implementation of stronger security measures to prevent future unauthorized access.

4. A formal response detailing the Departments corrective actions and any borrower remedies.

This breach has significantly eroded trust in the Department of Educations handling of borrower information. Until this matter is fully addressed, I do not believe borrowers should be held responsible for repaying loans under a system that failed to secure their personal and financial data.

I expect a prompt response regarding the Departments plan to rectify this issue, including voiding all student loan payments for impacted borrowers. Please confirm receipt of this complaint and provide updates on any actions taken.

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, OH XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Mohela XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, MO XXXX Subject : Immediate Cease of Loan Payments Due to FERPA Violation Dear Mohela, I hope this letter finds you well. I am writing to formally inform you that I will no longer be making any payments toward my Parent PLUS loans due to a violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) by your organization. Specifically, I have recently discovered that my personal and financial information was compromised without my authorization when shared with XXXX XXXX and his employees, which is a direct violation of FERPAs protections regarding the privacy of student and parent records. 
FERPA requires that educational institutions and loan servicers such as Mohela safeguard and protect the privacy of student and parent records. By disclosing my personal information to individuals and entities not authorized under FERPA, you have breached the legal requirements set forth under this act.

As a result of the severity of this breach and the compromise of my personal and financial information, I have lost trust in your ability to protect my private information and therefore request that my loans be immediately canceled and discharged.

Please consider this letter an official notification that I am discontinuing my loan payments until I receive satisfactory answers regarding the FERPA violation. If I do not hear back from you within 5 days, I will be forced to take further legal actions to protect my rights. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to your response. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative: I have a consolidated federal loan with Mohela. I applied on XX/XX/year> to be put on the SAVE plan. My application is still processing. The Education Department states on their website :. If servicers need time to process a borrowers IDR application, servicers will move the borrower into a processing forbearance for up to 60 days. Interest accrues during this short-term processing forbearance, and time in the processing forbearance is eligible for PSLF and IDR forgiveness. If the borrowers application is not processed by their servicer within 60 days, the borrower will be moved into a general forbearance that does not count toward PSLF or IDR until their application is processed. Interest will not accrue in this general forbearance. I have been in processing for much longer than 60 days and they still have not moved me into an interest free general forbearance which the government website states they should do so I am filing this complaint.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Mohela has seriously and repeatedly mismanaged my student loans in multiple ways. 

In XXXX, Mohela placed me into multiple forbearances and provided me with incorrect and conflicting information regarding each. 

In XX/XX/XXXX, I was forced into a forbearance due to Mohelas website platform transition - but was repeatedly assured that any months spent in this forbearance WOULD be eligible months for Public Service Loan Forgiveness ( PSLF ). 

In XX/XX/XXXX, I was again forced into a forbearance by Mohela- this time with the stated justification of seeing if I was eligible for new benefits. Again I was assured that any months spent in this forbearance WOULD be eligible months for Public Service Loan Forgiveness ( PSLF ). 

Despite the facts outlined above, and also in spite of the fact that I have an approved employment certification form on record for the entire period of XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX, Mohela has deemed both my months of XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX as ineligible for PSLF. 

In XX/XX/XXXX, I was forced into a forbearance due to SAVE litigation - but I was assured that I could 1 ) switch from SAVE to another payment plan and 2 ) apply for buyback of any months spent in this forbearance. 

Subsequent to the events above, in XXXX - XX/XX/XXXX, I : 1. Applied for reconsideration of XXXX & XX/XX/XXXX based on the previous assurances I received from Mohela, along with those months not being part of SAVE litigation. I have received no response to these requests, and when I have repeatedly asked for information on request status, I am told they are under review with no estimated time for the review provided. 
2. Applied for buyback of XXXX & XX/XX/XXXX. 
I have followed up on each of those multiple times since then, only to be told that they have been escalated and are under review with no estimated time for the review provided. 

In XX/XX/XXXX, I applied to switch from the SAVE repayment plan into the IBR repayment plan. According to official guidance from both the Federal Student Loan program and Mohela, upon receipt of any IDR Application, a student loan account will be placed in a Processing Forbearance for 60 days, during which interest accrues and is eligible for Public Service Loan Forgiveness ( PSLF ) and IDR forgiveness. However, despite this official guidance and also repeated requests from me, Mohela has refused to place my student loans into a Processing Forbearance, and instead is leaving them in the SAVE Forbearance, which does not count towards PSLF or IDR forgiveness. 

The result of the above outlined actions is that, although according to the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and Mohelas own system, I have 187 qualifying payments for PSLF and 154 of those payment months also have accepted employment certification forms, Mohela has only deemed 118 of my payment months as eligible for PSLF ( the latest being XX/XX/XXXX ). 

Via the following actions : 1 ) Refusing to honor their assurances that XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX would count towards PSLF, and 2 ) Refusing to place my account into a PSLF-qualifying Processing Forbearance for 60 days as required by Federal Student Loan guidance, Mohela is effectively holding my account hostage at 118 payments ( two payments below the number required for PSLF ) and refusing to forgive my loans through PSLF despite my having earned it.

To whom it may concern We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXXaffiliated schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding Borrower Defense applications and provide full relief for those impacted.

Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX The Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXX XXXX misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within six months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 

At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in 26 states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts.

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : 1. Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions.

2. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans.

3. Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts.

Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the American Dream, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it.

We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays.

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX & XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

I have been working towards Public Sector Loan Forgiveness ( PSLF ) for the past 10 years. I have engaged in qualifying employment for 120 months as of XX/XX/year>, satisfying the requirements of PSFL. In XX/XX/year>, I submitted a Employment Certification Form ( ECF ) via studentaid.gov in order to have the remainder of my loan balance forgiven under PSLF. That ECF was processed in XX/XX/year>, and I was determined to only have 115/120 qualifying payments toward PSLF, with the months of XXXX XXXX  not qualifying. After that determination, I submitted a Request for Reconsideration via studentaid.gov in XXXX of XXXX, seeking the months of XXXX to be considered qualifying months. Studentaid.gov failed to respond to that request, and instead suggested I submit a buyback request to buy back months of employment that did not qualify because I was placed on a mandatory SAVE forbearance. I subsequently submitted a buyback request in XXXX XXXX, and re-iterated my Request for Reconsideration to have the months of XXXX through XXXX count as qualifying months. As of today, I have not yet heard from studentaid.gov regarding either the buyback request or the renewed Request for Reconsideration. 

To put it bluntly, I am in PSLF purgatory ; I have qualified for forgiveness, yet studentaid.gov has not yet processed my buyback request or renewed request for reconsideration. Until they act on those two things, I am unable to avail myself of loan forgiveness I have earned, and am entitled to, under PSLF.

Consumer complaint narrative:
**Subject : Urgent Demand for Validation of Reporting Authority and Account Accuracy** To Whom It May Concern, I am formally disputing your continued reporting of late payments on my student loan account, which, according to my records, was **paid in full and closed**. Despite this, your company persists in reporting inaccurate negative information, which is a clear violation of my rights under federal law. I am demanding immediate proof that Edfinancial Services has the **legal right** to report this account and to substantiate your claims in full compliance with federal regulations.

Under the **Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C . 1681**, and recent updates to consumer protection laws, I am requesting the following documentation : 1. **Proof of ownership and servicing rights : ** Provide certified documentation that establishes Edfinancial Services as the legal owner or authorized servicer of this student loan, including all transfer and assignment agreements from the original creditor.

2. **Regulatory compliance approval : ** Show evidence that your company is in compliance with the latest federal regulations governing student loan reporting, including any approvals or licensing required under applicable consumer protection laws.

3. **Complete account validation : ** Supply a full and detailed payment history, including confirmation that the account was **paid in full and closed**, along with proof of notifications sent to me in compliance with **12 C.F.R. 1022**, which mandates accurate reporting and consumer disclosure.

4. **Legal right to report : ** Cite the specific legal authority under which you claim the right to report this account as delinquent, including references to federal regulations that authorize such reporting.

If you are unable to provide the requested documentation within **30 days** of this notice, I demand that you **immediately cease reporting this account** to credit bureaus and remove all negative entries related to this matter. Any failure to comply with this request will result in my pursuit of legal action to enforce my rights under the law, including potential complaints to the **Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) ** and other regulatory agencies. 
This letter serves as a formal demand for validation and dispute of inaccurate reporting. 
XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
This complaint is regarding my student loan servicer 's ( Nelnet 's ) unfair and deceptive interest accrual practices. My loan servicer is continuing to charge interest on a loan even after I have paid it in full, applying interest to the previous balance until the next billing cycle. This practice is misleading and financially harmful to borrowers who, like me, are hard workers, struggling to pay off their loans while providing for themselves and family. When I pay off a loan, I expect that my payment immediately stops all interest accrual on that balance. However, an advisor told me that interest continues accumulating based on my old balance until the next billing cycle begins, even though the loan has already been paid off. I seem to be getting new information every time I call the servicer, too! I believe this is an unfair financial practice because : Borrowers are misled into thinking they have fully paid their loans when they actually owe additional interest. This creates unnecessary additional charges that make it harder for borrowers to pay off debt
efficiently.

Other financial institutions ( like credit card companies ) do not operate this way, so why are student loan servicers allowed to?

I request that the CFPB investigate this practice and enforce clearer, fairer policies regarding interest accrual and loan payoff timelines.

Student loan servicers are gauging VULNERABLE people. I, for one, am very well-read and intelligent -- yet there is alway something new and different I learn about the loopholes that student loan servicers exploit. Again, if I were to loan individuals money and pull this criminal activity, I would be sued. These companies need to have spines and operate fairly. MAYBE THEN, fewer people would try to get OUT of paying their loans!
