Consumer complaint narrative:
I have been working toward loan discharge for XXXX. In XX/XX/year>, I completed my XXXX payment. In XX/XX/year>, I sent in my employee certification form using the manual upload from the PSLF help tool. 

After receiving no response, in XXXX, I contacted customer service on studentaid.gov. The agent suggested I wait until " the end of fall '' to submit again. I submitted it again using the same manual upload method via PSLF help tool on the studentaid.gov website in XX/XX/year>. 

A few weeks later, I once again contacted customer service. The agent told me that there was no signature on the XXXX XXXX. Knowing that was not true, I thanked the agent, hung up, and called again to speak to a new agent. The new agent said she could see that the form had the appropriate signature but maybe I should try submitting it through USPS. 

In XX/XX/year>, I mailed the XXXX using USPS. I also faxed the form. Still no response. 

On XX/XX/year>, I submitted the form using the electronic signature option through the PSLF help tool. For all of these attempts, I used the same form that I originally filled out in XXXX with all of the correct information, including my employment start date. The form was signed by the HR representative of the organization I work for. 

The studentaid.gov website shows, under " My Activity '' that the form I submitted in XX/XX/year> is still in review. It also shows that the form I submitted electronically in XXXX has been reviewed and is complete. Under the " My Activity '' section, there is nothing indicating that the form I sent via USPS or fax has been received. There is also no information for the form I uploaded manually in XX/XX/year> under " My Activity. '' On XX/XX/XXXX, my payment count for PSLF on the studentaid.gov website was updated to reflect that I have reached 120 payments. However, I also received a rejection letter stating that the employee start date was missing or invalid. I checked on the studentaid.gov website under " My Dashboard. '' The status tracker states that the form I submitted via manual upload in XXXX was received on both XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/year> and then rejected and closed on XX/XX/XXXX. However, the PSLF Form Information on the website for that same submission has the employee start date plainly stated and when I downloaded the XXXX form that was rejected, it also had the employee start date plainly stated. 

I called customer service twice to ask what steps I needed to take next. Both customer service agents acknowledged that they could see that the employment start date was there but since the form had already been rejected, I needed to send the form yet again. Both suggested that I submit it with the electronic signature, even though the form I sent in XXXX via electronic signature has already been reviewed and the website says is complete. 

In the past week, I have attempted to go through the PSLF help tool, which is the only way to submit the form either electronically or via manual upload, and that page of the PSLF website will not load. I have been trying for a few days. The help tool page will not load.

At this point, I have no idea what to do. My payment count has been updated saying no more payments on my loan are required. Every form that I have sent has the employee start date written plainly on the form, and the studentaid.gov website itself shows the correct employee start date that the rejection letter says is somehow missing or incomplete. 

Because the help tool will not load on the website, I have no way to even try to resubmit again, unless it is once again via USPS or fax. But since the website does not even acknowledge receiving the form that I sent via USPS and fax, I have no reason to believe that sending it again through these methods will result in any forward movement with this process. 

I fulfilled my contractual obligations for PSLF and have submitted and resubmitted my employee certification form in every way that is possible. Now that the PSLF help tool doesn't even work, I am completely out of options.
Company: Servicer under contract with Federal Student Aid

I am writing to formally file a complaint under the Family Education Rights and privacy Act ( FERPA ) regarding the unauthorized access to my personally identifiable information by XXXX XXXX and his employees through the Department of Education 's databases. 
On or about XX/XX/year>, I became aware that individuals associated with, XXXX XXXX, who are neither school officials nor authorized representatives, accessed databases that include my personal education records without my knowledge or consent. I am aware that usage of database is monitored, recorded and/or subject to audit. I did not provide any authorization for such access, and I believed this constitutes a violation of my FERPA rights.

To my understanding, the Department of Education is required to safeguard students ' personal records and only grant access to unauthorized parties under FERPA guidelines. The unauthorized access by private individuals or corporate representatives is a serious breach of these protections. 
I respectfully request that your office investigate this matter and take appropriate action to ensure my personal information remains protected. Please provide me with any relevant findings, corrective actions, and steps, I can take to prevent further unauthorized access to my records.

This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study.

The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Summary and Statements of Facts. 
We are asking you to take immediate steps to : 1. Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions.

2. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans.

Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the XXXX XXXX, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it. 

We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays.

Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
Under 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), data furnishers are prohibited from reporting inaccurate information. Additionally, 15 U.S.C. 1666b of the Fair Credit Billing Act ( FCBA ) mandates that payments must be properly credited as of the date received. If this late payment resulted from a billing error, 16 CFR 1026.13 under the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) requires correction and resolution.

My Dispute & Request for XXXX XXXX Compliance Verification I am formally disputing the late payment entry on my Equifax report and demanding a XXXX XXXXcompliant reinvestigation. Under 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ), Equifax must conduct a reasonable investigation of disputed information. Therefore, I request the following documentation as proof of the investigations validity : 1. XXXX XXXX Compliance Records Provide a copy of the Automated Consumer Dispute Verification ( ACDV ) or any other XXXX 2 documentation used to verify this late payment.

2. Furnisher 's Verification Response Documentation from XXXX verifying the accuracy of this late payment, including payment processing records. 
3. Method of Verification A detailed explanation of how Equifax verified the information as required under **15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 6 ) ( B ) ( iii ) **.

4. Date of Payment Processing Proof from XXXX showing the exact date the payment was received and credited. 
**Resolution Requested If Equifax XXXX not provide sufficient documentation proving this late payment is **100 % accurate**, it must be **immediately deleted** per **15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) **, which requires consumer reporting agencies to ensure maximum possible accuracy. 
**Legal Notice** Failure to comply with FCRA provisions may result in legal action, including statutory damages under **15 U.S.C. 1681n and 1681o**. Additionally, if Equifax fails to provide a proper XXXX XXXXcompliant investigation**, I will escalate this matter to the **Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) ** and consider further legal remedies. 
I expect a written response within XXXX days** as required under FCRA guidelines XXXX Please provide all requested documentation and confirm the resolution of this dispute.

Thank you for your immediate attention to this serious issue. I am available to provide any further information or clarification necessary to resolve this matter.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/XXXX my mother applied on my behalf ( I was aXX/XX/XXXX) to apply for the Federal Direct Student Loan to attend Georgia College and XXXX University, and used her credit/tax information for the original Master Promissary Note. I went to school, and then on XX/XX/XXXX paid the full entire amount of the loan, including interest, {$5900.00} paid off. I then closed the account with EdFinancial and never heard any further correspondance. 
On XX/XX/XXXX ( 4 years later ) - I received an email stating that I had an outstanding balance on my EdFinancial account. I had to create a new account to access it, and when I did, the amount of {$6100.00} was on my account. I called, and after 3 months of trying to get ahold of a supervisor, they stated that on XX/XX/XXXX at XXXX, I had called and " verbally requested '' something called " COVID Relief ''. I then asked to hear the voice recording, and was told I needed a subpoena from a judge to hear my own voice recording. They stated that because of this recording, it was a " Legal and Binding Contract '' - and that they REOPENED my ORIGINAL loan of from XXXX based on the Master Promissary Note, and the US. Treasury mailed me a check for my {$5900.00}. They tried to say I deposited the check, but I have no evidence of this in my checking account or history, and they did not have the evidence on my online account. In Fact, they DELETED my payment history of all my interest payments, the date where I paid it off. I have all the proof on my end in the form of bank statements, and I also recorded the conversation I had over the phone with the EdFinancial Supervisor. 

I NEVER Requested to reopen this loan. I do NOT believe I owe ANY money to this program or loan. This is FRAUDLENT- if I do not have WRITTEN and SIGNED contract stating that I will pay back this loan in full, when I supposedly " requested '' it in XXXX, then I will not be repaying this. EdFinancial needs to be held responsible, and take this balance off my account entirely.

Consumer complaint narrative:
NOTICE OF DISPUTE ; DEMAND FOR VALIDATION AND PROOF OF CLAIM HAS NOT BEEN MET! 

To Whom it May Concern Your company is illegally trying to collect and is furnishing false items that violates my consumer rights and FDCPA and FCRA. Be advised that your claim is disputed. Debt validation has to be provided in accordance with the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, 15 USC {$1600.00} and as amended by adding the following new Title 8 US {$800.00} et seq., and the Fair Credit Billing Act, 15 USC. {$1600.00} et seq. All of which work in conjunction with each other, including the Truth In Lending Act ( TILA ) 15 USC 1601 et seq. It is not now, nor has it ever been, my intention to avoid paying any alleged obligation that is lawfully owed by the Claimant. 
In order to make arrangements to pay an obligation which may be lawfully owed, please document and verify the " debt '' by complying, in good faith, with this request for validation and return it to me, within thirty ( 30 ) days of receipt of this letter.

This is was NOT a request for " verification '' or proof of Claimant mailing address or copies of bank statements you could find, but a request for VALIDATION and PROOF OF CLAIM made pursuant to the above named Titles and Sections. I respectfully request that your offices provide Claimant with competent evidence as per the attached " Declaration and Proof of Claim '' that I have any legal obligation to pay you the unsubstantiated alleged debt. Furthermore you shall cease all verbal communication. No phone calls to the Claimant. 

At this time I will also inform you that if your offices have reported invalidated information to any of the 3 major Credit Bureaus, such as, XXXX, XXXX and XXXX prior to validation and proof of claim of the disputed debt, this action might constitute fraud under both Federal and State Laws. Due to this fact ; if any negative mark is found on any of Claimant credit reports by your company or the company that you represent I will not hesitate in bringing legal action against you and your client for the following : - Violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act - Violation of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act Defamation of Character - Violation of United States Code TITLE 18 PART 1 CHAPTER 63 1341 ( Mail Fraud ) This debt is considered to be invalid and all collection of this alleged account be stopped until I receive proper validation and your offices provide Claimant with proof of claim of the disputed debt. Your offices have 30 days to produce the required documentation in accordance with FTC guidelines. During this validation period and proof of claim, if any action is taken which could be considered detrimental to any of Claimant credit reports, said action will be considered a " dishonor '' and cause the self-executing contract portion of this notice to be implemented. This includes any listing any information to a credit reporting repository that could be inaccurate or invalidated. 
If your offices fail to respond to this validation and proof of claim request within 30 days from the date of your receipt, all references to this account must be deleted and completely removed from Claimant credit file and a copy of such deletion request shall be sent to Claimant immediately. 
Title 8 USC {$800.00}. Validation of debts [ 15 USC 1692g ] ( b ) If the consumer notifies the debt collector in writing within the thirty-day period described in subsection ( a ) that the debt, or any portion thereof, is disputed, or that the consumer requests the name and address of the original creditor, the debt collector shall cease collection of the debt, or any disputed portion thereof, until the debt collector obtains verification of the debt or any copy of a judgment, or the name and address of the original creditor, and a copy of such verification or judgment, or name and address of the original creditor, is mailed to the consumer by the debt collector. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX : VERIFICATION. 

Confirmation of correctness, truth, or authenticity, by affidavit, oath, or deposition. 

RULING 1002 - Requirement of the original An original writing, recording, or photograph is required in order to prove its content unless these rules or a federal statute provides otherwise.

Counter Claim with Self-executing Contract If Respondent, such as by commission, omission, and otherwise : ( a ) Fails to provide VALIDATION and PROOF OF CLAIM within thirty ( 30 ) days ; ( b ) Makes a false representation of the character of the herein above-referenced alleged debt ; ( c ) Makes a false representation of the legal status of the herein above-referenced alleged debt ; ( d ) Makes any threat of action that can not legally be taken, in violation of any applicable law, such as, the law codified at the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, will be construed to be Respondent 's tacit acceptance of the terms and condition stated herein.

In which case RESPONDENT agrees to : ( e ) Voluntarily report this account to all credit bureaus as " paid as agreed ; '' and, ( f ) Voluntarily waive all claims against Claimant, their Agent or Heirs with prejudice ; and, ( g ) The matter regarding the alleged debt is finally and totally settled ; and, ( h ) Voluntarily admits the Claimant is the depositor for this account, that Respondent risked none of their assets at any time regarding this account and that they failed to disclose these material facts to Claimant ; and, ( i ) Voluntarily report the date of last activity on this account is the date of this notice. 
Furthermore, RESPONDENT 'S failure to " Cease and Desist '' in accordance with the requirements of the FDCPA and other related law, and/or satisfy the above " terms and conditions, " its a XXXX for each violation. 
This is a private communication and is intended to affect an out-of-court settlement of this matter. Conduct yourself accordingly. Should any provision on this agreement be found to not be enforceable by order of a court of competent jurisdiction, it shall not adversely affect any other provision of this agreement and reasonable opportunity and effort shall be taken to modify it to become enforceable.

" Equality under the Law is PARAMOUNT and MANDATORY by Law '' NOTICE TO THE PRINCIPAL IS NOTICE TO THE AGENT NOTICE TO THE AGENT IS NOTICE TO THE PRINCIPAL

Issue: Improper use of your report
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
The US dept of Education has two loans reporting on my account. One was for {$1700.00} and the other for {$46000.00}. The two loans have so many errors & incorrect data, and I have no clue where they got this information. For example, the loan for {$1700.00} isn't even a loan with the US dept of education. I've never received disclosures or notice about this loan being transferred or handled by the US dept of Ed or Nelnet. I wasn't even informed that Nelnet was the new servicer of the {$46000.00} loan until I tried settling the loan with a negotiable instrument, then a few days later I've received an email that US dept of Ed wasn't my loan servicer anymore, and Nelnet will be put in its place. 

The loan for {$1700.00} was opened in XXXX, of XXXX. 16 years ago, it was my knowledge that reporting of a student loan after 10 years fell off your report, I was told this by XXXX. So why is a loan from XXXX, that was never handled by the US Dept of Ed still reporting and showing incorrect information to make it seem accurate? They applied false information to my report to make it seem as if it was initially with the Dept of Ed the entire time. So either there is a huge error or a lie. 

The loan for {$46000.00}, reports it was opened in XXXX. Another error or false reporting. I am XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX would mean I was XXXX when I took out the loans and was in school. It's possible for a XXXX to be in college, but I was never in college at age XXXX. So why is it reporting data on my report that reflects an opening of XXXX? This doesn't only apply to the US dept of Education loans. Some other closed student loan accounts are showing XXXX as well. That shows blatant disregard for accuracy in reporting, which falls on the furnished, and the CRAs maintaining the reports. 

Today I received a notification from XXXX reported a XX/XX/XXXX XXXX Bankruptcy filing on my report, not sure where they got this information because the case has already been filed and dismissed. So doing a " report '' on the filing has just dropped my credit score by XXXX points! Not sure if that's an error on XXXX 's part of the US dept of Education. They are not reporting information accurately as required by law, causing me major harm to my consumer report and financial standing. It seems they keep changing the dates to extend the time it will report on my credit report. I say that because the closed accounts by the US dept of Ed also have incorrect data.

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem with your payment plan
Consumer complaint narrative: My student loans are being serviced by EdFinancial. I was previously serviced by XXXX. I was automatically switched from the REPAYE plan to SAVE without requesting it. When the SAVE plan was challenged in court, I was placed in the general administrative forbearance. When applications to change off the SAVE plan reopened, I submitted an application to switch to the PAYE plan. After a month of waiting, on XX/XX/year> I started a secure chat with an agent, XXXX, to request an update and to also request to be moved from general forbearance to processing forbearance. I was told that there is no timeline for application processing for anyone trying to leave the SAVE plan, and I have heard separately that some servicers are not processing these applications at all. This agent also lied to me by saying that anyone on the SAVE plan would not be moved into processing forbearance per policy, when in reality the policy states that this should be done ( I have talked with others in repayment who were successfully moved to processing forbearance, which would count toward monthly payments for PSLF eligibility ). All I want is to start paying on an acceptable payment plan, but the servicers including EdFinancial are making this unbelievably challenging and stressful during a time of great uncertainty for all Americans.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I recently received a communication from EdFinancial, my student loans servicer, marked XX/XX/XXXX, that the grace period on one of my loans is about to end and that the first payment is due in one month ( XX/XX/XXXX ). In addition, several of my loans ( 4 out of 6 ) list a payment due date as XX/XX/XXXX, despite the other two showing that I am in in-school deferment. Granted, the amount due showing up on the Account Summary page shows {$0.00} ; however the letter I received about the grace period ending indicates that I will owe {$840.00} per month. Both a screenshot of my Account Summary Page and the letter about the grace period ending are attached to this complaint. The problem is that I am currently in law school, which is the same course of education for which these loans were received. All of my loans should be listed as " In XXXX. '' To add to the confusion, on the Loan Details Page ( also screenshot attached ), the loans with the XX/XX/XXXX due date are listed as " In School Deferment '' in the dropdown, which does not match the Account Summary, the due date, nor the end-of-grace-period letter I received. None of them should have an initial due date before XX/XX/XXXX, as I graduate in XX/XX/XXXX and then have a 6-month grace period. Unfortunately, this seems to be a widespread problem, as several of my classmates are encountering this with EdFinancial as well, and the company has thus far not resolved it for them. 

I had a similar issue occur with EdFinancial in the fall of XXXX, and despite calling and speaking to representatives 3 times, during each of which I was assured that the problem was fixed and would appear as such on my portal soon, a month went by and it still said I owed money. Nothing was corrected until I filed a CFPB complaint, after which someone actually fixed the issue. I am not sure if this current issue is a continuation of whatever manual measures someone took to fix that old issue, leading to a loan now coming due when that is not, in fact, true.

After XXXX  months, I demand clear terms for any federal loans I take out. XXXX promises dont cut it. If we take out XXXX new federal loans when our spousal loan is finally separated, and these promises dont come to fruition, we will be stuck with XXXX loan payments, no credit for much greater than the required XXXX payments for XXXX and now thousands of dollars deeper in debt because of the XXXX years that interest has been allowed to accrue while the DoE figured XXXX a way to implement the law. I dont know how this can be viewed any way other than consumer abuse. It should not be legal to withhold our right to separate loans under the XXXX for over XXXX  years, cause us to go deeper into debt, expect us to sign paperwork for loans BEFORE our payment counts have been adjusted and not provide any hard deadlines for anything on their end, only a deadline for us to have those promissory notes signed by XX/XX/XXXX.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I have contacted both the Department of Education and my loan service Edfinancial multiple times regarding my student loans.

My experience has been the same every time. Both helplines have customer service representatives that claim they can not see my specific account information and claim that I am contacting the wrong entity. DOE reps claim that Edfinancial has the information, Edfinancial claims DOE has the information. This has left me in an endless loop of calling one, then the other. Both parties claim they can not see my specific account information. 

Last week I called the DOE omnibudsman. The representative gave me false information about the type of loans I have taken out. She also accused me of having another party on the line. It was very bizarre. She said she only handles PSLF. I am not in that group. She recommended that I call Edfinancial, which I did. They told me to call the DOE back. 

Here is my question. How many payments have I made over the life of my loans? I entered repayment after XXXX  in XXXX. I should have about XXXX payments. Then I went to XXXX XXXXl & went into an XXXX XXXX. I graduated in XXXX of XXXX with a XXXX. Went back into repayment in XXXX of XXXX. I consolidated my loans in XXXX of XXXX. And I think at that time they became Direct Loans. I made every payment until the COVID forbearance. Then I changed over to Repay, now Save. I went into repayment with everyone else last XXXX. I made XXXX payments then asked to be placed into forbearance because I was pretty sure I was at XXXX payments. 

My frustration is this. No one knows what they are talking about when you call at either place. How am I supposed to make an informed decision when you can't speak to someone who understands your specific needs?

Consumer complaint narrative:
Ever since my loan servicer was switched from XXXX to Nelnet, I have had nothing but problems with trying to access their website or log into my account. Over the last two years, I can count on one hand the number of times I was able to successfully log in. Today, the site is completely down and is returning a " 503 Service Unavailable '' error message, displaying only a blank page. This is the case in every browser, on multiple devices, and I had someone else in another city try as well and they got the same result.

I had to contact the main studentaid.gov website to get a hold of Nelnet 's phone number to call for help. When calling Nelnet today, the system asked me to verify my social security number, date of birth, and zip code -- and told me three times in a row that they were incorrect. The representative I spoke to confirmed that their phone system isn't working properly either. He was unable to give me an estimate as to when I'd be able to access my account again.

This marks at least the dozenth time I've been unable to log into my account to check my balance, the terms of my loan, or make changes to payments. For such a large financial institution that services the loans of so many borrowers, this is completely unacceptable. As a XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  myself, I know how things work behind the scenes. From the looks of it, Nelnet needs to fire their entire IT and engineering department and hire a new one. 

If you take a quick look at the XXXX XXXX and search for the term " nelnet '' within that XXXX, you'll see how astonishingly common this experience is. Over the years, people have had nothing but problems with this company, to XXXX XXXX that class action lawsuits are being proposed. Again, this is beyond unacceptable and needs to be addressed. If you have the infrastructure in place to withdraw funds from my account each month, you also need to have the infrastructure to let me log in and change which account you're withdrawing it from! 

Here are some dates that I was unable to access the website or log in due to technical errors with Nelnet 's infrastructure : XX/XX/XXXX ( phone system also had issues ) XX/XX/XXXX ( phone issues too ) XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX ( could technically access the site, but the login wasnt working ) XX/XX/XXXX ( could technically access the site, but the login wasnt working ) XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX ( down since the week prior ) XX/XX/XXXX ( phones also werent working )

Consumer complaint narrative:
To the Departments Overseeing School & Loan Server Compliance, I am writing within a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXX schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding Borrower Defense applications and provide full relief for those impacted. 

Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX The Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXX XXXX  misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX  and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within six months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 

At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in 26 states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts. 

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : 1. Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions.

2. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans.

3. Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts. 

Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the XXXX XXXX, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it. 

We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays. 

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 

Sincerely, Students & Graduates of XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern, This letter serves as a formal demand for relief under the terms of the recent settlements involving XXXX and Trellis Company concerning student loan mismanagement, improper servicing practices, and consumer protection violations. 

In XXXX XXXX upon reviewing my credit report, I discovered that Trellis Company had charged off my student loans without prior notice or correspondence. At no point was I made aware that Trellis had acquired my loans from Navient Student Loans. To my knowledge, the loan was in forbearance and qualified for an income-driven repayment plan. Despite XXXX failure to provide accurate information regarding my loan status, Trellis proceeded to execute a charge-off, denying me the opportunity to address or rectify the matter. 

Upon contacting Trellis to dispute this charge-off and seek clarification, I encountered representatives who were uncooperative, dismissive, and combative. My repeated requests for documentation, as well as transparency regarding the loan transfer and servicing, were denied. This conduct constitutes a failure of fiduciary duty and has resulted in significant and unjustified damage to my credit profile, causing material financial harm and limiting my access to credit. 

In light of the {$1.00} XXXX multi-state settlement and the {$120.00} XXXX settlement with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), I hereby demand the following actions to remedy the harm caused : Immediate Review and Cancellation of the Charged-Off Loan Pursuant to the terms of the settlement, I request that the charged-off loan in question be thoroughly reviewed for eligibility under the settlements loan cancellation provisions. Any associated derogatory marks must be expunged from my credit report. 

Restitution for Credit Damage and Financial Harm I seek restitution for the adverse financial consequences resulting from the mismanagement and improper charge-off of my loan. This includes compensation for any reduction in creditworthiness, increased borrowing costs, or denial of credit.

Full Disclosure and Documentation I demand full transparency regarding the acquisition, servicing, and charge-off of my loan, including : Documentation verifying the transfer of the loan from Navient to Trellis ; A comprehensive loan payment history, including forbearance and repayment options extended to me ; The amortization schedule and all communications pertaining to the loans status.

Correction of Credit Reporting Errors I request that Trellis promptly communicate with all relevant credit reporting agencies to remove or amend any negative reporting associated with this charge-off.

Failure to address and resolve this matter within 30 days from receipt of this letter will compel me to escalate the issue by filing a formal complaint with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and relevant state and federal regulatory agencies. Additionally, I will explore legal avenues for recovery of damages sustained as a result of Trelliss conduct.

This letter serves as official notice of the harm caused and your obligation to take corrective action in compliance with the terms of the recent settlements and prevailing consumer protection laws. I trust that Trellis will act in good faith to remedy this matter expeditiously.

Please confirm receipt of this letter and provide a written response outlining the steps Trellis intends to take to address my concerns. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Issue: Incorrect information on your report
Sub-issue: Account information incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Dispute of Unauthorized Loan Consolidation and Request for Proof of Contract Dear Nelnet, I am writing to formally dispute the consolidation of my student loans and to request immediate verification and documentation regarding the loan servicing agreement and any contracts associated with the consolidation.

To clarify, I never requested or authorized the consolidation of my student loans, nor did I consent to any such action. Upon reviewing my loan account, I noticed the consolidation was made without my approval or knowledge, and I did not sign any documents that would legally bind me to such an agreement.

Specifically, I request the following : 1. Proof of Contract : Provide a copy of the signed agreement or authorization form that I allegedly agreed to in relation to the loan consolidation.

2. Loan Consolidation Documentation : Supply any documents detailing the terms and conditions of the loan consolidation, including any notices, agreements, or authorizations indicating that I consented to the consolidation.

3. Verification of Loan Consolidation : Provide clear evidence and records showing when and how the consolidation was executed, including the date of the action and any notices sent to me regarding the change in loan status.

4. Account History and Balance : Provide a complete breakdown of my loan balance, showing how the original loans were consolidated and how the new balance was calculated. Please ensure that all transactions, interest, and fees are accurately reflected.

Given that I did not authorize this consolidation and have not received proof of my agreement to it, I believe the current status of my loan is incorrect and should be investigated and corrected.

Relevant Laws and Violations This dispute is based on violations of the following laws, which ensure that loans are serviced and handled correctly, and that consumers are protected from unauthorized actions : 1. The Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq. ) : Under the FCRA, creditors and servicers are required to report accurate information to credit bureaus. If there are inaccuracies on your credit report resulting from u
nauthorized loan consolidation, you have the right to dispute these errors. The FCRA also mandates that servicers investigate disputes and provide the requested documentation in a timely manner ( usually within 30 days ).

2. The Higher Education Act ( HEA ) ( 20 U.S.C. 1071 et seq. ) : The HEA outlines the rules for federal student loan servicing and consolidation. Loan consolidation must be authorized by the borrower, and servicers are required to provide proper disclosures and documentation regarding any changes to loan status. Unauthorized consolidation is a violation of the borrowers rights under this act.

3. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1692 et seq. ) : The FDCPA protects consumers from unfair, deceptive, or abusive practices by debt collectors. If the loan consolidation is being handled by a debt collection agency or servicer acting as a third party, they are required to adhere to certain standards when communicating and collecting debts. Unauthorized consolidation or failure to provide proper documentation could be a violation of this law.

4. The Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1601 et seq. ) : TILA requires lenders to clearly disclose the terms and conditions of loans, including any consolidation agreements. If your loan was consolidated without your consent, the servicer may have violated TILA by failing to provide the required disclosures before proceeding with the consolidation.

5. Regulation Z ( 12 CFR Part 1026 ) : Under Regulation Z, which implements the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ), lenders and servicers must clearly disclose all loan terms, including those related to consolidation. If these disclosures were not provided, it may constitute a violation of this regulation.

6. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) : If you are unable to resolve this matter directly with your servicer, you may file a complaint with the CFPB, which enforces consumer protections related to debt collection, loan servicing, and other financial matters.

Given that I did not authorize this consolidation and have not received proof of my agreement to it, I believe the current status of my loan is incorrect and should be investigated and corrected.

Please treat this request as a formal dispute under the FCRA, HEA, FDCPA, and TILA, which require that loan servicers maintain accurate records and provide proper documentation of loan servicing actions. I expect to receive all requested documentation within 30 days from the date of this letter, in compliance with applicable laws.

If you are unable to provide the requested proof, I ask that you reverse the consolidation and restore the original terms of the loans immediately. Should I not receive a satisfactory response, I will consider escalating this matter through regulatory channels, such as the CFPB and the Department of Education. 

Please respond to this dispute at your earliest convenience and provide the necessary documentation. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX : XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I must address an important matter regarding Navients servicing practices related to my account. Throughout my experience, I relied on Navients communications to stay informed about my loan status. At no point did I fail to meet my responsibilities as a borrower to remain in good standing and pursue options for loan management and forgiveness. Despite my efforts, which included regularly contacting Navient and submitting necessary applications, I received repeated denials for student loan forgiveness. Unfortunately, I was not informed that my loan had entered default status ; instead, Navients correspondence consistently indicated that my account was in deferment or forbearance, never notifying me that my loans were actually in default. 

Had Navient provided clear information that my loans were in default, I would have immediately pursued an appropriate program to rehabilitate my loans. Instead, Navient continued to advise that my loans were ineligible for forgiveness without disclosing the reason was due to the default status. This lack of transparency left me under the impression that my loans were in forbearance and misled me away from the necessary steps to resolve my account status and regain eligibility. 

Given these circumstances, I am requesting a thorough review of my account history and a resolution that addresses these miscommunications and omissions. I am hopeful that the CFPB can provide guidance or assistance in ensuring that because of these injustices, my loans are considered paid off. Due to the lawsuit against Navient for my relief, I am asking for all of my loans to be paid off. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. Please feel free to reach out if any additional information is needed from my end. 

XXXX XXXX

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative: I have submitted an application to switch from the SAVE to PAYE plan in order to continue count towards public student loan forgiveness (PSLF). Per StudentAid.gov/saveaction and Department of Education guidance, if Mohela cannot (or will not) process my application to switch repayment plans, they must remove me from the SAVE forbearance and place me into a 60-day processing forbearance: If servicers need time to process a borrowers IDR application, servicers will move the borrower into a processing forbearance for up to 60 days. Interest accrues during this short-term processing forbearance, and time in the processing forbearance is eligible for PSLF and IDR forgiveness. If the borrowers application is not processed by their servicer within 60 days, the borrower will be moved into a general forbearance that does not count toward PSLF or IDR until their application is processed. Interest will not accrue in this general forbearance. XX/XX/XXXX I called and spoke to 3 Mohela representatives from different (escalating) departments, each Mohela representative responded that accounts in SAVE forbearance cannot be placed in processing forbearance which is inaccurate based on others experiences in a similar situation and not outlined anywhere in the FSA guidance. Nowhere does the US Dept of Education or FSA guidance state that Mohela CANNOT process applications for borrowers on SAVE who are seeking to switch to PAYE. And the updates issued on XX/XX/XXXX by the US Dept of Education, explicitly state that borrowers on the SAVE plan who want to earn credit towards PSLF SHOULD switch to a PSLF-eligible plan (at which point they will be eligible for a 60 day processing forbearance); PAYE is a PSLF-eligible plan. Further, the guidance notes that processing is still paused for CERTAIN IDR plans, but PAYE is NOT one of those plans. In the coming weeks, the Department expects servicers to begin processing certain IDR applications that were paused following court orders affecting the terms and availability of IDR plans. Specifically, the Department will begin processing borrowers applications to enroll in: IBR, ICR, PAYE. See - https://www.ed.gov/highereducation/manage-your-loans/save-plan.

Consumer complaint narrative:
After graduating the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX in XXXX, my federal and private loans were given to XXXX XXXX. Then, a year or two later, Navient took over my loans. I was paying back my loans with an Income Driven payment plan wonderfully and easily until a year or two ago when my payments jumped from Income Driven to not Income Driven, so the payment amounts went from {$55.00} to more than {$1000.00} / month. I attempted to re-establish Income Driven payments again, but the woman with Navient customer service stated I had no other choice but to go into forbearance. That was right around or right before Covid. Then, Biden did his thing, stating we didn't have to pay back student loans for a while... that was a reprieve until I figured out how to get back on Income Driven payments with Navient.

Then, just recently, I learned that Navient is no longer allowed to service student loans due to unfair practices, such as what I feel I experienced with them, being steered into unnecessary forbearance instead of offering doable Income Driven payment plans. Then recently, a company named XXXX started calling me incessantly. I researched them and they too have pending lawsuits due to unfair practices with servicing student loans. So today, XX/XX/XXXX, I begin my journey with trying to figure out what to do. A lovely being named XXXX, with CFPB, offered me what she could as far as what steps to take. I know I want to have this complaint against Navient on the record. Next, since I am understandably incredibly uncomfortable with handing over my student loans to yet another servicer who has pending lawsuits due to unfair practices, I have to figure out how to navigate that. And that is at this very moment of XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX, where I stand.

I am requesting immediate corrective action to remove or amend the disputed accounts, as XXXX 's inaction violates federal law and my rights as a consumer.

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem with forgiveness, cancellation, or discharge
Consumer complaint narrative:
In XX/XX/XXXX, I was informed that the federal administration would aid student loan borrowers in reaching their loan forgiveness status by including any student loans made prior to the updated consolidation date in XXXX. I immediately submitted five PSLF/Temporary Expanded Certification Applications ( XXXX. No. XXXX ) for all my current employers and four prior employers from XXXX in hopes of having any student loan payments made during this time to count toward my loan forgiveness counts. 
Since XXXX of XXXX, I have made countless phone calls, from being assigned to XXXX XXXX to XXXX to now StudentAid.gov to check the status and to ensure that my TEPSLF forms were not lost in the transition and would still be counted toward loan forgiveness. I have literally phoned either XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, or StudentAid.gov, especially in XXXX  when the deadline for all counts to be updated. I even phoned on XX/XX/XXXX to studentaid.gov to ensure that although I noted the current counts for my current employer only, the counts for the previous employers ( who should have counted under the TEPSLF forms ) were still being evaluated. I was again assured that these counts were still in process and that I should see the dates updated by the end of XXXX even filed a complaint via the student aid.gov website twice about my concerns about these counts and I was told the counts were accurate. My concern was that no one was really taking to time to explain to me how my TEPSLF application was not actually doing what it was set up to do... to include counts of payments I had made PRIOR to XX/XX/XXXX. Keep in mind my student aid account does show all five employers listed and approved since XXXX of XXXX, but the only counts included to date for loan forgiveness stop at XX/XX/XXXX, so nothing prior between XXXX ( which has never changed ). Jump to today, XX/XX/XXXX. My first phone call to StudentAid, I was told any of my payments prior to XX/XX/XXXX would not be counted (!!!! ) I was in shock. When I asked how, she had limited information to provide and suggested I speak to a supervisor, so I waited and waited. Then told to leave a call back number and a supervisor would return my call. I insisted on same day call back ( it is now XXXX PST and still no call back ). I suspected this, so I called studentaid again and asked specifically WHY the TEPSLF applications were approved but not considered in my counts and this time ( rudely, I may add ) I was told something different : 'because the TEPSLF deadline has already passed '. I was confused so shared with her that I have copies of the same forms I sent to studentaid all date back to XX/XX/XXXX, way before the XX/XX/XXXX deadline on the form, so again requested to speak with a supervisor or file a complaint. I asked for information for both suggestions. Again, no supervisor was available to ask to be put on the wait list a second time with notice to call back the same day ( NADA! ). So, I filed a second complaint with the same issue with student aid today ( XX/XX/XXXX at XXXX XXXX  ) with a 15-page PDF copy of all correspondence and copies of the TEPSLF forms originally submitted. In desperation and complete exhaustion of this now 3-plus year saga, I came across your website for help and answers. I am at the point of considering reaching out to the local Congress. No one should have to work on getting a clear answer on this issue for 3 years, especially when they have spent these years consistently calling and waiting for an answer only to be told " it ' 's still in process '' and now 'it doesn't qualify? ' The other suspicion I have is how on my student aid loan forgiveness tracker all the dates now through XX/XX/XXXX are listed, then from XXXX are listed ( and I know these dates do not qualify ) but the dates that would actually put me at 120 plus payments XXXX XXXX are not even listed ( interesting ). I just need a clear answer to what in my mind seems simple. It really hurts to see ones with loans being forgiven just under a year or two from start to finish following the same steps I have been struggling to get through for years trying to be compliant and patient, but this is too much and 3 plus years is more than valid.
Company: Servicer under contract with Federal Student Aid

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX Consumer Financial Protection Bureau XXXX XXXX XXXX, IA XXXX Subject : Dispute of Department of Education Accounts and Request for Compensation Dear CFPB, I am writing to dispute three negative accounts reported by the Department of Education ( DeptEdNelnet ) on my credit report. Below are the details of the disputed accounts : DeptEdNelnet Account 1 Account Number : XXXX Date Reported : XX/XX/XXXX Status : Collection/Charge-off DeptEdNelnet Account 2 Account Number : XXXX Date Reported : XX/XX/XXXXXXXX  Status : Past Due 120 Days DeptEdNelnet Account 3 Account Number : XXXX Date Reported : XX/XX/XXXX Status : Past Due 90 Days These accounts are inaccurate and should not have been reported. As per the Department of Education 's policies and the executive order issued by President Joe Biden freezing student loan payments and collections, no negative actions should be taken against borrowers during this period. 

Under the FCRA 611, I request an immediate investigation into these accounts and their removal if validation can not be provided. Furthermore, I am seeking compensation for the financial and emotional harm caused by these inaccuracies, as allowed under FCRA 616. 

Thank you for your assistance in resolving this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem with forgiveness, cancellation, or discharge
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have an ongoing research request that has been escalated to the Department of Education by XXXX XXXX of XXXX. The goal : to get my entire payment history for loans taken out between XXXX and XXXX credited back to XXXX, when repayment began. 

This document shows that DoE said the adjustments would apply to all XXXX accounts and forgiveness would be conferred on those grad accounts over 25 years in repayment. Yet my data shows I began repayment in XXXX, with servicer abuses disappeared from the system. 

The document here from XXXX says that the Department would remedy forbearance steering and other issues from the XXXX servicer management of loans, issuing retroactive credit when records were not kept. 

My account lacks accounting for loans XXXX " Direct '' loans from XXXX to XXXX, which is the disputed time here. 

The documentation suggests that the Department acknowledges systemic failures and my case shows one example of such that has yet to be corrected.

This is legally dubious given the guidance from XXXX XXXX, and again I am requesting my account be given payment credit back to XX/XX/XXXX. There is no 'consolidation ' contemplated in this guidance to get relief. 

Thank you. See below for link and material. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX  " Department of Education Announces Actions to Fix Longstanding Failures in the Student Loan Programs XX/XX/XXXX Today, the Department of Education announced steps that will bring borrowers closer to public service loan and income-driven repayment ( IDR ) forgiveness by addressing historical failures in the administration of the federal student loan programs. Federal Student Aid ( FSA ) estimates that these changes will result in immediate debt cancellation for at least 40,000 borrowers under the Public Service Loan Forgiveness ( PSLF ) Program. Several thousand borrowers with older loans will also receive forgiveness through IDR. More than 3.6 million borrowers will also receive at least three years of additional credit toward IDR forgiveness.

" Student loans were never meant to be a life sentence, but it's certainly felt that way for borrowers locked out of debt relief they're eligible for, '' said U.S. Secretary of Education XXXX XXXX. " Today, the Department of Education will begin to remedy years of administrative failures that effectively denied the promise of loan forgiveness to certain borrowers enrolled in IDR plans. These actions once again demonstrate the XXXX XXXX XXXX commitment to delivering meaningful debt relief and ensuring federal student loan programs are administered fairly and effectively. '' These actions are part of the Department 's commitment to address historical failures in the administration of the federal student loan program and support student loan borrowers through the pandemic... .Today 's steps will help restore the promise of IDR plans by ensuring that borrowers have an affordable and effective path out of debt. 

Beyond the immediate corrective actions announced today that will provide relief to borrowers harmed in the past, FSA will take action to ensure that borrowers receive these benefits in the future. Below are the actions being taken today. 

Ending " Forbearance Steering '' Department regulations require that borrowers who are facing difficulty making their loan payments get clear and accurate information from servicers about their options for staying out of delinquency, including IDR plans, and the financial consequences of choosing short-term options like forbearance. However, FSA reviews suggest that loan servicers placed borrowers into forbearance in violation of Department rules, even when their monthly payment under an IDR plan could have been as low as XXXX dollars. These findings are consistent with concerns raised by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and state attorneys general. A borrower advised to choose an IDR plan instead of forbearance can get a reduced payment, stay in good standing, and make progress toward loan forgiveness. A borrower advised to choose forbearance -- particularly long-term consecutive or serial uses of forbearance -- can see their loan balance and monthly payments grow due to interest capitalization and lead to delinquency or default. 

The Department will address forbearance steering by : Conducting a One-Time Account Adjustment to Count Certain Long-Term Forbearances toward IDR and PSLF Forgiveness Borrowers steered or inappropriately placed into long-term forbearances miss out on critical progress toward IDR and PSLF forgiveness ; this can set them back years. The Department 's regulations and servicer contracts have safeguards, including a 12-month limit for any single use of forbearance, and a 36-month cumulative limit on discretionary forbearance. A review of past forbearance use shows that long-term use of forbearance was remarkably widespread. More than 13 % of all Direct Loan borrowers between XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX have used forbearance for at least 36 months cumulatively. These changes will be applied automatically to borrowers ' accounts later this year. To mitigate the harms of inappropriate steering into long-term forbearance, FSA will conduct a one-time account adjustment that will count forbearances of more than 12 months consecutive and more than 36 months cumulative toward forgiveness under IDR and PSLF. Borrowers who were steered into shorter-term forbearances will be able to seek account review by filing a complaint with the FSA Ombudsman at StudentAid.gov/feedback. 

Increasing Oversight of Servicers ' Forbearance Use FSA will target forbearance steering by restricting servicers ' ability to enroll borrowers in forbearance by text or email, conducting an external review of patterns of forbearance use and servicers ' practices to identify other potential changes to address steering, and working in partnership with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to do regular audits of forbearance use. This will build upon other FSA efforts to improve oversight of loan servicing activities, including stronger accountability provisions in servicing contracts, renewing partnerships with federal and state regulators and clarifying its position on federal preemption of state oversight of loan servicing. 

FSA will begin implementing these changes immediately, but borrowers may not see the effect in their accounts until the last quarter of XXXX. 

Tracking Progress Toward IDR Forgiveness IDR plans offer substantially lower monthly payments for most borrowers. Borrowers on most plans are entitled to forgiveness after 20 years of payments and depend on FSA and its servicers to accurately track their progress toward relief. However, the Department 's review of IDR payment-tracking procedures has revealed significant flaws that suggest borrowers are missing out on progress toward IDR forgiveness.

The Department is committed to fixing this problem swiftly and permanently. XXXX XXXX has directed FSA to : Conduct a One-Time Revision of IDR Payments to Address Past Inaccuracies To fully address past issues with IDR payment counting, FSA will do a one-time revision of IDR-qualifying payments for all Direct Student Loans and federally-managed Federal Family Education Loan Program ( FFEL ) loans . Any months in which borrowers made payments will count toward IDR, regardless of repayment plan. Payments made prior to consolidation on consolidated loans will also count. This fix is necessary to correct for data problems and past implementation inaccuracies. Any borrower who has made the required number of payments for IDR forgiveness based on this payment-count revision will receive loan cancellation automatically. Additionally, FSA will count months spent in deferment prior to XXXX toward IDR forgiveness ( with the exception of in-school deferment ) for this same population of borrowers to address concerns that, prior to that date, its data can not distinguish IDR-eligible deferments from other deferments.

Permanently Fix IDR Payment Counting by Reforming FSA 's IDR Tracking Borrowers should be able to rely on FSA and its loan servicers to keep accurate records of their progress toward forgiveness through IDR plans. FSA will issue new guidance to student loan servicers to ensure accurate and uniform payment counting practices, and it will track payment counts in its own modernized data systems. In XXXX, FSA will begin displaying IDR payment counts on StudentAid.gov so borrowers can view their progress after logging into their accounts. In addition, the Department plans to revise the terms of IDR through rulemaking to further simplify payment counting by allowing more loan statuses to count toward IDR forgiveness, including certain types of deferments and forbearances.

FSA will begin implementing these changes immediately, but borrowers may not see the effect in their accounts until the last quarter of XXXX. ''

Consumer complaint narrative:
My student loan serviced is Nelnet ( previously was Great Lakes ). Every month, Nelnet successfully auto-debits my monthly payment from my checking account on file. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I made a one-off payment of {$500.00} towards my student loans using the same checking account on file. I received an email from Nelnet that confirmed my payment was made. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I made an additional one-off payment of {$1100.00} towards my student loans ( which would have fully paid off one of the high interest loans ) using the same checking account on file. 


On XX/XX/XXXX, my checking account didnt look like it had the money withdrawn yet. I checked and neither of the two one-off transactions from Nelnet had posted. I called my bank ( XXXX ) this morning, XX/XX/XXXX, and they confirmed that not only do those transactions not exist, they were never even attempted. There is no record of a failed attempt, even. 

I then called Nelnet today, XX/XX/XXXX, to ask why they didnt notify me of the failed transactions, which they said they dont know why it happens but sometimes it does. 

Nelnet is actively defrauding myself and potentially other student loans using recipients by failing to a ) apply payments b ) continuing to charge accrued interest against loans that should have been paid c ) failing to provide correspondence about their payment failures and d ) allowing accounts to potentially fall into delinquency.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/year>, I went to aidvantage.com to pay off XXXX student loans. These were XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, XXXX. I paid them with {$9600.00}. At that time, I took extra care to ensure that I entered in the total full balance noted for the full amount of each loan, down to the cent. This was completed within their loan specification feature. 4 days later, I saw that the loans had still not cleared from my account and it was showing that my account still had very small interest amounts due on each of them. On XX/XX/year>, I called to inquire why the company had not discharged the loans from my account and why it was still showing that I owed money. The representative could not provide me with a clear answer. Please pull this call recording, because you will hear the representative talk about what she sees in the account and she could not clearly state why it was still showing interest on my account. Additionally, the amount of money owed on these loans have since increased since this call. When I called, one of the loans had a {$2.00} balance and it has not magically increased, because I no longer see that balance on any of the loans. She stated that they had a certain amount of time before the loans would show discharged and that I would get a letter stating the loans had been released or discharged. In the past when I have cleared loans, they did NOT send a letter to state that my loans had been discharged. I have never received this information from Aidvantage. Since my loans moved to aidvantage, I completely paid off loan XXXX, and instead of receiving discharge, they magically added on a few dollars to the account. 

The biggest issue is that they have added a collective of {$180.00} to all XXXX of my loans, which collectively, originally had a balance of {$9600.00}. I know that I took extreme care to enter what they noted as the total account balance. I also called an additional time sometime in XXXX to inquire, once again, about why the status of my loans had not changed, and the representative could not provide me with any specific information about why this was the case.If you listen to that call, the lady stated that I would receive an email from their team from the escalation of the issue, but I have still yet to receive this email. 

Today, I spoke with an escalation specialist at Aidvantage ( name has been redacted for privacy, but can be provided upon request ) and she maintained that the account balance currently listed on the account is correct. She claims that on XX/XX/year>, the balance currently listed was the same, however, I am 100 % sure that I entered the total due amount that was listed for each and every loan that I paid toward on XX/XX/XXXX, because I wanted to avoid this predatory practice of hidden fees being added on after the fact. I believe they did this to savor the opportunity to add on additional interest to my account or their record keeping practices are not up to par. Aidvantage needs to make this right by crediting the balance between what I paid, which was XXXX, and the new balance amount they are stating I have to pay. I am going to pay the difference now, because I do not know how much power Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has in rectifying this matter, and I do not want the balance to continue to increase via interest, but Aidvantage is criminal and in due time, a thorough investigation into their IT and record keeping practices will show that.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I was transferred from Navient to XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX. I live in the State of Illinois. 
In XX/XX/XXXX, Navient announced its desired departure from the student loan servicing business, with plans to transfer its six million federal borrower accounts to a company called XXXX XXXX. However, XXXX created a subsidiary called XXXX, which will now be the official student loan servicer for those who were previously stuck with Navient. 
Federal loan borrowers who were placed in long-term forbearances instead of income-driven repayment plans ( IDR plans ). Must have been a resident of one of the following participating states or had an address with a military postal code as of XX/XX/XXXX : AZ, CA, CO, CT, DC, DE, FL, GA, HI, IA, IL, IN, KY, LA, MA, MD, ME, MN, MO, NC, NE, NJ, NM, NV, NY, OH, OR, PA, TN, VA, WA, and WI. 

I have been hugely affected by Navient 's deceptive practices. I had no idea and was never informed I could start making monthly payments as an XXXX, while I was still working as a XXXX. I was forced to obtain my XXXX for XXXX status at the hospital or lose my job. Navient absolutely was guilty of these deceptive practices. The University program just went right along with it. How can the online fees for a XXXX online program rack up to {$40000.00} plus???? I have kids in XXXX kids in college now. I am looking to be included with Loan Discharge when I was with Navient. 
The CFPB accused Navient of numerous practices that hurt borrowers financially during Navient 's role as a federal student loan servicer. 
These practices include : Charging the wrong monthly payments Steering borrowers into forbearance and deferment instead of low IDR payments Inaccurate credit reporting Providing incorrect information about PSLF Charging incorrect late fees I have sent emails regarding this to the new company XXXX I just keep getting pushback saying that they have nothing to do with what Navient did with their loans.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Immediate Action Needed : Approve Outstanding Borrower Defense Applications To the Departments Overseeing School & Loan Server Compliance, We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXX schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding Borrower Defense applications and provide full relief for those impacted. 
Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : * XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX The Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXX  University misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXX and XXXX, falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within six months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 
At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in XXXX states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts.

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : 1. Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions.

2. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans.

3. Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts. 
Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the American Dream, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it. 
We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays. 
Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 
Sincerely, Students & Graduates of XXXX XXXX
